Further, the CAA does not cover the ethnic and linguistic issues of Tamils in Sri Lanka”.The plea, without articulating how the CAA became a Centre-state dispute, said since the Act was “manifestly arbitrary and unconstitutional” as it violated secularism and right to equality, “thus, there exists a dispute involving questions of law and facts between the state of Kerala and the Union of India, regarding the enforcement of legal rights as a state and as well as for the enforcement of fundamental, statutory, constitutional and other legal rights of the inhabitants of the state of Kerala”.

Title: Tejashwi’s ‘Pratirodh Sabha’ in Seemanchal from tomorrow
Content:
This story is from January 15, 2020

PATNA: Perhaps with an eye on assembly elections scheduled in the state in October-November this year, RJD chief Lalu Prasad’s younger son and leader of opposition in state assembly Tejashwi Prasad Yadav has decided to hold a three-day ‘Pratirodh Sabha’ in Muslim-dominated Seemanchal region from January 16 in protest against Citizenship (Amendment) Act (CAA), National Register of Citizens (NRC) and National Population Register (NPR).

Tejashwi will start his anti-CAA, NRC and NPR campaign from Kishanganj. He will hold public meetings in Araria and Katihar on January 17 and 18, respectively.

Meanwhile, Tejashwi also met the anti-CAA protesters at Shanti Bagh in Gaya on Tuesday.

Asked about the reason for selecting Muslim-dominated region for his public meetings, Tejashwi said, “It is not about any particular religion. I am going to different places on the request of people.”

“What the central government is doing is anti-Constitution and anti-people. There is confusion everywhere and I will meet people and discuss the issues. PM Narendra Modi speaks opposite to what home minister Amit Shah announces. Even in JD(U), there are two blocks,” he added.

Tejashwi said CM Nitish Kumar was making people fool by calling for a discussion on CAA as his party had supported it in the Parliament. “Nitish should stop the NPR exercise in the state. Shah has already said that NPR is a first step towards implementation of NRC in the country. Additional questions are being asked in NPR exercise. It shows the government’s true intention,” Tejashwi said.

Title: Dalai Lama: India a living example of religious harmony
Content:
This story is from January 15, 2020

GAYA: Amid controversy over introduction of Citizenship (Amendment) Act in the country, Buddhist spiritual leader the Dalai Lama on Tuesday lauded India for its tolerance and pluralism. Addressing the IIM-Bodh Gaya students and faculty members, the spiritual leader said India offered a living example of how different cultures and religions could exist together in perfect harmony.

Giving tips to aspiring business leaders, Dalai Lama regretted that though everyone seeks happiness, little real effort is made in this direction. “We are the creators of our own problems. War did not offer any solution to our problems and we have to see to it that the vagaries of the 20th century wars do not revisit us in this century,” the spiritual leader said.

He added that education played a crucial role in shaping human personality and its proper orientation. The spiritual leader also released the institute’s logo. The logo has been designed by Chandrashekhar Sasawade of National Institute of Design, Bangalore.

At the IIM campus, Dalai Lama was received by the institute’s director Vinita Sahay. The spiritual leader also planted a ‘peepal’ sapling on the campus.

Title: Allow employees to question without fear of retaliation
Content:
This story is from January 15, 2020

By Prabir Jha

Safety is a growing priority for most companies across sectors today. And this is so reassuring to see. However, much of their definition is still the classical definition of safety — physical, products, processes, systems and equipment. But what unfortunately is still missing in many places is the appreciation and practice of psychological safety.

In my advisory experience, I witness various organisational challenges that leadership teams identify — lack of agility, unwillingness to take risks, dry leadership pipeline, low trust, subdued innovation, poor work culture, team dysfunctionalities, to name a few.

And often, as one peels the onion, one sees a common underlying issue. It is the absence of psychological safety where employees just do not feel assured enough to express themselves. They are reluctant to suggest ideas, share their anxieties or question leadership thinking. This, despite the standard formats of town halls, suggestion boxes and small group activities.

‘Niti’ (rituals) do not substitute for ‘Niyat’ (intent). Unfortunately, the fuzziness of understanding the issue of psychological safety is often not an adequately developed leadership strength. Most leadership growth over years has been about brute numbers, directive activity and a lone ranger-ship mindset. And suddenly, one is responsible for larger teams and their engagement to deliver strategic outcomes.

This is not something that they were consciously prepared for, and many struggle and fail.

How then could you enhance psychological safety in your organisation? I have simple tips:

Make it a mainstream narrative: Unless you call out this licence, your employees and other stakeholders will not even know it is an option, or even a desired behaviour. Explain the contours of this concept through simple illustrations. Every communication platform must highlight this. This must become an underlying tenet of your operating culture. Equally, clarify what cannot be construed as included in psychological safety. The best example: A bona fide mistake is fine, but wilful negligence is not an alibi.

Practice psychological safety to its fullest: I advise companies to discourage anonymous questions and whistleblowing to the extent they can. People should be able to lend their names to their questions without fear of retaliation. Admitting management slips and omissions is an act of vulnerability that can be role models for psychological safety. The top management must demonstrate this each time. And soon, the culture starts trickling down. The guarantee of psychological safety must come right from the top.

Rewire all your people practices to reinforce psychological safety: Who we hire, promote, reward and celebrate reinforces most significantly the culture of a workplace. Companies must signal through all their HR interventions that they endorse managers who encourage plurality of ideas, respect difference of opinion and invite contrarian points of view. They must spot and amplify leaders and individuals who speak up their suggestions, concerns and constructive criticism. In my own experience, this is the toughest one to do. But if you do practise this, the institutional culture is more vibrant, innovative and engaging than one can imagine.

Invest in coaching for building psychological safety: Like every leadership skill, this too needs conscious investment. Many companies realise this need only when people are already prisoners of their success and behaviour. Help younger managers to know how to deal with this subject. Train them in the art of conversations that counts, beyond just tasks. Teach them to appreciate human psychology so that they understand how their little leadership acts impair psychological safety in their teams.

Measure the state of psychological safety in your organisation: Firms must regularly seek to measure — both quantitatively and qualitatively — the state of the nation. A young HRpreneur recently shared with me a platform that measures in real time organisational dynamics that could help intervene and coach for improving the environment. Such smart tools are there to leverage, provided we realise the strategic risks that a lack of psychological safety poses to an enterprise, beyond just a feel-good.

In the emergent chaos and uncertainty of our times, no past can predict the future. No grey hair can underwrite the script for tomorrow. Our people must want to feel free to ideate, own, critique and improve their individual and collective outcome. This cannot be mandated or commanded. It has to be nursed and earned. Build not just physically safe workplaces but also, importantly, nurture psychologically safe ones.

(The writer is the founder & CEO of Prabir Jha People Advisory )

Title: Bihar to host pollution control boards’ meet on January 16 and 17
Content:
This story is from January 15, 2020

Youth protecting themselves from air pollution in Patna (File Photo)

PATNA: The state government in association with Bihar State Pollution Control Board (BSPCB) is to conduct the 64th Conference of Central Pollution Control Board (CPCB) at Bihar Museum here on January 16 and 17.

Track the pollution level in your city

CM Nitish Kumar would inaugurate the two-day conference, which will be attended by CPCB chairman SP Singh Parihar, principal secretary of ministry of environment, forest and climate change CK Mishra, chairman and secretary members of 28 state pollution boards and pollution control committees from eight union territories. Deputy CM Sushil Kumar Modi will also attend the event.

Principal secretary of state environment, forest and climate change department said on Tuesday that environment experts from across the country would prepare a recommendation policy based on the discussions.

Singh at a presser said one inaugural session and seven technical sessions will be held during the two-day event. “Discussion will be held on solid and plastic waste management and biomedical waste on the first day while experts will deliberate on water quality assessment, industrial pollution and air quality action plans in apportioned cities on the second day of the conference,” he said.

BSPCB chairman Ashok Ghosh said a technical session on case study on air quality management would take place on the concluding day. “The state government would throw light on its ambitious ‘Jal Jeevan Hariyali’ scheme. Based on these discussions, a recommendation policy would be prepared by the CPCB to curb pollution,” he said.

Ghosh said Bihar would host the conference for the second time and first time after its bifurcation in 2000. Earlier in 1992, the conference was held in undivided Bihar.

Title: Use aircraft to prepare human chain map: CM Nitish Kumar
Content:
This story is from January 15, 2020

Bihar CM Nitish Kumar

PATNA: Chief minister (CM) Nitish Kumar on Tuesday suggested officials concerned to prepare a map using aircraft for statewide human chain to be organised on January 19 to create awareness about Jal Jivan Hariyali mission, liquor prohibition and the government’s anti-dowry and anti-child marriage campaigns.

Chairing a meeting to review the preparations for the human chain, Nitish asked the officials to ensure that the map shows connectivity of all routes in all districts and people should stand in their respective areas only.

The CM also asked the officials concerned to ensure safety of people standing in the human chain on the national highways and strict patrolling on all routes. He asked the officials to take all necessary precautions to ensure well-being of people in view of the prevailing biting cold conditions in the state. The CM said video-recording of people as well as the routes should be done using drones and motorcycles.

Additional chief secretary of education department R K Mahajan made a detailed presentation on the preparations done till date for the human chain. Various divisional commissioners, district magistrates, DIGs and other senior officials were also connected to the CM secretariat for the meeting.

Mahajan said human chain with Gandhi Maidan in Patna as its epicentre is proposed to be 16,351km long, with its branches touching the state’s boundaries in all four directions. The length of the main route will be 5,052km.

Mahajan said with an estimated number of 2,000 people per kilometre and 100 people in each ward, the total number of human chain participants would touch 4.27 crore. The participants will include students of government and private schools, teachers, government employees, cooks, Jeevika Didis, Asha workers and common people.

Mahajan said that all schools will remain open despite being Sunday and students of classes I to IV will make the human chain on the premises of the school only. He said spots are being marked on the left side of the routes of the human chain, where people can stand.

Title: Patna: PPU teachers, staff peeved at non-payment of salaries
Content:
This story is from January 15, 2020

Representative image

PATNA: Peeved at the non-payment of salaries to both the teaching and non-teaching staff of different constituent colleges of Patliputra University (PPU) for three months, a delegation of the Patliputra University Teachers’ Association (PPUTA) met vice-chancellor (VC) Gulab Chand Ram Jaiswal at the university headquarters on Tuesday. They also submitted a memorandum to him in this connection.

According to PPUTA president A K Singh Thakur, the association urged the VC to ensure payment of salaries as per the revised pay scale recommended by the University Grants Commission (UGC) by January 31. “We also requested him to look into all pending cases of appointment and promotion,” he told this newspaper.

The memorandum submitted to the VC highlighted the need for payment of all retiral benefits to the teachers so that they do have to run from pillar to post.

Others, who were part of the delegation, included PPUTA general secretary Hridya Narain Singh and executive members Yogendra Sinha, Birendra Prasad Singh, Awadesh Rai, Rajeshwar Singh, Subodh Kumar as well as Alakhdeo Prasad.

Title: Extra MPC meet likely, RBI may hold rates in February
Content:
This story is from January 15, 2020

(File photo)

MUMBAI: The Reserve Bank of India’s ( RBI ’s) monetary policy committee (MPC) is likely to hold a consultation before its next bimonthly meet in February, given the surge in inflation beyond the panel’s tolerance level of 6%. While the MPC is unlikely to hike rates, the much-anticipated cut in February 2020 might not be forthcoming.

Economists are revising their earlier views of a rate cut in the RBI’s February 2020 policy and many now believe that the central bank will hold rates. The central government has notified in the official gazette 4% consumer price index (CPI) inflation as the target for the period from August 5, 2016 to March 31, 2021 with the upper tolerance limit of 6% and the lower tolerance limit of 2%. If inflation stays above the tolerance level, the MPC must take action. Although the MPC is mandated to meet at least four times, it can hold meetings more frequently.

“December CPI inflation rose sharply to 7.4%, the highest in more than five years. This was also higher than 6.8% expected by HSBC. Previously, we were calling for a 25-basis-point (100bps = 1 percentage point) rate cut in February, which we are now taking off the table,” HSBC India chief economist Pranjul Bhandari said in a report.

“CPI inflation jumped to 7.35% in December on the back of a significant increase in ginger, onion and potato (GOP) prices. Stripping aside the GOP impact, the headline inflation declines to 4.48%. The impact of increase in telecom tariff has added another 16bps to inflation. We now expect inflation to breach 8% in January and then start bottoming out,” said SBI chief economic adviser Soumya Kanti Ghosh.

“We believe the RBI missed the bus in cutting rates in December. Our worry is that if the food price inflation does not mean revert, we can slip into stagflation. Our inflation trajectory shows headline will only materially decline beyond September, with December 2020-January 2021 inflation declining to below 3%,” added Ghosh.

Title: 745 people fined Rs 7.85 lakh for violating traffic rules
Content:
This story is from January 15, 2020

Representative image

PATNA: Altogether 745 vehicle owners and drivers were issued e-challans and fined Rs7.85 lakh for violating traffic norms as the transport department along with traffic police launched a special drive to enforce the helmet and seatbelt rules in the state capital on Tuesday. The drive was conducted under the 31st National Road Safety Week .

The vehicle owners and drivers were fined for violating traffic norms such as driving without helmet, seatbelt, pollution certificate, using tinted glasses and not possessing the required documents. The drive was conducted near Hartali Mor, Dak Bunglow roundabout and Kargil Chowk.

Transport secretary Sanjay Kumar Agarwal distributed 20 free helmets to women riders as well as the pillion riders near Hartali Mor and encouraged them to wear helmet while riding two-wheelers. “Not only the driver’s but also the pillion rider’s life is at risk without helmet. We want to create awareness that the Motor Vehicles Act mandates a pillion rider also to wear helmet,” he said.

Agarwal, who is also the Patna divisional commissioner, said through the weeklong special drive has been launched to send message among public to wear helmets and seatbelts. “Those caught for violating the Act for more than two reasons were sent to Sultan Palace for corrective classes conducted by the experts of Aurangabad’s Institute of Driving Training and Traffic Research (IDTR),” he said.

During vehicle checking, the commissioner caught one Mohd Shamim Khan, who was talking on mobile while driving a two-wheeler without a helmet. The bike had an extra silencer, which was creating noise. Agarwal directed traffic SP D Amarkesh to seize the vehicle and impose a fine.

Another two-wheeler belonging to one Uday Singh was seized as the rider was neither wearing helmet, nor had a pollution under control certificate and vehicle papers. The driving licence of both the riders were suspended for three months and they were directed to attend the corrective classes at Sultan Palace.

Meanwhile, state transport minister Santosh Kumar Nirala launched the corrective classes at Sultan Palace for the traffic violators. Around 20 traffic violators attended the class on first day.

Title: Bihar: Fatuha farmer killed over old land dispute
Content:
This story is from January 15, 2020

Representative image

PATNA: Unidentified bike-borne criminals shot dead a farmer while he was working in his field at Supanchak under Fatuha police station area in eastern Patna on Tuesday evening. The deceased was identified as Jagdeo Yadav (55). Four empty cartridges were recovered from the spot.

Fatuha SDPO Maneesh said the family members of the deceased have accused co-villagers Umesh Yadav and Pintu Yadav of killing Jagdeo. “Pintu is a hardcore criminal and is on bail. Raids are being conducted to nab the duo,” he said.

Maneesh said Jagdeo was also the prime accused in a murder case lodged with Fatuha police station in 2014. “A close relative of Umesh was killed over land dispute ,” he said.

“However, police found Jagdeo innocent during investigation. However, Umesh’s family suspected that police had somehow connived with Jagdeo and set him free,” the SDPO said, adding that the two families have an old land dispute .

Quoting villagers, Maneesh said four criminals on two bikes reached Jagdeo’s field and shot him dead. “They fired several rounds. The bullets hit Jagdeo in his head, shoulder and waist. But only the postmortem report would confirm about the bullet marks,” he said.

Title: Bihar: Amit Shah’s Vaishali meeting likely to kick-start BJP’s poll preparation
Content:
This story is from January 15, 2020

Amit Shah

PATNA: The proposed public meeting of BJP national president and Union home minister Amit Shah at Kharauna Pokhar near Vaishali Garh in Vaishali district on January 16 is set to generate political heat in the state.

Though Shah’s meeting is meant to clear the mist over the controversy on Citizenship Amendment Act (CAA) and elaborate its significance in the larger interest of the country, speculations are rife that he would kick-start the party’s preparations for the assembly polls due later this year.

Union minister of state for home Nityanand Rai and state BJP president Dr Sanjay Jaisawal besides the party’s organizational general secretary Nagendra Ji visited the meeting venue on Monday and took stock of the preparations. Significantly, LJP MP from Vaishali Veena Devi was seen seeking blessings of the people of her constituency to make the meeting a grand success, while JD(U) leaders of the district were maintaining a distance from it. Veena also took part in a meeting attended by senior BJP leaders at Hajipur, the district headquarters of Vaishali, a couple of days back.

The ideological differences among the JD(U) leaders on the CAA and proposed NRC have given credence to the belief that Shah’s speech would be loaded with political message both to the coalition partners in the state and to the party workers ahead of assembly polls in the state.

The meeting is equally important for Nityanand Rai, who till recently was state president of BJP and is considered a prominent Yadav face in the organization. He belongs to Hajipur and had earlier represented the constituency in the state assembly before being elected as MP from Ujiarpur Lok Sabha seat in 2014 and also in 2019. “Nityanand ji will not miss the opportunity to prove his strength on the occasion,” said a BJP leader.

The selection of the venue also matters for the party. Considered the cradle of the first democratic set up the world over, Vaishali Garh has a major chunk of Muslim population and also from backward classes. Shah might have been made aware of these things before finalizing the meeting venue, BJP sources said.

BJP’s Vaishali unit general secretary Manish Shukla said a public campaign was launched in the villages. On Monday, Nityanand and Dr Jaiswal addressed public gathering at Mansoorchak, Bhagwanpur Ratti and Daudnagar in Vaishali assembly segment.

He said the party leaders of both Vaishali and Muzaffarpur districts have been assigned the task to invite people for the public meeting. “It will be a historic meeting,” Shukla claimed.

Vaishali district administration has also made elaborate security arrangements for the meeting. “The meeting of the coordination committee of the local police and also from Delhi police was held to chalk out strategy for the security arrangements. “We have requisitioned additional police force from the police headquarters for the purpose,” Vaishali SP Guarav Mangla told this newspaper on Tuesday.

Title: Bihar: RJD, LJP and HAM(S) to contest Delhi election
Content:
This story is from January 15, 2020

PATNA: RJD , LJP and HAM (S) have decided to contest the Delhi assembly elections scheduled for February 8. BJP ally LJP announced on Tuesday that it will contest all the 70 Delhi seats and released its first list of 15 candidates.

RJD’s Rajya Sabha MP Manoj Jha also said his party will field candidates in alliance with Congress but only if they get respectable number of seats. “Otherwise, we will go solo,” he said. Jha told TOI on Tuesday that they have demanded seven seats from Congress. “Talks are going on in this regard. It was our party only which spoke clearly against Citizenship Amendment Act (CAA) and National Register of Citizens (NRC) in the Rajya Sabha as these issues are not only against the minority community, but also against the poor who look to us,” said Jha.

LJP’s Delhi incharge Kali Pandey told reporters on Tuesday that the party released its first list of 15 candidates for Delhi polls. “Our alliance with BJP is limited to Bihar only and it was for the BJP to decide on a tie-up in Delhi elections.

“It is for the bigger ally in a coalition to take a call about any tie-up ahead of the polls. We have seen what happened in the recently held Jharkhand assembly elections,” he told reporters, referring to the BJP's loss in it.

JD (U), another BJP’s ally, has also decided to field its candidate in Delhi elections, like it did in Jharkhand. However, both JD(U) as well as LJP could not win even a single seat in Jharkhand elections.

Meanwhile, former CM Jitan Ram Manjhi’s HAM(S) has also decided to contest 15 seats in Delhi, including Purani Dilli (Old Delhi) and Patparganj, against Delhi CM Arvind Kejriwal and deputy CM Manish Sisodia , respectively.

HAM(S) spokesperson Danish Rizwan told TOI that Aditi Singh from Purani Dilli and Shatrughan Kumar alias Munna Singh from Patparganj will be the party candidates. “They will file their nomination papers on January 16. We also held a meeting in Patparganj on Tuesday in the presence of Manjhi ji,” he said and added: “Our candidates on 15 seats have already started campaign. We are fighting this election on local issues.”

Title: Yogi: CAA will provide justice to persecuted Hindus of Pak
Content:
This story is from January 15, 2020

GAYA: UP chief minister Yogi Adityanath on Tuesday held an awareness rally in Gaya on the recently enacted Citizenship (Amendment) Act (CAA). Addressing the public meeting at Gandhi Maidan, he said Indian Muslims enjoy equal citizenship rights, but minorities in Pakistan were ill-treated.

“While the population of Indian Muslims increased by more than five times since Independence, the Hindu population of (undivided) Pakistan came down from 20% to less than 4% in the same period,” Yogi said.

Attributed the decline of minority population in Pakistan to “mass killings, forced exodus and coercive conversion”, he added: “The CAA will provide justice to such Hindus who were compelled to leave their homeland on account of religious persecution and oppression.”

The UP CM, who arrived at the venue to slogans of ‘Jai Shri Ram’ and ‘Hindu Hriday Samrat’, in his 28-minute speech, praised the “tolerance” of Indians. “Even Sonia Gandhi, a Christian by faith, was welcomed in India, something that was possible only in our country.”

Echoing the assertions of PM Narendra Modi and home minister Amit Shah on CAA, Yogi reiterated the “innocuous” nature of the Act and said it was about giving and not snatching citizenship rights.

“Those who are calling the CAA unconstitutional are, in fact, heaping insult on Babasaheb Bhimrao Ambedkar, the architect of the Indian Constitution,” said Yogi. He also questioned Congress’s moral right to talk about constitutionality as the party, during emergency, ran amok with all constitutional values.

However, while Yogi was nearing the end of his speech, hundreds of black balloons dotted the Gandhi Maidan skyline, purportedly released by anti-CAA protesters in Gaya. Both Yogi and the organisers ignored the black balloons and Yogi soon ended his speech.

Other dignitaries present at the rally included Bihar deputy CM Sushil Kumar Modi and state BJP chief Sanjay Jaiswal.

Title: Makar Sankranti celebrations today
Content:
This story is from January 15, 2020

PATNA: With the smell of freshly-made ‘til’ products wafting across the city, Patnaites are ready to celebrate Makar Sankranti on Wednesday.

While many will welcome the first festival of the year by eating ‘tilkuts’, laddoos, ‘dahi-chura’ and ‘khichadi’, others will invite friends over for kite-flying competitions.

Neha Shree, who will host a ‘dahi-chura’ feast at her residence, told this newspaper on Tuesday, “I organize a feast for my friends, relatives and colleagues every year. It usually begins in the morning and goes on till late evening. It is a great way to come together and celebrate.”

Gola Road resident Avinash Kumar visits his native place every year on Makar Sankranti. He said, “I celebrate the festival with my grandparents because I get to eat the world’s best ‘khichadi’ every year.”

After eating ‘dahi-chura’, Rajendra Nagar Ashok Gupta will organize a kite-flying contest in his locality on Wednesday. “Kids as well as adults can participate in the competition,” he said.

Deliberating on the importance of Makar Sankranti, city-based priest Gyan Pandey said, “Also known as the ‘dahi-chura’ day in Bihar, the festival has a special significance. On this day, the Sun lord, who is revered in the Hindu culture, enters the northern hemisphere. People eat ‘til laddoo’, ‘tilkut’, ‘dahi-chura’, jaggery and other delicacies on the occasion.”

He added, “Many people also bathe in the Ganga on Makar Sankranti.”

Meanwhile, city markets were flooded with men and women buying ‘tilkuts’ on Tuesday evening. Kids, on the other hand, were seen flying kites.

Title: Foreign tourists get a taste of Pongal festival
Content:
This story is from January 15, 2020

Trichy: It was a fulfilling Pongal celebration for a team of 11 foreign tourists from Mexico and Netherlands who could not only taste sweet pongal prepared in a traditional way but also perform traditional folk dance along with college students on Tuesday.

Invited as chief guests for the Pongal celebration organized by the tourism department at Kalai Kaviri College of Fine Arts, they were welcomed in a traditional manner with shawl and rose garlands.

The celebration was inaugurated by district collector S Sivarasu and entirely managed by the students. Girl students performed Karagattam to the traditional thavil and nadaswaram tunes. The foreign guests also joined the performance with karagam (water pot) on their heads.

Folk art forms like Poi Kuthirai attam, Oyilattam and Kummiadi dance performance followed to the tune of traditional percussion instrument Parai. Terming the event to be one of its kind experience for him, Mexican tourist Jose Antonio Guzman Bravo said he was particularly impressed with the way students displayed folk art forms. “We didn’t expect such warm hospitality,” said another tourist from Victoria who liked the sweet pongal.

Rokus De Groot, a tourist from Netherlands said he had heard a lot about Indian tradition, specifically south Indian, but this was the first time he could witness folk dance though he had visited India several times. Trichy district tourist officer T Jegatheswari said that usually the tourism department hosted Pongal festival amidst rural background in villages. However, this year it was decided to have the festival in a city college known for promoting art forms.

Title: KKR to infuse $150 million in financial services arm
Content:
This story is from January 15, 2020

(File photo)

BENGALURU: Global alternatives assets major KKR is infusing $150 million in its corporate lending unit KKR India Financial Services (KIFS) at a time when non-banking finance companies (NBFCs) are reeling from a liquidity crisis. The additional infusion will help the KKR unit beef up its balance sheet. It plans to continue lending as it expects an attractive market for deal-making in 2020 given the liquidity crunch, said two sources briefed on the matter.

This comes even as KKR deals with several portfolio companies — like Coffee Day, Kwality Dairy and CG Power — facing governance and repayment issues, leading to questions if the company will get caught up in a liquidity crisis. KKR India head and veteran banker Sanjay Nayar had taken over as CEO of the NBFC unit in October from B V Krishnan, who stepped down citing personal reasons.

But with fresh infusion coming in from KKR’s balance sheet, it is likely to continue its play in the structured credit market. “This commitment demonstrates our ongoing support of the KIFS franchise and its future prospects. Moreover, it solidifies KIFS’ financial position, allows KIFS to be proactive in a dislocated market, and reflects our confidence in KIFS and its mission to finance India’s homegrown champions,” said Joe Bae and Scott Nuttall , co-presidents & co-chief operating officers of KKR, in response to TOI’s queries.

In October, rating agency Crisil downgraded KIFS to AA from AA+, citing “pressure on asset quality”. The unit had a loan book of Rs 5,878 crore as of June 2019 with a gross non-performing asset (GNPA) of 2%, according to Crisil, with gearing of 1.6 times and net worth of Rs 2,510 crore.

Crisil had also noted that KKR India has been able to recover money from stressed accounts, which covers “repayments (including prepayments) aggregating around Rs 2,000 crore, which is substantially higher than the scheduled collections” from January to August 2019.

KKR has been one of the major alternative asset players to launch the lending business in India back in 2009, and has also got Abu Dhabi Investment Advisory and Texas Teachers Retirement as shareholders. KIFS has focused on wholesale lending, primarily financing promoter groups and acquisitions, closing 150 deals and deploying over $5 billion till now. Currently, KKR has 36 active borrowers from this unit.

KKR is also likely to put its plans to raise a new Rs 5,000-crore credit fund on hold till the market improves and there are additional opportunities, said one of the sources briefed on the matter. KKR had before this raised two credit funds for India.

Title: Bihar: Now, Met forecasts rain on January 16 and 19
Content:
This story is from January 15, 2020

Representative image

PATNA: Sun God reappeared in the skies on Tuesday, much to the relief of people who saw morning temperature in the city plunging from 8.2 degrees C on Monday to 7.6 degrees C.

Dehri in Rohtas district and Sabour in Bhagalpur district were the coldest places in the state on Tuesday where minimum temperature was recorded at 6 degrees C.

Meanwhile, India Meteorological Department (IMD) has issued a forecast for cold day conditions at isolated places in the state on Wednesday.

In its daily weather bulletin issued on Tuesday evening, Patna Meteorological Centre stated that severe cold day condition was observed at some places and cold day condition at many places in the state during the past 24 hours.

In meteorological parlance, cold day condition is declared when the minimum temperature touches 10 degrees C or low and there is a departure of 4.5-6.4 degrees C in maximum temperature on two consecutive days. Severe cold day, on the other hand, is declared when the minimum temperature touches 10 degrees C or low and there is a departure of more than 6.5 degrees C in maximum temperature.

However, weathermen have predicted two consecutive rain spells later this week. Officials at Patna Meteorological Centre said while the first rainy spell is expected to occur primarily in the western parts of the state from the evening of January 16 to January 17, the second spell would occur on January 19 and 20.

“Back to back western disturbances would to showers in the state. An approaching western disturbance has led to formation of a cyclonic circulation over east Uttar Pradesh and adjoining Bihar, which is likely to lead to showers in western parts of the state from the evening of January 16 to morning of January 17. A fresh western disturbance would affect western Himalayan region and adjoining plains of northwest India from January 15 onwards. This is likely to lead to showers in Bihar on January 19,” an official at Patna Meteorological Centre said.

Title: Bihar: Cash, jewellery worth Rs 10 lakh stolen
Content:
This story is from January 15, 2020

Representative image

BIHARSHARIF: Thieves cut open shutter of a jewellery shop at Biharsharif’s Chowk Bazar on Monday night and decamped with cash and jewellery worth around Rs 10 lakh.

In his police complaint, Mohd Umar, owner of Jannat Jewellery, said thieves cut open shutter of his shop and stole Rs 5 lakh in cash and jewellery worth Rs 5 lakh. Umar said he came to know about the theft on Tuesday morning when owners of other shops in the locality brought the matter to his notice.

SHO of Biharsharif Town police station Deepak Kumar said CCTV cameras installed in the vicinity were being scanned to identity the thieves.

There are around 40 jewellery shops at Chowk Bazar in Biharsharif.

Title: 1 more held for kidnapping son of Chausa PACS head
Content:
This story is from January 15, 2020

PATNA: A day after the safe recovery of Chausa PACS chairman’s son Manish Ranjan from Motihari, police arrested another youth from Patna for his alleged involvement in his kidnapping case on Tuesday evening. Police had arrested eight youths in the case on Monday night.

The arrested accused was identified as Yamraj alias Ujjwal Kumar. “The youths planned to randomly kidnap anyone for making easy money through ransom and lead a lavish life. Ankit Kumar alias Ankit Sarkar and Sanjeet Kumar Singh were their group leaders,” City SP (central) Vinay Tiwary said.

Ankit and Sanjeet were among the eight kidnappers arrested on Monday. Others arrested in the case were identified as Raju Mishra alias Rajnish Mishra, Shivendra Kumar Chaubey, Rahul Kumar alias Charsi, Kamal Kumar Pandey alias Prince, Arjun Kumar alias Sunny and Srijan Kumar Gupta, all in their early 20s.

The SP said kidnappers had planned to take ransom of around Rs10-15 lakh from Manish’s father after they came to know that he was a PACS chairman’s son. They were, however, arrested before making any ransom call.

Manish was kidnapped while walking with another friend Raghvendra Singh near Sai temple under Patliputra police station on January 9 evening. He had come to Patna to write the JEE Main examination from his native village Chausa in Buxar district. Manish’s father Manoj Kumar Singh is Chausa primary agriculture cooperative society (PACS) chairman.

He was recovered from a lodge under Town police station area in Motihari on Monday. A Patna police team led by Tiwary had gone to Motihari for conducting raids and rescuing the victim.

Tiwary said Ujjwal was one of the five kidnappers inside the car when they kidnapped Manish from roadside. He said altogether ten youths were involved in the case. “Car used for kidnapping Manish was also seized from Motihari,” he said.

“Sanjeet and Ankit had planned the kidnapping and hired a car using an app for three days at Rs2000 rent per day. They took Manish to Motihari via Gopalganj,” he said, adding the duo with one more were arrested from Patna..

The SP said police laid a trap after which four more kidnappers got arrested from Motihari. The lodge where they had kept Manish was also raided, leading to recovery and arrest of another kidnapper.

Title: Minister lays stone for second biomedical waste treatment plant
Content:
This story is from January 15, 2020

PATNA: State health minister Mangal Pandey laid the foundation stone for a common biomedical waste treatment facility (CBMWTF) at Ramachak Bairiya on Tuesday. This plant with two incinerators will have the capacity to treat 500kg of waste in an hour and is expected to start functioning in three months. It is being built at the cost of Rs4.93 crore.

The plant is coming up on 1.5 acres of land, which was allocated to Indira Gandhi Institute of Medical Sciences (IGIMS) in 2017. Though it was supposed to be completed in 2018, sources said waiting for getting the state environment body’s nod delayed the project.

Once completed, this will be the second CBMWTF in the capital, as one has been already functional on IGIMS campus since 2006. However, the plant at IGIMS will be closed down as the area has been earmarked for a 500-bed hospital. Also, the plant is completing its lifespan, an official said.

Superintendent engineer-cum-nodal officer of CBMWTF at IGIMS, Shailendra Kumar Singh, said the upcoming facility is being built on a public-private-partnership (PPP) mode. “While IGIMS will also provide its customers, a Prayagraj-based firm is installing the plant and will carry out waste treatment work. IGIMS will be given 20% of the revenue generated. Also, it will not be charged for its own waste,” said Singh.

He further said the new CBMWTF will start functioning in the next three months, while construction of office and green area will take six months to complete. It will treat biomedical waste of from Patna, Buxar, Nalanda, Ara, Kaimur and Rohtas districts.

As of now, 2530 medical institutes, including government and private hospitals, clinics and laboratories are registered with the biomedical waste treatment plant at IGIMS.

Title: District administrations fix rent for harvester
Content:
This story is from January 15, 2020

Trichy: Following complaints from the farmer community across delta districts about the exorbitant rent charged for harvester machines by private parties, the district administrations intervened into the matter and fixed the rental rates for these machines.

Farmers said that since the number of harvester machines owned by agriculture engineering department in Thanjavur, Nagapattinam and Tiruvarur are very few in few in number, they are forced to rely on private operators who rent their harvesters during the paddy harvest season. K Gunasekaran, a farmer from Papanasam said that private operators are mostly from outside the state, particularly from Karnataka and Andhra Pradesh. “We are already in a spot due to issues like labour crunch rising wages and input costs. After spending almost all we have got to raise the crop, we find it difficult to spend a large sum for harvest”, he lamented.

The secretary of Thanjavur District Cauvery Farmers Protection Association, Swamimalai S Vimalnathan, alleged that some of the locals act as middlemen and influence the harvester machine owners to charge more by getting some brokerage. Meanwhile, the Thanjavur district collector, M Govinda Rao convened a meeting where officials from the agriculture department, Regional Transport Office and leaders of farmers’ associations participated. During the meeting, the rent was fixed at a maximum of Rs. 2,000 per hour for belt type harvester and Rs 1,500 per hour for tyre type harvester. There are certain variations in the rents fixed district-wise, depending on the demand. The collector also warned the harvesters not to fleece farmers. The rent for the belt type and tyre type harvesters owned by the agriculture engineering department has been fixed as Rs 1,415 and Rs 875 respectively across delta districts.

Title: As jobs get data savvy, techies take to digital marketing courses
Content:
This story is from January 15, 2020

Chennai: Now, being a data savvy techie does not mean your options are narrowed to just data science and AI, when it comes to jobs. With the increasing relevance of data and analytics one can chalk a career in digital marketing too. The increasing need for such professionals has led to techies taking up digital marketing courses to utilise the growth in digital marketing vacancies and leverage their skills.

City-based e-learning platform Great Learning for e.g. claims to have about 50% of its students — who take up digital marketing programme — having a tech backgrouund. “The skillsets needed for the digital marketing role are changing to include more data centric approach. This fits naturally with techies and we are doubling this segment with each new group,” said Hari Krishnan Nair, co-founder, Great Learning.

Apart from having an edge over non-techies, the transition is a lot easier, feels the engineering clan. Sriram R, an engineer-turned freelance digital marketer adds that he is able to apply the number crunching that he learnt during his stint at an IT firm to his newly-acquired skills learnt through a 6-month digital marketing course. “The transition is much easier than going through a whole new course involving more languages and coding. We all use social media and consume ads and content there, and therefore I could relate to them better,” he added. Mayank Kumar, founder of Mumbai-based upGrad adds that engineers and tech professionals who formed only about 15% of the total base less than a year ago, have risen to claiming 25% of their student base. “Digital marketing is getting more technical and data driven and the engineer participation is growing at 100% because the field is becoming more analytical and the transition from a tech course/job is easier,” he said. However, it is not just professionals who are looking to transcend to digital marketing careers, even tech students are taking up internships to have an early head start in their careers. Gurgaon-based intership platform Internshala, has seen “a 27% increase in the number of STEM( Science Technology, Engineering and Mathematics) students opting for non-technical online trainings since 2018. 45% of these are taking up digital marketing, claims the online training platform,” said Sarvesh Agarwal, founder, Internshala. “As the supply of engineering students is higher than demand, it becomes extremely difficult for them to find a suitable job. As a result, students find their comfort in digital marketing training as there are endless opportunities for them in this field. Job-specific skills like analytical rigour, strategy making, problem-solving, and technological competency that engineering graduates acquire during their coursework help them clinch good offers,” said Sarvesh Agarwal, founder, Internshala.

Title: HC to hear broadcasters’ plea against Trai on Jan 22
Content:
This story is from January 15, 2020

Swati Deshpande | TNN

Mumbai: The Bombay high court on Tuesday passed no orders in a challenge raised by the Indian Broadcasting Foundation (IBF) to a January 1 government circular that caps pricing by TV channels. The HC , however, placed it for hearing and interim orders on January 22.

The bench of Justices S C Dharmadhikari and R I Chagla granted no immediate relief to the broadcasters and gave time to regulator Trai to file its reply. The counsels for various broadcasters and associations that approached the HC sought to impress on the bench the urgency and need for orders to prevent coercive steps, since the deadline for them to offer their new rates is January 15. The new regulation requires channels in a bouquet to be priced no more than Rs 12, which is lower than the current bar of Rs 19. The reduction is arbitrary and unconstitutional, broadcasters said.

“A prescription of ceiling of MRP of Rs 12 on a-la-carte channels forming part of a bouquet, or for that matter, fixation of any ceiling on a-la-carte and/or bouquet is an invasion in broadcaster’s right to enter into commercial contracts for exploitation of free speech,” the broadcasters’ foundation contended. Others who were present in court included Films and Television Producers Guild, Sony Pictures, Star India, Zee, Disney India, Asianet and TV18.It espouses interest of consumers, is what Trai contended as its counsel Venkatesh Dhond sought time to file a reply to justify what was done “was with good reason”. It will benefit consumers who were hit by “bouquets” offered by broadcasters, which prevented people from choosing an a-la-carte menu of channels of their preference, is what Trai suggested.

The IBF, represented by advocate Abhishek Malhotra and counsel Gopal Jain, essentially pleaded that the Trai’s latest regulation to curb pricing totally encroaches on freedom of broadcasters. The Trai feels consumers’ a-la-carte choice is being interfered with. “There are 909 channels and 336 broadcasters,” said Dhond. “Paid channels are 330 and rest are free to air. The scheme is in interest of all broadcasters,” he added, complaining that the broadcasters “can’t come at the last minute and say no coercive steps”. A battery of counsels like Janak Dwarkadas, Darius Khambata, Aspi Chinoy, Navroz Seervai, Ravi Kadam and Soli Cooper stood up to point out that “it can’t at the same time be said that the consequences of not filing rate card by January 15 won’t ensue”.Dwarkadas said the latest move flouts rules that “clearly allow for 60 days for publishing a rate card” and sought that the January 15 deadline be deferred till court hears the matter. He said the rules permit a bouquet being given as a choice to consumers as they contain a variety of paying channels.

On publishing the rates, a distributor can accept it and broadcasters will have to then mandatorily enter into a contract for a year on such rate, said a counsel. There are 800 distributors whose contract are expiring. “Now they want chaos.”

Chinoy said, “We will be exposed to all sorts of consequences” if no relief is granted and the matter is defeated by a week by court. He pleaded that the court look at “balance of convenience”. “It should not be such that it irreversibly alters the status quo.”

“All that we are saying is protect us against any coercive action that may ensue,” said the broadcasters’ counsels.

“...the analogy given by respondent (Trai) in coming to the conclusion that the subscribers are not choosing a-la-carte channels on account of bouquets being available at discount is not only incorrect, but is not based on any facts, and has not been assessed based on the market realities about consumer behaviour qua economic considerations,” the IBF petition said.

The judges said there are “seized of the matter” and that there were other petitions filed by individuals too. The counsels for broadcasters said the court could record that it was seized of the matter while adjourning it. Justice Dharmadhikari smiled.

Title: Y Combinator doubles India bets, selects 26 startups
Content:
This story is from January 15, 2020

(Representative image)

BENGALURU: Top Silicon Valley accelerator Y Combinator told TOI it has picked 26 Indian startups in its winter 2020 or W20 batch, almost doubling the number of startups in this batch from India. In the previous batch, the influential accelerator had picked about 14 Indian startups, which was also a record number.

TOI first reported the development in December 2019 on Y Combinator — popularly known as YC — doubling down on its bets in India. This comes at a time when YC last year announced its exit from China and top venture-capital firm Sequoia Capital is being bullish on early-stage local startups with its accelerator programme — Surge — in India.

The Mountain View-based YC typically picked 5-10 startups each batch from India over the last 2-3 years. It has a portfolio of 2,000 companies and over 20 unicorns, which includes some of the most valued startups in the world including Airbnb , Stripe, Dropbox and DoorDash.

The spokesperson of YC declined to disclose the names of the Indian startups selected in this batch.

Typically, a YC batch sees about 180-200 startups and about 40% of them would be from outside the US. According to the latest numbers from India, it would mean domestic startups would have a larger share among international startups for YC at about 15% in the winter batch compared to 7% in the previous batch.

YC’s increased focus on India is also reflected in its top executives coming to India last year to conduct interviews. Earlier, startups had to go to the US. In September last year, YC’s new president Geoff Ralston had told TOI he wants to fund more Indian unicorns and that India will dominate as a market, outside the US.

Some of the prominent bets of YC in India include payments startup Razorpay, fin-tech firm ClearTax and social commerce player Meesho, which were part of its earlier 2015 and 2016 batches.

Title: Maharashtra: Education divisional office to move to new building
Content:
This story is from January 15, 2020

NASHIK: The divisional office of the state school education department will no more face inconveniences like setting up pandals for distributing exam papers or holding meetings of principals as it will soon start functioning from a spacious building.

“The department will move from its rented place at Mumbai Naka to its own three-storey building at Adgaon near New English School from the first week of February,” Nitin Upasani, secretary of the Nashik divisional office of the department, said on Tuesday.

The department spent nearly two decades at its old office in a 22,000 sqft rented space of a private hospital. In 2018, the government had sanctioned five acres of land for the building, which has been constructed at a cost of Rs 22 crore.

“The process of submission of SSC and HSC answer scripts and moderation of answer books and examination meetings will be conducted at the new building ,” said Upasani.

The old office created a major hindrance to the staff due to a lack of space, he said. “Apart from paying heavy rent, we had to arrange for pandals and coolers for moderators while distributing the exam papers to them.”

By putting the construction process on priority, the board came up with the new building within a year which will be closer to the schools of Dhulia, Jalgaon and Nandubar districts, which come under the Nashik division .

“The new building has an elevator, a waiting lounge for the visitors, conference halls for meetings with the principals, projectors to conduct training and presentations, closed-circuit cameras, a warehouse, a beautiful landscape with 1,700 plants and several other amenities. The board is also in the process of getting a bus stop sanctioned for the area,” said Upasani.

The new building will help schools from other districts and will ease the functioning of the departments, he added.

Title: Reliance Jio, asset rejig co top bidders for debt-hit RCom, group companies
Content:
(File photo)

MUMBAI: UV Asset Reconstruction Company (UVARCL) has emerged as the highest bidder for Reliance Communications ( RCom ) and Reliance Telecom (RTL) — including real estate assets, enterprise and data centre business — with a bid of a little over Rs 16,000 crore. Mukesh Ambani’s Reliance Jio is understood to have emerged as the highest bidder for Anil Ambani ’s telecom infra firm Reliance Infratel with an offer of Rs 3,609 crore.RCom, once a flagship company of the Anil Ambani-led group, received bids from Bharti Airtel and alternate investment firm Varde Partners in addition to UVARCL. Banking sources said that UVARCL’s bid was the highest. Bharti Airtel and UVARCL had also bid for Reliance Infratel.Although RCom is non-operational and has lost its mobile customers for good, the winning bidders will have access to the company’s assets, which include airwaves in the 850MHz band in 14 of India’s 22 telecom circles. Infratel has about 43,000 telecom towers, some fibre and data centres.According to banking industry sources, this is not a done deal as yet. Lenders expect the department of telecom (DoT) to throw a spanner in the works by pressing for repayment of its dues. This is going by their experience with bankrupt telecom operator Aircel where DoT is challenging a deal cleared by the lenders. Bankers also said that the RCom resolution is a complex affair as there are a lot of conditionalities involved with every asset of the company. The meeting of the committee of creditors, which started last weekend, has continued until late on Monday.Lenders had sought the help of Dun & Bradstreet for a feasibility report, while SBI Caps appraised the financial bids. A large chunk of UVARCL’s repayment to creditors is understood to be spread over seven years, linked to recoveries from sale of RCom’s assets.Resolution profession Anish Nanavati had verified claims of Rs 31,788 crore of financial creditors and an additional Rs 22,455 crore from DoT. In the case of RTL, loans of Rs 35,192 crore and DoT’s Rs 2,073 crore have been verified. Reliance Infratel has received claims of Rs 36,195 crore. The bid amounts are lower than the 20-25% recoveries that lenders were anticipating through the bankruptcy process.

Title: Patna: Police rescue youth kidnapped in group rivalry
Content:
This story is from January 15, 2020

Representative image

PATNA: Police on late Monday night arrested one Mishal Ranjan (22) for his alleged involvement in the kidnapping of a youth at gunpoint from Patliputra roundabout. The youth was kidnapped in a SUV and taken to the basement of Maharaja Kameshwar Complex near Dak Bungalow roundabout and thrashed mercilessly.

The victim was identified as Ankit Singh (22). He is a resident of Siddeshwar Nagar under Patliputra police station area.

The incident took place around 8pm and police rescued him within an hour from the Maharaja complex. SSP Upendra Sharma and City SP (central) Vinay Tiwary rushed to the spot after the matter was brought to their knowledge.

An FIR was lodged with Patliputra police station on Ankit’s statement. At least three more named accused are absconding.

Tiwary said Mishal was detained from the spot immediately after rescuing Ankit. “More than a dozen of sticks, rods and other blunt weapons were seized from there,” he said.

In reply to a query, the SP said no firearms were recovered. “He was rushed to a hospital for treatment due to injuries received from thrashing. The matter was related to rivalry between two groups,” he said.

Meanwhile, Anshuman Singh, who accompanied Ankit when he was kidnapped, said Mishal was continuously threatening and abusing them on phone for helping a youth named Lucky whose high-end bike was forcefully snatched by the accused from a gym at Nageshwar Colony around a fortnight back. Anshuman is a resident of New Patliputra Colony.

“That bike was later recovered with the help of police but no action was taken against Mishal that time as his family is well connected to influential people. He continued to threaten us since then, leading to the Monday night incident,” he said.

Anshuman said at least 35-40 people, including Mishal and his relatives, had reached the spot in four separate SUVs.

“They first tried to drag me inside but Ankit pushed them apart. After that Mishal and other pointed gun at Ankit, hit him hard with pistol’s butt and dragged him inside one of the SUVs,” Anshuman said, adding Ankit’s cellphone was snatched and he received multiple stitches on his head.

Anshuman said he along with his one more friend rushed to Patliputra police station and informed the policemen about the incident. “We came to know from police that Ankit was taken to a marketing complex. We immediately reached there followed by the police,” he added.

Title: Verlinvest to invest in VC firm Spring
Content:
This story is from January 15, 2020

(Representative image)

BENGALURU: Verlinvest , the Belgium-based investment holding company created by the founding families of beer major Anheuser-Busch InBev, is coming in as the anchor investor in Spring Marketing Capital , a $30-million venture capital fund. The firm expects to make a first close of $15-20 million by March this year and start making new investments.

The new venture fund has also got managing partners from top VC firms like Matrix Partners’ Avnish Bajaj, A91 Partners’ Abhay Pandey and Saama Capital’s Ash Lilani. There are also entrepreneurs like Cred’s Kunal Shah and Citrus Pay’s Amrish Rau & Jitendra Gupta as backers.

Spring Marketing Capital is taking up a unique concept where it will closely work with VC firms to co-invest in their consumer-facing portfolio companies to help founders shape branding and marketing strategy in the early days. Its founders include Sequoia Capital India’s former chief marketing officer Raja Ganapathy, besides top professionals from advertisement world, including former DDB Mudra CEO Vineet Gupta and Lowe Lintas chairman Arun Iyer.

“Internet is clearly shortening the time-to-market for consumer products and winners will be players who build a brand and not just distribution. The marketing industry is fragmented and is not tailored towards startups but large corporations,” said Ganapathy, who has also worked at Ogilvy and Deutsche Bank, talking about the gap it is filling in the market.

The commitment by Verlinvest, which manages assets of $1.8 billion globally, will give it heft as it has backed companies like Kishore Biyani’s Future Consumer Enterprises, yogurt maker Epigamia and wine maker Sula.

Spring Marketing expects to make about five co-investments of $1-2 million each year, while it will also work on around 15 projects or assignments, especially with larger players. Over the last 12 months, it has already worked with 20 brands including education technology unicorn Byju’s and mattress company Wakefit besides large companies like Cipla for its Nicotex product.

Title: RBI economist becomes deputy governor after 28 years
Content:
This story is from January 15, 2020

Michael Debabrata Patra (File photo)

Title: Splendid skies, syrupy sweets mark the coming of Sankranti
Content:
This story is from January 15, 2020

Hyderabad: From homemade laddus to spongy rasgullas and gulab jamuns, the International Sweet Festival being organized at Parade Grounds in Secunderabad has something to offer to everyone.

The three-day annual event witnessed over 500 sweet and snack stalls set up by participants from nearly 15 states this year.

On the first and second day of the festivals, sweets from Telangana, Kerala and West Bengal saw maximum takers.

Mousumi Chowdhuri, representing the Bengali community at the festival said, “This year, almost all the stalls have homemade sweets and snacks. The products are sold directly by people who have cooked them. This makes it more special. People are lapping up these sweets because they are pure and homemade.”

Apart from sweets, stalls offering lassi, organic coffee, pani puri, bhel puri and other Indian snacks also attracted large crowds.

“We got good for our sweets on the first two days. People are loving our Wayanad Payasam,” said Libby Benjamin from Kerala.

Meanwhile, the International Kite Festival which was being organised at Parade Grounds saw a total of 45 professional kite flyers from 15 countries this year.

“I have been organizing the Kite festival in Hyderabad for the last five years. This year, we have invited two big kite-flying teams from Australia and Ukraine. The national and international participants of this kite festival have been selected according to the professional kite flying standards. We have chosen only 100 professional kite flyers this year out of over300 applicants,” said Pavan Solanki, kite consultant for Telangana tourism department.

Secretary for Youth Advancement, Tourism and Culture, Burra Venkatesham said, “This year, we have also set up stalls that sell snacks and sweets at the International Kite and Sweet festival. Over five lakh people are expected to visit the festival this year and at any point, you will find 50,000 people at the venue.”

Title: Idol wing recover 10 idols worth several lakhs in Vedaranyam, two held
Content:
This story is from January 15, 2020

Trichy: The idol wing of the police has recovered 10 idols worth several lakhs of rupees from a house in Vedaranyam in Nagapattinam district and secured two in connection with the incident on Tuesday.

Based on a tip-off, the idol wing police intercepted Selvam, a resident of Ayakkaranpulam No. 1 Sethi in Vedaranyam, and his accomplice Bairavasundaram. During interrogation, the police team found a 1.5ft tall Amman idol in their bag. They had planned to sell the idol for 1.5 crore to somebody. Based on their confession, nine more valuable idols were recovered from one of their houses, police said.

Police have registered a case against the accused under various sections under the Antiquities and Art Treasures Act, 1972. Police have commenced investigation to ascertain from which temple these idols were stolen and for whom the idols were going to be sold.

The idol wing police are on to arrest the persons who are all involved in the case, the statement added.

Title: Indian Dartlet spotted for first time in Trichy
Content:
This story is from January 15, 2020

Trichy: Oriens goloides (Moore) or Indian Dartlet, the butterfly species mostly seen in areas receiving heavy rain, has been spotted on National College Trichy (NCT) campus. Researchers say the butterfly which belongs to the family hesperiidae (skippers) has been spotted for the first time in the region.

“It took us three months to confirm the species to be Indian Dartlet,” says V Muthu Krishnan who spotted it on the campus. An NCT alumnus and junior research fellow at Tropical Butterfly Conservatory Trichy (TBCT), Muthu Krishnan said Indian Dartlet was not spotted so far among the 109 species of butterflies found in TBCT. It appeared similar to Plain Palm Dart, Dark Palm Aart and Pale Palm Dart. It is found more in Western Ghats, particularly Coimbatore, Nilgiris and Kanyakumari, he said.

“This is the forty-third butterfly species spotted on the college premises over the last one year,” said V Gokula, associate professor and head of zoology department in NCT. He said that the zoology department has been preparing a checklist of butterfly species on the campus over the last one year. The work was carried out as part of the Star scheme of the department of biotechnology, government of India to promote biotechnology. In all, five departments including zoology has been selected under the scheme.

Muthu Krishnan said that considerable rain this year could be a possible reason for the butterfly to be spotted in the region. Apart from places with heavy rainfall, it is commonly found in hills with an altitude of 1600 feet.

Title: Man kills wife, two sons, tries to kill self in Trichy
Content:
This story is from January 15, 2020

The lodge where a jewellery shop owner killed three of his family in Trichy

TRICHY: The owner of a small-time jewellery store at Pattukottai taluk in Thanjavur district murdered his wife and two sons by slitting their throats at a lodge in Trichy. After murdering his wife and sons, Selvaraj, 47, of Urani, attempted suicide.

Preliminary investigations revealed that Selvaraj had taken the extreme step worrying about the future of his elder son who was suffering from learning difficulties. The couple feared that nobody would take care of him.The deceased have been identified as Selvaraj’s wife S Chellam, 43, and sons S Nikhil, 20, and S Mugil, 14.

All the four arrived here on Sunday evening and stayed at a lodge located on the West Boulevard Road. While booking a room at the lodge, Selvaraj stated that they had arrived here to visit temples in and around the city. On Monday night, Guru Ganesh, one of the friends of Selvaraj, received a message from him stating that he was going to commit suicide with his family members. Ganesh alerted the Trichy police.

A team from the Fort police station arrived at the lodge and broke open the doors of the room. They found the bodies of Selvaraj’s wife and sons.

Selvaraj, who was struggling for life, was rushed to Mahatma Gandhi Memorial Medical College Hospital. Investigations revealed that Selvaraj had made all the three swallow sleeping pills. When they fell unconscious, he slit their throats.

Title: Security beefed up at Sabari temple
Content:
This story is from January 15, 2020

Thiruvananthapuram: Perceived threat from Maoists, in the wake of the encounter with the police in Palakkad last October, has prompted the force to step up the security at Ponnambalamedu (where Makara Jyothi is lighted) and its surrounding viewpoints. Policemen have already taken over all strategic points as part of intensive surveillance of the region for Makaravilakku festival on Wednesday.

Ponnambalamedu hill, which falls in Goodrical range of Ranni forest division, is located opposite to the eastern side of Sabarimala Hill at an altitude of 1,170m. The security document prepared by the police, accessed by TOI, showed 16 major points in and around Ponnambalamedu that are inside dense forests.

Police have also divided the locations from where Makara Jyothi can be viewed in Pathanamthitta to six security divisions for augmenting security. Police have increased the security measures at Panjippara, Nellimala, Ayyanmala, Elavumkal, Attathode, Hill Top etc. All these points, except Attathode and Hill top, are forest areas which are vulnerable to landslides and human stampede.

After the recent police action against left-wing extremists (LWE), we believe that Maoists might make use of every possible opportunity to exact vengeance. The proximity to forest area makes the festival more susceptible, since LWE could hide in the woods and attack police, said the document.

Police personnel on duty at Ponnambalamedu have been given arms and they have been equipped with automatic weapons as well. Recently a ‘threat’ was conveyed in writing at Vadakara station over the killing of Maoists in alleged encounters since 2016.

Taking a cue from the defamatory posters and social media posts regarding the conduct of Makaravilakku festival, police are engaged in removing defamatory social media posts and posters that might hurt the sentiment of believers. Cyber cell and social media unit have been directed to monitor trolls and discussions on the topic.

The police document said that the threat from anti-national elements, hardened criminals, extremists and religious fundamentalists groups operating in India, local disgruntled elements, misguided individuals and communal elements cannot be ruled out.

For ensuring free and uninterrupted flow of vehicles, ‘one-way’ traffic will be introduced from 2pm on Wednesday till Friday, till the outflow becomes normal. Outgoing vehicles from Nilackal will be allowed to go through Elavunkal, Kanamala, Plappally, Laha, Perunadu and Vadasserikkara.

Vehicles coming from Erumely will not be allowed to take deviation to Nilackal at Chethonkara in Ranni. These vehicles will be directed to Mandirampady-Vadasserikkara road to Nilackal. Also, no vehicle can be parked at Laha, Perunadu and Vadasserikkara towns after 2pm on Wednesday till traffic restrictions are withdrawn. The traffic scheme has been divided into 13 sectors, for which additional SP (Pathanamthitta) will be responsible.

As many as 2,400 police officials are on duty at Sannidhanam, Pamba and Nilackal during Makaravilakku festival. This excludes senior officials, bomb squad, and other special teams who have been deployed for emergency requirements.

Title: FDA team collects samples from sweetshops in Karond
Content:
This story is from January 15, 2020

The mobile food lab visited Nishatpura on Tuesday

Bhopal: A day ahead of Makar Sankranti, food safety officials collected samples of sweets made of til (sesame) from sweetshops on Tuesday.

A team of food safety officials took six samples consisting of til ladoos, til papdis, gur, edible oil and gajaks from shops in Karond and Gulmohar area and sent them for testing at the food lab under the provisions of the Food Safety & Standard Act (FSSA).

Senior food safety officer D K Verma said that Bhopal is on the top in the entire state in collection of samples of edibles for purity test. A total of 650 samples of edibles of different types have been collected so far in Bhopal district alone.

Meanwhile, the mobile food lab, which is going to different places in the city since January 9 to create public awareness on state government’s drive against adulteration (shudh ke liye yudh), was in Nishatpura and Kabitpura on Tuesday.

The food safety team and technicians accompanying the lab talked to 20 to 22 people during the day, gave them simple tips to find out impurity in their food stuff at home itself and put to test 32 food items brought by people of the two areas for purity test.

On Wednesday, the mobile van will go to Jehangirabad, Malviya Nagar and Jawahar Chowk and interact with people and carry out free food tests for the residents of these areas.

Title: Jagan attends Pongal festivities in Gudivada
Content:
This story is from January 15, 2020

Vijayawada: Chief minister YS Jaganmohan Reddy joined Pongal celebrations at Gudivada in Krishna district on Tuesday on the invitation of minister for civil supplies Kodali Srivenkateswara Rao.

The minister organised celebrations at a function hall in the outskirts of Gudivada town. The celebrations included a wide range of competitions including bull and goat fights, besides rangoli.

The chief minister distributed sweets and greeted people on behalf of the state government. He wished them a bountiful harvest and a prosperous year ahead. The government prioritises agriculture and has constituted Agriculture Mission to help the farmers, he said.

The chief minister recalled that the government’s initiative of creating basic infrastructure in all marketyards in the state, besides linking them to national and international markets. The government had already established quality centres and agriculture labs to help farmers, he said and added that every measure of the government would help the farming community to be happy all through the year.

The chief minister said the harvest would be good in the years to come and added that the people would celebrate Pongal with more wealth.

Ministers Velampalli Srinivas, Perni Nani, Machilipatnam MP Vallabhaneni Balashowri, Pamarru MLA K Anil Kumar and several others were present along with the chief minister in the celebrations.

Title: Green belt to protect coast from sea erosion, cyclones
Content:
This story is from January 15, 2020

Naturally grown vegetation that protects the shore from sea erosion and wind at Kirimanjeshwara in Udupi.

Mangaluru: The department of environment is all set for the creation of green belts of coastal vegetation on the Karnataka coast to prevent sea erosion on the shore and to protect agriculture and properties on the landward side.

‘Adoption of Wind Resistant Aerodynamic Green Coastal Infrastructure’, a bio-shielding as a biological barrier to control coastal erosion and protection, will be taken up at 10 identified coastal villages in Uttar Kannada, Udupi and Dakshina Kannada districts. The World Bank funded Integrated Coastal Zonal Management Project (ICZMP) will be commenced from April and will be completed in four years.

A total Rs 310 crore has been reserved to take up various measures to address issues of coastal Karnataka, said Dr Dinesh Kumar, regional director (environment).

“It is observed that in the entire shoreline management plan, least importance has been given to biological means of coastal protection measures or living shoreline. Various studies conducted by central government agencies like National Institute of Ocean Technology, National Centre for Sustainable Coastal Management and the volume II of ‘Coastal Ecosystems of the Karnataka State’ by Dr T Ananda Rao and Dr A N Sharief also recommends green belt/ living shoreline as a biological barrier to control erosion of beaches,” he said.

“In the past one year, we have experienced seven cyclones of different magnitudes. In addition to coastal erosion, noticeable damage also has been caused during cyclones. Salt spray during cyclones damages agricultural land by burning crops. Ingression of saline water leads to loss of fertility of soil. Sand drifting due to wind not only harms agriculture, but also damages houses and properties. High winds during monsoons and cyclones damages life and property of fishermen and coastal dwellers. The project aims at protecting the coast, fishermen and agriculture,” Kumar said.

“On a pilot basis, the project will be implemented at Tannirbavi, Idya, Kodikanyana, Shiroor, Gangolli, Kaggala, Dhareshwara, Machali, Harvada and Belikeri. The project involves creation of fidelity creepers and grass zone (growing species like ipomoea, spinifex, Cyprus, cynodon, hydrophylax, sesuvium, launaea and canavalia), closed herbaceous zone (clerodendrum, vitex, pandanus, premna, crotalaria, scaevola and dattura), middle mixed bushy zone (pandanus, premna, vitex, scaevola, opuntia, calotropis, cerbera, morinda citricifolia, nili gida, calophyllum) and landward woodland zone (bushy, woody and tall growing trees), at the identified places. This will not only prevent coastal erosion, but also take the coastal wind direction upwards to safer heights, to save lives and properties on the landward side,” he added.

Title: JDA’s latest housing scheme gets good response
Content:
This story is from January 15, 2020

Jaipur: Jaipur Development Authority’s ( JDA ) Shiv Vihar housing scheme where 346 plots are proposed to be developed is receiving overwhelming response from residents.

Learning lessons from the past when the projects were developed in far-flung locations, the JDA this time has proposed to develop the scheme inside the city near Muhana Mandi. The civic body is receiving applications in large numbers as the last date is approaching. A senior official said, “The civic body has received 6,288 applications so far. The lottery for the scheme will be held on February 5.”

The civic body has fixed a reserve price of Rs 25,000 per square-metre in this scheme. The plots, sized between 45 square-metre to 220 square-metre will be developed in the colony.

Officials were expecting good response as it is situated on the 200-Feet Road connecting Muhana and Gopalpura Road.

A senior official said, “The move is expected to boost revenue that will be utilised to develop infrastructure. As the market condition has improved, the JDA filled its coffers after auctioning plots in its old scheme,” he said.

As JDA has many schemes in far-flung areas, not many residents have applied to buy those in the past as the authorities failed to provide even basic facilities.

Due to lack of power and water, the sites of these colonies continue to wear a deserted look. An official source said since 2005, the civic body has launched 31 housing schemes, but most of those are still unoccupied.

When the previous BJP government came to power in the state, the JDA launched many housing schemes after a gap of four years. The cash-strapped body earned a revenue of Rs 700 crore from those schemes. However, this money has not been spent on developing these colonies.

Title: Tamil Nadu: IMD blocks free access to sat data
Content:
This story is from January 15, 2020

IMD’s decision comes at a time when independent weather bloggers are gaining popularity for accurate forecasts... Read More

CHENNAI: The decision of India Meteorological Department ( IMD ) to block access to certain weather-related datasets on its new website, by either removing them or by making them paid, has sparked outrage.

While bloggers believe the move was to stop them from using IMD data to draw their own forecasts, researchers believe denying free access to certain weather parameters will discourage young researchers from planning new study topics.

Last week, soon after http://www.mausam.imd.gov.in was launched and links to a few datasets, including high resolution full disk, sector and divisional sector satellite images, images of INSAT 3A and Oceansat-1, were removed, a few researchers and weather enthusiasts expressed disappointment online.

In a release, the agency said, “India Meteorological Department has launched a new website specially for general public. It contains information for the general public. If any organization is interested to access further information from IMD for commercial and R&D purpose, they may contact IMD...”

Researchers are unhappy. “Open data has sparked a lot of research before. At present, we know what kind of data is available with IMD that we can request for. But a few years later, researchers would no longer even know the kind of data that exists with IMD. Writing to their officials to get access to data is only going to create more red tape. It will eventually lead to data closure and the presence of the data itself would be forgotten,” said Raj Bhagat Palanichamy, GIS and remote sensing analyst, World Resources Institute.

IMD’s decision comes at a time when independent weather bloggers are gaining popularity for accurate forecasts intelligibly presented to the public, while the national forecaster is drawing flak for getting it wrong.

Weather blogger Pradeep John, with more than seven lakh followers on his account, said he wouldn’t buy the idea that people will misuse IMD data and make money out of it. “I don’t think the potential of making money in weather forecasting in India is huge.
