If somebody uses it without acknowledging it to IMD, then they can look for other ways to stop it than denying free access to data to all,” he said.

After the online outrage, IMD restored some data on its new website. “What they have done is not correct. They are the nodal agency and are supposed to provide open access to their data to everybody,” said Prof Sridhar Balasubramanian, climate expert, IIT Bombay.

A few researchers have welcomed IMD’s decision as an effort to protect its scientists’ workforce.

“Bloggers use IMD data and handout forecast which is in contrast to that of IMD and people get confused. I think IMD is doing it to protect its scientists who have been constantly facing public criticism even if their forecast is right and weather bloggers have a major role to play in this,” said a researcher on anonymity.

M Rajeevan, secretary, ministry of earth sciences that includes IMD, said the website was not meant for researchers or bloggers. “Our old website had a mix of products meant both for the public and experienced weather forecasters. Now, we have filtered and retained only those that could be understood by the public. Those who want our data for other purposes can contact us,” he said. “We are a government organisation and we cannot deny information. But we are also worried that many use our data and do not acknowledge IMD.”

Title: Rajasthan’s experiential tourism gets fillip via cultural promotion
Content:
This story is from January 15, 2020

File pic of desert festival

JAIPUR: Rajasthan may have built its tourism around its storied monuments but the state now wants to make it more experiential, woven around its cultural riches and intangible heritage to increase the number of repeat tourists which is in single-digits now.

Be it kite festival that starts early in the beginning of the year, desert festival in Jaisalmer or the world music extravaganza in Udaipur that hosts global artists and ensembles from over 20 countries, the cultural calendar is chock-a-block.

As the experiential travel is growing apace, the government has also been investing in fairs and festivals that not only complement the state’s iconic monuments but help promote activity-based tourism “We support over 60 fairs and festivals and the cultural calendar is jam-packed. While we can still add new festivals that have tourist potential, our focus is now to expand the scope and impact of existing ones,” said Bhanwar Lal, director, department of tourism.

Currently, the department spends around Rs 9 crore annually to preserve and promote the intangible heritage of the state that includes its various art forms, music, handicraft and rural traditions.

Many countries and travel companies in the world are diversifying their tourism products through experiential activities, covering adventure, culture, culinary journeys, wine, sports etc. They are catering to new breed of travelers who are no more interested in a post-card picture of sitting on the beach and relaxing.

“Culturally, Rajasthan is a treasure-trove. The people in the rural areas with colourful turbans and long mustaches themselves are an attraction to any outsider. But they possess amazing skills in folk music, dances, puppetry, acrobatic dances, etc. These are our natural strengths and they have a great universal tourism appeal. Besides, fairs are also about living our traditions in way and thus we need to preserve them,” said Bhanwar Lal.

During the past few years, some popular monuments in Jaipur were opened to the public during night time realizing the emerging trend of activity-based tourism.

“We have wonderful monuments that can be compared to any structure in the world. But sadly, our percentage of repeat foreign tourists is not even 5%. Unless we focus hard on experiential tourism, the repeat tourist numbers will not increase,” said a leading tour operator.

Recently, UNESCO India and the Rajasthan tourism department signed a partnership agreement to promote community-based responsible tourism based on the rich intangible cultural heritage of the western Rajasthan. This is expected to add further impetus to the efforts of the state for promoting experiential tourism in the state.

Content:
This story is from January 15, 2020

File pic of desert festival

Title: Youth arrested for raping farm labourer in Bareilly
Content:
This story is from January 15, 2020

Bareilly: Days after a 17-year-old girl was dragged into a sugarcane field and allegedly raped by a youth, who shoved his mobile phone into her mouth to ensure that she doesn’t shout during the assault, police nabbed the accused from his house. The girl worked as a labourer in cane fields near the plywood factory where the accused, Sunil Kumar, was employed in Fatehganj East area of Bareilly. The mobile phone, which Sunil used to muzzle the voice of the minor girl, later helped the police reach him. According to police, the assault took place on January 7. Sunil, after the alleged assault, fled after seeing people approaching towards the field, leaving the phone behind. The rape survivor and her family members didn’t approach police for a few days.

“They didn’t know who the accused was. But, when they received a phone call on the accused’s mobile, they decided to contact the police,” a police officer said. Police reached Sunil with the help of SIM card found in the phone, which was registered in his name. An FIR was registered and Sunil was arrested on Monday. The girl was sent for medical examination.

After his arrest, the accused told police that he knew the girl for the last one month and had gifted the mobile phone on her request. “But the girl has denied knowing the accused,” said Ashwini Kumar, SHO of Fatehganj East police station.

SHO Kumar told TOI, “We have arrested the main accused and during questioning he said that he knew the girl for the last one month and had gifted the mobile phone on her request. We cross checked with the girl but she denied it.”

Title: 1.5 tonnes of refuse collected Bhogi’ collection centres
Content:
This story is from January 15, 2020

Trichy: The corporation on Tuesday opened five waste collection centres in the city and netted 1.5 tonnes of refuse that would have been otherwise set on fire by the city dwellers. The civic body will transport the collected waste to cement factories to use it as a fuel in furnaces.

The move is expected to prevent people from burning the discards at public places, thus polluting the air during Bhogi festival. Bhogi festival, as a part of Pongal festivities, is traditionally known for burning waste materials.

The smoke emanating from the waste often degrades the quality of the atmosphere, even causing health issues to people with respiratory illness. Ariyamangalam and K Abishekapuram zones of Trichy corporation opened five waste collection centres on Allithurai road, Edatheru, EB road, Madurai road and Raja street (G corner) where sanitary workers received the waste handed over by the residents.

Around 1.5 tonnes of waste, mostly non-recyclable and no resalable waste was collected in the centres that operated between 10 am and 6 pm on Tuesday, officials said. Sanitary workers manning the collection centres received the waste from houses that geared up for Pongal by cleaning their households. The waste was segregated in bins based on their quality. “Mostly tyres, boxes, rags, mats and rexin materials were handed over by the residents. We will ship the collected waste to cement factories in Ariyalur where the waste will be used as refuse-derived fuel (RDF) in furnaces,” a sanitary official with Trichy Corporation said. TNN

Title: International wrestler threatens to return medals over encroachment of road near her house
Content:
This story is from January 15, 2020

Meerut: International wrestler Indu Tomar on Tuesday approached Meerut district authorities alleging encroachment of a passage near her house in city’s Mundali area by a local.

“Despite repeated complaints, no action has been taken in the matter and it is affecting the passage near my house. If no action is taken, I will return my medals as mark of protest,” said 22-year-old Tomar.

She has bagged a silver medal in Under-23 National Wrestling Championship in 2018 and represented India in Asian Championship in 2015 and also in World Championship in 2014.

According to the complaint filed by Tomar, her family owns a house in Mau Khas village.

“The passage was spread in 210 square metres. But, a local has encroached on 90 square metres of land,” she alleged.

“My family is being harassed by the local, who is trying to build a boundary wall for his farm on the government land. An application in this regard was earlier submitted to the district authorities, but to no avail. The Mundali police station officers have also started troubling us,” Tomar alleged in the letter.

“If any action is not taken in the matter, I will be left with no option but to return all my medals,” said Tomar.

Sunita Singh, additional city magistrate, who took Tomar’s complaint application, said, “The wrestler in question has asked for the demarcation of boundaries in the area on allegations of encroachment. A team headed by lekhpal has been asked to look into the matter and demarcate the boundaries.”

Title: TRS set to take on BJP and Cong in three-way contest
Content:
This story is from January 15, 2020

Hyderabad: Though the ruling TRS may have won quite a number of municipal wards even before the votes are cast as Congress and BJP went without candidates in a large number of wards, it is going to be a triangular contest in the elections to 129 urban local bodies to be held on January 22.

The process of withdrawal of nominations came to an end on Tuesday amidst huge drama. Several candidates refused to withdraw from the electoral fray and threatened to commit suicide. A couple of them actually attempted to commit suicide before the locals and police saved them.

TRS member Abdul Raheem attempted to hang himself before being saved by the locals. He had filed his nomination from municipal ward 39 in Suryapet after taking out a huge rally. However, he was not given the ticket and another candidate got it. Another candidate, Vijay of TRS also attempted to commit suicide in Medchal on not being given a party ticket. The leaders of respective parties were still trying to cajole the party members until reports late on Tuesday night.

While the State Election Commission is yet to release the official data on number of candidates and political parties that remained in fray, TRS secretary Gattu Ramachandra claimed that the TRS candidates have won unanimously in 84 wards in 35 municipal bodies as no other candidates remained in the fray after withdrawal of nominations.

Ramachandra also claimed that there were no BJP candidates left in the poll fray in about 700 wards and that there were no Congress candidates contesting about 400 wards. However, this has not been confirmed by the State Election Commission.

While political analysts said that the ruling TRS has a clear edge over the Congress and BJP in the municipal elections, they said the polls to the ULBs should be viewed as a triangular contest as candidates from Congress and BJP are in fray from a majority of the wards and a keen contest between the parties is on the cards in several urban local bodies. The TRS has more than one candidate in several wards even after the exercise to withdraw nominations concluded on Tuesday.

“TRS has resorted to threats, misuse of police, money and muscle power to ensure that the candidates from other parties withdrew from the electoral fray in many wards. This does not mean that TRS is a clear winner. There is going to be a contest and the Congress will win a large number of municipal wards defeating TRS and BJP,” said Telangana Congress treasurer Gudur Narayana Reddy.

The ensuing ULB elections will also witness a multi-cornered contest in urban local bodies of Nizamabad, Kothagudem, Mahbubnagar, Sangareddy and Nalgonda as the MIM, CPI, CPM, TJS, BSP and TDP too are in the electoral fray in the wards of ULBs falling in these districts.

Title: Man accuses cops of harassment after son found hanging at home
Content:
This story is from January 15, 2020

Bareilly: A 21-year-old youth, Guddu, of Moradabad district, was found hanging from a ceiling hook in his house on Monday evening. A few days ago, he was detained by police for questioning in connection with the abduction of a teenage girl by his friend. He had “admitted” to helping his friend to abduct the girl, said police. Now, Guddu’s father, Satpal, has blamed both police and the girl’s family for his death.

Terming the allegations as baseless, Neeraj Sharma, SHO said, “We called him (Guddu) only once and after questioning him, we let him go. Since, he was not involved in abducting the girl, we didn’t arrest him. Now, after his father lodged a complaint, we have registered an FIR under IPC section 306 (abetment of suicide) against the girl’s father and two brothers.”

According to sources, on December 31, the 17-year-old girl went missing from home. On January 3, her father approached the police and lodged an FIR against Guddu’s friend for abducting his daughter. Though Guddu’s name did not figure in the FIR, the complainant had alleged that Guddu had helped his friend in abducting his daughter.

Police had registered a case under IPC section 363 (kidnapping) and 366 (kidnapping, abducting or inducing woman to compel her marriage) against Guddu’s friend.

Police had detained Guddu and interrogated him. Police claimed that Guddu had confessed that he helped his friend in executing his plan and escorted the couple to Joya. Thereafter, he left them and said he had no clue about the couple’s whereabouts.

Guddu’s family alleged that since the girl’s family had lodged an FIR, police had been harassing their son by calling him at the police station.

“My son had completely broken down due to police torture. On Monday evening, he took the extreme step as he was fed up of police harassment. The girl’s father and brothers had also been threatening our son that they would frame him in a false case soon,” alleged Guddu’s father.

Title: Ex-servicemen’s rally held in Jaisalmer
Content:
This story is from January 15, 2020

War widows and ex-servicemen were felicitated in the rally organised by Battle Axe Division at Jaisalmer military station on Tuesday. District sainik kalyaan officer Col (retired) Bhojraj Singh, among other officers, was present at the programme.

Title: Pawan Kalyan, JP Nadda meet sparks speculation of BJP-Jana Sena tie-up
Content:
This story is from January 15, 2020

Pawan Kalyan

KAKINADA: Fuelling speculation of a BJP-Jana Sena alliance in Andhra Pradesh ahead of local body and municipal polls, Jana Sena president and actor Pawan Kalyan on Tuesday announced that a meeting of Jana Sena and BJP leaders would be held in Vijayawada on January 16.

BJP’s national leaders are likely to attend the crucial meeting, four days before AP assembly session on January 20 in which chief minister and YSRCP president Y S Jaganmohan Reddy is likely to announce shifting of state capital from Amaravati.

Incidentally, both BJP and Jana Sena are opposed to the three capital cities plan and have categorically stated that Amaravati should be continued as the capital city. Pawan said state administration should be carried out from one place while development should be spread across regions. He also said PM Narendra Modi ’s aspirations were not reflected in Andhra Pradesh. Pawan, who reached Kakinada on Tuesday after holding talks with senior BJP leaders including BJP working president JP Nadda in Delhi on Monday, told reporters that the proposed BJP-Jana Sena meeting in Vijayawada will discuss important issues confronting the state including the proposal to shift the state capital.

He said he had briefed Nadda on the developments in AP, agitation by farmers in Amaravati and foreign investors withdrawing from the state. He said he had visited Delhi only after the BJP leadership invited him.

Jana Sena sources said Pawan was likely to enter into an electoral alliance with BJP in the ensuing mandal and zilla parishad and municipal polls. Local body elections are due next month while the schedule for civic body polls is yet to be announced.

The party, however, ruled out merger of Jana Sena with the BJP. Incidentally, Pawan’s brother Chiranjeevi, who had floated Praja Rajyam Party and won a few assembly seats, later merged his party with the Congress.

Pawan joining hands with BJP is likely to throw a new political equation in Andhra Pradesh. The actor had launched the party after meeting Narendra Modi before the general elections in 2014. Though he did not contest the election then, he had supported the BJP-TDP alliance, which won the assembly elections. He sailed with the BJP till 2017 when he pulled out of the NDA accusing the BJP of cheating AP on the promise of special category status.

Jana Sena contested polls in April 2019 in alliance with the Communists. Pawan had lost both assembly seats he contested including one in his native place, dominated by members of his social group. Jana Sena, however, managed to win one seat. All through the campaign Pawan did not criticise Prime Minister Narendra Modi or the BJP, though he was critical of the YSRCP and the TDP.

Pawan hails from numerically strong Kapu community. If Jana Sena and BJP combine could manage to consolidate the Kapu vote bank, the new alliance may pose a political and electoral challenge to YSRCP and TDP. The Kapu community is spread across the state but it is dominant in East and West Godavari districts. Historically, the political party that had won the maximum number of seats in these districts had always formed the government.

Earlier, Pawan’s visit to Kakinada was marred by high tension in view of prohibitory orders in the town. On Sunday Jana Sena and YSRCP activists fought a pitched battle forcing the police to resort to lathicharge. Several people were injured.

Title: Karnataka: MBBS dropout treats patients in two hospitals, arrested
Content:
This story is from January 15, 2020

Representative image

MANGALURU: A quack was arrested at a private hospital in Derlakatte and sent behind bars. The accused, who is a first-year MBBS dropout, had entered two hospitals, examined patients and even written prescriptions.

The incident took place at Yenepoya Medical College , Derlakatte, on Sunday night. The accused is Mohammed Habib Hussain , 28, a resident of Shivamogga , who currently resides in Attavar, Mangaluru. The motive of the accused for visiting hospitals is not known, but police said that he was a medical college dropout. He discontinued studies after the first year due to personal reasons. Dr Sampathila Padmanabha, medical superintendent, Yenepoya Medical College, said the accused had come to the medical college at midnight on December 29.

After speaking to the security guard at the hospital entrance, he introduced himself as an assistant to the consulting urologist, and wanted to visit patients at the private ward situated at floor number 7. After entering, he called the duty nurse to get case sheets. Later, he examined two women patients in the presence of the duty nurse, and also wrote a prescription on the patient case sheet. He also yelled at a nurse, saying that she isn’t doing her duty properly, and left the place.

Nurse grew suspicious

However, the nurse who grew suspicious, informed the management, after the accused had left the place. The management, who crosschecked about the accused, found out that he is not a doctor, and that he is also not associated with the hospital.

The management sent an advisory to all employees to produce their identity cards, whenever they enter any wards, especially at night, and also to keep an eye on anyone suspicious. The same message was passed on to other hospitals in the vicinity.

The accused again showed up at the hospital on Sunday night. As security guards were told about strangers visiting the hospital in the guise of doctors, he was allowed to enter the hospital premises, so that he can be apprehended. He later went to the reception counter and queried about the consultant urologist. When he noticed that the staff had an idea about what was happening, he tried to flee from the spot. He was later caught by a security guard, and the police were informed. He was arrested by Ullal police station personnel.

Dr Padmanabha added that he used to roam around with his friend in a car. He was also involved in a similar incident at a private hospital in Kankanady, and the same has been informed to the police. He visited hospitals in a car, which has been seized by police.

Title: GOC to demand toll exemption for ex-servicemen
Content:
This story is from January 15, 2020

Bareilly: General officer-in-command of Uttar Bharat area, Lt Gen CP Mohanti, has said he will press for an exemption from toll on national highways for ex-servicemen. He made this announcement at the function organized at the Jat Regiment Centre (JRC) at the fourth Veterans’ Day here on Tuesday. The day is observed in memory of first Field Marshal K M Cariappa’s superannuation date on January 14, 1953.

As many as 300 soldiers, officers and 25 ex-servicemen, ‘veer naris’ and war widows of Second World War and their families participated at the function.

GOC Mohanti said by organizing Veterans’ Day, they get an opportunity to express gratitude towards the selfless service and sacrifices made by veterans and their families.

“There were some queries regarding ex-servicemen’s contributory health scheme (ECHS) and these were addressed. The veterans and their families can avail of benefits of the scheme. Besides, the veterans raised a demand seeking exemption from paying toll while they commute on national highways. We feel it is a genuine demand and will the raise the matter with National Highway Authority of India as well as the government,” Mohanti said.

Sunil Dhingra, a retired colonel, said there are several issues, including health facilities, pension and other benefits, about which a number of ex-servicemen and their families are still unaware of. “Today, bankers to education sector and placement agencies hold camps to educate ex-servicemen and their kin about the various schemes being run for their benefits,” he said.

Title: 1K govt-managed temples of Indore in state of neglect
Content:
This story is from January 15, 2020

Indore: Like Khajrana Ganesh and Ranjeet Hanuman temples, they are also managed by district administration but the condition of these around 1,000 ‘government’ temples of Indore speaks volumes about administrative apathy.

Collectively, these temples have around 5000 acre of land and a regular income through donations that runs into lakhs. Yet, they are totally depended on state government for maintenance of their buildings which in most cases are of historical importance. Even salary of around 1,600 priests in these temples adds up to mere Rs25 lakh per month.

In absence of any proper development plan and regular monitoring, land belonging to many of these religious structures has witnessed encroachments in form of illegal colonies.

Ram Mandir, Maruti Mandir, Pandharinath Mandir, Mahaveer Mandir, Sri Ranchod Mandir and Sri Khedapati Hanuman Mandir are some of the government temples, on whose land illegal colonies and structures have been constructed, official sources said. In some cases, the matter is even pending before courts.

Administrative officials say that there is clear instruction from Apex Court not to consider any sale/purchase or encroachment on government temples as valid but many cases related to private ownership of land attached with the said religious structures are pending in courts as officials concerned failed to deal with it in proper manner.

Another issue that is yet to be addressed by administration is of not keeping records of donations received at most of these temples, which could have been used for their upkeep and further development.

“In 1984-85, state government had appointed district collector as manager of historical religious structures and he had authority to allot land associated with these temples on annual lease for maintenance of priests while donations were used to fund routine tasks. However, some years ago, the land allotment on annual lease was stopped,” ADM Pavan Jain told TOI.

He said that like Khajrana Ganesh Mandir and Ranjeet Hanuman Mandir, some big temples of the city were directly regulated by district administration and a similar plan would be prepared for remaining temples.

“We have asked all SDMs and Tehsildars to present records of number of government temples and land attached with them, identify encroachments on them and present report of maintenance and development that needs to be carried. The income of these temples would also be recorded to help prepare further plan,” Jain said.

District collector Lokesh Kumar Jatav told TOI that development work was carried out at any temple to facilitate number of devotees visiting there. “Huge footfall is recorded at Khajrana Ganesh, Ranjeet Hanuman and Bijasan Mata temples and the same are being developed accordingly. There are many temples in Indore and instructions have given for conserving their land from encroachment. We used to keep records of donation received at notable temples,” he said.

====

Pointers

Temples district collector manages …

298 in Indore tehsil

341 in Sanwer

290 in Depalpur

174 in Hatod

166 in Mhow

Pointers

Encroachments on temple land

1. In Sirpur, a residential colony has been developed on 1 hectare land of Ram Mandir

2. A residential colony and some other units have come up on 7 acre land of Sri Ranchod Mandir.

3. Mahaveer Mandir has also witnessed a colony being erected on its land Survey number 172 to 176.

4. A colony has come on Sri Khedapati Hanuman Mandir land at Survey number 135 to 138.

Caption: Pandrinath temple near collectorate is one of the neglected govt temples in Indore

Title: 50 students of Madhya Pradesh to meet PM for pariksha pe charcha
Content:
This story is from January 15, 2020

Sukriti Chakravarti

BHOPAL: Fifty students of Madhya Pradesh are all set to meet Prime Minister Narendra Modi in New Delhi on January 20 for‘Pariksha pe charcha’; this event is being organised for the students appearing for board examinations. Of these, seven students have been selected from Jabalpur while five were selected from Indore. Two students from the state capital have also made it to the list. The selection was done through an essay-writing competition organised by MyGov website.

Bhopal girl Sukriti Chakravarti of class 12 studying in Carmel Convent has also been shortlisted for the prorgamme after her essay on topic ‘Are our exams sufficient to analyze the true potential of students?’ was chosen by the selection committee. “I wrote against the topic as I feel that students’ potential can’t be measured by theoretical exams in all the subjects. I’m also going to ask a question to the PM about lack of awareness about different career paths among the students. All biology students want to pursue MBBS, all mathematics students want to become engineers while commerce students wish to become Chartered Accountants. They don’t know that they can pursue other career options too,” lamented Sukriti.

A student of class 11, Prabhanshu Malviya, of Kendriya Vidhayala No. 3, Bhopal, who has also been selected for the meeting from Bhopal said, ‘it is like a dream come true’ for him. “I never thought that of all the students, my essay will be selected. I am very excited and already working on a few questions that I wish to ask the PM about exam preparations,” he added.

Assistant coordinator, Rashtriya Madhyamik Shiksha Abhiyan, Mukesh Sharma, said, “All the schools of the state were asked to let students participate in the essay-writing competition and send their entries. It is a proud moment for us that 50 students of the state got selected. They will all come to Bhopal on January 18 and will leave for the event together along with the officials of education department.”

Title: Animal whisperer offers refuge, heals thousands of animals and birds
Content:
This story is from January 15, 2020

TV Siva Prakash with a bird

SECUNDERABAD: An animal lover at heart, TV Siva Prakash , has opened his home and wallet to help injured birds and animals ever since he can remember. Such is his love for animals that he has converted his garage and terrace of his house into a shelter to treat injured animals and birds.

Inspired by his father who worked as a forest department official in the Andamans in the 1980s, Prakash learnt the art of rescuing and treating animals from a veterinary doctor who was stationed in the Andamans back then. “During my teenage, I used to tag along with the doctor to rescue animals and birds. I learnt basics of first aid and then slowly went on to learn giving injections and administering medicines,” said Prakash.

Now, the 48-year-old animal rescuer even performs surgeries without having any formal degree in veterinary medicine. He spends Rs 40,000-Rs 50,000 every month from his own pocket to treat those injured.

Prakash’s family moved to Hyderabad in 1995, following which he started his own garage. In the early 2000s, he attended to an injured calf while travelling to Hyderabad from Srikakulam . “I realised that there is a lot of medical assistance available for dogs and cats. However, for the bigger animals like cows and buffaloes, there is very little help available. That’s when I decided to treat animals and birds,” said Prakash.

Prakash’a auto garage Sai Venkata Motors on Neredmet main road is now a clinic-cum-shelter for many cows, buffaloes, monkeys who are undergoing treatment. If that’s not all, the terrace at his residence in Sainikpuri houses ducks, parrots, pigeons and cranes. “Recently, we had a peacock which suffered severe burn injuries on its feathers at a power grid station in Tirmulgherry. While the forest department had lost hope on its survival, I decided to treat the peacock,” said Prakash, who saved the peacock and handed it over to the forest department after 12 days.

Prakash added that the number of injured birds went up during Srankranti due to the use of Chinese manja. “ There is a lack of awareness about animal rescue and rehabilitation. People can take small steps such as keep a bowl of water for birds during summers, feed cows and buffaloes at your doorstep etc,” said Prakash.

He also conducts an adoption drive for dogs outside his garage every Sunday and holds seminars on first aid for animals and birds in schools.

Title: This Class 8 pass-out duped many by posing as cop, judge
Content:
This story is from January 15, 2020

Indore: Crime branch police on Tuesday arrested a man who had been duping influential people of lakhs of rupees by posing as senior police, administrative or judicial officer.

Crime branch ASP Amrendra Singh said that they had received a complaint from MLA Akash Vijayvargiya stating that he got an extortion call from an SP in Indore. On the complaint of MLA’s employee Ram Singh, Pardeshipura police registered a case of fraud.

After tracing the number, a raid was conducted in Falna of Rajasthan and accused Suresh alias Bheriya Ghanchi, a resident of Rajat Nagar was arrested.

During sustained questioning, Suresh told police that he researched about the senior police officials serving in Indore. He then saved his number as CSP Indore on an app and made a call to the MLA while asking him to send Rs 10 lakh to the SP for some personal work.

Police said that the man was good at mimicking voices and used to extort money from famous people. The accused had only studied till Class VIII but is well-versed in internet and smartphones. He has also been jailed several times.

The police said that he claimed he had stopped living with his family long time ago and operated alone .

He asked the victims to send money to him in rented bank accounts through RTGS, online transfers and wallets, withdrew the cash and then closed them. Interestingly, the accused is known in Rajasthan by the name -- Mr Natwar Lal. He had committed crimes in Madhya Pradesh, Rajasthan, Uttar Pradesh, Gujarat and other states. Over 36 cases were registered against him in Rajasthan.

He said that he used to break the smartphone and SIM card after every crime to avoid being arrested. TOI tried to contact the MLA but he was not available for the comment.

Title: Cold wave persists in state, few places receive rainfall
Content:
This story is from January 15, 2020

Jaipur: Cold wave persisted in parts of Rajasthan with Mount Abu recording a minimum temperature of 0°C, a meteorological official said on Tuesday.

Sriganganagar, Bikaner and Jaisalmer and several other places recorded rainfall in the past 24 hours.

Foggy conditions was also witnessed in several places, the official said.

Sriganganagar recorded 4.9°C followed by 5°C in Pilani, 6°C in Jaisalmer, 6.5°C in Ajmer, 8.2°C in Alwar and 8.7°Ci n Banasthali. Jaipur recorded minimum temperature of 10.4°C on Monday night. On Tuesday, city witnessed bright sunlight. PTI

Title: Kerala: Munambam boat people still a mystery
Content:
This story is from January 15, 2020

File photo of Sahayamatha, the fishing vessel seized in connection with the Munambam human trafficking case

KOCHI: The Munambam illegal migration case, in which around 243 people, including newborns and pregnant women, illegally left the Indian coast on a fishing boat via Maliyankara boat jetty near Munambam harbour, turned one on January 12. But it still remains a mystery whether they have made it to the unknown destination as planned or perished in the deep blue waters.

The police team probing the case has confirmed that the investigation has hit a dead end with no clues about the whereabouts of the missing people, boat and the kingpins behind the voyage , who too were suspected to have left in the same boat.

However, sources from the department said they are hopeful of getting new links in the case as a team from Ernakulam Rural police is gearing up to go to Australia , one of the suspected destinations of their voyage, at the invite of the Australian government to coordinate the investigation. The department is awaiting central government’s clearance for the trip.

It was in the early hours of 12 January 2018, about 243 people, mostly Sri Lankan Tamils from Delhi’s Madangir colony, had left Munambam coast on a fishing boat ‘Dhaya Matha-2’. The incident came into light by noon on the same day when the residents in the area spotted 12 bags containing clothes, packed dry foods and medicines in an abandoned state in a vacant compound near the jetty.

At first many, including the police, assumed that the bags were abandoned by tourists but the gravity of the issue heightened when more similar bags were found abandoned at various places in Cherai and Kodungalloor later.

Initial investigation had later revealed that it was a well-coordinated operation to smuggle out people to foreign countries, mostly Australia, New Zealand and Christmas Islands, which are safe havens for illegal migrants who leave their country chasing their dreams of better fortunes.

Additional superintendent of police (Ernakulam Rural) M J Sojan, lead investigation officer, said, “Our probe found out that it was a pre-planned illegal immigration where the migrants willingly paid up to Rs 3 lakh per head for the voyage. We don’t know where they were headed to or whether they reached anywhere at all. We arrested 10 people in connection with the case but have not been able to trace one Sreekanthan and Selvan who were the kingpins. All others were just organizers who had their share of money for bringing in migrants. They had no idea about where Sreekanthan was taking the people to,” he said.

The ministry of external affairs has alerted all countries where the immigrants could have possibly gone to. The Interpol also has issued a Blue-Corner notice with names, photographs of the missing people, but all in vain as no leads were found till date.

“We have not closed the investigation, but we have not filed the chargesheet as we could not find any main accused or victims. The Australian Federal Police are in constant communication with the state police. With a team going to Australia, there is a chance to pick up some new leads in the case as Australia was suspected to be one of their destinations,” said district police chief (Ernakulam Rural) K Karthick.

Title: India-US in talks to lock Trump visit dates
Content:
This story is from January 15, 2020

NEW DELHI: India and the US remain in touch to finalise mutually convenient dates for a visit by Donald Trump , according to official sources here. Indian officials, though, refused to hazard a guess as to when the visit would take place, even as reports from Washington said Trump’s trip, which will be his first to India as president, could happen in the last week of February.

Trump’s impeachment trial which is set to begin this week doesn’t come in the way of the dates in February end both sides are said to be discussing. February 24 is said to be one of the dates the two sides are considering for Trump’s arrival in India. tnn

Trump had turned down India’s invite to attend the Republic Day parade as chief guest in 2019 because of, as the White House put it, scheduling constraints. The two sides though had continued to discuss the possibility of a visit by Trump in their diplomatic engagements.

The US President had last year said that PM Narendra Modi wanted him to visit India and that he himself was keen on travelling to India.

In a phone conversation with Trump last week, Modi had stated that India-US relations, built on trust, mutual respect and understanding, had grown from strength to strength. Modi also highlighted the “significant progress’’ made in deepening the strategic partnership between the two countries in the previous year and expressed his desire to continue to work with Trump for enhancing cooperation in all areas of mutual interest.

Trump too had expressed satisfaction at the achievements in the relationship in last few years and reiterated his readiness for further deepening bilateral cooperation. An official said though the conversation didn’t dwell much on the proposed visit. Modi though had reiterated the invite to Trump when he met him on the sidelines of UNGA in September.

Title: Continue with Amaravati, as capital: Sujana to CM
Content:
This story is from January 15, 2020

Vijayawada: Former Union minister and BJP leader Y S Chowdary or Sujana Chowdary on Tuesday requested chief minister Y S Jaganmohan Reddy to continue Amaravati as capital. Stating that Amaravati is a “sovereign commitment”, he cautioned the chief minister against disrespecting it.

The former Union minister wrote a letter to the chief minister explaining how the previous government had selected Amaravati as capital and how 33,000 acres of land was taken from the farmers for the capital after the bifurcation. He said the commitments made to the farmers were sovereign and it is binding on the successive government to honour them.

Chowdary recalled that the TDP, BJP and YSRC had agreed to Amaravati as capital. The location was also cleared by the central government and it was agreed upon to develop it as a green-field city, he said.

He further recalled that the central government had paid Rs 1,500 crore, while the state government had mobilised Rs 2,000 crore through bonds. The state government also received donations from people to the tune of Rs 42 crore. The previous government had initiated 62 projects in Amaravati, while land allocations were made to 130 central government institutions and private organisations, he listed down.

Chowdary said the legislature, executive and judiciary were all functioning from Amaravati, besides the Raj Bhavan. There was no need for the present government to spend any money on the capital, he said and added that the capital could continue in these institutions like it did in the past seven months.

He further said the government would have 8,442.75 acres of land in hand out of the 33,000 acres that could be sold to get Rs 1.26 lakh crore at Rs 15 crore per acre.

“Farmers, entrepreneurs and contractors are stakeholders in the Amaravati project. Governments are permanent unlike people. If any attempt is made to shift the capital from Amaravati, the stakeholders may be forced to seek compensation, which might be a financial burden on the government,” the former Union minister said.

Title: Class X student blackmailed, gang-raped by 4; one accused held
Content:
This story is from January 15, 2020

Bareilly: A Class X girl was blackmailed by her friend into coming to a hotel room, where the youth along with his three friends allegedly overpowered and gang-raped the 17-year-old girl in Moradabad’s Katghar area. Local police on Tuesday arrested one of the accused while the hunt to nab the remaining three was on.

In his complaint lodged with police on Monday, the father of the girl said that the accused had filmed a video of his daughter and was threatening to upload it on social media platforms if she didn’t fulfil his “desires”.

The complainant said that on January 10, when the girl went to attend coaching classes after the school, the accused waylaid and took her to a hotel room. “He threatened that if she didn’t accompany her, he would upload the video,” the complainant said.

Over there, she was gang-raped by the four accused.

When the girl didn’t return after the coaching classes were over, her family members reached there. But they were told that the girl didn’t attend the class that day. Later, during their search, someone told the family members that the girl was seen at a hotel in Peer Ka Bazar area.

When they reached there, the girl narrated the whole incident. On the basis of complaint filed by rape survivor’s father, police have lodged FIR against the four accused. One of the accused was arrested on Tuesday.

The inspector (crime) of Thakurdwara, Tejveer Singh, said that they have started investigation after lodging FIR under sections 376 (rape), 354 (assault or criminal force to woman with intent to outrage her modesty), 342 (punishment for wrongful confinement), 507 (criminal intimidation by an anonymous communication) and POCSO Act.

“Today, we got initial success after nabbing one of the accused. He has been sent to jail by a court. We are conducting raids to nab others,” the inspector said.

Title: Delay over Mahadayi notification may adversely impact BJP in North Karnataka
Content:
This story is from January 15, 2020

Representative image

BELAGAVI: Mahadayi issue is likely to prove costly for the BJP in the long run as people in North Karnataka are none too pleased over the delay in issuing the gazette notification by the Centre on sharing the river water. Seers of important mutts in the region have taken up the matter seriously and any further delay in resolving the river row could negatively affect the party’s vote bank in the region dominated by Lingayats.

A few days ago, about 20 religious heads of various mutts gathered in Belagavi and passed a resolution. As per the resolution they sent a letter to Prime Minister Narendra Modi seeking mediation between Karnataka and Goa. The meeting was spearheaded by Siddarama Swami, pontiff of Tontadarya Mutt in Gadag.

Venkatesh Patil Vatgal, former JD(S) leader and a political analyst from North Karnataka region said if the issue remains unresolved for limited political gain of some leaders in the BJP, it will boomerang. “Some leaders in BJP do not want BS Yediyurappa claim credit for launching the project. Hence they are buying time for change of guard. People are now realising this conspiracy and if anything unceremonious happens to Yediyurappa, the Lingayat community will shift loyalty.”

He further said that the Gadag mutt has its influence not just on Lingayats but the masses.

People in the region are venting their ire against elected representatives from BJP for not applying pressure on the Centre to issue the gazette notification. Ashok Chandaragi, a pro-Kannada activist said if the BJP is not sincere enough on addressing water woes of the parched districts of North Karnataka, the the potential to become a turning point in Karnataka politics. There are no elections now, but it is clear that aversion towards the BJP is slowly building up and Congress may capitalise on it, he said. “PM Marendra Modi and home minister Amit Shah appear to have no idea about the ground realities of the state,” he added.

For districts in North Karnataka — Dharwad , Belagavi, Bagalkot and Gadag will benefit from the Kalasa-Banduri project.

Title: Let’s debate CAA, Jha throws challenge at Rahul Gandhi
Content:
This story is from January 15, 2020

Khargone: Throwing an open challenge at Congress leader Rahul Gandhi over a debate on Citizenship Amendment Act (CAA), BJP vice-president Prabhat Jha on Tuesday said that if public supports Rahul even after the debate, he will quit politics but if people support him (Jha), Gandhi should leave politics. He was addressing a seminar organised for CAA at town hall of Khargone on Tuesday.

He said that Congress has been involved in creating confusion over CAA. "It is unfortunate to do vote bank politics by spreading confusion in the country but BJP has won the hearts of people by clarifying confusions," he said.

He said that cases are being registered against BJP activists for organizing rallies in support of CAA but BJP is not afraid of it. Indira Gandhi also tried to suppress activists by sending them to jail. Ones who are afraid of lawsuits cannot stay in politics, he added.

Jha said that Congress had first resolved to pass the law in Parliament on November 25, 1947. Next, when Vajpayee government was at Centre, former Prime Minister Dr Manmohan Singh, being Leader of Opposition in Parliament also supported the demand on December 18, 2003. He alleged that Nehru was responsible for division of India on basis of religion and as Nehru-Liyaqat pact was not followed, CAA became mandatory to save minorities of Pakistan.

He said that due to atrocities in Pakistan, minorities have reduced significantly. This law is made to give citizenship, not to take it away from anyone. He also termed removal of triple talaq, Section 370 and passing of SPG bill as important steps.

Title: Gold worth Rs 2 cr hidden inside sprockets seized
Content:
This story is from January 15, 2020

Mangaluru: Sleuths of Directorate of Revenue Intelligence have affected one of the biggest gold seizures in recent times in this coastal city.

Based on a tip-off, DRI officials from Bengaluru and Mangaluru in a coordinate effort seized 5 kg of gold valued at Rs 2 crore at the air cargo complex here on Monday. A unique method of smuggling gold through the air cargo complex at the old airport in Bajpe was unravelled.

The smuggled gold was concealed in five metal sprockets which were imported by M/s Swaroop Mineral Pvt Ltd of Udupi. The gold was deftly concealed inside the heavy metal sprockets by way of a groove and gave only the slightest hint of being tampered with on physical examination. Officers retrieved the gold with the help of a local mechanic and a lathe machine.

On examination by an authorized jeweller, the gold pieces were found to be of 24-Karat purity and their current market value was estimated to be around Rs 2 crore. The DRI officers later seized the contraband gold under the provisions of the Customs Act, 1962, Shreyas K M, deputy director, DRI stated.

The active director of M/s Swaroop Mineral Resources Manohar Kumar Poojari involved in the case was arrested in Bengaluru on the same day in a co-ordinated effort by DRI Bengaluru.

DRI Mangaluru officials nabbed Lohith Shriyan, a person hailing from Ashoknagar, looking after the logistics of smuggling. Further investigation in the case is in progress to unearth other members of the syndicate and investors in the case, Shreyas said.

Title: BMC razes illegal shops in Jehangirabad, Gandhi Nagar
Content:
This story is from January 15, 2020

BMC’s anti-encroachment squad demolished 12 illegal shops in Jehangirabad on Tuesday.

BHOPAL: The anti-encroachment squad of the Bhopal Municipal Corporation (BMC) — under the district administration’s supervision — razed several shops in Jehangirabad and Gandhi Nagar areas on Tuesday. The demolition squad also razed an illegal house built in an area of 4,000 to 5,000sqft on Jinsi Road in Jehangirabad. The structure was a stronghold of criminal James Michael, who is wanted in a murder case and is absconding.

Sub-divisional magistrate (city), Jameel Khan, who led the demolition squad at Jeharingabad , told TOI that 12 shops and a vast house built on an area of 4,000 to 5,000 sq feet -- without requisite permissions -- was razed by the BMC's anti-encroachment team. He said the house was under the control of history sheeter, James Michael, who allegedly killed his uncle in a dispute over control of the house and is currently absconding. Khan said that nobody lived in the house. The demolition squad spared the second house in which members of Michael’s family live.

Another team led by sub-divisional magistrate (Bairagarh), razed 18 shops built on a government land in Gandhi Nagar area. The shops were under the control of Raju Meena, who is said to have strongpolitical connections.

Meanwhile, divisional commissioner, Bhopal, Kalpana Shrivastava, told the media on Monday that a 150-acre plot, worth over Rs 110 crore, has been freed from encroachment in Bhopal division. Under the current drive against land mafia, several illegal buildings and shops have been demolished.

Shrivastava said that the district collectors have been specifically been asked to ensure that only criminals and mafia involved in land-grabbing and illegal construction are acted upon under the drive and common people are not affected.

Title: Madhya Pradesh: Medical equipment in govt hospitals needs urgent upkeep
Content:
This story is from January 15, 2020

Representative image

BHOPAL: Less than half of the 66,000 medical equipment in health centres or hospitals run by the state government are not under annual maintenance. It's no surprise then that 15,000 complaints of equipment malfunction was reported in the last year, according to state government data. Some 44 lakh people depend on health department-run hospitals for free treatment each year in Madhya Pradesh .

Believe it or not, on paper, the oldest ECG machine, being used in a government-run hospital dates back to 1974. It is in used in a ward in the district hospital in Sehore. Of the 40 oxygen concentrators, date of purchase of only 14 machines is known. The device, mostly used in special newborn care units, concentrates the oxygen from a gas supply (typically ambient air) by selectively removing nitrogen to supply an oxygen-rich gas stream.

Madhya Pradesh is the first state to map all medical equipment with a unique barcode . Annual maintenance contract makes it incumbent to have a problem fixed within a week. Also, non-reporting of equipment malfunction leads to action against the hospital incharge. Complaint can be made through a toll-free number, mobile application or system generated log.

However, some of the equipment like mercury-based blood pressure instrument have been not covered under annual maintenance contract. Health department officials said that digital BP meters are being introduced as per directives of the NGT.

For instance, in Bhopal division, of the 1,630 medical equipment accounted for, expiry date or end of annual maintenance of 1,052 equipment is listed as ‘not available’. Sources said in many cases there are no log books or other references to cross-check the manufacture or purchase of these equipment. 790 of these equipment were purchased between 2010 and 2013.

As many as 199 equipment were purchased between year 2000 and 2009. The oldest purchase dates back to 1981 -- one being Mass Miniature Radiography (MMR) in radiology department and two shadowless lamps. All three are in the Sehore hospital. Supply date of one X-ray machine in the same hospital is also 1981.

Bhopal division includes Hoshangabad, VIdisha, Betul, Raisen, Sehore, Bhopal, Harda and Rajgarh. “Some of old equipment are still in use,” said CMHO Sehore district, Dr Padmakar Triwari

Title: Thiruvabharanam procession: Panchayat stops meat sale, sparks row
Content:
This story is from January 15, 2020

Thiruvananthapuram: A notice issued by Vadasserikkara panchayat secretary — directing meat merchants in Pathanamthitta not to conduct sales on the day the Thiruvabharanam procession (carrying casket of ornaments for special Makaravilakku pooja) passes through the panchayat — has triggered a row.

The secretary issued a notice on January 6 directing fish, meat and chicken shops to stop sales for two days (January 13 and 14) citing the Thiruvabharanam procession in the panchayat on Tuesday. The notice, which was widely circulated on social media, sparked a heated debate on how it affects the ‘secular ideals’ and the ‘freedom to earn a livelihood’.

With the notice snowballing into a controversy, the panchayat committee said that such a decision was never taken.

“Every year, during Sabarimala pilgrimage, certain routine measures are taken by the panchayat. This is kept in a file. When I enquired about the notice, I was told that it was kept in the file and hence issued. The panchayat committee has never taken such a decision,” said panchayat president Swapna Susan Jacob.

She added that there was a previous instance in which an Ayyappa devotee, who took a bath in the river, reported of it being tainted with poultry waste. Panchayat had then conducted an informal discussion with merchants to reduce generation of waste, she added.

Panchayat secretary Jyothi S said the notice was meant to prevent waste generation. “It is a normal practice. We had cleaned up the path for procession and still poultry waste was dumped yesterday. The notice is being misinterpreted. We have a facility for collection of poultry and meat waste, but some of the merchants don’t cooperate and that’s why the notice was issued as a precaution to avoid dumping of waste along the path of procession as it could lead to other issues,” she said.

However, merchants said the notice was being issued for the first time. “The procession passes along 3.5km in this panchayat. We have around 14 meat and fish shops. More than the sale, the notice derails the secular system we have here. What if they try to halt sales for one week next year? This is unacceptable,” said president of Vyapari Vyavasayi Ekopana Samiti KM Chacko.

The procession, which began at Pandalam on Monday, passed through Vadaserikara on Tuesday.

Deputy director of Pathanamthitta’s panchayat directorate Saima S said that the issuance of notice was quite normal. “This time, some people are causing unnecessary trouble to flare up communal sentiments. The secretary only wanted to ensure that the path was clean during a religious event. That’s a peaceful and proper way for conducting religious events,” she said.

Title: State youth commission holds first trans adalat
Content:
This story is from January 15, 2020

Thiruvananthapuram: With an aim to resolve the social issues faced by transgender community, the Kerala State youth commission organized a special trans adalat. As many as 56 complaints were examined by the state-level adalat chaired by youth commission chairperson Chintha Jerome here on Tuesday.

Commission secretary T K Jayasree, assistant Manoj C D and commission member V Vinil also chaired the adalat held at the conference hall of Government Guest House in Thycaud.

Major suggestion at the adalat was about opening transgender care home in all districts. Transgender care home is a short stay home for three months that provides facilities like food, counselling, medical treatments and legal assistances for the community members. “The extension of the stay period from three months was another proposal. Some of them have also complained against mentioning them as third gender in voter’s identity card. They demanded that it should be corrected as transgender person. We have note down the suggestions and complaints. Various complaints have been forwarded to departments concerned to find an immediate solution” said Jerome adding that adalat has been scheduled for another day to give report and solution to the transgenders’ complaints regarding the violence they face.

Laya Maria Jaison from Changanassery said gender recognition is their primary need. “Though Supreme Court has accepted, declared basic fundamental rights and gave us right to self – identification of our gender, we are referred to as third gender in our voter’s identity which itself is a discrimination. It should be corrected as transgender. Another suggestion is that Transgender Cell should coordinate with community based organizations across the state to conduct an accurate survey and based on that just like any other minority community; reservations should be implemented for transgenders which would ensure job opportunities”, said Jaison.

“There should be opportunity for trans students to participate in arts and sports competitions in our own category. At present we have to select either male or female category. Another complaint is, police forces aren’t taking our complaints seriously. It’s been five months since the mysterious death of transgender person Shalu from Kozhikode, police haven’t taken any interest in the case”, said Nadira Mehrin, a student of University College.

Title: Twin murder case: Rajasthan Cops wait for FSL fingerprint report
Content:
This story is from January 15, 2020

Accused Saurabh Chaudhary and Rohit Tiwari’s remand ends today

JAIPUR: The two accused in the murder of the mother-son duo in Pratap Nagar will be produced before the court on Wednesday as their remand was till January 15. While cops are now unveiling more details in the brutal murders, the FSL is yet to give a report on the fingerprints that were found on the weapon used for the two murders.

A 35-year-old woman and her 21-month-old son were murdered by a contract killer hired by her husband last week. The two accused — the woman’s husband Rohit Tiwari and Saurabh Chaudhary, who was hired by Rohit to kill his wife and son — were arrested on January 10. The body of Shweta Tiwari was found at her flat on January 7 while her son’s body was found the next day. Both of them had been murdered within minutes of each other.

DCP East Rahul Jain, who is spearheading the investigations said, “We have enough evidence against the accused and are now in the process of strengthening the case against them. The FSL report is yet to come in, but we are confident that the fingerprints on the murder weapon would match Saurabh’s.”

Police have also ruled out the possibility that Saurabh killed Shweta and her son due to some personal issue. “Rohit was the contact point for Saurabh and there is no evidence to suggest that he executed the crime for any reason other than the fact that the accused husband asked him to.”

Rohit had given Saurabh an advance of Rs 20,000 and at the time of murders he had only Rs 43,000 in his bank. Cops had previously also claimed that more than money, the motivation behind the two accused conspiring was to get rid of each other’s wives though part of their plan was foiled after they were arrested. They could not execute the second part of the plan which involved Rohit killing Saurabh’s wife, said police.

Shweta’s family since the beginning had been accusing Rohit of planning the murders and her brother Shubham Mishra said, “Rohit had been physically abusing my sister for very long and even his family did not intervene. In fact even after my sister and nephew were killed, Rohit’s family did not get in touch with us.”

Title: Uttar Pradesh: Army man’s son shoots himself dead while making TikTok video
Content:
This story is from January 15, 2020

Representative image

BAREILLY: In a bizarre incident, a class XII student, who was trying to make a TikTok video using his parent’s licensed revolver, shot himself accidentally when it went off in Hafiz Ganj area of Bareilly on Monday.

The incident occurred in Mudia Bhaikampur village of Nawabganj in the district, Nawabganj circle officer Yogendra Kumar said.

According to him, Keshav, 18-year-old son of Army man Virendra Kumar, had pressured his mother Gayitri to give him the revolver for making the TikTok video.

Keshav was preparing for national eligibility-cum-entrance test (NEET) and was fond of sharing his videos on TikTok. He had even earlier shared his pictures with a revolver on social media.

His father who is posted in Roorkee and was to retire this month-end, refused to hand over his son’s body for a post-mortem.

Suresh Pal Singh, Hafizganj station house officer, told TOI, “The family told us that Keshav took the licenced revolver from his mother for making a TikTok video and went inside his room. Sometime later, the mother heard the noise of a gunshot and rushed towards Keshav’s room. She found him writhing in pain with blood all over his body. He was rushed to a private hospital where the doctor declared him brought dead. The family refused to send the body for autopsy and gave us in writing that they don’t require police. There was no suicide note with the body and the family members told us that their son shot himself accidentally while recording a video. The body has been cremated by the family without autopsy.”

SSP Shailesh Pandey said, “I have asked the SHO to seize the revolver and take further steps for the cancellation of firearm’s license for showing negligence in keeping the weapon.”

Title: Dacoits rob SI’s family by holding six-year-old daughter at gunpoint
Content:
This story is from January 15, 2020

SI Pushkar Singh Gangwar is the SHO of Amariya police station in Pilibhit district. His wife Ruchi lives in th... Read More

Bareilly: A group of six armed robbers forcefully entered the house of a police sub-inspector (SI) in Shashtri Nagar locality in Premnagar area of Bareilly city on Tuesday evening, and looted the family by taking the SI’s six-year-old daughter hostage at gunpoint.

SSP Shailesh Pandey and SP (crime) R K Bhartiya rushed to the spot after receiving information, along with the anti-dacoity team and forensic experts.

SI Pushkar Singh Gangwar is the SHO of Amariya police station in Pilibhit district. His wife Ruchi lives in their house in Bareilly. According to Ruchi, at 6.30pm, six people knocked on her door, and when she opened it, they introduced themselves as crime branch officials, before forcefully entering the house and taking hostage all occupants, including tenant Prem Shankar Sharma, at gunpoint. Then they forced Ruchi to hand over all the cash and jewelry at home, by threatening to shoot her six-year-old daughter Ananya.

After grabbing all valuables from the house, the robbers snatched the DVR of the CCTV cameras at the house and threw Ruchi’s mobile phone into water. They then locked everyone in a room and fled.

SP (crime) Bhartiya told TOI, “We’re investigating the case on priority. All nearby police stations have been alerted and patrolling intensified. We’re checking every suspect. The accused appears to have done a reconnaissance of the house before committing the robbery, as they appeared to know the inside of the house very well. Fortunately, no one was hurt.”

Title: Postal cover released to mark Paryaya 2020
Content:
This story is from January 15, 2020

Udupi: To commemorate Paryaya 2020, the postal department has issued a special postal cover on Adamaru seers , Vishwapriya Teertha Swami (senior seer) and his junior seer of paryaya peetha, Ishapriya Teertha Swami, who will ascend the paryaya peetha on Saturday.

The postal cover, which was released on Pura Pravesha, includes images of both the seers of Adamaru Mutt.

Postal superintendent of Udupi postal division, Sudhakar Devadiga, said, “Sri Krishna Mutt, Ashta Mutt, and the Indian postal department share a good relation. Indian postal department has been releasing these special envelopes to mark the historical event of paryaya, which happens every alternative year. However this year, it’s more special because we are celebrating the 250th paryaya, and the postal department wants to participate in the celebration by issuing the envelope. It has the chariot of Krishna Mutt, both the seers, and the logo of Adamaru Paryaya”.

“Such envelopes are printed only in fixed numbers, and once it runs out of stock, reprinting the same is not possible. Due to the shortage, its values increases. Currently, it is available for Rs 5, and special cancellation envelope costs Rs 20. Similarly, the postal department has launched ‘My Stamp’, so that the public can get stamps with their own and loved ones picture on it. The fee for the same is Rs 300,” he said.

Title: Rajnath credits veterans for unity & integrity of country
Content:
This story is from January 15, 2020

Jaipur: Defence minister Rajnath Singh and Chief of Defence Staff General Bipin Rawat were in the city on Tuesday to participate in the Veterans Day celebration. Singh addressed a gathering of veterans in the cantonment area and acknowledged their contribution.

This was Rawat’s first visit after his appointment as the CDS. Singh hailed the ex-servicemen by crediting them for maintaining the unity and integrity of the country.

Speaking at an event here on the fourth Armed Forces Veterans Day, Singh said, “If India is safe today, not only the borders but the unity of the country is intact, the credit goes to brave people like you, the jawans of the Armed Forces."

He stressed that the country understands - once a soldier, always a soldier.

Singh said that he was pleased in his role as the defence minister. He also pointed out that while discussions regarding the creation of Chief of Defence Staff had been going on for the past 20-21 years, it is the NDA government that cleared it. “Discussions had been going on for over 20 years that there should be a Chief of Defence Staff. But as soon as I became the defence minister, I discussed this with the Prime Minister Narendra Modi. He didn't wait for even a moment and said OK to it,” he said.

He said it was a veteran who had suggested him to take the step to create the CDS.

He said welfare of the veterans was a top priority for the Union government and initiatives were being taken to enhance the facilities given to them. “We have a created a department of military affairs which would look into the welfare of the defence personnel.”

Title: First swine flu case of 2020 reported in Jaipur, health department on alert
Content:
This story is from January 15, 2020

Woman from Malviya Nagar tests positive for swine flu

JAIPUR: The health department is on alert after the first case of swine flu this year was reported from Malviya Nagar area on January 7. Officials, however, claimed that since then no more cases of the disease had been reported from the city. Officials said a 35-year-old woman, resident of Malviya Nagar, tested positive for the disease.

“We have conducted a survey of the area and no more such cases were detected. We found that she had travelled to Mumbai and returned to Jaipur recently,” said Dr Hansraj Bhadaliya, chief medical health officer (Jaipur -II).

The woman has since then recovered.

The health department has conducted 359 swine flu checks but all tested negative for the disease except one. “We have alerted doctors and recommended swine flu test on those who are suspected to be suffering from the diseases,” said a health official.

Moreover, the department claimed that they have procured 15 lakh Tamiflu tablets, which are useful in treatment of swine flu.

According to the health department report, the state reported 5,092 cases of swine flu and 208 people had died of the disease in 2019. In 2018, there were 2,419 persons diagnosed with the disease and 225 had died.

Title: 10 Rajasthan railway stations under advanced video surveillance system
Content:
This story is from January 15, 2020

The video surveillance system will be extended to other stations and coaches soon

AJMER: RailTel, a PSU under ministry of railways, has installed advanced video surveillance system at 10 railway stations of North Western Railway in Rajasthan . This high-resolution surveillance system is aimed to ensure safety of people on platforms, parking slots and even in coaches of trains.

The stations where the advanced video surveillance system has been installed include Gandhinagar Jaipur railway station, Alwar , Falna, Marwar junction, Phulera, Rewari, Abu Road, Pali, Bhilwara and Suratgarh junction. This work has been completed under Nirbhaya fund. The surveillance includes railway stations, premium and EMU coaches of premium trains and suburban EMU coaches.

Chairman and managing director of RailTel Puneet Chawla said that they have completed work at 125 stations across India. The video surveillance system will be extended to other stations and coaches soon. The work is being done mostly for safety of women. It will have better coverage and clearer images with four types of full HD cameras in which there will be bullet-type coverage for indoor areas, for platforms it will be tilt zoom type and for parking area, there will be ultra HD cameras. All CCTV cameras will be networked on optical fibre cable and the video feed of the CCTV cameras will be brought to a centralized CCTV control room, from where the feed will be monitored by RPF personnels.

He added that the video feed from CCTV cameras will be stored for 30 days for playback, post-event analysis and investigation purposes. Important videos will be stored for longer duration. The video surveillance system is expected to ensure better security for the passengers at railway station property also.

Title: IIT-Hyderabad adds light and heat to meds to kill cancer cells in novel way
Content:
This story is from January 15, 2020

Representative image

HYDERABAD: Researchers from the Indian Institute of Technology, Hyderabad (IIT-H), have found that adding light and heat to anti-cancer chemicals helps in treating cancers more efficiently. At present, cancer patients are treated with chemotherapy in which powerful chemicals are used to kill cancer cells.

The IIT team found that adding light and heat, or photothermal therapy to chemotherapy helps in killing malignant cells, providing relief to patients. Called a combination therapy, the IIT-H cancer treatment model involves photo (light) and heat (thermal), apart from the usual chemicals (chemotherapy).

This gives much-needed synergetic impact to anti-cancer treatment currently followed worldwide. Moreover, the chemical used in chemotherapy by the IIT team is derived from natural sources, and thus, has little negative impact.

The IIT-H team collaborated with counterparts at IIT Bombay and Bose Institute, Kolkata, in developing the new treatment regimen. During research, the team found that a synergetic combination of photothermal therapy and chemotherapy had shown efficacy in fighting cancer cells. The result of the research was published in the recent issue of the science journal, ‘Nanoscale’.

“Combination therapy, which combines more than one therapeutic procedure, is being increasingly considered for treatment of cancer because it can deal with the heterogeneity (different varieties) of cancer cells in addition to providing synergic therapeutic effects,” said Dr R Aravind Kumar, assistant professor in the department of biomedical engineering, IIT-H.

The team comprised A Tejaswini, P Deepak Bharadwaj, Rafiq Ahmad Khan, Syed Baseeruddin Alvi, Rohit Srivastava, Mahadeb Pal, and Nooruddin Khan, apart from Aravind Kumar.

While chemotherapy involves use of chemicals, in photothermal therapy material that converts light to heat is directed to the tumour. It destroys cancer cells. The team used an iodide dye (IR780) to kill the malignant cells.

Stating that development of effective therapies specific to cancer tissues without damaging the surrounding healthy cells remains the ultimate challenge in the battle against cancer, the IIT team said that the present methods of cancer treatment such as surgery, chemotherapy and radiotherapy badly affect healthy tissues too. “The combined photothermal and chemotherapy holds significant promise for enhanced therapeutic benefits with minimal or no side effects on cancer patients,” the researchers stated.

Title: Vasundhara Raje reason for BJP defeat, says Hanuman Beniwal
Content:
This story is from January 15, 2020

AJMER: Rashtriya Loktantrik Party (RLP) MP from Nagaur Haunuman Beniwal on Tuesday said that if BJP had replaced former chief minister Vasundhara Raje before assembly elections, the Congress would not have come to power. RLP was keen to have an alliance with the BJP. However, the BJP lost the election as Raje was Saffron party’s face.

While speaking to media after the inauguration of students’ union office at Government Girls College here, Beniwal said Sachin Pilot also wanted to become the CM, however, he was left out.

This led to power struggle between chief minister Ashok Gehlot and his deputy Pilot.

Speaking on Congress rule in state, Beniwal said youths, farmers are facing problems and many are committing suicide due to unemployment. I will take up the issues after the panchayat polls and will take out a yatra from Jodhpur to Ajmer, he said.

Title: BJP state secretary’s health stable, likely to be discharged soon
Content:
This story is from January 15, 2020

Kottayam: The health condition of BJP state secretary A K Nazeer continues to be stable and is likely to be discharged on Wednesday, said hospital authorities.

Nazeer was admitted in Amrita Institute of Medical Sciences (AIMS) in Kochi after being attacked allegedly by SDPI activists in the compound of a mosque in Nedumkandom in Idukki district around 7pm on Sunday.

Meanwhile, cops have registered a case against five people whom the victim could identify. The move is based on the statement of Nazeer. However, he has not mentioned the names of the five people in the statement.

According to police, a case has been charged for attempt to murder, unlawful assembly, rioting, and causing hurt voluntarily using dangerous weapons. The Nedumkandom police station circle inspector has launched a probe.

Correction: The headline of a related report published on January 14 inadvertently said five persons were arrested in the case. Police had charged five persons, but were not arrested.

Title: Madhya Pradesh: Honeytrap accused Aarti Dayal’s turn for grilling
Content:
This story is from January 15, 2020

Aarti Dayal, accused in the honeytrap case, was brought to Bhopal and questioned by income-tax officials on Tu... Read More

BHOPAL: Aarti Dayal, accused in the honeytrap case, was brought to Bhopal and questioned by income-tax officials on Tuesday, a day after another suspect, Shweta Vijay Jain, went through the similar interrogation.

I-T officials grilled Aarti for nearly 7 hours, longer than Shweta’s questioning. Police brought Aarti to the IT office around 11am and took her to the first floor of the investigations wing where she was interrogated till around 6pm, said sources.

Officials are trying to track the money trail and identify the source of the cash and valuables seized from the honeytrap accused . Once statements of all the suspects are recorded, those who had allegedly paid them off after being trapped in the sex-and-blackmail racket will be summoned, say sources.

Aarti is accused of assisting Shweta in running the racket with the help of other accused named in the chargesheet — Shweta Swapnil Jain, 35, Barkha Soni, 35, Om Prakash, 45, and Rupa Ahirwar and Abhishek Thakur. I-T officials have summoned Shweta Swapnil Jain for questioning.

“Officials who paid them off will also be summoned once their names come on record,” said an officer.

Police have concluded that all the accused “worked as an organized group to extort people”. They recruited women of poor backgrounds and used them to film obscene videos of wealthy, white-collar persons, say investigators. The racketeers then used these videos to manage postings and transfers and extort money from those caught in their trap, the chargesheet says.

The ring was busted after the now suspended IMC executive engineer Harbhajan Singh went to police, accusing Aarti and Monica of trying to extort Rs 2 crore from him using objectionable videos. The duo was arrested in Indore on September 17, and the others a day later from Bhopal. Rupa and Abhishek are on the run.

Title: As social media takes over, matinee idols lose print space
Content:
This story is from January 15, 2020

Biographies of film icons MGR and Sivaji Ganesan besides popular stars, including Rajinikanth and Kamal Haasan... Read More

CHENNAI: Top Tamil movie stars may add huge value to the big screens, but they no more matter for publishing houses. Growth of social media has taken a heavy toll on books on Kollywood stars with readers ignoring the genre, which used to be the most sought after till a decade ago. Biographies of movie icons MGR and Sivaji Ganesan besides popular stars, including Rajinikanth and Kamal Haasan that have their portraits, do not have many takers. At the same time, a new generation of youngsters are looking for titles on technical aspects of film making such as acting, editing and screenplay.

V Mathiselvan, a publisher at the Chennai Book Fair , said advent of social media and YouTube channels have had an adverse impact on books about Kollywood. “Ten years ago, at least 30 out of 100 visitors will look for such books in our stall during the annual book fair. Of late, hardly two enquire about books on Tamil movies,” he said. Curious readers seeking information on Tamil cinema get all of it online. “Readers feel books do not offer any new information over and above what they get online, on WhatsApp and on YouTube. This is the major reason for the dip in readership,” he added. There is also a big shift in readership with the new generation preferring technical subjects in film production. With multiple movie streaming platforms opening up space for global cinema, publishers said it has changed the perspective on film viewing. K Kishore Kanna, a film student specialising in direction, said youths focusing on film career explore books of translated international authors. “Youngsters look for specific titles to enhance their skills in cinematography,” he said.

The book fair also had a couple of novels that were converted into screenplays for recent movies. One such novel had a portrait of actor Dhanush on its cover from a blockbuster flick in 2019. Some titles on biographies of actors were also available in English.

Meanwhile, a section of writers gave a representation to the fair’s organisers -– Booksellers and Publishers’ Association of South India (BAPASI) – at YMCA, Nandanam, protesting the eviction of a publisher on charges of displaying anti-government books and seeking withdrawal of BAPASI’s complaint against the journalist.

Title: DGP: It was a typo, no access granted
Content:
This story is from January 15, 2020
