Kochi: The state police chief has informed the high court that the order issued by him for granting access to ‘ crime data ’ to Uralungal Labour Contract Cooperative Society (ULCCS), allegedly for handling police clearance for passport verification , was a typo and that ULCC won’t have access to ‘crime data’.

An order issued by state police chief Loknath Behera on January 10 clarifying the earlier order was produced before the court.

The court is considering a petition filed by KPCC secretary Jyothikumar Chamakkala alleging that permitting access to Crime and Criminal Tracking Network and Systems (CCTNS), commonly called ‘crime data’, to a private entity affects right to privacy of citizens and amounts to failure of constitutional functions of the State.

The new order by the state police chief stated, “Due to certain typographical error, instead of mentioning ‘the access of CCTNS to the POC application of the ULCCS team’, it was mentioned as ‘the access to the ULCCS team’. Hence, the order read 2nd is hereby modified as ‘DIG APBn who is the Nodal Officer of the CCTNS will make available the access of production environment of CCTNS to the blockchain based POC application’.”

It was also stated in the new order that CCTNS data will be accessed by the Kerala Police personnel involved in passport verification work only, through the dedicated police computers installed in the police premises and that nobody else will have access to the same.

Further, the order said, “It is, once again, reiterated that the ULCCS team is not authorized to access CCTNS data or the software. Like any other software developing firm, M/s ULCCS has developed the software only and it is the System Integrator for the POC of blockchain platform and the blockchain based Passport Verification Application. M/s ULCCS will have no access to the data held by either the Passport Verification Application or the CCTNS Application.”

Title: Blood transfusion gives pet Rottweiler second lease of life
Content:
This story is from January 15, 2020

Hubballi: Blood has always been thought to be magical and it proved so for a Rottweiler suffering from jaundice. Roti, a four-year-old female, was given a second lease of life after receiving a blood transfusion from Rana, a three-year-old male Rottweiler.

Rana’s owner Manish Kulkarni, a city-based civil engineer, told TOI Ganesh Naganur, the owner of Roti had approached many dog owners but could not get blood. When Kulkarni heard about Roti’s condition, he immediately consented to donate the blood of his pet.

Manish said the transfusion was conducted at Dr SG Ron’s clinic in Hubballi. He said he is happy his pet was able to save a life of another pet. Rana donated about 300ml of blood.

Naganur, an engineer who works in a private firm, was grateful to Manish and Rana for saving the life of Roti. He said he approached more than 10 dog owners, but none were willing to help. He says Roti is doing fine and has recovered from jaundice.

Manish said though Rottweilers are known to be aggressive, Rana is “a very different animal”. “He is highly social and a people’s man,” Manish said. “In my absence, my father Mohan and mother Meera take care of him. I purchased him as a puppy from a local breeder in Hubballi. He eats a healthy diet and is regularly vaccinated.”

Ron, the vet who carried out the transfusion, said many dog owners hesitate to come forward to donate their pet's blood. He said in the past two years he has conducted 18 transfusions. “The checklist for blood transfusion is not very lengthy,” Ron said. “Any dog of any breed, which is more than a year old, healthy and has had regular vaccination shots and de-worming, can donate blood. Rana was mildly sedated during the time of the transfusion and it took almost 90 minutes to complete the process.”

Title: Info on 6,000 tribal settlements just an app away
Content:
This story is from January 15, 2020

Thiruvananthapuram: The state government, with the help of a startup company, has created a ‘realtime’ database of individuals and families from around 6,000 tribal settlements across Kerala , thus placing the photograph, geolocation and socio-economic status of every single tribe at the government’s fingertips.

It took almost a year for the state SC/ST department to complete the initial survey, which covered around five lakh tribes people, for creating a database through an android application developed by a Technopark-based startup company.

The database, which is now undergoing a final validation, will be updated regularly. Plans are afoot to create a similar database to cover scheduled caste communities in the state.

Though some chose not to cooperate with the survey featuring 198 questions, it covered almost 95% of the tribal population in the state, residing even in the remotest settlements in Wayanad, Palakkad and Idukki districts. Tribes people with economically strong background chose not to cooperate with the survey as they were apprehensive about losing existing benefits.

About 1,025 field promoters were engaged in the survey. They were provided tabs installed with ‘Geo Sat’ android and web application developed by Technopark-based Mergious IT Solutions, which also provided necessary training for the promoters. The app also has an offline feature to add information as several settlements do not have internet coverage.

The main purpose, according to officials, is to make effective and targeted intervention to raise the socio-economic status of tribes people. The field promoter will be updating information with regard to education, health, job/income, assets and family life of each individual, thereby helping the department to plan and implement welfare schemes and other projects, they said.

“With our application, the department will now be able to establish a management information system (MIS) with ward-level statistics for proper planning and scheme implementation,” said Ratheesh Kumar R, who heads Mergious along with Siju P G and Manu S.

The government now has the exact location and details of each tribal member and photographs of both individuals and families, he pointed out.

The company is currently developing an application for ‘medical promoters’ appointed by the ST department at various government hospitals. “The app will help these health promoters receive information from field promoters about accidents or medical emergencies and arrange for medical care at the nearest hospital. The software will record the patient’s medical history,” said Siju.

The data, which is undergoing a two-level validation (first by tribal extension officers and then by tribal development officers), will remain secure with the department, and will be utilised for tribes people’s welfare and progress, officials said. The information will come handy to identify school dropouts, people eligible for financial assistance and potential beneficiaries under various schemes, they added.

As per 2011 Census, there were around 4.83 lakh tribes people in the state, which is now estimated at 5 lakh.

Title: 2 killed as car overturns in Barmer
Content:
This story is from January 15, 2020

Jaisalmer: Two persons were killed and three others injured when their car in which they were travelling hit a divider and overturned at Chauhatan Road in Barmer on Monday night. Bodies have been handed over to their families after post-mortem. The deceased has been identified as Mustaq and Sawai Lal, both residents of Barmer. Injured have been undergoing treatment at the government hospital.

Police have started investigation after filing the case. According to police, all were returning from a birthday party. Barmer SP Sharad Chaudhary has appealed locals not to drive after getting drunk. TNN

Title: Rajasthan: SEC and panchayat wing in blame game over elections
Content:
This story is from January 15, 2020

Deputy chief minister Sachin Pilot at PCC office in city on Tuesday

JAIPUR: A blame game is on between the state election commission and the panchayati raj department over the delay in panchayat elections after the Supreme Court stayed the high court order cancelling two notifications issued for reconstituting new panchayats after November 15.

Deputy chief minister Sachin Pilot on Tuesday wrote to the state election commissioner, Prem Singh Mehra, reminding the commission that it was a constitutional obligation of the commission to hold the polls to panchayat bodies before their term ends as per the Constitution.

He said after the apex court stayed the high court order, the two notifications issued by the panchayat raj department have been revived. The commission should hold elections as per the conditions existed before the high court order on December 13.

But the commission had put on hold the elections of the affected panchayats by the two notifications under which many panchayats would have no elected representatives after the term of the present incumbents expire. So, the commission had not announced election to panchayat samiti and zilla parishad representatives whose term complete on February 7.

He pointed out that “If elections were not held before their terms complete, it would create a constitutional crisis.”

In order to avoid such a situation, he asked the commission to announce elections to the remaining panchayat bodies.

Sources in the election commission said the commission proceeded with the election process after getting directions from the panchayati raj department on December 16 in the aftermath of the Rajasthan High Court order.

ACS panchayati raj Rajeshwar Singh in his letter to all collectors had directed to reconstitute the wards and complete the lottery for reservations to various categories by December 22 in line with the high court order which was later extended to December 28. The commission has been proceeding with the election process to complete the elections on time. Then came the Supreme Court order.

“It was the department which went to the Supreme Court seeking a stay on the high court order. The top court had only stayed the high court order not cancelled it. We need clarity,” said an officer.

He pointed out that, “There is also a constitution provision that once the election process for panchayat bodies were set in motion, no court could interfere with the process.”

Title: Plastic kites flood Hyderabad sky despite ban
Content:
This story is from January 15, 2020

A child flies a plastic kite at Parade Grounds on Tuesday

HYDERABAD: Thousands of plastic kites have found their way into Hyderabad this Sankranti, despite a ban on single-use plastic by the Telangana government. Even at the state-sponsored International Kite and Sweet Festival on Tuesday several people were seen flying plastic kites.

While there’s a big profit for sellers, it’s a big loss for the city’s health as these plastic kites take years to disintegrate and would prove fatal for Hyderabad’s soil and water. “Plastic covering the land can stop water from percolating into the soil. This can stop the city’s groundwater levels from rising,” said Arun Krishnamurthy, founder of the Environment Foundation of India. He added: “And if this plastic is burned, it’ll cause severe air pollution.”

They can also endanger birds and animals. “Many kites get entangled on tree canopies. As plastic reflects light almost like a mirror, it can disorient birds and increase the chances of accidents,” said C Srinivasulu, head, Centre for Bio-diversity and Conservation Studies, Osmania University. And the threat of animals ingesting plastic is always there, he added.

“Plastic kites that end up in garbage are eaten by stray animals, causing immense pain or even death in some cases. The government should strictly ban the manufacture and sale of plastic kites in the state,” said Mirza Kareem Baig, member of the Forest and Wildlife Protection Society (FAWPS).

Amid environmental fears, kite traders across Dhoolpet, Gulzar Houz and Dabeerpura said that the sale of plastic ones has consistently increased in the city. This year, 90% of their profits came from selling ‘designer’ plastic kites, priced between Rs 4 and Rs 200. “We reduced our stock of traditional paper kites this year as there is very little demand. Customers prefer plastic kites because they don’t tear easily even on a windy day,” said Mohammad Rahmat, a 30-year-old trader from Dabeerpura.

When asked about plastic kites being allowed inside the state festival, Burra Venkatesham, secretary for youth advancement, tourism and culture said, “There are thousands of people coming to the festival. If we check each one of them, the enthusiasm will be lost. So, we are slowly trying to make them understand that using plastic is not good for anybody. It is more education than enforcement. Maybe they will slowly stop using plastic, if we continue to educate them.”

He added: “We have at least ensured that there is no plastic being used in stalls where sweets are being sold. We have asked participants to use recyclable material.”

Title: In tweet, Nakul Nath attacks Modi for shrinking jobs, rising inflation
Content:
Madhya Pradesh chief mInister Kamal Nath and his son Nakul Nath being welcomed during rally on Tuesday.

दीपिका पादुकोण अभिनीत ऐसिड अटैक सर्वाइवर पर बनी फ़िल्म “ छपाक “ जो 10 जनवरी को देश भर के सिनेमाघरों में रिलीज़ हो र… https://t.co/3R6SVgbgA2 — Office Of Kamal Nath (@OfficeOfKNath) 1578561867000

यह फ़िल्म समाज में ऐसिड पीड़ित महिलाओं को लेकर एक सकारात्मक संदेश देने के साथ-साथ उस पीड़ा के साथ आत्मविश्वास , संघ… https://t.co/yJTUMHdV9H — Office Of Kamal Nath (@OfficeOfKNath) 1578561867000

मोदी सरकार की ग़लत नीतियों के कारण ★ देश में 16 लाख रोज़गार घटे - एसबीआई रिपोर्ट ★ पिछले 5.5 वर्षों में खुदरा महँ… https://t.co/c3qiTxSbOM — Nakul Kamal Nath (@NakulKNath) 1578983639000

BHOPAL: In a first, Nakul Nath, Congress MP from Chhindwara and son of Madhya Pradesh chief minister, Kamal Nath “attacked” Prime Minister Narendra Modi government for the increase in unemployment and rising inflation in the country in a tweet on Tuesday.So far, junior Nath would usually tweet congratulatory messages to friends on their birthday, greet people on festivals or raise an issue concerning his constituency Chhindwara, but never used it as a tool to attack political opponents. Though, he retweeted his father’s tweet on Hindi film Chhapaak a few days ago in which Kamal Nath had praised the film while announcing to make it tax-free in MP.However, on Tuesday he posted some newspaper cutting relating to stories on declining job opportunities in the country and rise in inflation particularly prices of vegetables.With the # SabMehengaiSI, he wrote- Modi Sarkar Ki Galat Nitiyon Ke Karan (Because of erratic plicies of Modi government): * Desh Mein 16 Lakh Rojgar Ghate (Jobs in the country shrink by 16 lakh) * Picchle 5.5 Varshon Mein Khudra Mehngai Dar 7.35 % Par Pahunchi, Jo Sarvadhik Hai. (Inflation in retail prices touches 7.35 % in 5.5 years, which is the highest.) * 60.5 % Hua December mein Sabji Ke Dam Mein Ijafa (Vegetable prices rise by 60.5% in December)He concludes with a couplet “Aam Admi Ki Jeb Par Kar Ke Prahar So Rahi Modi Sarkar. (After drilling a deep hole in the pockets of common man, Modi government has gone to sleep).Responding to Nakul Nath's tweet, former state minister and BJP leader Vishwas Sarang said, “If he is so concerned about the economy, he should rather concentrate on the economy of MP and not the country, which is in safe hands. But, the economy of MP is in a shamble. The parallel economy based on corruption may be thriving but in real terms, the state government is taking Rs 100 crore loan again. Kamal Nath government in a year has taken a loan of Rs 20,000 crore, which is alarming, and would have its long-term consequence.

Title: Man set free over mismatch of names in detention order
Content:
This story is from January 15, 2020

Representative image

MADURAI: Setting aside a detention order passed by the Trichy district collector stating that the authority had passed it without properly applying his mind, the Madras high court has come to the aid of a man by setting him at liberty from prison.

The man’s wife, Kiruthiga had filed a habeas corpus petition before the high court Madurai bench early this year, seeking to set aside the detention order passed on June 23, 2019, branding her husband Sivakumar as ‘sand offender’ and sought to set him at liberty from the Trichy Central Prison, where he is lodged.

The petitioner’s counsel R Rajaraman submitted that the collector had wrongly passed the detention order stating that there is serious material discrepancy. He submitted that in the English version of the detention order the name is mentioned as ‘Sivakumar’, however, in the Tamil version it was mentioned as ‘Prabhakaran’ who was driving the vehicle smuggling sand. Hence, it was not known who was driving the vehicle.

The additional public prosecutor K Dinesh Babu submitted that though the FIR mentioned about involvement of two vehicles, the lorry driven by Sivakumar alone was captured from the place of occurrence. Hence, he submitted that the detention order was passed by following due process of law.

On perusal of the submissions, a division bench of justice T Raja and justice B Pugalendhi observed that when a query was raised by the court whether Sivakumar or Prabhakaran was involved in smuggling, it was unable to get any plausible answer. Even in the counter affidavit, it is not mentioned as to who drove the vehicle.

“A perusal of the English and Tamil version of the detention order clearly shows that the detaining authority has not applied his mind. Therefore, it is difficult to find out whether it was Sivakumar or Prabhakaran, who was another accused in the case drove the vehicle and attempted to run over the officials. Hence, the claim of the petitioner that there was no proper application of mind in passing the detention order is accepted,” observed the judges. The judges directed the Trichy superintendent of central prison to release Sivakumar from the prison forthwith, unless his presence is required in connection with any other case.

Title: More areas in Ekm now under CRZ
Content:
This story is from January 15, 2020

Kochi: With the government approving the revised coastal zone management plan (CZMP) for Ernakulam district prepared in February 2019, three municipalities and five grama panchayats have been included in the costal regulation zone (CRZ) limits. Intrusion of saline water into creeks, rivers and other waterbodies due to various reasons have led to these local bodies being included in CRZ limits.

Eloor, Kalamassery and Thrikkakara municipalities and Kunnukara, Alangad, Karumaloor, Kadungalloor and Amballur grama panchayats are the new local bodies which have come under the limits of CRZ, as per the new CZMP. According to experts, increase in the sea level and deepening of riverbeds and other waterbodies due to various aspects like sand mining have caused saline water intrusion. Kerala Coastal Zone Management Authority (KCZMA), the agency which is to regulate and monitor issues related to CRZ, entrusted National Centre for Earth Sciences Studies (NCESS) to conduct a study to fix high tide line (HTL) of waterbodies. It was based on the studies conducted by NCESS that more areas in the district have been included in CRZ limits. “We could find that salinity in many rivers and waterbodies is above five parts per thousand (PPT). If PPT is above five, it means there is tidal impact in the waterbody. That’s why new local bodies have come under CRZ purview,” said NCESS scientist K K Ramachandran.

“Deepening of riverbed due to excessive sand mining coupled with rise in sea level led to the saline water intrusion to more areas. Moreover, less rainfall in the catchment areas of rivers, rampant reclamation of rivulets, canals and other waterbodies which act as tributaries of rivers caused shrinking water level in the rivers. This led to flow of saline water into rivers,” said environmentalist S Sitaraman.

Authorities of local bodies are apprehensive that inclusion of their areas in the CRZ will affect development projects. “Now, five wards in our municipality will come under the purview of CRZ. Being the industrial hub of the state, around 40% of the total land in our municipality is being owned by public sector undertakings and other industries. So, we have got very little land for residential purpose. Including our municipality in the CRZ limits will further reduce the space for residential purpose,” said Eloor municipality vice-chairman M A James. “During various rounds of hearing prior to finalizing CRZ areas, we had demanded that our municipality should be exempted from CRZ limits,” he said. There are apprehensions that the development projects like electronic park, a park to house electronic hardware manufacturing units, may be affected. “Our officials are conducting inspections to check whichever areas and projects may be affected. Let’s hope that we will not have to scrap much projects,” said Amballur panchayat vice-president Manoj Kumar P K.

Title: 600m ‘goodwill’ banner to thank army
Content:
This story is from January 15, 2020

Jodhpur: A 600-metre-long banner bearing messages of citizens expressing honour and allegiance with the Indian Army will be handed over to army officials on the occasion of Army Day on Wednesday.

The idea conceptualised by two youths of the city, Arvind Singh Rathore and Chandrpal Singh Chouhan, is aimed at conveying to army personnel and jawans the respect of the common man for them.

According to Rathore from Blue City Cares, this is a New Year wish from Jodhpurites to soldiers for keeping people safe as well as a recognition of their supreme service to the nation in the face of all odds.

“This is a small token of gratitude to the Indian Army from all of us by presenting them the longest ever greeting card,” said Rathore.

This banner with messages will be handed over to the Lieutenant General V S Srinivas (GOC-12 Corps) at Lt. Gen Sagat Singh Stadium during the Army Day celebrations.

The campaign was initiated from Ganesh Mandir Circle on January 1 with an urge to people to write their wishes and messages for the Indian Army on it.

“Then these banners were taken at many other locations of the city and the messages of the people were taken on them till Tuesday evening. All these banners have been connected making a total length of 600 meters,” said Chouhan.

Title: State’s law suit in SC may boomerang, say experts
Content:
This story is from January 15, 2020

Kochi: The Kerala government’s suit challenging the controversial citizenship act in the Supreme Court may not have a sound legal basis, many in the legal fraternity believe. Those who support the move, however, say it is the only option available to the government.

T Asaf Ali, former director general of prosecution and Congress leader, questioned the government’s locus standi, arguing that it is a matter affecting the citizen and a government cannot move the court. Only a citizen can approach the Supreme Court for enforcement of fundamental rights under Article 32, he pointed out. Asaf Ali alleged that the government is playing politics and belittling a serious national issue.

Asaf Ali explained that the government can file a suit only in the matter of a dispute between states or between the Centre and a state, such as those over sharing of river waters, boundaries, tax, etc, A suit must also have a cause of action, which is absent in this case, he pointed out, adding that the govt’s move amounts to fooling the people of the state.

Asif Ali said the impact of the government’s suit is far-reaching and would derail over 60 petitions presently pending before the apex court challenging CAA . “The court would say this amounts to politicization of the issue and is a vexatious litigation. That would give strength to BJP’s claim that the issue is being politicized. It would belittle the importance of a national issue. While the Kerala government cannot file such a petition, as it has no fundamental right by itself; Pinarayi Vijayan could have done so in his personal capacity,” he said.

However, senior advocate TA Shaji asserted that filing a suit was the only solution available to the state government, short of being forced to implement CAA. “As justice Krishna Iyer said in the Maneka Gandhi case, ‘law is reasonable law, not any enacted piece’. When an unconstitutional law is passed, the only way is to approach a constitutional court to declare it as unconstitutional. As the state government cannot file a writ petition under Article 32, the only way before the government was to file a suit,” he said.

Another high court lawyer S Sanal Kumar termed the government’s move “legal adventurism or atrocity on the Constitution.” He agreed with Asaf Ali that a government cannot seek enforcement of fundamental rights, only a citizen can. “Can a state government allege violation of fundamental right by the Union in legislative or administrative relations” Sanal asked. The state government is bound to implement the law passed by the Union parliament and if every state starts following this course, the existence of the republic would be in peril, he said.

Title: BSF’s Operation Alert kicks off from Thursday
Content:
This story is from January 15, 2020

Additional security personnel have been deployed at sensitive places

JAISALMER: BSF will organise exercise Operation Alert at the international border with Pakistan from January 16 to 29. Officers and jawans from all branches of the BSF will participate in the exercise.

The entire western border with Pakistan, adjoining J&K, Rajasthan , Punjab and Gujarat, has been put on high alert for any possible intrusion under foggy conditions. To maintain additional security at the border, strict vigil would be kept using surveillance equipment and additional security personnel will be deployed. Patrolling at rear areas of border will also take place.

BSF Rajasthan Frontier IG Amit Lodha said keeping in mind the foggy conditions and with Republic Day around the corner, the force is maintaining strict vigil along the border. “We are doing day-night border domination. Review has been done on border tactics,” he said. Lodha said for the exercise, 20-30% additional security personnel have been deployed at sensitive places where there is heavy fog and added that orders have been given to foil any possible intrusion and untoward activities.

Lodha said that jawans have been given fog hand held search lights, night vision devices, battle field surveillance radar etc. and at the border posts, thermal imagers & many electronic surveillance equipment have been put, so that in case of any intrusion, BSF gets immediate information. At many places, CCTV’s and night electrical cobra wires have been installed to stop intruders.

BSF Rajasthan frontier DIG M S Rathore said about the exercise that looking to the heavy fog and mist at the international border, the Operation Alert exercise shall take place from January 16 to January 29.

Title: Beating Retreat 2020 to end with ‘Vande Mataram’
Content:
This story is from January 15, 2020

NEW DELHI: The “Beating Retreat” ceremony this time is likely to conclude with “Vande Mataram” instead of “Sare Jahan se Achha”, which in turn in recent years had replaced the decades-old tradition of playing Mahatma Gandhi ’s favourite “Abide with Me” at the end of the musical spectacle.

In earlier years, apart from ‘Abide with Me’, the military bands played popular tunes like the evergreen “Colonel Bogey” and “Sons of the Brave”.

“But in recent years, the focus has been to play more and more ‘desi’ tunes. In 2017, 2018 and 2019, the ceremony ended with the ever-popular tune of Sare Jahan se Achha,” said an officer. In 2018, 25 of the 26 performances were tunes composed by Indian musicians, with “Abide with Me” being the only western tune.

Title: Speeding car kills 4 returning from temple fest
Content:
This story is from January 15, 2020

Thrissur: Two families were left bereaving their dear ones when a speeding car plowed into a group of people returning from a temple festival, killing four, near Indira Bhavan on Thumpoor-Vellangaloor Road in Irinjalakuda early on Tuesday.

Police identified the deceased as Kottanallur residents Peranpulli Subran, 54, his daughter Prajitha, 23, Kannamthara Babu, 60, and his son Bibin, 20. They were walking back to their respective homes after attending the festival of Ayyappankavu at Thumpoor near Aloor, when the car knocked them down and tried to flee a little past midnight, Aloor police sub-inspector K S Susanth said.

Three of the victims, except Prajitha, were killed at the scene, police said, adding that the young woman died later in the morning while undergoing treatment.

Prajitha was a final-year degree student of St Joseph’s College, Irinjalakkuda. Subran and Babu were daily-wage workers, while Bibin drove an autorickshaw for a living.

Police and eyewitnesses chased the car, and took it in custody along with four college students in the vehicle.

The youths have been identified as Agnul, Dayalal, Jofin and Rovin. Agnul was taken for a medical examination to check if he was driving under the influence of alcohol.

Title: At long last, move to desilt Aruvikkara dam is initiated
Content:
This story is from January 15, 2020

Thiruvananthapuram: The Kerala Water Authority ( KWA ) is getting ready to desilt Aruvikkara dam , after a long delay. This week, the authority will invite expressions of interest (EoIs) from qualified contractors for desilting the reservoir, which was originally constructed as a weir across the Karamana river in 1933.

The high-level empowered committee, constituted to review the condition of dams in the state, decided to desilt the reservoir at its meeting on January 3.

As per a KWA preliminary study, around 10 lakh m3 of sand and silt sit in the reservoir, thereby reducing its capacity. “At current capacity, the reservoir can only meet four days’ supply of the city. Once desilted, storage can be increased enough for 10 days’ supply. However, storage is not the main concern with Aruvikkara dam as Peppara dam can also serve the purpose. Due to accumulation of silt and sand, weeds have infested the reservoir, which affects the turbidity and quality of water. Also, since the water level has to be kept at around 46m (above mean sea level) to enable pumping, shutters have to be opened after every rainfall,” sources said.

KWA sources said the EoI has been invited for preparation of a detailed project report, as well as desiltation. The work will be awarded on a turnkey basis, under which the authority will assess the probable amount of contract. The contractor who quotes the highest lump-sum amount will be the successful bidder. The contractor will pay the amount and carry out desiltation, and will be in charge of sale of components, such as sand.

The high-level committee had assessed that desiltation will also reduce flooding on the banks of the Karamana river. As per the preliminary report, restoration of the reservoir’s original capacity will help ward off unexpected flooding in parts of the city during heavy rains.

KWA officials said the tender process will take around three months. Desiltation is expected to take around two years to complete. “Around 500 working days will be required to remove over 10 lakh m3 of sand, silt and other organic matter from the reservoir,” they said.

The initial plan was to conduct a pilot for source improvement. Later, considering the need for proper desiltation, the government accepted the proposal for desilting the entire reservoir.

The water resources department also plans to desilt Neyyar dam, which is mainly used for irrigation.

ENDS

Title: Kochi: 5 arrested with elephant tusks at Thrippunithura
Content:
This story is from January 15, 2020

The elephant tusks, knives and currency counting machine seized by forest officers from an apartment at Tripun... Read More

KOCHI: Five persons were arrested by the flying squad of Perumbavoor forest range on Tuesday afternoon from an apartment at Tripunithura after seizing two elephant tusks from them.

The accused were identified as Roshan Ram Kumar (29) of Tripunithura, Shebin Sasi (28) of Eroor, Midhun T M (26) of Irinjalakuda, Sanoj T A (30) of Paravur and Shemeer K R (36) of Chendamangalam. According to forest officers, the accused were arrested around 2.30pm while they were fixing a deal to sell the elephant tusks at Kumar’s apartment at Thripunithura. They were arrested based on a tip-off from the intelligence wing of the forest department.

“On questioning, Roshan said that he received the tusks from his late father, who was an NRI. But we are yet to confirm it. One of the tusks was found in a half-sculpted state and the accused said that they were planning to sell it through brokers. We have also seized a few knives and a currency counting machine from them. The tusks will be sent for scientific test to find how old they are. The accused have been handed over to Kodanad forest range officers,” said Perumbavoor flying squad range officer P A Jaleel.

A case has been registered against the accused under Section 39 and 40 of Kerala Wildlife Protection Act. They will be presented in the court on Wednesday after recording statements in front of Malayattoor divisional forest officer.

Title: No search panel constituted to appoint Calicut univ VC
Content:
This story is from January 15, 2020

Kozhikode: The search committee for the selection of new vice-chancellor of University of Calicut (CU) is yet to be constituted months after the term of the previous committee expired.

The university and the state government have forwarded the names of their representatives to be included in the three-member search panel to the office of the governor and it is learnt that the UGC has also given the name of its representative to be included in the panel.

According to Raj Bhavan officials, the file for constituting the new search committee is before the chancellor and governor Arif Mohammed Khan and the new committee is expected to be constituted soon.

The office of the governor has asked the registrar of CU to submit the name of the nominee of the university senate to be included in the new search committee and the varsity on December 10 had elected Kerala state planning board vice-chairman V K Ramachandran as the nominee of the senate for the search committee.

Also, the state government informed Raj Bhavan of the nomination of chief secretary Tom Jose as its representative in the committee.

Both Ramachandran and Jose were members of the previous vice-chancellor search committee and it remains to be seen if the UGC nominee in the previous search committee M Jagadesh Kumar, vice chancellor of Jawaharlal Nehru University, will find place in the new search committee as well given the recent turn of events at JNU.The delay in constitution of the committee is likely to prolong the VC selection process further as the committee will have to once again invite applications from candidates. The delay has come at a time when the varsity is moving ahead with the mass appointment of 116 teachers.

Currently the VC of Thunchath Ezhuthachan Malayalam University, V Anil Kumar has been given charge of CU vice-chancellor.

Title: Naidu dares Jagan to call for referendum on capital issue
Content:
This story is from January 15, 2020

TDP chief N Chandrababu Naidu burns a copy of the GN Rao committee report that recommended three capitals for ... Read More

Vijayawada: TDP president N Chandrababu Naidu said that the proposal to shift the capital city was like a tsunami and political parties that support the move would be washed away.

He dared chief minister Y S Jaganmohan Reddy to call for a referendum on the proposal to shift the capital city. Naidu said he would quit active politics if Jagan’s proposal gained public support.

Naidu participated in Bhogi bonfire event organized to protest the capital city move in Vijayawada on Tuesday. Naidu, local MP Kesineni Nani and scores of TDP activists set copies of GN Rao committee and BCG reports on fire near Benz Circle.

Addressing the gathering, Naidu said that he had designed Amaravati as a people’s capital by involving people across the state. He said that people from every village in the state had sent their contributions and many had participated in construction activities in Amaravati. “Amaravati has divine blessings. It has a powerful history. No one could eliminate its history,” Naidu warned. He said that Amaravati has historical roots and people should unite to protect such a capital city.

He said people have showed their anger against the state government’s decision by setting reports of fake expert committees on Bhogi fire. He alleged that the expert committees drafted reports as per the whims and fancies of the chief minister. He said no state or country in the world has three capital cities.

He said that it was unfortunate that the state government had left farmers in the capital city area in deep sorrow on the biggest festival day by planning to move the capital city.

He, however, said that it was not so easy for anyone to move the capital city out of Amaravati as it has the backing of people from all parts of the state.

He said that Amaravati was selected as the capital not only because it was centrally located but has many natural advantages. He said that the local farmers had given up their agriculture land for the construction of the capital and undermining their sacrifice was not justifiable.

Naidu said that shifting of a few offices to Visakhapatnam would not help develop the most backward areas of Srikakulam and Vizianagaram. He said the government should plan decentralization of development instead of decentralization of administration. Naidu said except a few YSRC leaders people were backing Amaravati as the capital.

Title: Wayanad forests: Tiger that killed tribesman evading capture
Content:
This story is from January 15, 2020

The tiger moved to WWS from the adjoining Nagarahole Tiger Reserve in Karnataka around three years ago. The ti... Read More

KOZHIKODE: It has been a cat-and-mouse game going on in Wayanad forests for the last five days but involving a big cat and forest officials in this matter.

Though the forest department has identified the tiger which mauled to death and partly devoured a tribesman inside the Wayanad Wildlife Sanctuary (WWS) recently and had installed a cage trap five days ago to capture it, the tiger has been evading capture.

Forest officials said that the tiger which killed Jadayan (58) of the Pachadi Kattunayikka colony on December 24 has been identified as a four-year-old male tiger from analysis of camera trap images. The tiger moved to WWS from the adjoining Nagarahole Tiger Reserve in Karnataka possibly around three years ago as analysis of camera trap images showed that the tiger was first photographed while it was nearly one-year-old in Nagarahole.

It is believed that after getting weaned from its mother, it had been searching to establish a territory of its own and ended in the forests near Pachadi under the Kurichiad forest range of WWS. The animal has been first photographed in the area in April 2019 and officials say it could be in the process of establishing its home range in the area.

Chief conservator of forests (wildlife), northern region, B N Anjan Kumar said that camera trap images showed that though the tiger was coming as close as 100m from the cage trap which has a live bull calf kept as a bait but the tiger cat is not entering the cage.

“The reason could be that the identified tiger is a healthy animal and has the capability to hunt wild animals on its own and doesn’t need to depend on the bait. Also, the movement of forest staff deployed for monitoring it and for installation of camera traps would also have made the animal suspicious,” he added.

Forest officials said that in all the previous incidents involving the capturing of ‘problem’ tigers, the animals had either been aged, injured or having some problems with their teeth.

“But this is a healthy individual and its presence has been recorded in the area of around 50-100m near the cage but it is not entering the cage. Now we have to feed the animal kept as bait also,” he added.

The body of Jadayan was recovered from Pachadi forests around 400m inside the forests in the search conducted by local residents along with forest officials and people’s representatives on December 25. The lower limbs of the victim were eaten up by tiger.

Title: Madhya Pradesh: Congress for local polls through ballot papers; BJP sees ‘agenda’
Content:
This story is from January 15, 2020

PCC office-bearers submit the memorandum to the EC official

BHOPAL: A delegation of Congress leaders on Tuesday met Election Commission officials and submitted a memorandum demanding that the upcoming local body polls be conducted using the ballot papers, instead of EVMs. On the other hand, BJP has strongly opposed the demand.

Bhopal, Indore, Jabalpur , Gwalior and 16 major towns in the state will vote to elect their corporators in the next couple of months.

Among the Pradesh Congress Committee (PCC) office-bearers who met the poll body officials were organizational vice-president Chandra Prabhash Sekhar, vice-president Prakash Jain, general secretary Rajeev Singh and spokesman JP Dhanopia. The memorandum read: “It is an appeal from the state Congress that the local body elections are upcoming, and the last elections in the state were conducted through EVMs. The experience of the 2018 assembly elections and 2019 Lok Sabha elections was not satisfactory, and doubts were raised in the minds of the people. Therefore, under present circumstances, in the local body elections, preparations be made to conduct the election through ballot papers instead of EVMs.”

BJP alleged that Congress is seeking a chance to misuse the administrative machinery and muscle power to mend the election results in its own way.

“Wherever the Congress forms a government or gains majority, they do not react on the electronic voting machines (EVMs) but, when the results do not suit them, they blame the machines. Congress is demanding the local body polls through ballot papers when the party has formed a government Jharkhand with the help of its coalition partner through EVMs. It is displaying double standards,” said BJP state president Rakesh Singh.

BJP, however, alleged that Congress wants to misuse power and rig the polls, which is easier if polls are conducted through ballot papers. “There seems to be only one agenda behind this demand. Congress wants to misuse administrative machinery and muscle power to mend the elections in its favour. The ruling party is taking the state back to the lantern era,” said Singh. BJP leaders also said that ballot papers will promote the culture of booth capturing, long-drawn and a dull vote counting process and wastage of time and public funds. The government does not have a single valid logic for the use of ballot papers and should immediately reconsider its decision, said BJP.

Title: 37 low performing colleges under lens
Content:
This story is from January 15, 2020

Thiruvananthapuram: The academic council of APJ Abdul Kalam Technological University (Kerala Technological University-KTU) has decided to seek explanation from the managements of 37 engineering colleges under it, which failed to excel in the academic auditing.

The KTU academic council, which met here on Monday, also decided to send a team headed by the vice-chancellor to 10 colleges, which fared very poorly, to examine the existing infrastructure facilities. It also recommended the university syndicate to review the affiliation of these colleges if they fail to rectify the shortcomings.

The syndicate will consider the academic council’s recommendations in a meeting to be held later this week.

Another major recommendation was to place strict clauses for approval of new courses in engineering colleges. For considering fresh applications, the college must have NBA accreditation at least for one course, while for MTech course a college must have accreditation for the corresponding BTech course.

‘Stricter clauses for new courses’

Besides, colleges which apply for new courses should have a minimum average of 50% student admission to existing seats over the last three years. The college should also have secured a minimum 50% pass. Approval will be given only for courses which have industrial significance and job potential, and colleges should submit a no objection certificate issued by the state government along with the application for the AICTE approval.

Meanwhile, a four-member academic subcommittee headed by the pro-vice-chancellor was formed for inclusion of new subjects of industrial importance in all courses. It was also decided to include industry and technology experts in the curriculum committees entrusted with syllabus upgradation.

‘Restructure academic auditing’

The academic council, which directed to modernize the academic auditing on the model of NBA accreditation, noted that currently only around 30 out of the 142 affiliated colleges have NBA accreditation. The recommendation is to restructure the academic auditing so that all the colleges could secure the accreditation.

The academic council also decided to establish a review system which can provide students a last chance for reviewing the marks they are allotted after revaluation.

Rescheduled Exam

The university will conduct the third semester B Tech (computer science) exam on switching theory and logic design on January 18. The exam held on December 31 was cancelled due to a mess up of question papers.

Title: Job fair fails test of employability
Content:
This story is from January 15, 2020

Thiruvananthapuram: There were several vacancies and hundreds of candidates. However, only a few were offered placements. The two-day Spectrum 2020 job fair hosted by Govt ITI Chackai ended on a sour note on Saturday with the performance of candidates leaving most recruiters unimpressed.

“We are disappointed with the quality and mentality of the graduates. Out of 60 candidates we have shortlisted only four. This is quite unfortunate to see the younger generation shying away from hard work,” said Sanal Kumar from Aero Engineering , a recruiter.

A total of 2,113 candidates attended the job fair where 41 companies had advertised 1,600 vacancies. But with the a big question mark over the employability of candidates, most of the recruiters left the event disappointed.

“This is a very common problem. The new generation has failed to explore the positive side of internet and its addiction to mobile games and social media has had detrimental effects on efficiency and productivity,” said Kumar.

Concerns were also raised over the candidates’ ability to adapt to changing requirements in the work environment. “There is a radical change in the work culture of our youngsters. Most are not fully aware of the need to acquire and equip themselves with different skills. As soon as we assign a different work, most of them fail to cope because they are not trained to take on different challenges. These are not things which can be taught at an institute, and are self-acquired,” said Sreekanth Nair of Shivaji Motors.

Candidates with a national trade certificates, state trade certificates and national apprenticeship certificates appeared for the fair. “ITI students are trained on the practical aspects. We provide skill-based training and yet most of the students fail to work hard. This lethargic attitude is eclipsing the future of our nation,” said P Rajan, principal of Chackai ITI.

“BTech curricula are overly generalised and they lack practical training. This is why most BTech graduates fail to land jobs. But the situation is pretty similar even with the ITI graduates. If this generation doesn’t do a reality check, then most of the companies will be forced to adopt automation,” said Pritham Nair of Induja Motors.

ENDS

Title: Handy harvesters to make up for paddy machine crisis
Content:
This story is from January 15, 2020

Trichy: To overcome the scarcity of big paddy harvesting machines, agricultural engineering department has introduced handy harvesters and appealed to the farmers to make use of the equipment as they can procure it after availing up to 50% subsidy. For operation, the equipment requires only one person and can save time as well.

After the arrival of paddy harvesting machines, most of the farmers started opting for it as it would minimize time and labour. The process of threshing and winnowing of paddy have also become simple with the use of the big harvesters. However, it has some limitations as well. The large size of the machines makes it difficult for the operators to move it to a particular field, if the field is small in size. If the paddy field is very slushy, moving the machines would be difficult. The handy harvester fitted with a motor can overcome these limitations, agriculture officials said. “Farmers can buy this equipment from two companies recognized by the agriculture engineering department after registering their names with the Uzhavan App. The cost of the harvester is ranging from Rs 25,000 to Rs 30,000,” a senior official with the agriculture engineering department said.

Title: MahaMetro starts talks with private land owners
Content:
This story is from January 15, 2020

Pune: The Maharashtra Metro Rail Corporation (MahaMetro) on Monday said it has the possession of about 90% of government land required for the first phase of the mass transit project.

MahaMetro officials said they have also initiated talks with private owners to get the required land parcels for setting up entry-exit points of the stations and other facilities for the two Metro corridors, a 32-km stretch, it was executing. The government land is being used to start the depots and interchange stations.

“Non-availability of land is not a constraint at this stage to execute the Metro project in Pune and Pimpri Chinchwad. MahaMetro is thankful to the state government, Pune Municipal Corporation and the defence ministry for providing the required land parcels without much hassles,” MahaMetro managing director Brijesh Dixit said.

“The project has gathered significant pace because the land plots were made available at the earliest. The defence establishments recently gave use the crucial go ahead to initiate work in areas under their jurisdiction,” he said.

The officials said talks with the private land owners have been positive so far. “Several private plots , housing societies and educational institutes are on the list and we are establishing contacts with all possible stakeholders. The land parcels are required for the entry-exit points of stations. Bigger land plots, if available, can be utilized to build parking lots,” an official said.

Title: Naval arm inducts 15 airborne tacticians
Content:
This story is from January 15, 2020

Rear Admiral Krishna Swaminathan reviews the passing out parade

Kochi: A batch of 15 officers of the Indian Navy, including a woman officer, and three officers of the Indian Coast Guard graduated as Observers, at a passing out parade held at INS Garuda, Kochi, on Tuesday. Flag Officer Sea Training (FOST) Rear Admiral Krishna Swaminathan reviewed the parade and awarded the coveted ‘golden wings’ to the passing out officers, who would serve as ‘ Airborne Tacticians ’ on board Maritime Reconnaissance and Anti-Submarine Warfare aircraft of the Navy and Coast Guard.

The officers belonging to the 90th Regular and 21st Short Service Commission (SSC) Observer Course were trained in air navigation, flying procedures, tactics employed in air warfare, anti-submarine warfare and exploitation of airborne avionic systems.

Lieutenant Commander Harsukh Dadhich from the Regular Observer Course was awarded the Uttar Pradesh trophy, the Flag Officer Commanding-in-Chief, Eastern Naval Command Trophy and the Sub Lieutenant RV Kunte Memorial Book Prize on being adjudged ‘first in overall order of merit’, ‘best in flying’ and ‘best in ground subjects’. Sub Lieutenant Syed Abdul Kader from the SSC Observer Course was awarded the Book Prize for being adjudged ‘best in overall order of merit’.

Title: Cop gets 5-yr RI for abusing minor girl
Content:
This story is from January 15, 2020

Thiruvananthapuram: The Pocso special court here on Tuesday sentenced a policeman to five years of rigorous imprisonment after he was found guilty of sexually abusing an eight-year-old girl.

Bahuleyan, 49, a constable attached to Special Armed Police camp at Peroorkada in the city was also imposed a penalty of Rs 50,000, to be paid to the survivor of the abuse. The sentence was delivered by Pocso special court judge K V Rajaneesh.

Bahuleyan, a conductor in the police bus that ferried children from SAP residential quarters, sexually abused the 8-year-old girl on multiple occasions. He abused the girl in the bus, his residence in the quarters as well as inside his car.

Peroorkada police registered a case in April 2018 and arrested him on March 1, 2018. He was slapped with sections 7 and 8 of Pocso Act (inappropriate touch with sexual intent), 9 and 10 of Pocso Act (aggravated sexual assault committed by a police officer) and sections 11 and 12 of Pocso Act (sexual harassment). S Valsa Varghese was the special public prosecutor. During the trial, 16 witnesses and 22 documents were examined. tnn

Title: CPI(M) against capital city shift
Content:
This story is from January 15, 2020

Vijayawada: CPI(M) has opposed the state government’s proposal to have three capital cities. At a press conference here on Tuesday, state party secretary P Madhu said, “All parties, including YSRC, accepted the proposal to establish the capital in Amaravati , but the government is misleading people on the idea of inclusive development.”

Madhu said former governments had focused on certain cities while other regions remained less-developed. “The new stand on development of 13 districts is more dangerous,” Madhu said.

Title: Leopard trapped in Jabalpur firing range fence rescued
Content:
This story is from January 15, 2020

Forest officials rescue an injured leopard that was trapped in a barbed wire in an Army shooting area on the o... Read More

JABALPUR: A leopard that got trapped in the fencing of a firing range in Jabalpur was rescued after two hours of relentless operation on Tuesday.

The leopard was found trapped in fencing of COD firing range near Chewla-Tilhari village early on Tuesday morning by residents who informed the forest officials. The animal was rescued after tranquilizing it.

It had sustained injuries in its forelimbs , waist and chest, said sources.

Sources said that locals saw the animal at around 10 am and informed forest officials. However, it was only at around 11 am that the rescue teams of forest department reached the spot. The sighting of the leopard triggered panic as residents feared the animal might enter the villages if it manages to get out of the fence, said sources.

Chief conservator of forest, Jabalpur, RD Mehla told TOI, “The rescue operation lasted for nearly two hours. Doctor and rescue team caught the leopard after tranquilizing it. The forelimbs of the leopard were trapped in the fence of the firing range. The animal tried to get out of the fence and in this attempt it injured its forelimbs and chest. After the rescue, the animal was kept in a cage and sent to veterinary college for treatment.”

“It is a female leopard aged between 4 or 5. It is not the one which was seen in Naya Gaon area a couple of months and efforts are on to trap it,” he added.

Meanwhile, district forest officer, RM Tripathi said that the condition of the leopard which was rescued is critical and is being treated at the veterinary hospital.

Title: Thyagaraja festival takes a digital leap, set to get big online presence
Content:
This story is from January 15, 2020

Hundreds of musicians perform in front of the samadhi of saint Thyagaraja at Tiruvaiyaru in Thanjavur

CHENNAI: On the morning of January 15, lakhs of people will congregate on the banks of the Cauvery to render Thyagaraja’s pancharatna kritis marking the launch of the 173rd edition of the Thyagaraja Aradhana dedicated to the memory of the composer.

At the same time, from the confines of the city, Chennai’s Carnatic musicians will also launch their tributes to the 18th century composer – only it will be online .

With growing interest in the Carnatic art form, digital video sharing platform YouTube has decided to join in the annual celebrations at Tiruvaiyaru by roping in seasoned artistes such as Aruna Sairam , Ranjani-Gayatri and Sikkil Gurucharan as well as classical arts forum IndianRaga to share compositions of the composer as well as tributes.

Aruna Sairam said that on Wednesday morning, she is planning to post special excerpts from a pallavi she has composed inspired by Thyagaraja’s Pancharatna kritis. “I will post this on YouTube as well as on my social media handles – Twitter, Facebook and Instagram,” said the singer, adding that she has augmented her online presence over the past year.

“I want to build a deeper connect with my fans through digital media. In 2019, for instance, I created 5-8 minute vlogs on topics ranging from the tanpura to memories of my music lessons as a child, and they have been getting a lot of response,” she said.

The idea behind joining the Thyagaraja festivities, says a YouTube spokesperson, is to give people from all over the world a chance to be a part of it.

“Interest in Carnatic music has been growing online,” says the spokesperson. “Even sabhas have started finding value in putting content up online. Hamsadhwani sabha has started a YouTube channel among others like Vani Mahal and Arkay Convention Centre.”

Musician Jayanthi Kumaresh, who has 21,000 subscribers, said she has a team managing her social media presence. In 2019, for instance, the veena artiste had launched a web series highlighting lesser known aspects of the Carnatic season, which she said garnered two million views.

“The objective is to be accessible to people in different parts of the world so that people can stay connected to the veena,” said Jayanthi, who will also participate in the tributes to Thyagaraja. “Later this year we plan to stream kutcheris to give people a live concert experience,” she said.

Title: City to host Krithi festival from Feb 6 to 16
Content:
This story is from January 15, 2020

Kochi: Krithi 2020, the third edition of Krithi International Book Fair and Knowledge Festival, organized by the department of cooperation and Sahithya Pravarthaka Cooperative Society (SPCS), will be held in Kochi from February 6 to 16 .

Announcing the event, minister for cooperation, devaswom and tourism Kadakampally Surendran said Krithi 2020 will host one of the largest book fairs in India and on its sidelines, a literary and knowledge festival, cultural programmes and a food festival. For this, a total of 75,000 sq ft area will be used including a fully air-conditioned pavilion of 46,000 sq ft area for book fest. Krithi 2020 is expected to have more than 150 publishers from India and abroad. The event is expected to achieve a sales figure of Rs 20 crore.

Under ‘A book for every child’ scheme, Krithi 2020 aims to provide book coupons worth Rs 1.5 crore to students across the state through cooperative institutions. The third edition will also have a separate section for children’s books. In addition to these, Krithi 2020 will hold reading and poetry writing competitions for students and will stage magic shows on all days. For adults, Krithi has already announced short film and photography competition. There will be separate exhibitions of the yesteryear photographs of Kerala towns and a historical exhibition of SPCS, which is on its 75th year now.

Krithi knowledge festival, which is scheduled for February 12 to 16, is expected to be attended by eminent writers and scholars.

Title: Opposition mounts protest on SEC over draft voters list
Content:
This story is from January 15, 2020

Thiruvananthapuram: The opposition ramped up the protest against the decision of state commission (SEC) to prepare draft voters list for 2020 local body elections based on the voters list which was prepared in 2015. Muslim league approached high court against the decision and filed a writ petition following which a notice has been issued to SEC to explain the grounds on which the voters list of 2015 is being used to prepare draft voters list for 2020 local body elections.

The petition was filed by Suppi Narikatteri and P Hafish. They pointed out that the voters list used in 2019 Lok Sabha elections was in effect and hence it was wrong to use voters list of 2015. Muslim league also filed a complaint with SEC citing impracticality of the decision. The league leaders pointed out that as per Section 83 of Kerala Municipality Act 1994, election commission has no restriction in making use of voters list prepared by central election commission. The decision by SEC has complicated matters and will deny right to vote of many voters, they said.

KPCC general secretary Thampanoor Ravi has also demanded SEC to withdraw the move to prepare draft voters list based on 2015 list. “The 2019 list includes details of new voters and using this one would be more convenient,” said Ravi. He also said that delay in notification of ordinance regarding ward delimitation will cause delay in the process. The draft voters list will be published on January 20. Complaints can be submitted before February 14. Final list will be published on February 28. The state government had earlier communicated to SEC that draft list may be based on 2019 list, however, with SEC basing preparation of list based on 2015 list, the government is less likely to object.

Title: FASTag a must from today, only one hybrid lane for cash payment
Content:
This story is from January 15, 2020

Bengaluru: The FASTag toll collection system mandated by the ministry of road transport and highways (MORTH) is to be officially rolled out across all National Highways Authority ( NHAI ) toll plazas in the country from Wednesday.

Since December 15, 75% of all lanes (three to four) at toll plazas were converted into FASTag lanes. But Wednesday onwards, only one hybrid lane in either direction will accept cash payments.

Last week saw FASTag transactions climb to 46% and the figure crossed 54% as of Tuesday afternoon. The scramble to buy the stickers picked up pace on Monday; NHAI authorities say more than 60,000 FASTags have been sold in the state so far.

Despite the government relaxing the FASTag rollout mandate (from 100% to 75% electronic collection), the project has not helped reduce waiting time at toll plazas in the state, claim motorists, adding that system glitches continue to affect its smooth rollout. A common complaint is that often they’re forced to pay twice for the same journey, which occurs when scanners are unable to read the Radio Frequency Identification (RFID) stickers.

Initially supposed to be implemented by December 1, the project deadline was pushed to December 15. On December 14, the ministry again deferred the implementation and said the mandate had been relaxed to 75%.

First introduced in 2016 to ensure smooth traffic flow at toll plazas, the system involves the use of RFID stickers on the windscreens of vehicles, allowing motorists to pass through toll plazas without halting.

Free trip if machine is faulty

NHAI officials clarified on Tuesday that in cases of malfunctioning electronic toll collection infrastructure, the vehicle will be permitted to pass without payment of user fee.

“If a vehicle user with a valid, functional FASTag with sufficient balance in the linked account crossing a toll plaza is not able to pay user fee through FASTag owing to malfunctioning of electronic toll collection infrastructure, he/she shall be permitted to cross without payment of any user fee. An appropriate zero transaction receipt shall be issued mandatorily for all such transactions,” reads a notification issued by the ministry on May 7, 2018.

Title: New plaint against municipality official at Anthoor
Content:
This story is from January 15, 2020

Kannur: A private sector employee, working in New Delhi, has alleged that a councillor of Anthoor municipality illegally encroached his property and built a path to her home though there is a way that leads to her home. However, the councilor claimed the entire issue was fabricated to tarnish the image of the municipality once again. Earlier, it had faced a lot of criticism over the suicide of NRI businessman Parayil Sajan in June 2019, allegedly following issues with the municipality.

Ramesan Alinkeel said he had bought nearly 21 cents two years ago as he wanted to build a house. A few months ago, when the compound wall was being built, councillor T U Sunitha said that she wanted a way to her house through his plot, he said. “Since I paid for the land, I said I need money and then local CPM leaders asked me to come for a discussion. I met them when I visited home in July-August,” he said.

During discussion she agreed to pay the money in 10 days. She later retracted her offer and the local party leadership said they wouldn’t intervene in the issue, said Ramesan. Later, he built a compound wall in September 2019, despite some opposition.

Sunitha then approached revenue authorities and got an order in her favour saying that she does not have way to her home. “I was shocked because they did not listen to my side and then I approached the court which issued an injunction against her last month, saying that she should not enter the compound. Despite this, the compound wall was demolished on the night of January 12,” he said.

However, Sunitha said she had no role in the entire episode and that the way through his compound had been used by people over the years. She claimed that it is the only entry to her compound.

“I didn’t demolish the wall. I was in a hospital when this happened and I doubt it was a conspiracy by the complainant’s people to strengthen the case against me,” she said, adding that she had requested Ramesan to give her permission to use that path through his compound. When he refused, I had to approach revenue authorities, she added.

Sunitha said she had no issue with Ramesan and hence there was no question of her or CPM threatening him. “There is a conspiracy to tarnish me, the party and the municipality. I will take legal recourse,” she said.

Title: Row as panellists skip KLF session
Content:
This story is from January 15, 2020

Kozhikode: A session planned at Kerala Literature Festival (KLF), scheduled from January 16 to 19, has given rise to a controversy with some persons raising allegation that the theme of the discussion smacked of Islamophobia and two panellists backtracking from the debate citing different reasons.

K Jamida, Rafeeq Mangalassery and Jazla Madasseri were to participate in a discussion titled ‘From religious to irreligious life’. But, it was pointed out that those who had renounced Islam (ex-Muslims) were invited for the debate though the title referred to all religions.

“RSS is attempting to evict all Muslims from India and here KLF is celebrating those who are insulting Muslim identity. We will question such programmes that strengthen racial prejudice against Muslims,” said M Luqman, who works with the media department of Jamia Markaz. “What is the relevance of Jamida who is spitting venom against Islam at stages arranged by Sangh Parivar. Organizers have the freedom to invite anyone, but we will object against the spreading Islamophobia using government money,” he said.

We contacted KLF director K Satchidanandan when we came to know about the session and he promised changes in the session, said Muhammadali Kinalur, who works with Risala magazine.

But KLF organizers said it was not right to pick a session from over 250 debates to spark a controversy. “Contemporary issues are being debated at KLF. Sr Lucy Kalappura will be addressing an exclusive session and there are sessions on right-wing politics and CAA,” said AK Abdul Hakeem, one of the organizers.

“We selected the particular topic as we thought it would be worthwhile to discuss the experiences of those who left Islam. Later it was suggested that those who are leading Islamic life should also be part of the interaction. We then included Mujeeb Rehman Kinalur and Muhammad Shameem on the panel,” Hakeem said. But this change infuriated Rafeeq Mangalassery who felt organizers had succumbed to the pressure from Muslim fundamentalists.

“The answer to the issue of non-representation from other religions is not including a Salafi and a Jamaát-e-Islami worker on the panel. Moreover, I was not consulted before changing the panel structure,” he said, adding that he would skip the event as a mark of protest.

Jazla Madasseri also decided to leave the panel. In her Facebook post Jazla said there are people from all religions who have renounced faith and it is not fair to include only those who left Islam. She added that such discussion will only help to strengthen Islamophobia in the current scenario.

Title: Vivekananda’s 16ft statue to stand tall at flower show
Content:
This story is from January 15, 2020

Bengaluru: The 211th edition of the Republic Day biennial flower show at Lalbagh Botanical Gardens will kick off on January 17. The main attraction this year will be a 16ft-tall statue of Swami Vivekananda made out of more than 40,000 cut flowers. It’s a floral tribute to the swami on his 157th birth anniversary, the organisers said.

The statue will stand on a 3ft-tall pedestal, making the floral arrangement itself over 19 feet high. It will be kept on display at the Glass House of Lalbagh along with a floral model of Kanyakumari fashioned out of 3.3 lakh flowers, and a floral replica of the Chicago Memorial made from 1.5 lakh cut flowers.

Some famous moral stories associated with Swami Vivekananda’s lectures, such as the Monkey and Crocodile, Frog in a Well and Frog in a Sea, will be visually depicted using 60,000 crysanthemums at the Band Stand.

Screening of films and documentaries depicting the swamiji’s life, exhibition and sale of books, special demonstration sessions on vertical gardening, growing micro-greens, landscaping and hydroponics will also mark the flower show.

Ninety-two species of flowering plants will be exhibited at this year’s edition. Over 2.21 lakh flowering pots will also be on display. Gardening, Ikebana, Bonsai, vegetable carving and Indian floral art competitions will be held on the sidelines.

The show will conclude on January 26.

Title: Kerala: 500 cops deployed for Lakshadeepam festival
Content:
This story is from January 15, 2020

Sree Padmanabha Swamy Temple in Thiruvananthapuram. (File photo)

THIRUVANANTHAPURAM: City police have made security arrangements for the Lakshadeepam event that marks the culmination of 56-day-long murajapam rituals of the Sree Padmanabhaswamy Temple on Wednesday. Over 500 police personnel have been deployed in the temple zone. This includes 13 inspectors and 102 sub inspectors comprising both male and female officers. The police have divided the temple and surrounding areas into five zones. Deputy commissioner (Sree Padmanabhaswamy Temple division) will be in charge of the zone that comprises the temple compound. The zone comprising the area outside of the periphery walls of the temple will be under the supervision of deputy commissioner (administration and crimes). City commissioner Balram Kumar Upadhyay said they expect over 50,000 devotees to turn out as Lakshadeepam, which is observed once in six years, coincides with Makar Sankranti. Entry into the temple are restricted for those with special passes. Entry will be through the south west and north nadas (gates) of the temple. Public will be allowed to enter the temple only between 4pm and 7pm. The police have identified parking spaces for the vehicles of devotees: Putharikkandam ground, Attukal temple ground, Gandhi Park, Central School Attakkulangara, Theerthapada Mandapam, Ananthasayanam Auditorium compound, Priyadarsini Auditorium, paid parking areas on MG Road near Fort, Sringeri Math, NSS High School Perunthanni, Sreekanteswaram Park, Fort School ground, Fort Mission Girls School, Padma Nagar, and Technical Director’s office. “Vehicular traffic on the roads near the temple zone will be regulated from 10am to 9pm on Wednesday. There will a ban on entry to certain roads close to the temple at these hours. The police will divert traffic at select junctions as part of the regulations. The public is requested to follow the instructions of the policemen on traffic duty to avoid traffic snarls,” the commissioner said.

Title: Coimbatore: First water vending machine opened at Ukkadam bus stand
Content:
This story is from January 15, 2020

The civic body has plans to open at least 130 water vending machines in the city

COIMBATORE: From now on, public could collect a litre of purified drinking water by just inserting an Rs 1 coin in the water vending machine that is installed at Ukkadam bus stand in the city.

Nearly one and half years after municipal administration minister S P Velumani announced the plans to supply purified drinking water through automatic vending machines in all the wards of urban local bodies in the state, the city corporation had inaugurated its first such machine on Saturday.

While a litre of water is sold at Rs 1, it costs just Rs 7 for 20 litres if the customers were to collect it from the plant. If the residents want 20 litres water to be delivered at their doorstep, it will cost them Rs 20.

R Lokesh, a bus driver at Ukkadam bus stand, said, “Earlier, we used to request some of the shopkeepers to fill our water bottles as we could not afford to purchase water daily. Now, we have to pay just Re1 for a litre of water. It is really a good move.”

S Krishnaveni, leader of self-help group that runs the project, said they were selling close to 100 litres water daily. “The demand is for one litre water. Now, our focus is to get bulk orders and sell 20-litre water cans.”

The self-help group had taken a loan of Rs 9.50 lakh to get the project running and spent another Rs 49,000 to purchase 500 20-litre water cans.

Krishnaveni said they were talking to shopkeepers in and around Ukkadam to convince them to buy water from them as it was priced very cheap. She said they were also planning to sell water cans for functions like marriages.

“While shopkeepers at fish market and TTK market have already started to purchase water cans from us, others, especially the big shops, are reluctant. So, we have sought the city corporation’s help and officials have agreed to print pamphlets explaining about the project. Maybe, we could gain the trust of customers if we visit them with the pamphlets from the city corporation,” she said.

Krishnaveni said they had to sell at least 500 water cans a day to be able to pay the interest on the bank loan.

The civic body has plans to open at least 130 water vending machines in the city.

Title: Bright spot eludes solar powered agri income plan
Content:
This story is from January 15, 2020

Chennai: Solar farms of private companies have been sprouting up on arid lands in Tamil Nadu to generate power, but ‘solar panels’ on fertile agricultural lands too may soon come up if the Tamil Nadu Energy Agency (TEDA) has its way.

TEDA has drawn up a plan to enlist farmers from across the state and supply them solar panels free of cost to generate power. While farmers could use the generated power to run their agricultural pump sets to irrigate farmlands, they will also get to export the surplus power to the grid and earn money for it.

Solar panels with a power generating capacity of 11KW would be installed and connected to the grid in the vicinity. With the targeted 20,000 farmers, TEDA aims to establish a solar power generating capacity of around 220MW. These farmers would join the Centre’s farmer energy security and regeneration campaign, which has aimed to establish 10 lakh grid-connected agriculture pumps across the country.

According to the original plan, the Centre would extend 30% subsidy and the respective states would contribute an equal share for the scheme, with the farmers contributing the rest (40%). Since the Tamil Nadu government is already extending free power supply to farmers, the government is envisaging of bearing 70% of the subsidy to make it free for farmers.

Officials in TEDA, the nodal agency to implement the scheme, have sent a proposal to the state seeking its nod to give "incentive for farmers" for the excess power generated from the solar panel installed in the farm and supplied to the grid. Generating power at the farms would ensure quality and uninterrupted supply for agriculture.

"Though irrigation activities will be restricted to daytime, unlike the present when free power is made available at night, farmers could have an income from the excess power sold to the grid," says a senior TEDA official.

But, Tangedco seems to be skeptical about the whole plan, especially since it will be a double whammy for it, say officials.

"We tried to convince farmers, waiting for free power, to withdraw their applications and opt for the solar power scheme. But many of them want both free power as well as solar power, and the rest are not interested," says a senior Tangedco official.

In Tamil Nadu, 21.17 lakh farmers have been benefiting under the free electricity scheme, consuming 13.064 million units per annum. Burdened with rising debts and losses, Tangedco’s cash flows too suffer due to delayed payments by the state for the free power supplied to farmers.

"We are not confident about the scheme taking off, unless farmers are made to join it and quit free power," says the Tangedco official.

The concept is a take-off from the ‘solar pump’ scheme, says Sudhakar Thanikai, director-technical, YanSun Natural Energy. While the solar pumps could generate electricity for around 12 hours a day, the farmer’s irrigation requirement and other purposes was limited to usually about four hours a day, rendering the balance energy going waste. "Under the new scheme, the government plans to get free land, especially those lying vacant, to generate power. While farmers with round-the-year cultivation may not be willing to give their land for such schemes, those with limited water resources could join," says Sudhakar.

In terms of farmers’ income, the scheme looks better only on paper. "From a 11KW farm, around 44 units of electricity per day can be generated. Even if one takes a liberal 80% plant load factor, each plant can generate 36 units per day. With solar power being bought by the grid at a maximum of Rs3 per unit that works out to an income of Rs108 per day," says Sudhakar. If farm usage of generated power and the evacuation expenditure of Tangedco are accounted for, it leaves a big question mark over the farmers’ actual income.

In Tamil Nadu, while officials from agriculture engineering department are claiming that solar power pump sets are a big hit among farmers, numbers say otherwise.

A mere 584 farmers have installed solar-powered pump sets in the delta districts such as Thanjavur, Nagapattinam, Tiruvarur and Trichy, officials said.
