N Srinivasan, a progressive farmer from Veeran Arasanpettai near Boothalur in Thanjavur district said in the case of agriculture lands where there is no source of power, farmers opt for solar pump sets, but it is the electric and diesel-powered ones that are preferred, he said.

(With inputs from Sivakumar B and Vincent Arokiaraj)

Title: Rangolis, bonfires usher in Sankranti celebrations
Content:
This story is from January 15, 2020

Vijayawada: The three-day long Sankranti celebrations commenced across the state on Tuesday with bonfires in the city marking ‘Bhogi’, the first day of the festival.

Walkers’ associations across the city conducted special ‘Bhogi’ celebrations and mega-walks. “Sankranti is a festival of joy and fun. A majority of us are from farming communities and have settled in cities. We conduct traditional Sankranti celebrations similar to what is held in villages, and resembling a village atmosphere, to continue the tradition for future generations,” said K Kranti Kumar, a member of Vijayawada Walkers’ Association.

In keeping with tradition, several families in the city celebrated ‘Bhogi pallu’ by showering a mixture of seasonal berries, flowers and sugarcane on the heads of children.

Rangolis were painted on the front yards of houses and ‘gobbellu’ placed by women while ‘gangireddula’ (decorated bulls) were special attractions on streets.

Crowds of devotees gathered at temples in the cty from the early hours on Tuesday. Vedic scholars at the Kanaka Durga temple offered special prayers for Sankranti.

Minister of endowments Vellampalli Srinivas lit a bonfire at the Kanaka Durga temple and inaugurated a ‘bommala koluvu’. Authorities at the temple also invited senior citizens from various old-age homes to participate in celebrations at the temple.

Meanwhile, a section of residents in the city skipped Sankranti celebrations in protest against the government’s proposal to set up three capital cities for the state and to continue with the capital at Amaravati. “Sankranti is a festival celebrated to mark the end of the harvest season. But for the farmers in the capital region who have given up their land to the government, there is no celebration. We have skipped Sankranti celebrations and decided to conduct protests opposing the government’s proposal in the name of decentralisation,” said Pothina Venkata Mahesh, a spokesperson for Jana Sena.

Title: Classmates write to min, Aswin gets free treatment
Content:
This story is from January 15, 2020

Kollam: Rays of goodness can sometimes cut through the dark clouds of pessimism and pain. The thirty-three 3rd standard students of West Kallada Govt LP School in Kollam have proved that little acts of kindness trickling down from the depths of the heart can have the desired effect.

Their joint effort to bring the plight of Aswin Madhu, who has cerebral palsy , to the attention of authorities, to help him receive expert treatment, has paid dividends.

A letter the pupils wrote moved minister for health and social welfare KK Shailaja . She ordered free treatment for Aswin at the Thiruvananthapuram Medical College’s physical medicine & rehabilitation centre under the ‘we care’ scheme of the Kerala Social Security Mission.

The minister also found time to meet Aswin at the hospital and interact with his mother. She also congratulated R Nila, Aswin’s classmate who inspired the children to write to the minister.

"The kind act of a group of children has helped ensure expert treatment to Aswin,” the minister said.

“Under the care of PMR wing chief Dr Abdul Gafoor, Dr Suresh and Dr Zakhariah, Aswin will get effective treatment. Besides the treatment and therapy, medicines and aid equipment will also be provided free of cost. And surgery will be conducted, if required,” Shailaja added.

It was around mid-December that the children wrote to the minister. Unable to stand or walk on his own, Aswin is also incapable of speech. The boy, who has the growth of a two-year-old, was dropped during his birth, resulting in his condition.

His mother’s hope of providing a proper treatment for Aswin’s return to a normal life prompted the children to write seeking the minister’s intervention. The teachers also wrote a letter detailing the helplessness of the boy and his family.

On receiving the letter, the minister contacted the headmistress of the school to understand the problem. The very next day, Social Security Mission regional director Dr Diana reached Aswin's house and examined him. She was convinced that he could be given a normal life with special treatment.

Title: Man who spread derogatory remarks against minister held
Content:
This story is from January 15, 2020

Representative image

COIMBATORE: A 38-year-old man has been arrested for circulating derogatory remarks against municipal administration minister S P Velumani and city corporation officials.

The RS Puram police identified the arrested as A Zahir Hussein, of Karumbukkadai in the city. A police officer said Zahir had recorded an audio message, criticizing the city corporation on the implementation of 24x7 water supply and solar plant projects, and circulated the same on WhatsApp.

“He also passed derogatory remarks against the minister and corporation officials in the 10-minute long audio message that went viral. He said the solar plant near the sewage treatment plant in Ukkadam would create a lot of health hazards to the public. He said the plant was deliberately installed at Ukkadam, a Muslim dominant area, to spread diseases to the minorities,” the official said.

As the message was intended to provoke a section of people, based on city corporation commissioner J Sravan Kumar’s direction, west zone assistant corporation commissioner Senthil Arasan lodged a complaint with the RS Puram police on Monday.

The RS Puram police then arrested Zahir the same night under Sections 505 (with the intent to incite any class or community of persons to commit offence against other class or community) and 506 (punishment for criminal intimidation) of the Indian Penal Code. Zahir was later produced before a judicial magistrate, who remanded him in judicial custody.

Title: ‘Malakha’ project to watch over kids, prevent abuse
Content:
This story is from January 15, 2020

Thiruvananthapuram: The state police have launched an awareness programme titled ‘ Malakha ’ in order to prevent sexual atrocities against children .

State police chief Loknath Behera said that the police intends to provide awareness to all those closely interacting with children, including, their parents, teachers, relatives, police officers, doctors, staff in the healthcare sector and media persons. The programme has been scheduled from January 15 till March 31, and each district police chief will be in charge of their respective districts.

A vehicle named ‘Vava Express’ will travel across the state, exhibiting messages against atrocities on children. In addition, there will be signature campaigns, processions, cultural programmes, plays, street plays, programmes involving celebrities, public functions by including various arms of police like the police band team, mounted police, student police cadets, etc.

Involvement of anganwadi teachers, Asha workers, Kudumbashree and Janasree workers among others will also be ensured. Police beat officers will visit houses and take the messages to them. The state police chief said that all police officials will participate in the programme.

The police have also decided to launch a special project with special focus on vulnerable children of the society, prone to physical or sexual abuse. As part of this, such children will be identified through multiple ways, and the children along with their parents will be given counselling. Police have already launched such a project titled ‘Kavacham’ in Kannur range.

Title: Fapi asks CM to retain capital in Amaravati
Content:
This story is from January 15, 2020

Visakhapatnam: President of the Federation of Andhra Pradesh Industries (Fapi) BV Rama Rao demanded that chief minister YS Jaganmohan Reddy retain the capital city at Amaravati.

The Federation of Andhra Pradesh Industries is in favour of Amaravati continuing as the state capital, Rama Rao said, especially as the Pime Minister laid the foundation stone for its development. He also requested the chief minister to enable setting up of industries and their development in the state.

Addressing the media here on Thursday, Rama Rao, also the founder of Telugu Shakti organisation, said that while former chief minister YS Rajasekhara Reddy developed industries and IT during his tenure, Jagan is yet to chalk out plans for the development of industry.

“Ministers, MPs and MLAs lack knowledge and awareness about setting up industries or their development. Moreover, existing industries are faced with many problems, resulting in their closure. Workers are thrown out of employment,” Rama Rao said, adding that developing the sector would generate employment for the youth.

Title: Child rights panel asks govt to curb stray dog menace
Content:
This story is from January 15, 2020

Thiruvananthapuram: The Kerala state commission for protection of child rights has asked the government to take immediate steps to contain the stray dog menace in the state.

Commission chairman P Suresh placed the demand before the government in the wake of a seven-year-old child suffering from grave injuries after being bitten by a stray dog in Kannur.

He said that the government should provide financial assistance to the child’s family for treatment as the child’s face has been severely mutilated in the stray dog attack.

Many times, the stray dogs scare away the children as they travel between their schools and homes. The commission is of the view that the Centre’s rule that the stray dogs should not be killed should not hamper the free movement of children. The commission registered a suo-motu case on the basis of media reports of the attack. The commission sought reports from the chief secretary, state police chief, director general of public education, Kannur district collector, panchayat director and director of animal husbandry within two weeks.

Workshop on child rights

The commission will hold a workshop on child rights in the capital as part of strengthening the child-rights systems. The workshop will be held at the district panchayat hall on Thursday.

Title: 29-yr-old man caught during theft attempt
Content:
This story is from January 15, 2020

Coimbatore: A 29-year-old man was caught red-handed attempting to burgle a house at Avarampalayam in the city on Monday.

The Peelamedu police, who took K Sekar Babu into custody, said he entered 31-year-old P Lingammal’s house when she was alone. “Lingammal heard some noise and when she checked the rooms, she noticed the burglar. Immediately, she raised an alarm. The burglar threw chilli powder on her face and tried to escape. However, neighbours caught him and handed him over to us,” a police officer said.

Based on Lingammal’s complaint, police arrested Sekar Babu under Section 393 (attempt to robbery) of the Indian Penal Code (IPC). He was later produced before a local court and lodged in jail under judicial custody.

In another incident, unidentified people broke into a house at Thudiyalur on the outskirts of the city and made away with gold ornaments weighing 18 sovereigns and Rs 5,000 cash on Monday.

Police said the incident took place when the house owner, K Mathiyazhagan, 50, had left for Jolarpet on Sunday morning. “When he returned on Monday morning, he found the front door of the house was broken open and valuables were missing.”

Based on his complaint, the Thudiyalur police have registered a case and further investigations are on.

Title: Madhya Pradesh: 6 babies die in 13 hours in govt hospital, BJP alleges negligence
Content:
This story is from January 15, 2020

Minister Kamleshwar Patel at district hospital in Shahdol.

BHOPAL: Six tribal infants died in a span of 13 hours at Shahdol district hospital in Madhya Pradesh between Monday evening and Tuesday morning, triggering allegations of negligence.

Officials, however, said all these children were ailing and some had been brought to the hospital in a critical condition. There were no lapses by medical staff, they said. Health minister Tulsi Silawat has ordered a probe and promised action if anyone is found guilty of negligence.

Two of the infants had been admitted there for around a fortnight. Two were in the general ward and the remaining two were in the special neonatal care unit (SNCU) and paediatric ICU of the hospital, say sources. All the babies are below six months of age.

Three of the deaths happened in a span of four hours — first, Subhash, son of Jhalumanu Baiga of Harratola village at 6.50pm in the paediatric ward, followed by Anjali, daughter Majhlu Baiga of Kotma region, in the same ward at 7.30pm, and then an infant, Chaiti Kumari, born to Balak Das of Kharla at 10.50pm. A fourth infant Shyam Narayan son of Narmada Kol resident of Amliha died at 3.30am on January 14 in PICU, followed by a fifth — baby Suraj, son of Santlal Baiga of Padmaniya village — at 6am. The sixth death was in SNCU — Phoolmati Singh, daughter of Lal Singh of Bhatigama village — at 7.50am.

Chief medical and health officer Rajesh Pandey said, “Of the six, two were brought to the hospital in critical condition and were admitted to SNCU for more than 15 days. Three others had pneumonia in a late condition. All of them were given proper treatment and assistance of doctors from the medical college was also taken. It is a tragic coincidence that six babies died. On an average, 1-2 paediatric deaths are reported daily at the district hospital.”

Pandey said rural development and panchayati raj minister Kamleshwar Patel, who is in charge of Shahdol, and the collector visited the hospital after the deaths. “A high-level team will probe the incident and submit its report soon, based on which action will be taken against,” Patel said.

Health minister was holding a review meeting of the health department when reports of the six deaths came in. He expressed grief over the deaths and ordered a probe by the district collector and CMHO. Appropriate action will be taken if any negligence is found, he said.

The BJP demanded action against those responsible. “It’s heart-rending to hear of the death of several children in paediatrics ward in Kushabhau Thakre Hospital, Shahdol. I pray to the Almighty to give courage to the family of the deceased to bear this loss. This is due to gross negligence and lack of facilities in the hospital,” said former chief minister Shivraj Singh Chouhan, adding: “Kamal Nath ji, how long will it continue to play with the lives of innocent children under your rule? God will not forgive your government for this criminal negligence.”

BJP state vice-president and MLA Rameshwar Sharma said, “The MP government is working like its counterpart in Rajasthan. The government should take immediate action against those responsible for the negligence.”

Title: Tributes paid to army sepoy from Vizag dist
Content:
This story is from January 15, 2020

Visakhapatnam: The funeral of sepoy Sammingi Tulasi Ram was held in his home town Pitanivanipalem of Pedagantyada, Visakhapatnam with military honours with a ceremonial guard of the Navy in attendance on Tuesday.

Floral tributes were paid to the mortal remains of sepoy Tulasi Ram at Visakhapatnam airport on Monday. Sepoy Tulasi Ram of the Naga Regiment succumbed to a head injury when rocks fell on him during routine patrol.

Earlier, wreath laying ceremony with military honours was conducted at Shradhanjili Sthal at the airport by G Swaroopa Rani ACP (West) and Col DK Rai, the Station HQs (Army) Visakhapatnam on Monday night.

Title: Adolescent girls in govt schools to be sensitized on health & hygiene
Content:
This story is from January 15, 2020

Coimbatore: The school education department is all set to spread awareness on psychological and physical health among the adolescent girl students of government schools in the district. The move would benefit around 80,000 girl students studying in classes IX to XII in 174 government schools in the district.

The programme would be organized on January 24 to mark the ‘National Girl Child Day’.

Samagra Shiksha officials said under the programme they would bring doctors and psychologists to schools to spread awareness among the girl students on aspects of safety, health and hygiene.

“They would talk to the students on the importance of leading a healthy lifestyle, good touch/bad touch and menstrual hygiene,” said a Samagra Shiksha official. The programme would be held in all the 174 high and higher secondary government schools in the district, he said.

According to the official, in each school one lady teacher should be assigned to make the girl students aware of the adolescent phase and deal with adolescence issues. The programme aims to inculcate values and self-confidence into the girl students, while ensuring their emotional wellbeing and helping them develop good social relationships.

The official said schools have been directed to conduct elocution, essay writing and drawing competitions for the girl students on topics such as women empowerment, physical health and women safety. “The competitions will be conducted in the week leading to January 24.”

Each school would be given a fund of Rs 1,539 for conducting the events. In Coimbatore, a total of Rs 2,67,786 has been disbursed, the official said.

The programme would be conducted in a total of 5,711 schools across the state.

The school education department has set aside a total fund of Rs 87,89,229 for the purpose.

Title: Bihar OKs Rs 120 crore to build homes for 33 lakh poor families
Content:
This story is from January 15, 2020

Bihar CM Nitish Kumar

PATNA: The state cabinet on Tuesday sanctioned Rs 120 crore for housing facility to around 33 lakh poor families , who had not been covered under the Pradhan Mantri Awas Yojana of the central government.

Briefing media after the cabinet meeting, rural development and housing department’s principal secretary Arvind Choudhary said 32.86 lakh housing units would be constructed under the CM Gramin Awas Yojana for the poor families. He said the houses will be built in phases depending on the availability of funds.

The cabinet also approved the proposal to provide pucca houses to the SC/ST and Extremely Backward Classes (EBC) families affected by Acute Encephalitis Syndrome (AES) in Muzaffarpur district. Five blocks of Muzaffarpur — Kanti, Minapur, Aurai, Musahari and Bochaha — were identified as worst hit by AES last year. A total of 164 children below the age of 15 years had died during treatment at the SKMCH and Kejriwal Matri Sadan in Muzaffarpur in 2019.

The cabinet also cleared the health department’s proposal to upgrade the Purnia Medical College and Hospital from 300-bed to 500-bed facility. A sum of Rs87.78 crore was sanctioned for the that.

Principal secretary of health department Sanjay Kumar said the cabinet gave administrative approval of Rs78.50 crore for setting up advance molecular microbiology and molecular genomics lab at the IGIMS, Patna.

In yet another important decision, the cabinet sanctioned Rs329 crore for setting up schools up to Class IX in every panchayat. Additional 2750 classes in altogether 2950 primary schools in the panchayats, which were upgraded to middle schools, were required to meet the demand.

The cabinet also sanctioned Rs45.67 crore for renovation of altogether 7,319 wells in rural areas under Jal-Jeevan-Hariyali scheme of the state government. In the first phase, the renovation of 1068 wells will be completed. A total of 14 proposals were approved at the meeting chaired by chief minister Nitish Kumar .

Title: Mohite-Patil takes a dig at NCP for acting against 6 members
Content:
This story is from January 15, 2020

Kolhapur: Sharp differences in the Nationalist Congress Party ( NCP ) in Solapur district have resurfaced with the supporters of former deputy chief minister Vijaysinh Mohite-Patil who voted for zilla parishad president election for BJP challenging party leadership to take action against deputy chief minister Ajit Pawar.

Jaysinh Mohite-Patil, younger brother of Vijaysinh, reacted sharply on NCP’s action against six of its members under the anti-defection act. All the six members, who voted for BJP, were suspended from the party with action under anti-defection act being sought against them. NCP leaders have submitted a letter to the district collector for violating party’s whip.

Jaysinh Mohite-Patil said, “We are not weak as considered by party leaders. The party should first take action against Ajit Pawar for taking oath of deputy chief minister early in the morning. NCP should act against six zilla parishad members later”.

Jaysinh Mohite-Patil criticized the party’s leadership by giving examples of some incidents in Solapur district where the NCP did not take any action against its members for defying the party’s decision.

Addressing the media, Jaysinh recalled that a group of NCP members voted for Sanjay Shinde in the zilla parishad election, but the party did not act on it.

Citing another example, Jaysinh said that a few members also voted against Dilip Salunkhe Patil in the election for legislative council, but the party did not take any action against them. “The party should not threaten us”, he said.

Political rivalry between Pawar and Mohite-Patil family resurfaced when six members of Mohite-Patil voted for BJP in the zilla parishad election. Two of the six members, who are facing party action, are from Mohite-Patil family.

The NCP leaders were aiming to capture zilla parishad from BJP following the formation of the Thackeray government. BJP retained power in Solapur despite all the non-BJP parties coming together in the election.

Mohite-Patil family has adopted the anti- NCP stand since the Lok Sabha elections when few of its members had joined BJP. The Mohite-Patil family has played a crucial role in the defeat of NCP in the prestigious Madha constituency.

Title: Promises galore, yet poll season fails to bring cheers to slum dwellers
Content:
This story is from January 15, 2020

New Delhi: Even as AAP, BJP and Congress are fighting a pitched battle to garner votes in the name of slum dwellers , proper housing and even basic amenities are still a distant dream for most of them living across the city.

Targeting the vote bank in slums, incumbent chief minister Arvind Kejriwal has announced that pucca houses would be provided to those living in jhuggi clusters under the Mukhyamantri Awas Yojana. The AAP government, through Delhi Urban Shelter Improvement Board, even carried out a survey and identified more than 65,000 such families living in 156 slum clusters across the capital. Similarly, the BJP government at the Centre has announced that the DDA would soon float bids for in-situ slum redevelopment to benefit at least 10 lakh people while the Congress has announced that 25-square-metre flats in multi-storey buildings would be provided to such residents, if they are voted to power.

Despite the tall promises and political war of words, there is much concern and apprehension among slum dwellers ahead of the assembly polls early next month.

Manbir Singh, a peanut seller who has been living in Yamuna Bazar slum for over 26 years, said, “This area which many consider to be a garbage dump is our home. Our families have lived here for decades.” “Except a public toilet, we don’t have any basic facilities here. Not even a proper drinking water or electricity connection. A proper house is too big a dream for us. Even my Aadhaar was made when we were settled near the flyover. Those huts were demolished for the beautification of the city. That document is also useless for me now,” he added.

When asked why he didn’t apply for an electoral ID card, he said, “We are already struggling with our lives. If we stand in long queues to bring to power governments that don’t care for us, what is the point anyway?”

The state of affairs in the other slums is also hardly any different.

Sharda Sharma, who has been living in Delhi slums for three decades after escaping from the clutches of her violent in-laws in Maharashtra, said, “No government representative came to my aid when my house in Majnu ka Tilla was usurped by a gangster when I fell sick. However, I brought the guilty to book with the help of fellow slum dwellers.”

Rajwati, 60, from a slum in East of Kailash adds, “No government bothers about our problems, be it the present one or any other.”

Meanwhile, Raju Punjabi, who lives in a shack near Kalkaji Mandir, said, “I got my voter ID card made this year itself. However, I am not sure whether I will cast my vote or not as I have no faith in any political party. Only the new generation can do something for the betterment of people like us. I have faith in the youth. They have to lead the way.”

Title: BJP state gen secy says Modi comparison is ‘honour of Shivaji’
Content:
This story is from January 15, 2020

Kolhapur: There was a lot more brewing than just the BJP’s Kolhapur district president on Tuesday.

After BJP functionaries elected Samarjeetsinha Ghatge the district president of the party, BJP state general secretary Suresh Halwankar decided to jump into the controversy surrounding the new book “Aaj ke Shivaji: Narendra Modi’, which compared the prime minister with the Maratha king. Throwing his weight behind the book, Halwankar went on to say that the comparison was, in fact, an honour to Chhatrapati Shivaji Maharaj.

Halwankar said: “I support the writer. It is not wrong to compare Narendra Modi with Shivaji Maharaj. The comparison is an honour of Shivaji Maharaj. Shivaji Maharaj cared for the farmers. Narendra Modi has started the scheme for the farmers to pay money directly into their account.”

The statement was made while state BJP chief Chandrakant Patil was sitting on the dais. Patil said that a fuss is being made on the issue which is not directly related to BJP. “Congress never gave honour to the families of Shivaji Maharaj and Shahu Maharaj. NCP defeated descendants of Shivaji Maharaj. On the other hand, Modi and Amit Shah have honoured them. We had a choice of inducting Sambhajiraje Chhatrapati into BJP, however Modi, said it will be an honour to Shahu Maharaj if Sambhajiraje is nominated by President in Rajya Sabha. The writer of the book has remained a member of Shiv Sena for 25 years. The book has been banned,” he said.

New dist BJP president slams loan waiver scheme

Meanwhile, newly-elected district president of BJP Samarjeetsinha Ghatge said the loan waiver by the state government is a bluff and he will organise a protest march of farmers soon. Ghatge belongs to the royal family of Kagal. His father, Vikramsinha Ghatge, was a long-time parliamentarian.

Title: Brick kilns continue to mine red earth despite TNPCB notices, say residents
Content:
This story is from January 15, 2020

Coimbatore: Two months after the Tamil Nadu Pollution Control Board (TNPCB) and the department of mines had sent show-cause notices to unauthorised brick kilns in Thadagam and surrounding areas, the brick kilns are continuing to function as before, said residents and activists from the area.

Official sources, meanwhile, said a state-level team had recently conducted a field-level independent assessment of the region and is expected to come up with a course of action soon.

In October 2019, the office of the district environment engineer, Coimbatore north, had sent show-cause notices to 183 brick kilns in Thadagam and surrounding areas such as Chinna Thadagam, Veerapandi and Nanjundapuram near the city after complaints that brick kilns were mining red earth and causing air pollution.

It was mentioned in the notices that the kiln units were ‘operating without the consent of the board under Section 21 of the Air (Prevention and Control of Pollution) Act’. The kiln owners were given 15 days to reply why penal action should not be initiated against them and warned that non-receipt of reply would attract penal action.

However, residents said nothing seemed to happen since then. S Ganesh, a resident from the area, who has been fighting against unauthorised soil mining, said their RTI replies revealed that none of the kilns had necessary approvals or permissions. “Without the permission from the pollution control board, the kilns were given electricity connections, which is a violation,” he said.

Pollution control board officials from Coimbatore north said they were looking into the issue and the investigation was in progress.

Official sources, meanwhile, said a state-level team had come around five days ago and conducted a field-level independent assessment of the existing pattern of operations of the kilns and the possibility of modernising them, to control pollution. Sources said they expected the team to come up with the further course of action soon.

Also, a case against the mines has been filed by a group of activists from the region and probe is being carried out.

Title: Father-son duo held for cheating businessman of Rs 1.8 crore
Content:
This story is from January 15, 2020

Representative image

COIMBATORE: A father-son duo were arrested on Monday night by the crime branch police for cheating an iron merchant by not paying him Rs 1.8 crore for the consignment they had purchased.

Police identified the accused as Paramasivam, 65, and his son P Prabhu, 40, of Race Course in the city. They were running an iron-works unit at Pappanaickenpalayam. They had purchased raw material worth Rs 1.8 crore from Ganesh Babu, an iron dealer in the city. But they were delaying the payment.

To compensate the payment, the father-son duo, meanwhile registered their land at Aruppukkottai in Ganesh Prabhu’s name. But later they fraudulently sold a part of the land to another person. Upon knowing this, Ganesh Babu confronted them. But the duo threatened him.

Following this, Ganesh Babu lodged a complaint with the crime branch police, who registered a case and arrested the duo.

Title: Kid abducted in Chennai found in Dindigul
Content:
This story is from January 15, 2020

Representative image

CHENNAI: A two-year-old girl, who was kidnapped from MGR Chennai Central railway station early on Monday, was rescued the same day at Dindigul railway station by the Government Railway Police personnel after they were alerted by a few passengers travelling by the Mumbai-Nagercoil Express.

The passengers, who noticed the man begging with the girl who was continuously crying, questioned the man. They found his replies unsatisfactory and realised the girl may have been kidnapped and they informed GRP police personnel at Dindigul railway station.

Police identified the accused as Deepak Mandal, 32, a native of West Bengal.

The police officers rushed to the spot, questioned Mandal and confirmed he had kidnapped Rejitha, 2, when she was sleeping beside her mother Marjina from Guwahati, Assam.

After the rescue, the girl brought to Chennai Central railway station and reunited with her mother before the two were sent back home by train. Police said Mandal, who had been doing odd jobs and staying on the footpath on Walltax Road was sent to jail.

A police inspector said, “Deepak who boarded the Dhanbad-Alappuzha Express with Rejitha got down at Salem and boarded the Mumbai-Nagercoil Express. He begged on the train, with the child in his arms, and after a few passengers objected and questioned him, he got off at Dindigul railway station. Railway police there secured him and informed us.” Mandal allegedly kidnapped the girl after a quarrel with Marjina’s husband Hameed.

The GRP personnel said Marjina and Hameed came with their daughters Hajitha, 4, and Rejitha to Chennai Central about 10 days ago where they met Mandal. “Hameed and Deepak used the two-year-girl to beg on the station premises with the knowledge of her mother,” said police. Marjina was a construction worker in the city.

Meanwhile, the city police released the photos of an eight-month-old boy who was kidnapped from Rajiv Gandhi Government General Hospital on Sunday by a woman. “RGGGH inspector E Sasi can be contacted on 99401 01363,” said a release.

Title: FASTag compulsory at toll plazas from today
Content:
This story is from January 15, 2020

Kolhapur: Toll plaza across Kolhapur will have only one lane for cash payment from Tuesday, while all other lanes will have electronic toll collection system through FASTags .

FASTag has become mandatory for all vehicles travelling on National Highway from January 15. According to an official from the National Highway Authority of India (NHAI), the cash lane will be kept open for few days where instructions will be given to the motorists to get the FASTags as early as possible.

“Only 40% of the total toll is collected through electronic transaction at Kini toll plaza on the Pune-Bangalore national highway,” he said.

The ministry of road transport and highways had last month stated that vehicles the electronic payment lanes without FASTags will have to pay double toll. “The penalty will force the motorists to get FASTags instead of paying double toll or spending time in long queues manual toll fee lanes,” the official said.

The government had earlier declared that no vehicle will be allowed to pass through the toll plaza without FASTag from December 1. However, the deadline was extended to December 15 stating it will be mandatory for all vehicles to have the FASTags.

The government again extended the deadline to January 15 and it was decided to keep one lane for collecting toll through cash for time being and once all vehicles have FASTags, all lanes will be closed for collecting tolls through cash.

Title: Vizhinjam police start PSC coaching camp
Content:
This story is from January 15, 2020

Thiruvananthapuram: Vizhinjam Janamaithri police have found a novel method to keep the youngsters of the coastal area away from illegal activities and to bring them to the mainstream of society. They have launched a free PSC coaching camp for these youngsters, which was inaugurated by city police commissioner Balram Kumar at a function held at the police station here on Monday.

The initiative, as part of improving the relations between police and the youth of the coastal belt, was launched in collaboration with people’s representatives, voluntary organisations and residents’ associations.

During his inaugural address, the city police commissioner said the first batch of the PSC coaching camp will be accommodating 60 students residing within the Vizhinjam police station limits, and the applications will be accepted till Saturday. “This coaching camp inside the police station will act as a centre to help the youngsters from these coastal communities to get themselves register with the PSC and to have a proper direction in life rather than to engage in criminal, illegal and immoral activities involving alcohol and drugs,” the police commissioner said.

Kumar also took the opportunity to laud civil police officer Jose and community relation officer Sharaffudheen who had come up with the initiative.

“This is a first-of-its-kind initiative by police in the district. The classes will be taken by expert teachers and police personnel of Vizhinjam station. Besides, we are planning to organise a pulse polio camp at the station from 10am to 12pm on Sunday as a part of pulse polio immunization programme,” said S B Praveen, the station house officer inspector who presided over the function.

More details about the coaching camp can be had over the phone: 9400133559 or 9061557825.

Title: Patient delivers baby girl at mental hospital
Content:
This story is from January 15, 2020

The girl will be handed over to Shraddhanand Anathalaya

Nagpur: A mentally unstable woman, who was admitted to the Regional Mental Hospital (RMH) in the city four months ago in pregnant condition, gave birth to a healthy girl on January 13.

The woman was found loitering around by Hinganghat police in Wardha district . As the woman, aged around 35, was unable to tell her whereabouts and identified herself only as Pinky, the police had produced her in a court which ordered her hospitalization.

Police suspect that the woman could be from Wadner town near Hinganghat. Cops had even called some Wadner residents to the RMH for identification of the woman. However, all residents denied having seen the woman in their town.

After the delivery, the woman has been admitted to Government Medical College and Hospital (GMCH) while the baby will soon be handed over to an orphanage.

“Many such mentally unstable persons from across Vidarbha are admitted to the RMH regularly,” said Dr Madhuri Thorat, medical superintendent of the hospital.

According to the medical officer, the patient has several mental health issues including dyslexia. She was more than six months pregnant when brought to the hospital. The woman is addicted to tobacco and becomes very aggressive sometimes and because of which the newborn cannot stay with her, said the doctor.

“Initially, the woman had contracted several infections and was treated at the mental hospital for two months. As she was expecting, we tried to shift her to a nursing home at Shraddhanand Anathalaya. But, it became difficult for the staff there to handle her as she used to turn hyper quite often,” Dr Thorat added.

Finally, RMH authorities decided to bring her back and keep in a separate ward. A medical officer having specialization in gynaecology was appointed to ensure her safe delivery. Pregnancy kit was kept ready from last two weeks, the doctor said.

“The woman had a normal delivery and she gave birth to a healthy girl weighing 2.250kg. Both were shifted to the GMCH for further care. At present, both have been kept in separate wards. “As the mother will not be able to handle the baby, the girl will be handed over to Shraddhanand Anathalaya,” said Dr Thorat. The woman will be shifted back to mental hospital for further treatment and rehabilitation.

Title: Scarcity of meat in city; will take 2-3 days for normal supply
Content:
This story is from January 15, 2020

Kolhapur: After eight days of protest, mutton shops in the city have opened; however, the sellers said that it will take at least two to three days for regularising the supply as they are falling short of sheep and goats.

The meat sellers said that they are ready to sell mutton at Rs 520 per kg. Out of 154 mutton shops in the city, very few had meat stock. The sellers said that they have to visit places such as Sangli, Satara and other districts of Marathwada to get healthy sheep and goats.

Vijay Kamble, member of mutton sellers association said, “For the next couple of days, the supply of mutton will be low as there is a scarcity of healthy goats and sheep in the market. The meat is a perishable product and cannot be stored for a long time. We have to visit faraway places to get healthy goats and sheep. We expect the supply to be regularised in the next two to three days.”

As there is less demand of meat on festivals such as Makar Sankranti, meat sellers have set off on their quest to find good quality and healthy goats and sheep as people are likely to throng meat shops in a day or two once the festival is over. To ensure adequate supply of meat to the customers, sellers have began visiting the neighbouring districts in search of healthy animals.

Meanwhile, some mutton sellers said that the rules of the food and drugs administration (FDA) to ensure the sanitation in the shops will require huge funds. In such cases, selling mutton at Rs 520 per kg is digging a huge hole in their pockets.

“We have for a table made up of steel which is quite expensive. Also, we have to make all the arrangements for disposing the waste which again requires money. We will request price hike of the mutton in next couple of months,” a mutton seller said on the condition of anonymity.

Title: HC censures TNPSC over denial of post
Content:
This story is from January 15, 2020

Chennai: Pulling up the Tamil Nadu Public Service Commission (TNPSC) for its callouses and insensitive action in rejecting candidature of a person under reserved category in recruitment for a civil judge post, despite production of a valid community certificate, the Madras high court observed that the premier recruiting agency clothed with constitutional status cannot abdicate its constitutional responsibility and deal with the claims of reserved candidates in a cavalier fashion.

A division bench of Justice V Bharathidasan and Justice V Parthiban made the scathing observation while concurring with the submissions of senior advocate P Wilson and setting aside the rejection order of the commission dated December 5, 2018 and accept the community certificate produced by the petitioner and allow him to participate in further proceedings of the recruitment process.

“This is a fit case on hand that the action of the commission in rejecting the candidature of the petitioner to be discountenanced outright. The impugned decision by the commission, in the opinion of this court, is borne out of bureaucratic callousness and insensitivity, stifling the constitutional right of the candidate aspiring for public appointment on the basis of socially disadvantaged status and therefore, the same is liable to set aside,” the bench said.

Petitioner A K Anand said he participated in the recruitment called for by TNPSC for the posts of civil judges in the Tamil Nadu state judicial service for the vacancies of 2014-15 to 2016-17. As he cleared the preliminary and written examinations, he was called for certification on October 1, 2018 after provisionally admitting him for oral test under scheduled caste category,” his senior counsel Wilson told the court.

When certificates were produced by the petitioner, it was found that the community certificate produced by him was not found in the prescribed format. Therefore, he obtained time to produce the same in the necessary format. On November 28, 2018, he mailed the certificate through registered post to the commission. However, his name was left out in the list of provisionally selected candidate, Wilson added.

Aggrieved, the petitioner approached the court through the present plea. Allowing the plea, the bench directed the commission to complete the selection process in eight weeks.

Title: Suspect in Jaysingpur theft case identified
Content:
This story is from January 15, 2020

Kolhapur: Kolhapur police have identified a suspect involved in stealing mobile phones from Jaysingpur police station, adding that they have launched a manhunt to nab him.

Kishor Kale, deputy superintendent of police, Jaysingpur division, said, “We have recovered the CCTV footage from shops and other places located on the backside of the police station where the incident took place and have spotted one suspect walking on a road holding some material — probably stolen mobile phones — from the police station. Based on the footage, we have started gathering information about the criminals on police record from the Jaysingpur area, other police stations in the district as well as the neighbouring Sangli district.”

Police said that they are using the latest technology and other methods to nab the suspect.

“We are also using the call details of the stolen mobile phones that would help us to find out if the suspect has used any of them. If he has, it can help us in tracing his location,” he said.

Title: Tirupur cluster sees increase in fabric and garment thefts
Content:
This story is from January 15, 2020

Tirupur: Fabric and garment thefts have increased in apparel units in recent years in Tirupur. More than 10 cases including two murders were registered in connection with such thefts in the district.

On November 13, 2017, K Muthusamy of Thirumalai Nagar in Ganapathipalayam near Palladam was found murdered in a unit run by his son in Kavundapalayam Pudur. The unit was providing service of drying fabrics which were dyed in other dyeing units. Police registered the case and found that fabrics worth Rs 10 lakh were stolen after tying the 75-year-old Muthusamy, who was donning the role of night watchman in the unit. Police arrested four accused and recovered the stolen fabrics.

On contrast, S Murugesan, 37, who was working as watchman in a knitwear unit in Anaipudur, was beaten to death after he allegedly tried to steal a few kids garments from the unit on December 25, 2019. Police said Murugesan had tried to steal the garments to gift them to his niece. When the incident came to light, eight employees of the unit allegedly beat him, and he eventually died.

Among other such cases, at least three cases came to light after accused were caught red-handed while stealing the goods. In August 2018, yarns worth Rs 68 lakh were stolen while transporting near Nallur.

A knitwear unit owner said, “Nowadays, the production costs have increased, and so, it may tempt such employees or others to steal the fabrics. In Tirupur cluster, most of the apparel units would depend on other units for one process or other. The fabrics or garments would be moving often, and so, it is always important to maintain proper records along with continuous monitoring.”

A senior police officer said, “All those thefts were involved mostly by employees of the apparel units concerned or of other units who have knowledge about the garments or fabrics. In most of cases, the owners of the units would not monitor the day to day affairs properly, and the theft would have come out only when final tally of goods witness a shortage.”

Another police officer said, “It is important that the knitwear unit owners should inform about the theft immediately to the police once it has surfaced, instead of beating the culprit up.”

Title: Man held within hour of killing friend in Chennai
Content:
This story is from January 15, 2020

Representative image

CHENNAI: A man who on Monday murdered his friend for verbally abusing him at Mylapore was arrested within an hour of committing the crime.

The Mylapore police said Mohan, 50, of Pallaku Ma Nagar, was a friend of Lokesh, 26.

They often drank together. While Mohan was into catering services, Lokesh was a labourer.

Lokesh got married five years ago and has a child. His wife was upset over Lokesh’s addiction to liquor despite financial problem the family was facing. The couple would often quarrel.

During one such fight a couple of months ago, his wife deserted him and went to live with her mother. She had also taken her son along. Meanwhile, Lokesh and Mohan met and decided to drink liquor at the former’s house on Monday night.

Even as they were talking, an argument broke out when Lokesh teased Mohan. Mohan in turn verbally abused him saying he was unfit to lead a marital life and that was the reason his wife ditched him. Angry, Lokesh stabbed him with a kitchen knife repeatedly. Bleeding profusely, Mohan managed to leave Lokesh’s house but collapsed on the way. Some people took Mohan to Government Royapettah hospital where he was declared dead. Police managed to nab Lokesh from his house. He was remanded in judicial custody.

Title: Disagreement over Amma Vodi money ends in suicide
Content:
This story is from January 15, 2020

Tirupati: A 35-year-old woman, Ratnala Adi Lakshmi, at Nettigunta village, Chittoor district, on Tuesday committed suicide following an altercation with her husband on how to utilise the Amma Vodi benefit money.

Speaking to TOI, Ratnala Maheswara, husband of Adi Lakshmi, said they had an argument on Tuesday morning over how to use the money, which they received as financial assistance from the government under the Amma Vodi scheme.

“As part of the scheme, Rs 15,000 was credited by the state government to my wife Adi Lakshmi’s account. She went to the bank and withdrew Rs 10,000 and came home. She told me she was planning to buy something for her children. But I asked her to spend the money on our household needs to which she did not agree. We argued over it,” he added.

Moments after the argument, Adi Lakshmi in a fit of rage rushed to the backyard of the house and consumed pesticides and collapsed on the floor. Later, finding her unconscious, Maheswara rushed her to the government hospital at Madanapalli. But she died while undergoing treatment.

Following a complaint registered by the relatives of Adi Lakshmi, the police have registered a case.

Title: MLA celebrates Pongal with school kids
Content:
This story is from January 15, 2020

Erode: Andhiyur MLA E M R Raja alias Rajakrishnan celebrated the Pongal with government school students on Tuesday. He also participated in the cultural programmes organized by them.

The MLA was the chief guest at the Pongal celebrations at the government girls’ higher secondary school in Andhiyur. He addressed the gathering and highlighted the importance of Pongal festival. He said the festival was usually celebrated on the first day of the Tamil month of ‘Thai’. “This festival is celebrated to worship Sun god,” he said.

Later, he cooked pongal with students and teachers. He also participated in the pujas.

Overwhelmed with the arrangement, the MLA eagerly participated in the cultural programmes that were organized by the school management.

Hundreds of students encouraged the MLA to give a shot at Uri adithal. After a few attempts, the MLA succeeded in the challenge.

He also danced with the students on the occasion.

Title: Kolkata: Left side still paralyzed, but student injured by javelin now stable, says doctor
Content:
The javelin was removed in an emergency surgery at SSKM’s Trauma Care Centre on Monday night

KOLKATA: The Class VI student whose head was pierced by a javelin during the school sports meet on Monday is out of ventilation. Doctors at SSKM Hospital, where Sourajit Bera is being treated, said his condition was stable though his left side was still paralyzed.“Bon kothai achhe? Bhalo achhe toh (Where is my sister? Is she fine?)” was the first thing the boy asked his uncle Harish Bera on Tuesday morning when family members were allowed to meet him for the first time since Monday’s surgery.The student of Narayan Chandra Vidyapith in Howrah ’s Shyampur was hit by a javelin during the school’s annual sports event on Monday afternoon. The javelin was removed in an emergency surgery at SSKM’s Trauma Care Centre on Monday night. But the injury has left his left side paralyzed.“He gave me a smile and asked if I could get him a cell phone so that he could play games to get some relief from the pain. My nice is a brave boy. He did not cry once or lose consciousness on way to hospital even with the javelin jutting out of his head,” said Harish.Sourajit was first rushed to the nearby Uluberia State General Hospital for treatment, from where he was referred to SSKM. At the Trauma Care Centre, the team of neurosurgeons wasted no time. After conducting emergency tests and imaging, the boy was wheeled into the OT around 6pm. “The pointed end of the javelin had hit the right side of his head, piercing about 4cm into the brain. The motor cortex was injured, which resulted in paralysis on the left side,” said Subhasis Ghosh, head of the neurosurgery department at SSKM Hospital. Motor cortex is in the rear portion of the frontal lobe and is responsible for generating neuro impulses that control the execution of movement.“He is off the ventilation now and his parameters are normal. But we will continue to monitor him for the next couple of days to rule out infection before we start the treatment for paralysis,” said Ghosh.A team from the physical medicine department was roped in for Sourajit’s treatment on Tuesday. This team will take over once the boy recovers from the surgery. “The surgery team has done a wonderful job. We will examine the extent of the paralysis once he is out of ICU and try to do our best to tackle the paralysis issue,” said Rajesh Pramanik of the physical medicine department.“Sourajit looked a little worried as he could not move his left hand. I assured him that the doctors will take care of that as well,” said mother Rina. The family, however, questioned the school authority’s failure to ensure safety of children during the sports meet.

Title: Farmers in Andhiyur extend shallot cultivation period
Content:
This story is from January 15, 2020

ERODE: With growing demand and supportive rainfall in the last couple of months, farmers in Andhiyur block in the district have extended shallot cultivation period .

M A Chinnasamy Gounder, a farmer, said, “We have cultivated shallots for nearly 5,000 acres in Andhiyur block.”

Price of shallots crossed Rs 200 in local markets in the last three months.

On seeing the upward trend, many of farmers, who usually prefer sugarcane or any other pulses this season, turned to cultivate shallots with expectation of bumper harvest.

Usually, shallots are cultivated in May-June and October-November.

“After seeing high demand, we have extended it up to January,” T Madhavan , another farmer, said.

Shallot is cultivated in Dindigul, Tirupur, Perambalur, Trichy and Namakkal districts in the state.

“Now, we have given our produce to meet the demand for our district,” a farmer added. Usually, farmers in the district will harvest eight tonnes of shallots per hectare. Due to good spell, this time they have got 12 tonnes per hectare.

“Due to good rain, this year we have harvested good quality of shallots,” a farmer said, adding that they would realise good profit in the local market.

Rate for shallots in the local market stood between Rs 90 and Rs 120, depending on the quality and size.

Title: Cockfights continue across Andhra Pradesh despite court ban
Content:
This story is from January 15, 2020

A cockfighting racket at Pragadavaram village in West Godavari district

VIJAYAWADA: Court orders and police warnings have failed to curb cockfights across the state, particularly in Krishna , Guntur and East and West Godavari districts.

Arenas for the bloodsport have come up in the two Godavari districts while lakhs of rupees changed hands in betting on the sport on the first day. The sport, which involves a fight between two specially-bred roosters with small knives or blades tied around their legs, usually ends with the death of one of the birds.

In defiance of the law, LED screens were installed at several venues and the sport telecast to the crowd. While raids were conducted at some places, the popularity of the event in coastal districts raises a challenge for law-enforcement agencies. In Nellore, police arrested nine persons and seized eight cockerels and Rs 27,560 in cash.

Police said punters from various cities, including Hyderabad and Bengaluru, place bets on the roosters. The scale of betting can range anywhere between Rs 25,000 to Rs 2 lakh on each rooster.

Police added that cockfight arenas must have CCTV cameras and the programme be completed by 6 pm. Mandal revenue officers (MROs), along with police officers, have formed committees to ensure no cockfight is organised. Though the police claimed that they are prepared to crack down on organisers, they remain apprehensive that the number of cockfights will increase over the next few days.

Meanwhile, organisers of Sankranti Sambaralu are requested to attain permission from the respective police station by submitting an application that contains the name of the prgramme, the address and consent of the owner of the venue.

Citing animal cruelty, the high court had banned cockfights in 2016. The ban was later upheld by the Supreme Court.

Title: online job scam nigerian arrested
Content:
This story is from January 15, 2020

Kolawole Boboye

Thiruvananthapuram: Cyber police officials under crime branch have arrested a Nigerian citizen who is a key member of a gang that has swindled huge amounts of money from a city resident after offering job abroad.

Kolawole Boboye, 26, was nabbed from his hideout in Mumbai following an elaborate investigation. He was brought here on Tuesday following which his arrest was recorded at Thiruvananthapuram cyber police station. He was produced before the court and remanded in judicial custody.

According to the cyber police, Boboye was arrested based on a complaint filed by a city resident, Nandana. As per her complaint, she was approached by the gang, who pretended as a job-consultancy agency, offering the job of a nurse at Flowers Hospital situated in the city of Dothan in the United States of America. They also offered help to arrange visas for her entire family so that she could relocate to the US along with the family. The accused convinced her to deposit Rs 13 lakh in instalments. The money was deposited to bank accounts as per their instructions. After a point of time, the complainant grew suspicious about the gang as they kept demanding to deposit more money. Following this, she filed a complaint before the cyber police.

Police first took details of the bank accounts in which the money was deposited and found out that they belonged to branches scattered across the country. However, police found out that the emails that the gang sent to the complainant originated from Maharashtra. Further probe into the withdrawal of money from the accounts revealed that all withdrawals were made through ATMs in Mumbai city. Thus, a team of officials set out to Mumbai, under the directions of DIG (Thiruvananthapuram) Kori Sanjay Kumar Gurudin, who managed to locate the accused and take him into custody.

The team that caught the accused included cyber inspector H Mohammed Khan, sub-inspectors Aneesh Karim and Biju Lal K N and civil police officers V U Vijesh and P Anish.

Police said a probe was on to track down the other members of the gang, which include both Nigerian citizens as well as Indian citizens. Police have confiscated SIM cards, debit cards, laptops and bank passbooks, from which they expect to get vital information about the remaining members of the gang.

Title: Cop on Uttarayani Mela duty killed in accident
Content:
This story is from January 15, 2020

Nainital: A policeman, identified as Chetan Gangwar, died after his motorbike hit a barricade in the Subhash Nagar area near Lalkuan in Nainital district. Gangwar was travelling from his home in Kichha area of Udham Singh Nagar district to Lalkuan for duty at Uttarayani Mela .

Police said that Gangwar was posted at Bhimtal police station and was travelling on his bike late on Monday when the incident took place.

“He was taken to Haldwani hospital where he was undergoing treatment, but later succumbed to his injuries,” Nainital SSP Sunil Kumar Meena said.

After conducting postmortem, the body was handed over to his family in Kichha.

Meanwhile, in another accident, Sujeet Mandal, 24, who was going back from Nainital died after his bike hit a car in Shakti Farm area of Nainital district.

Police said that the incident took place on Monday when Sujeet along with his three friends was returning from Nainital.

Title: Fresh spell of rain, snow in offing from Jan 16
Content:
This story is from January 15, 2020

Dehradun: A fresh spell of rain and snow will lash Uttarakhand on January 16 and 17, which is likely to bring back cold conditions in the Himalayan state.

According to regional meteorological centre, a strong western disturbance is going to have an impact on the weather conditions in Uttarakhand from January 16 onwards.

“Higher reaches in the hill districts, mainly located at an altitude of 2,500 and above, are likely to witness snowfall, while the plains and foothills are going to receive moderate to heavy rainfall,” said Bikram Singh, director of meteorological center.

Significantly, the Met office issued a yellow-color warning of hail at isolated places in Dehradun, Pauri, Udham Singh Nagar, Nainital and Haridwar districts on January 16 and 17.

Besides, heavy snowfall is predicted in the higher reaches of Uttarkashi, Pithoragarh, Rudraprayag and Chamoli districts on January 16.

Mercury is also likely to see a sharp drop once again across Uttarkahand following rain and snowfall activity. Notably, the temperatures have surged and settled around normal or above normal in most of the places due to clear weather conditions.

On Tuesday, the maximum temperature in Dehradun was recorded at 22 degrees Celsius, about three notches above normal. The mercury in daytime hovered around 22 degrees Celsius in Pantnagar too.

Title: After two rescues, illegal pet breeders in city under scanner
Content:
This story is from January 15, 2020

canine cruelty: Puppies were found in unhygienic conditions without adequate food or water in illegal breeding... Read More

Thiruvananthapuram: Federation of Indian Animal Protection Organisations (FIAPO) and People for Animals (PFA) volunteers in the city have launched a campaign against the illegal breeding and sale of pets. This comes against the backdrop of two consecutive rescues of dogs and puppies from two illegal breeders, in Chenthitta , who claimed to be affiliated to the Kerala Kennel Club. FIAPO has registered a case against Sarath — one of the two — with Thampanoor police station.

According to FIAPO district coordinator Parvathy Mohan, the dogs in both cases were found in unhygienic conditions without adequate food or drinking water. “On Sunday, we received information about an illegal breeder operating near the Chaithanya Ayurvedic Centre in Chenthitta, and on reaching the spot, we found three female labradors and around six puppies stacked in two cages which had not been cleaned for a while. The mother dogs looked famished. The meat found on one of the plates was at least two to three days old. We immediately contacted Thampanoor police, who helped us shift the dogs to a PFA shelter,” she said.

The second recovery was from a man near Chenthitta Railway Station Road on Monday. He has been given two days to ensure a hygienic shelter for his dogs. “Waste was found around the cages. The breeder claimed that he was unaware of rules and regulations. So we have given him two days’ time to shift the two rottweilers, three pugs and a labrador with three puppies to a hygienic shelter and 30 days to procure a licence from the State Animal Welfare Board. We will register a case against this breeder as well if he fails to comply,” Parvathy said.

According to Thampanoor sub inspector Jijukumar PD, a case invoking Prevention of Cruelty to Animals Act, 1960 and Dog Breeding and Marketing Rules, 2017 has been registered against one of the breeders. “As per the request of the complainant, the second breeder has been given time to meet regulations. We have registered a case against Sarath. His dogs have been moved to an authorised PFA shelter in Sasthamangalam” he said.

ENDS

Title: Husband murders pregnant wife, absconding
Content:
This story is from January 15, 2020

Kolhapur: A three-month pregnant woman was allegedly strangulated to death by her husband in Wadange village in Karveer taluka on Tuesday morning.

An officer at Karveer police station said that the husband is on the run since the incident. The deceased is identified as Sarika Vittal Mahanoor (21) from Wadange while her husband hails from Dalimba village in Umarga taluka.

The couple has been married since June 12, 2019. Her husband used to work as a cook at a Wadange hotel and use to reside in one of the hotel rooms. “The incident came to light when the owner of the hotel called the couple in the morning but did not receive any response from them. When he entered the room, he found Sarika’s body lying on the bed. He immediately informed her parents and the police,” said an officer.

The police said that there were marks on her neck and they suspect that he had beaten her before committing the crime . “The body has been sent for post-mortem. We are awaiting the report to confirm the cause of death. We have also launched a search operation to find out his whereabouts. A case has been registered against him with the Karveer police station,” he added.

Title: Dacoits held in Nellore, cash, phones recovered
Content:
This story is from January 15, 2020

Vijayawada: Police nabbed a gang of six dacoits who target youngsters by dressing up as women at Naidupet in Nellore district on Monday night.

The accused — Venkatagiri Sriram alias Hari (32), Amasya Venkata Ramana (38), Venkatagiri Raja (27), Kampa Venkateswarlu alias Annamaiah (26), Killa Alleiah (25) and Nemalapudi Venkateswarlu (25) — are all masons from Naidupet. Naidupet circle inspector G Venugopal Reddy said the incident happened on Sunday night.

Cops said the accused had attacked several men on National Highway 16. Venugopal said all the accused got drunk around 9 pm on Sunday and Hari dressed up as a woman by donning a wig and saree. He then intercepted bike seeking a lift. Within seconds, the rest of the accused pounced on the vehicle and thrashed the biker on the spot, stealing cash and gold among valuables. They then gave back the vehicle’s keys and walked away from the spot.

The cops arrested them from their homes. Police recovered Rs 8.8k, a wrist watch, two silver rings, two cellphones, earphones, a bag, a rug, pens and books together worth Rs 50,150.

A case under Section 341 and 395 of the IPC has been registered at Naidupet police station.

Title: Rajasthan youth ‘steals’ Kolkata cop poems, held
Content:
This story is from January 15, 2020

Representative image

KOLKATA: He had posed as an IPS officer who loved shayaris. But then, it was not ordinary when vegetable seller Vinod Ali from Jaipur in Rajasthan started to pass off the shayaris written by a senior IPS officer in Kolkata Police as his own.

As the IPS officer, whose love for Urdu and shayaris go much beyond police circles, decided to initially ignore, Ali did the unthinkable. He used multiple photographs of the IPS officer and began posting the poems written by the officer as his own. The cyber cell finally cracked the IP address and arrested Ali this weekend. But after some initial questioning, the cops did not contest his bail petition.

“I was convinced that he had no evil intention or motive. He loves shayaris genuinely and might have got a bit carried away. I am not one to take this personally,” said the IPS officer when TOI spoke to him on Tuesday.

Police sources said that Ali was asked to reveal the sources from where he collected the photographs of the officer. “He might have borrowed the pen name from a film he watched when he was young,” said the officer. The IPS officer has several published Urdu books in his name.

“Urdu is never a language of a particular community and around 75% of Urdu words have their etymological roots in Sanskrit and Prakrit and approximately 99% of Urdu verbs have their roots in Sanskrit and Prakrit,” the IPS officer had told the police journal Protector some time ago.

During his childhood, the article had stated, he used to attend nashishts (sittings) of Urdu poets and would listen without letting them know that he wrote ghazals as well. As he was not well versed with meters, he was not keen to let others know about his ghazals. He has time and again stated how a Maulana of a mosque near his office was teaching him Urdu for quite some years.

Title: Man arrested for rape bid on toddler
Content:
This story is from January 15, 2020

Haridwar: A 21-year-old man, Lalu Prasad, was arrested on Tuesday for allegedly trying to rape a two-and-a-half-year-old girl. The accused allegedly lured the toddler away when she was alone at home. A case has been registered against the man under relevant sections of the POCSO act.

According to sources, the man had come to Haridwar from Shahjahanpur, Uttar Pradesh, looking for a job and stayed in a room close to the victim’s. He had even befriended her parents.

Talking to TOI, senior sub-inspector of Jawalapur police station Vikas Bhardwaj said, “The incident took place around 5 pm on Monday. The toddler was alone at home as her father, a daily wage labourer at a company in SIDCUL, was at work and her mother had gone out for a while. The accused brought the child to his room and tried to rape her. When her mother came home, she found the girl missing and her neighbour’s door locked. After she knocked furiously on his door, the man left the child and fled.”

Title: Bhogi celebrated on a grand note in Tirumala
Content:
This story is from January 15, 2020

Tirupati: The annual Bhogi festival was celebrated on a grand note at Tirumala as well as in other parts of Chittoor district as the Sankranti festivities set in on Tuesday.

Officials and priests accompanied by visiting devotees set up the Bhogi bonfire in front of theLord Venkateswara temple marking the beginning of the Sankranti festival.

Braving the winter cold, homemakers made attractive Rangolis at the break of dawn in front of their homes and placed ‘‘gobbemmalu” (cow dung balls with pumpkin flowers placed on them) in accordance with the tradition.

They also made a bonfire of old things to welcome the new. People along with their families went around the ‘‘Bhogi manta”.

Title: Road Safety Week marked with student rallies in city
Content:
This story is from January 15, 2020

Kolhapur: The city marked the Road Safety Week with scores of students from schools and colleges participating in a rally organised by the city traffic department and the regional transport office (RTO), Kolhapur .

More than 1,000 students from various schools and colleges took part in the rally that began from Bhavani Mandap area at 8 am on Tuesday and concluded at Dasara chowk before passing through major roads in the city.

Mayor Surmanjiri Latkar inaugurated the rally that saw youths carrying placards and banners appealing to the people to follow traffic rules, avoid accidents, wearing helmet while riding motorcycles, avoid jumping signals and over speeding, etc.

The Road Safety Week programme was initiated by the Ministry of Road, Transport and Highways since 2011 and is conducted during the second week of January every year. A series of programmes are launched to mark the week with promotional materials including cloth banners, safety posers, pocket guides, safety films, etc.

According to RTO officials, this is the 31st Road Safety Week and the theme of this year is “Bringing Change Through Youth”.

“There are around 356 million youngsters in the country and our aim is to spread awareness about traffic rules and the importance of following rules in day-to-day lives,” said RTO officials.

Title: Lobbying on for U’khand BJP president’s post
Content:
This story is from January 15, 2020

Dehradun: The race for BJP’s new state party chief has heated up with several names believed to be in the fray including incumbent president and Nainital MP Ajay Bhatt, Kaladhungi legislator Bansidhar Bhagat, Almora MP Ajay Tamta and BJP leader from Pithoragarh Kailash Pant among others.

Sources said that the state party chief, in all likelihood, would be chosen from the Kumaon region. The party may pick a Brahmin face for the state party president post to balance the Garhwal-Kumaon and Brahmin-Thakur dynamics in the state's politics. “As chief minister Trivendra SIngh Rawat is a Thakur leader from Garhwal region, the party is most likely to pick a Brahmin leader from Kumaon region,” a source told TOI.

Party insiders say that choice of the candidate for the coveted post has deeper political significance for the two major camps in the party — the one led by CM Rawat and the second led by other party leaders. “CM Rawat’s choice for the post is Bansidhar Bhagat. Other leaders back candidates like Ajay Tamta and Kailash Pant. If Bhagat is selected for the post, CM’s position would strengthen in the party,” said a BJP insider.

The decision on the next party chief is expected to be made after the saffron party’s senior leaders — including national vice-president Shivraj Singh Chouhan, Union minister Arjun Ram Meghwal, and others — arrive in the state capital on Wednesday.

“After the announcement of the new BJP state president, duties of state leaders in upcoming Delhi assembly election campaign would be finalised,” said a BJP state unit member.

Title: 1st batch of Agasthyarkoodam trekkers begins journey
Content:
This story is from January 15, 2020

adventure junkies: The first batch of trekkers to Agasthyarkoodam peak comprised three women and 113 men

Thiruvananthapuram: The first batch of trekkers , comprising three women and 113 men , to Agasthyarkoodam this year started journey from Bonacaud on Tuesday. They are among the 3,600 people, including two foreigners, who were able to register for the most sought-after wild trekking in the state.

Though the forest department had stated that there wouldn’t be any special facility for women trekkers, 170 women have registered for this year’s two-day trekking trip to the 1868 metre-tall peak which will be on till February 18. The trekking was opened to women last year, which saw 103 women joining the annual trekking event.

The registration had begun on January 8, and like during previous years, the booking got closed in a couple of hours, leaving scores of trekkers and nature lovers disappointed.

The first batch started off from the forest picket station at Bonacaud, and a guide each is leading 10-member groups.

As many as 32 specially-trained guides will be on duty to facilitate the annual trip into this natural habitat of rare medicinal herbs and other flora and fauna, which has been added to Unesco’s list of ‘World Network of Biosphere Reserves’. The department has also ensured round-the-clock service of two women forest staff members at the Athirumala base camp.

Entry has been limited to trekkers aged above 14 years, as the trekking features a difficult forest trail and a continuous presence of wild animals. Wayside shelters have been arranged at Lathimotta, Karamanayar, Attayar and Ezhumadakkantheri, besides at Athirumala, from where the steep 8km-climb to Agasthyarkoodam peak would begin after an overnight stay.

Canteens have been arranged at Bonacaud picket station and at Athirumala base camp.

The registered trekkers have to bring the printout of the ticket and a photo identity card, and should reach Bonacaud forest picket station at 7am on their allotted trekking day. The visitors are allowed to start their trekking between 7am and 11am, and they are not allowed bring offerings, plastic, alcohol and other banned substances like cigarettes. Cooking is also not allowed inside the forest.

Title: Prior to cabinet expansion, govt accords state minister status to 10 BJP leaders
Content:
This story is from January 15, 2020

Dehradun: While speculations are rife for a cabinet expansion in Uttarakhand — to fill up three vacant positions — the state government on Tuesday accorded state minister status to 10 BJP leaders. All have been given key positions in different boards and councils.

Rajveer Singh and Vishwas Dabar have been given post of chairman, whereas the remaining eight were accorded positions of vice-chairperson.

Recently, CM Trivendra Singh Rawat had hinted at a cabinet expansion by saying that the “need was being felt.” With budget due in February, possibilities of expansion and finance ministry being given to a senior leader are high. After the demise of Prakash Pant, the CM has been looking after the charge of finance ministry.

According to the list announced by the state government, Rajveer Singh has been made chairman of state seeds and organic products certification agency and Vishwas Dabar was given charge of chairman of housing and development council.

Bahadur Singh Bisht was made vice-chairperson of state higher education development committee, Atar Singh Aswal the vice-chairman of irrigation advisory committee and Atar Singh Tomar has also been made vice-chairperson of irrigation advisory committee.

Shobha Ram Prajapati has been made chairperson of Maati Kala Kendra, Fakir Ram Tamta has been given key charge of vice-chairman of social welfare projects monitoring committee, Khem Pal Singh was made vice-chairman of backward category welfare council.

Karan Bohra has been named vice-chairperson of van panchayat advisory committee and Sunil Chauhan was made vice-chairman of organic products council.

With BJP expected to announce its new party chief on January 16, the decks have been cleared for cabinet expansion. While a party senior is expected to be made the state chief, three others would be accommodated in the state cabinet.

Munna Singh Chauhan, Bansidhar Bhagat, Mahendra Bhatt, Pushkar Dhami and Bishan Singh Chuphal are being regarded the frontrunners for the cabinet berth.

Title: NMC’s garden dept under scanner for hiring agency to plant saplings
Content:
This story is from January 15, 2020

Newly planted saplings at Neeri Road

Nagpur: The Nagpur Municipal Corporation’s (NMC) garden department has come under the scanner for hiring an agency to plant 11,200 saplings across the city at a cost of Rs4.94 crore.

In other words, the NMC is spending around Rs4,400 for planting one sapling and maintaining it for two years. The National Highways Authority of India (NHAI) also appointed a private agency for planting 87,113 saplings along the Nagpur-Hyderabad national highway with maintenance for five years. It is spending around Rs1,897 per sapling. The difference in the cost and maintenance tenure between the two agencies is alarming.

In September 2019, following a nod from the standing committee and the general body, the NMC had entrusted M/s Rainbow Greeners to plant 11,200 saplings (12 feet high) along 56 roads.

According to the proposal, the firm was to take care of the maintenance of the saplings for two years against a payment of Rs4.94 crore.

Sources alleged that the terms and conditions of the project were formulated to favour the company.

A vigilant Nagpurian, Darshan Maheswari, procured documents from NHAI which said that it paid Rs10.61 crore to an agency to plant 87,113 saplings on the Nagpur-Hyderabad national highway or Rs1,216.81 per sapling. The firm was to maintain the saplings for five years. Maheshwari shared the NHAI documents with TOI. He pointed out that comparatively, NMC is paying more money to the firm which will maintain the trees only for two years, while NHAI’s contractor is doing it for five years.

Municipal commissioner Abhijit Bangar assured to look into the issue raised by Maheshwari. “Though the work order to the firm has already been issued, I will cross check the rates of both NMC and NHAI. The payment to be made to the firm will be subject to the survival of the plants,” he said.

Meanwhile, the civic administration has made it mandatory for the private firm to obtain a no objection certificate (NOC) from its public works department for planting saplings.

The civic chief issued the order after complaints from motorists which led to a spot inspection on Neeri Road where the firm dug pits just over the pipeline. The pits were left open for almost eight days, without carrying out any plantation work.

“The firm will now have to get an NOC from the office of superintendent engineer (PWD) Manoj Talewar for shortlisting the ideal spots for planting saplings alongside cement roads across the city,” said the civic chief.

The administration has also set a 48-hour deadline for the firm to restore the road after planting saplings.

Title: Parking stand employees fleece visitors at Perur Patteeswarar temple
Content:
This story is from January 15, 2020
