Coimbatore: Many devotees of the Perur Patteeswarar temple, who regulalrly visit one of oldest temples in the district, have alleged that the employees of the parking lot at the temple were charging excess fee.

One of the devotees said ticket sellers sometimes levy Rs 50 for a four-wheeler and Rs 20 for a two-wheeler, which is expensive than malls and multiplexes on a weekend. Often ticketing receipts do not mention the fee, they said.

A senior official in the HR&CE (Hindu religious and charitable endowments) department said the actual charges at the temple were Rs 20 for four-wheelers and Rs 50 only for buses.

State secretary of the Tamil Nadu Vivasaigal Sangam P Kandasamy, who visited the temple in a four-wheeler last week, said he paid Rs 50 as parking charge. “However, the receipt the man at the parking stand gave me was a torn piece of paper without mentioning the charge,” he said, adding that it was a weekday too.

Consumer activist V Jayaraman recalled that while visiting the temple last year, he paid Rs 20 to park his two-wheeler.

People living in and around the temple also said the parking employees had charged Rs 50 for four-wheelers earlier. “A few of the men at the parking lot have charged Rs 50 for four-wheelers,” said Sri Ramesh, a resident living near the temple.

“Parking contractors should display charges on a board. But it was not always followed,” said Jayaraman, who heads Coimbatore Consumer Club.

Parking stand contractor Srinivasan, who also runs parking stands at multiple theatres, admitted that the charges were Rs 5 for two-wheelers, Rs 20 for four wheelers and Rs 50 for small buses and vans and Rs 100 for buses. “I will investigate into complaints immediately and take action. Maybe there was a miscommunication, but if there is any wrongdoing, I will take action and ensure such high charges are not levied again,” he said.

Title: Promotion plea of teacher with invalid MA dismissed
Content:
This story is from January 15, 2020

Madurai: Madras high court has dismissed a physical education teacher’s plea to be included in the promotion panel saying he had obtained his MA degree through open university which is invalid according to University Grants Commission (UGC) regulations. Petitioner I Sundararajan had passed SSLC in 1974 and also completed a certificate court in physical education in 1979. He was appointed as physical education teacher in a government high school at Periyakovilankulam in Tirunelveli in 1988. He obtained MA degree under open university system in 1999 without having any basic degree which was an essential qualification for joining a postgraduate course. However, with the MA degree, he obtained a Bachelor of Physical Education (B.P.Ed) in 2001. The joint director of school education department sent a communication to all chief educational officers to send the seniority list of physical education teachers for promotion to the post of physical education director grade II. Since his name was not in the list, he inquired about it. The joint director sent a communication on May 17, 2010 informing him that he was ineligible on the ground that he did not have a general qualification of a bachelor’s degree. The petitioner challenged the communication before the HC Madurai bench in 2010 and sought to consider his promotion without insisting on the general qualification of a bachelor’s degree.

On perusal of the submissions,court observed that the petitioner had obtained MA through open university system without plus two qualification or basic degree. The judge said the BPEd degree obtained by Sundararajan though a summer course was also not valid under UGC regulations. In this regard, the judge referred to a Supreme Court verdict in 2009 which held that a postgraduate degree obtained through distance education programme in contravention of UGC regulations is not valid. Hence, as contended by the authorities, the petitioner who does not possess a basic degree is not eligible to show his BPEd degree to get promotion.

Title: Drivers served tea and biscuits in wee hours to curb accidents
Content:
This story is from January 15, 2020

Madurai: In order to drivers from dozing off and to prevent accidents, especially during the Pongal season as many are involved in hectic schedule, officials from the Tamil Nadu State Transport Corporation (TNSTC) have started serving tea and biscuits to them.

Drivers are stopped at Batlagundu toll gate and are served with tea between 1am an 5am starting from Monday. Officials said that drivers feel sleepy between this particular timing and even a second of lapse in concentration may prove fatal to many.

The initiative was taken based on instructions from the managing director of TNSTC, Madurai Region, M A Murugesan. Officials said that apart from bus drivers, private car drivers and van drivers are also served with tea and biscuits. They are also sensitized on how to drive safely. Pilgrims, who are on foot to Palani are also sensitized by issuing pamphlets. TNSTC general manager for Dindigul district N Ganesan has been deploying a team of employees to distribute tea and create awareness on a rotation basis.

Due to Ayyappa season and Pongal holidays traffic on the Dindigul-Kumuli highway has increased. With the road becoming busier, it has increased risk to the commuters using the road.

Title: Tamil Nadu: Cracks wide open in AIADMK-BJP alliance
Content:
This story is from January 15, 2020

Pon Radhakrishnan

Title: Hoax bomb call keeps Madurai police on their toes
Content:
This story is from January 15, 2020

Representative image


MADURAI: A hoax call , threatening of a bomb planted in a bus terminal in Madurai city and the Avaniapuram jallikattu event on Wednesday, kept the city police on their toes on Tuesday. As soon as the call was received at the Chennai control room early on Tuesday morning, teams were swung into action in all the bus terminals like Mattuthavani, Periyar and Arappalayam. Another team was dispatched to Avaniapuram to ensure there is no threat to the venue. Dog squads were also swung into action. The terminals and jallikattu venue were thoroughly combed by the teams consisting of bomb detection and disposal squad and police personnel. Later, a large number of police officers and personnel were deployed for security measures and traffic arrangement for the jallikattu event. A police officer said that in Mattuthavani, the search, which began at around 6am ended at 10.30am after thoroughly checking all the platforms, buses and passenger bags. The search created a buzz in the busy terminal, which was overcrowded on Tuesday as people were leaving for their native to celebrate Pongal. Similar searches were conducted in other terminals as well. As the city police did not find anything suspicious, they declared that the call was hoax. Meanwhile, a box found under suspicious circumstances under a railway bridge in Ellis Nagar, created panic in the locality. Through the local police, a BDDS team was alerted. While the area was corned off by the police, a BDDS team rushed there and conducted a check. After a thorough check, the team announced that it was only a tiffin box left behind by someone. Meanwhile, an inquiry was underway to find out the miscreant, who had made the hoax call.

Title: Four arrested for robbing sari merchant
Content:
This story is from January 15, 2020

Erode: Four people were arrested by Erode district police for cheating a sari merchant of Rs 4.29 lakh on Tuesday.

The accused have been identified as K Purushothaman, 31, of Karungalpalayam from Erode, V Sekar, 45, of Kumarapalayam, P Gopiraj, 42, of Anankur, both from Namakkal district and S Palaniswamy, 50 of Salem.

According to Veerappanchatram police, they received a complaint from S Velusamy, 40, of Sriram Nagar in Ayigoundampalayam near Thuduppathy in Perundurai taluk. He mentioned that a person had contacted him on January 3, asking him to deliver 618 saris.

“Based on the conversation, Velusamy approached him with the saris in a car,” Inspector R Sivakumar, who was investigating the case said. The person who received the saris asked Velusamy to wait for a while to get the money. He failed to return even after four hours, the inspector added.

Realising that he was cheated, Velusamy lodged the complaint with Veerappanchatram police on the same day. The inspector formed a team to nab the culprits.On Tuesday early morning, the special team was on vehicle check on Sulai road in the city. While checking a car, they found the stolen saris.

“Upon inquiry, the four accused who were in the car, confessed to their crime of having cheated Velusamy,” the inspector said. Based on their confession, the police nabbed the culprits.

The police also seized the 618 saris, worth Rs 4.29 lakh. The police have lodged them at the Gobichettipalayam sub-jail under judicial custody.

Title: M K Stalin warns of massive protest if TN stays mum on NRC
Content:
This story is from January 15, 2020

M K Stalin

CHENNAI: The DMK on Tuesday warned of a “massive protest” against the National Register of Citizens and the National Population Register if the AIADMK government in Tamil Nadu remained silent.

In a statement, DMK president M K Stalin said chief minister Edappadi K Palaniswami and revenue minister R B Udayakumar had said the state would not implement the NRC. “But the government is silent on NPR. Once NPR details are collected, it will lead to the NRC and people will suffer,” said Stalin.

The DMK chief said the CM and the minister accused opposition parties of unnecessarily raising the issue when it was taken up by Stalin in the assembly last week. “We wanted a resolution to be passed in the assembly against the CAA . But the AIADMK government is afraid of passing such a resolution against the Centre,” said Stalin. While all other states (Bihar, Assam, West Bengal) are opposing the move, the AIADMK government is silent and is in favour of implementing the NPR, said Stalin.

“If the government’s silence continues, there will be a big protest by DMK and its alliance parties,” said Stalin.

Title: FASTag deadline ends, but only 40% vehicles using new system
Content:
This story is from January 15, 2020

Madurai: The deadline for the implementation of FASTag by the Union road transport ministry ended on Tuesday, but only less than 40% of vehicles using toll plazas in southern districts are using the new system. However, officials claim that the collection of toll amount through FASTag has crossed the 50% mark in Kappalur plaza and 40% mark in the remaining plazas .

At present, 25% of the lanes have been reserved for non-FASTag vehicles. While the deadline, which was extended by a month time ends on Tuesday night, only one lane on each side will be reserved for non-FASTag vehicles from Wednesday if no relaxation is given by the government. Highway users say that while FASTag lanes are free, other lanes are still crowded hindering fast movement.

U Vigayaragavan, a resident of Nagamalai Pudukottai said, “Many like me are not willing to take it up at least for now. I have been hearing about various discrepancies like FASTag not getting read at some toll plazas and deduction of double amount. I will wait for some more time before taking a call.”

Sources from Kappalur toll plaza said that while most commercial vehicles like trucks have come into the system, car owners are still reluctant. Less than 40% of the cars have got the tags fixed. They prefer to use cash payment. FASTags, which were in demand one month ago, are now freely available, as people are reluctant to come forward to buy them.

Project director of National Highways Authority of India (NHAI), Madurai, said that there is a good improvement in terms of money collection through FASTag. Marshals have been deployed to guide vehicles to use correct lanes at all toll plazas, he added.

Apart from Kappalur in Madurai district, there are five more toll plazas in southern districts located at Kodai Road, Sattur, Kayathar and Nanguneri. Although Chittampattti plaza is in Madurai district, it is managed by NHAI, Trichy.

Title: This Pongal, TNAU gifts 13 new crop varieties to farmers
Content:
This story is from January 15, 2020

Coimbatore: In a way to celebrate the harvest festival, the Tamil Nadu Agricultural University has released two drought tolerant varieties of rice, a new variety of cotton, which allows dense planting and mechanized cutting, and new varieties of six vegetables. A total 13 new varieties—seven agriculture and six horticulture crops were released.

Calling it a Pongal gift to farmers in the state, the TNAU said the new varieties are aimed to suit climate change, drought, acute labour shortage and farm mechanization, while sustaining farm productivity and profitability.

The two rice varieties are CO 53 and ADT 54. While CO 53 is suited for dry and semi dry conditions, the ADT 54 is suited for the late samba or thaladi season under irrigated conditions. “With many districts frequently facing drought and having to deal with delay in release of water from dams, these varieties are ideal in such situations,” said a TNAU press statement.

The university has also developed a new version of zero monopodia cotton CO 17, which is suited to mechanized harvesting and high-density planting. This variety will produce bolls close to the main stem, so the plant is more compact and sunlight will reach all the bolls. “When the plants are more compact, farmers can plant cotton stems densely. It also allows for mechanized cutting and harvesting reducing dependence on labour,” said K Subramanian, TNAU’s director of research.

In millets, two varieties, sorghum Co 32 and Tenai ATL 1, will improve the nutritional security among children. These are nutricereals rich in micronutrients especially iron and zinc that are essential for pregnant women and children. As these crops require less input, they can be recommended for doubling the farmers’ income. Further, stover can be used as the roughage or dry fodder.

Among vegetables, they have released six new varieties including banana CO 2, tomato hybrid CO 4, aggregatum onion CO 6, cassava YTP 2, manila tamarind PKM-MT 2 and manathakkali CO 1. “While banana CO2 is nematode and wilt tolerant, the YTP 2 cassace is tolerant to mosaic diseases and has shown a high tuber yield with a starch content of 30%,” said Dr Subramanian. The tomato hybrid (CO 4) is known to produce 27% higher fruit yield than other hybrids, besides having long shelf-life and high acidity. The aggregatum onion also possesses a long-shelf life, said the statement.

Further, the red aril manila tamarind (PKM 2) is a high-value crop in the market and drought tolerant. It costs Rs 150 to Rs 200 in the market and is highly recommended in Ramanathapuram, Tuticorin, Virudhunagar and Sivaganga districts. Manathakkali CO 1 is a highly valuable medicinal plant which has many properties including rich in vitamin B complex and a curative property against mouth lesions.

Title: Here's what Saif Ali Khan said when asked if he is afraid of getting older
Content: Actor Saif Ali Khan on Tuesday said he wants to star in roles that suit his age and that made him take up his next film 'Jawaani Jaaneman' . In the movie, billed as a quirky family comedy, the 49-year-old actor plays a man who suddenly discovers he has a daughter, played by debutante Alaya F , with his former lover, essayed by actor Tabu."I am lucky to get varied roles like 'Omkara', 'Tanhaji... ' and these kind of films. Producer Jay Shewakramani came to me with this offer."He had the script, but for one or two years we did not talk about it. I wanted to do age-appropriate roles. I felt the father's role was interesting. This part was cool and of a different kind," Saif said.He was speaking at the song launch of 'Jawaani Jaaneman' in Mumbai. Asked if he is afraid of getting older, the actor said he never felt the pressure."You have to be young at heart, you have to be good. I don't want to be very young, I don't want to be old either. But I am happy... Till the time, I am getting work I am ok. When I retire, I will retire, will chill."I like this idea of having some time for making money, some time to relax. There is a time for everything in life. And when that comes I will find other things to do, I will be very happy," the star said.Heaping praises on Alaya, daughter of former actor Pooja Bedi , the actor said working with the newcomer was a "brilliant" experience."... The new generation is so prepared as compared to what we were. I have worked with Shah Rukh Khan . And it was amazing, it was the same energy," Saif said.Alaya said she was both nervous and excited about working on the film."I could give my best only because I was surrounded by people who are the best. Every day was fun, I felt rewarded and content after the shoot. I am grateful I got to work with talented people," she said.Tabu has a cameo in the film and Saif said she is one of the best actresses in the country. The actor duo has worked together in 1990s hits like 'Hum Saath Saath Hain' and 'Biwi No. 1'."Anything she does comes alive. It is brilliant working with her," he added.Directed by Nitin Kakkar, the film is slated to be released on January 31. Saif is also co-producing the film under his banner.

Title: NHAI draws flak for incomplete road, shoddy works
Content:
This story is from January 15, 2020

Several open drainages are visible on the road

Nagpur: The National Highways Authority of India (NHAI) is facing severe criticism for constructing cement road beneath the Y-shaped Sadar flyover. Residents and shopkeepers on the stretch have pointed out many flaws, substandard and incomplete work on this road.

“We have been suffering from open underconstruction drainage and stormwater drain from August 2019. Our building Sai Krupa Towers is situated near Regional Mental Hospital Square on the NH69, on which construction for flyover from Liberty Square to Mental Hospital Square started in March 2017,” said a miffed resident of Mankapur Rashi Jain.

“The entire road is being reconstructed by the NHAI. Because of the ongoing works, not just the motorists but residents also suffered a lot. We had to bear with loud noises from heavy machineries used for construction even at nights and wee hours apart from bad road right in front of the building for months. Our vehicles got damaged and there have been accidents too,” said Jain.

“While the road construction was going on, pathway in front of my building was dismantled for the work of a drainage line. The road is now almost complete but the authorities seem to have forgotten about the drainage line. The dismantled pathway till the entrance of the building has been left as it is. Now that the road is ready, no one is giving a thought about the plight of the people residing in the building,” she said.

TOI visited the spot and found that the residents can neither enter the building easily nor can they park their vehicles without causing more damage to them. “The open drainage has not just created problems for pedestrians and inconvenienced vehicle owners, it has also posed some serious health issues like malaria and dengue,” the residents complained.

A few people have even fallen in the drain and yet the authorities have turned a blind eye to the problem. “It has been months that we are suffering,” said the residents.

TOI also found that I-blocks used on the footpath have not been fixed properly.

Vinod Nangia, a shop owner on Residency Road, claimed the footpath constructed during IRDP ( integrated road development project ) work was of good quality. But the newly laid footpath is of very poor quality, he said. Nangia also pointed out that barricading of the divider alongside pillars of the flyover has narrowed down the road. At least on every alternate side of the flyover pillars, it could have been kept open for parking of vehicles. “We (shopkeepers) had suggested this, but in vain,” he pointed out.

When contacted by TOI, project director of NHAI, Abhijit Jichkar, assured to look into the matter.

Title: Goa to get private universities bill, educators approve
Content:
This story is from January 15, 2020

Representative image

PANAJI: Goa may soon get legislation that allows institutes affiliated to private and deemed universities to set up campuses in the state. The directorate of higher education has recently framed the private universities bill and the draft is now with the state government.

Educationists said that allowing other universities to set up extension campuses in Goa will help in offering currently unavailable courses to students in areas. It will also boost competitiveness and help raise standards. Educationists, however, cautioned that the law should be drafted in a manner that does not harm interests of Goa University . The legislation should also prevent these private institutes from turning into commercial centres, they said.

Sources said that already there are around five proposals from private and deemed universities pending with the state to set up campuses in Goa.The proposals to set up new institutes include a medical college and a hotel management institute.

As there is a demand for these programmes in the state, it was felt that such proposals could be considered and a legislation governing their establishment should be in place, sources said.

“Just because a university is public funded does not guarantee accountability, like if their students are getting sufficient placements. The prosperity of the education sector cannot be harmed by more competition. In the future, the entry of private institutes will become inevitable. At times, it is not possible for the state government financially to offer the entire variety of programmes and that is when the private universities can come in,” educationist Prabhakar Timble said.

He said that it only has to be ensured that the legislation is framed in a manner where it ensures that surplus funds are pumped back into the educational institute. “The law has to be drafted in a manner that ensures that surplus funds do not go back to business families or business houses and that the surplus is reinvested into the educational institutes,” Timble said.

A member of the Goa University executive council, Louis Vernal, said that many students are now willing to pay higher in exchange for better educational facilities in Goa.

“Many Goan students are already going outside the state by paying higher costs to study. In principle, it is good to have programmes by other universities in Goa because the government does not have the finances to fund all courses,” he said. “But it should be seen that Goa University’s interests are not harmed. Goa University is bound by rules like domicile for faculty recruitment, which is not letting it hire faculty from outside. The private institutes, on the other hand, will not be bound by such rules and will have an edge over GU,” Vernal added.

Title: PM-Xi meet proof of good law & order: Minister
Content:
This story is from January 15, 2020

Madurai: The meeting of Prime Minister Narendra Modi with Chinese president Xi Jinping would not have taken place in Mamallapuram if law and order was not under control in the state, information and publicity minister Kadambur C Raju said. He was talking to reporters in Perunkulam in Tuticorin district on Tuesday.

The minister was responding to senior BJP leader Pon Radhakrishnan’s allegations that law and order maintenance was poor in the state and that Tamil Nadu is turning out to be safe haven for terrorists. Raju said that the former union minister should be aware of the Centre ranking Tamil Nadu the best in law and order after studying various parameters. The minister counter asked if there was any terror attacks in the state during the said period.

He termed the murder of SSI Wilson at Kaliyakkavilai in Kanyakumari district unortunate and compared it with the killing of soldiers on country’s borders. “We should see how quickly our government has reacted to the incident despite Kaliyakkavilai located on Kerala border. The terrorists came from that state,” he added.

On DMK boycotting the anti-CAA meeting chaired by Congress leader Sonia Gandhi in Delhi, he said that the explanation given by chief minister and revenue minister in assembly that AIADMK would first voice against CAA if it attacked minorities could have changed the opposition’s views.

“Many other opposition parties boycotted the Congress meeting against CAA,” he said.

Title: College students go traditional during Pongal celebrations
Content:
This story is from January 15, 2020

Coimbatore: A growing number of city colleges and schools have joined in the tradition of celebrating Pongal, which was earlier restricted a few colleges. Many have begun celebrating the harvest festival, as part of efforts to ensure that their students remain in touch with Tamil festivities and customs.

After Sri Sakthi Engineering College organized a three-day livestock festival ahead of Pongal on Tuesday, Sri Ramakrishna College of Arts and Science celebrated the festival by organizing a pongal making competition within their departments.

The challenge was to make the best pongal in the traditional manner using mud pots and fire wood. “This is to ensure that the youth, who usually stays indoors or watches television while their mothers make Pongal, to learn to do it in the traditional way and realise the importance of it,” said a college official.

This was followed by traditional games including rangoli competitions, tug of war and a slow cycle race to see who could maintain balance while cycling at the minimum speed. It was followed by a traditional pattimandram (debate) on whether today’s youth and student culture would eventually turn out to be a celebration or destruction for life in the future. It was moderated by debater Kavitha Jawahar.

Students of Karpagam Academy of Higher Education also celebrated Pongal on their college premises.

Title: Export incentive cut hits Tamil Nadu’s matchbox makers hard
Content:
This story is from January 15, 2020

Madurai: The cut in export incentive from 4% to 1.5% has upset manufacturers and exporters of matchbox in Tamil Nadu, its production hub in the country. Since 30% of the match box produced is exported, they say this will be a major blow for the industry.

Tamil Nadu Match Manufacturers Association secretary G Kathiravan said more than 90% of the matchbox export from the state is through Tuticorin port and the rest from Chennai. The total export value is estimated to be about Rs 400 crore to Rs 450 crore with African countries importing 50% of it and Middle-East and South American countries 25%. “On an average 200 containers is exported through Tuticorin every month,” he said.

He said the export incentive was 7% when Pranab Mukherjee was finance minister. “This was reduced to 4% during P Chidambaram’s term after 2012. While we were seeking an increase, it has now been reduced to 1.5%” he said. Kathiravan said that the 4% incentive was given under two heads. It included the 1.5% drawback that is credited to the account within a week of export. “The remaining 2.5% is Merchandise Exports from India Scheme (MEIS) that is given to us after we get the payment for the merchandise,” he said.

Finance minister Nirmala Sitharaman has cancelled the 2.5 per cent MEIS now. “It was initially cancelled with effect from January but has been extended till March, after which it will be permanently closed. But we are unable to apply for it from the beginning of this month,” he added.

National small match manufactures association secretary V S Sethu Rathinam said that despite escalating raw material prices, the maximum selling price of a matchbox has been maintained at one rupee for close to two decades. Some manufacturers have managed to maintain the price by reducing the number of buds in a box from 50 to 40 now. The industry had difficulty in pushing the excess production into markets pan India without a price hike and found export as a ray of hope. But reducing export incentive will affect manufacturers as well as exporters. Association president M Paramasivam said that exporters were dependent on this incentive as a means of profit.

“By quoting little more to make up the drop in incentive we will lose to competition from Indonesia and Pakistan that are exporting at a highly competitive rate,” he said. Indonesia is fast gaining ground, capturing our markets due to competitive pricing as they have easy access to wood locally. “We buy wood from Kerala or import it from Belgium,” he said. The associations have appealed to the government to extend the same 4% export incentive to them by increasing the drawback to 4% from the existing 1.5% . They also said that GST on 10 of the 14 raw materials used for making matchboxes is only 12 % but GST on matchboxes is 18 % which they hope will be reduced.

Title: Girl kidnapped from Chennai Central rescued, man jailed
Content:
This story is from January 15, 2020

Representative image

MADURAI: The railway police have rescued a two-year-old girl and arrested a 32-year-old man who kidnapped her from Chennai Central railway station on Monday.

According to the police, the child identified as Rashida, was kidnapped by Deepak Mandal, a native of West Bengal when she was sleeping with her mother at the railway station in the wee hours of Monday. Based on a complaint from the child’s mother Marzeena, a case was registered with the police and an inquiry was conducted.

According to sources, the passengers who travelled on Mumbai-Nagercoil Express grew suspicious of him while he was begging along with the child. When the passengers questioned him about the child, he did not give a satisfactory reply and tried to escape from the coach.

However, a group of passengers surrounded him and alerted the railway protection force, who rescued the child when the train was at Palaiyam station and handed over to Railway police in Dindigul junction. After inquiries, the photo of the girl was immediately sent to their counterparts in Chennai, who confirmed the identity of the missing girl. The girl was then taken to Chennai on the same night and they reached there on Tuesday morning. Sources said that the girl was handed over to her mother.

Marzeena, a native of Guwahati in Assam had come to Chennai a couple of weeks ago. She was living on the pavement near Central Railway station with her daughters Mashida and Rashida.

Title: 313 maternal deaths between April-October 2019 in Telangana, pregnancy-induced hypertension the top cause
Content:
This story is from January 15, 2020

Representative image

HYDERABAD: Erratic eating habits, sedentary lifestyle and increasing number of assisted reproductive procedures are pushing up cases of pregnancy-induced hypertension (PIH), which has now become the top cause of maternal deaths in the state, surpassing post-partum haemorrhage (PPH).

As per latest records of the state health department, 313 maternal deaths were recorded in Telangana between April and October, 2019. PIH was found to be the leading cause of maternal deaths, 26%, during the period, while PPH caused 18% deaths and sepsis 14% of the 313 deaths. Anaemia, cardiac issues and hypertension caused a third of the deaths.

Explaining PIH, Dr Nabath Bandeli, gynaecologist and obstetrician, Mysha Clinics and Bloom Hospitals, said, “The blood pressure usually rises post-delivery and, if it crosses 160/ 110, it turns life threatening. PIH peaks in 48 hours and maximum occurrences (deaths) were seen within two weeks of delivery. PIH can cause multiple organ failure, fits (eclampsia) and tendencies to bleed.”

There are multiple reasons for increase in this phenomenon which are also linked with maternal deaths due to cardiac issues. Bad lifestyle and poor eating habits, family history and previous history of hypertension. “Another major factor contributing to increase in PIH is the fact that more and more couples resort to artificial reproductive techniques like IVF (in-vitro fertilisation) and IUI (intrauterine insemination). In assisted pregnancies, the placentation is a little different than the normal placenta. Also obesity, diabetes, multiple pregnancies, advanced maternal age and hectic work schedules contribute to increase in PIH,” Dr Prabha Agarwal, obstetrician and gynaecologist, Medicover Hospitals, told TOI.

Meanwhile, postpartum haemorrhage is on the decline say experts due to better facilities and infrastructure available at hospitals.

Title: Visually challenged lecturers beacons of hope for college students
Content:
This story is from January 15, 2020

Bengaluru: The third-year BCom class is under way at Jain University, Jayanagar. The lecturer is moving around in a specific pattern, explaining a sum on computation of taxable long-term capital gain to students. While a front-bencher reads out the question, lecturer Rajdeep Manwani solves it, narrating the steps one by one. A visitor at the door finally gives away that he’s visually challenged.

Like Rajdeep, coordinator at the faculty of commerce in Jain University and popular quiz master and motivational speaker, there are several visually challenged lecturers in institutions across Bengaluru. Driven by their passion and an inspiration for students, they come up with innovative ways to overcome their disability and impart lessons.

“Necessity is the mother of invention, they say. I practise a lesson for over two hours before class. Both my students and I read from the same textbook. So I ensure that I give them something more than what’s there in the book. With over 25 years of practice, I can easily memorise even big numbers to help students with sums,” said Rajdeep. He takes students’ help to mark attendance, write down sums on the board and go to the staffroom.

Prof N Dasharath, head of department at University Law College, Bangalore University, said: “I memorise students’ names and their backgrounds, whether they are from Kannada or English medium, and their strengths and weaknesses. I try to make the class as participatory as possible. When it comes to evaluation, I take the help of a colleague who reads out the answers and I mark papers accordingly.” A professor for over 25 years, Dasharath suffers from retinitis pigmentosa, which has led to constant degeneration of his eyesight.

Kalyan C Kankanala, guest faculty at National Law School of India University’s (NLSIU) distance education programme, also employs a similar method. “My classes are normally interactive and discussion driven, and I get to assess student participation based on the nature and extent of their responses, comments, observations and arguments. Most concepts I teach are followed by example fact patterns, which require students to apply the concept they’ve learnt and respond. Based on how they respond to questions and fact patterns, I get to know how effective the class is,” explained Kalyan, who’s also a senior partner at an IP law firm, BananaIP Counsels.

While most of these teachers believe no other profession can touch as many lives as teaching, adding that it creates empathy and compassion among students, they feel more institutions need to open up to differently abled teachers.

Need for more inclusiveness

As of now, most premier institutions are circumspect about hiring persons with blindness. Things have changed compared to 10 years ago but there’s still a long way to go. Premier institutions like IIMs, IITs and National Law Schools don’t have too many persons with disabilities as teachers and their policies have to change a little before they are compliant with the Right of Persons with Disabilities Act. If one can creatively overcome the hurdles posed by her/his disability, teaching is a very good profession to choose. I believe inclusiveness can be improved with effective education and enforcement

Kalyan C Kankanala, guest faculty, NLSIU distance programme

Title: Not mandatory: Central Bank of India clarifies stance on NPR for KYC process
Content:
This story is from January 15, 2020

Hyderabad: After asking its customers to submit a National Population Register (NPR) document as a proof for its Know Your Customer (KYC) procedure before January 31, the Central Bank of India has now said that NPR letter is not mandatory and that any other document is also valid for KYC .

In a clarification with regard to a recent advertisement in a Telugu daily on submission of NPR letter which caused disquiet among customers, the bank’s branch office in Rein Bazar, Hyderabad, said: “Any of the KYC documents can be given. Submission of NPR letter is not mandatory.” It said that NPR is just an additional document.

With customers questioning the rationale behind such a move, the bank, in response to a query from TOI, said : “As per RBI’s directives, not only the letter issued by the National Population Register, even other documents like passport, driving licence, Aadhaar number, voter identity card and NREGA job card are also officially valid documents (OVDs) for KYC purpose.”

Bankers pointed out that NPR letter had been one of the OVDs for KYC since 2017 when it was notified by the government under the Prevention of Money Laundering Act. “All banks have been asking for it as one of the KYC documents,” they recall. The recent tension was over the Central Bank of India’s insistence to customers on submitting the NPR letter before January 31.

The bank is also said to have warned customers that they would not be able to withdraw or transfer money if they fail to do so. “Why is the bank asking for an NPR certificate when Aadhaar and PAN are sufficient for KYC?,” asked one Twitter user. Many claimed that the bank notice was being largely circulated on social media. The notice was also published in certain newspapers.

The notice also gave a toll-free number from which additional information could be sought or doubts clarified. When TOI contacted the toll-free number, the executives said there was no information about the NPR letter in their database. A senior bank official said that he was not aware of any such requirement.

Title: Avarekai mela from Jan 17 despite opposition
Content:
This story is from January 15, 2020

Bean there done that: Avarekai Mela has been held for 19 years and is famous for the variety of dishes such as... Read More

Bengaluru: The annual avarekai (flat beans) mela, organised by a private store on VV Puram Food Street, has run into a controversy.

While BBMP claims it has not given permission for the event following objections from residents , the mela organisers held a press conference on Tuesday to announce that the fair will be held from January 17 for a week.

But BBMP commissioner BH Anil Kumar said it has not given permission for the mela so far. Local resident welfare associations and the VV Puram corporator are against the mela happening on Food Street. “They are concerned about an event being organised by a private store on the footpath and road which are public spaces. And there are issues of traffic chaos and hygiene,” he added.

Smitha Srinath, a resident of VV Puram, said, “The mela occupies the entire Food Street, not leaving any space for vehicles to move around. In case of an emergency, there will be little space even for an ambulance or a fire engine to enter the narrow road.” Residents alleged that the mela organisers draw electricity illegally from poles on the road and keep gas cylinders around , which could be dangerous.

Some residents said they were not against the mela but the venue has to be shifted to a space like National College Grounds or any other big space.

VV Puram corporator Vani V Rao said she won’t allow the mela to be held in the absence of BBMP’s permission. The organisers, however, announced on Tuesday that it will be held between January 17 and 23 from 10.30am to 11pm.

Asked about the controversy, Swathy KS, owner of Vasavi Condiments which organises the event, said they are in talks with the civic body and elected representatives. “If people are not cooperative, we will have no other option but to cancel the event. We will take a call soon,” she added.

Mayor Gautam Kumar said, “I wanted this to happen from day one as the event is also beneficial to farmers. I understand that managing traffic on the narrow road is not that easy, but if not for 10 days they should be given at least two days to host the mela.”

Title: Restricted water supply in Mormugao, Salcete on Wednesday
Content:
This story is from January 15, 2020

Representative image

MARGAO: Some parts of Salcete and the whole of Mormugao will have restricted water supply on Wednesday as the Japan International Cooperation Agency (JICA)-funded 100 MLD water treatment plant will be shut by the public works department (PWD) for urgent maintenance work of the 1,400mm main transmission line.

PWD assistant engineer Shrikant Gaonkar told TOI that the maintenance work entails installation of two zero velocity valves that will eliminate the creation of back pressure that often leads to breaches in the pipeline, disrupting water supply.

“Generation of back pressure in the pipeline is a common problem. We have had incidents of bursting of the pipeline recently, and in order to overcome the problem, we had proposed to install zero velocity in the pipeline. The plant will be shut for a day to install these valves,” Gaonkar said.

A zero velocity valve prevents a hammer effect in the piping system. It consists of a spring-loaded closing disc to stop reverse flow in case of failure of pumps.

While Mormugao and some parts of Salcete will receive restricted supply of water, the rest of South Goa will not be affected, it was informed.

Title: Three arrested for stealing 15,600kg copra
Content:
This story is from January 15, 2020

Representative image

TIRUPUR: Three people have been arrested for stealing more than 15,600kg copra from a copra drying unit in Kangeyam in the district.

The Kangeyam police arrested S Arunagirinathan, 62, of Chennimalai in Erode and his accomplices Prabhakaran, 29, of Musiri in Trichy and Hidros, 46, of Palakkad, on Sunday (January 12) based on a complaint lodged by S Tamil Selvan, manager of the copra drying unit.

According to a police officer, the unit at Kamatchipuram near Kangeyam was run by Karthikeyan, of Kinathukadavu in Coimbatore district. “He would buy coconut from farmers or traders and dry them in his unit to be sold to oil mills in Kangeyam and Kerala.”

On January 11, the unit got a call from a truck booking office saying that a truck was returning empty to Kerala and that the vehicle could be used to transport copra to that state. “Tamil Selvan agreed to send the goods in the truck,” the officer said.

Subsequently, the truck with three people, arrived at the unit the same day to take copra to an oil mill in Irinjalakuda in Thrissur district in Kerala. The truck was then loaded with 15,600kg copra. When Tamil Selvan asked the truck driver to provide vehicle registration certificate and driving licence, the latter said he had left them behind in some other place and promised to submit them before taking the truck.

But when Tamil Selvan went to attend nature’s call, the truck driver and his companions sped away in the truck. Following this, he lodged the complaint with the Kangeyam police, who registered a case and traced the truck to Kollengode in Palakkad, recovered the stolen copra and arrested the trio.
