Title: No provision to hand out docu: NPR official
Content:
This story is from January 15, 2020

Hyderabad: Officials in the National Population Register (NPR) division said that there was no provision for a person to request NPR document. ““We prepare an NPR every 10 days based on the Census information... but do not make it available to individual citizens. There is no provision for citizens to ask for it or give it from our side,” a senior NPR official told TOI.

The NPR is prepared by the Registrar General and Census Commissioner (RGCC) which falls under the Union ministry of home affairs. According to the RGCC website, the data for NPR was collected in 2010 along with the house listing phase of Census of India, 2011. The updating of this data was done during 2015 by conducting a door-to-door survey.

“Now, it has been decided to update NPR along with house listing phase of Census 2021 between April and September this year in all the states/Union territories except Assam,” the website says. The objective of NPR is to create a comprehensive database of every resident. “We will be taking up work pertaining to updating NPR this year and next. But, this information will not be given to individuals,” an official said.

Title: Many were under cop lens before riot
Content:
This story is from January 15, 2020

Hyderabad: Anticipating trouble in the wake of municipal elections, police in Bhainsa had started binding over of people with criminal antecedents since the first week of January. One of the persons bound over is the town president of a religious organisation.

In the past one week prior to the communal clashes, nearly all FIRs registered by Bhainsa police were bind over cases. Between January 6 and January 12, police had booked 13 cases under Section-107 of CrPC against people of both religious communities and bound them over to prevent them from causing any disturbance during upcoming municipal polls.

So far this year, police of Bhainsa town bound over 51 people from different communities. “The bind over process was started in view of upcoming municipal elections and those who have criminal antecedents especially history of election related cases, have been booked,” Bhainsa sub-inspector Balakrishna said.

After registering an FIR, the accused will be produced before the concerned RDO for bind over process and if the accused resort to any illegal activity during bind over period, they will have to pay a pre-specified amount to the government.

On January 2, Bhainsa police had booked a case under IPC sections 188 and 290 against seven members of a religious organisation, including one who is an accused in recent violence, for taking out a rally from a worship place to MRO office in support of Citizenship Amendment Act (CAA) in violation of police orders.

“The violence was not pre-planned. As soon as police came to know about initial confrontation between two groups, they rushed there and pacified both the parties to leave the place,” IG Y Nagi Reddy said.

Title: BMTC MD takes Volvo wheel, inspires employees
Content:
C Shikha

BENGALURU: Thousands of employees of Bangalore Metropolitan Transport Corporation (BMTC) were enamoured of managing director C Shikha on Tuesday, after a video of her test-driving a Volvo bus went viral. She’s the first IAS officer in recent times to have inspected a bus by getting behind the wheel.A visibly confident Shikha, accompanied by senior officials of the corporation, drove the vehicle on the test track at the Hoskote training centre on Saturday. Her driving skills not only got an overwhelming response from the utility’s male-dominated workforce but also brought a smile to Prema Ramappa Nadapatti, its lone woman driver. BMTC, with a daily ridership of 36 lakh, has 6,400 buses and employs around 14,000 drivers.On the job for more than a decade, Prema says bus drivers face several challenges, including traffic congestion and rash riding by two-wheelers. She drives on the Kempegowda Bus Station-Begur route.Shikha, a 2004 IAS officer, took charge as BMTC MD in September 2019. Her test drive came after a series of brake failures which led to accidents. Though a few netizens took potshots at her by seeking to know if she possessed a license, many were impressed with her for daring to test vehicles before making any purchases. Shikha was not available for comments.A BMTC spokesperson in a statement said: “The vehicle was driven at the bus training centre... in a controlled environment. No harm was caused to the public,” adding that Shikha has a learner’s licence for heavy vehicles. At Volvo’s manufacturing unit in Hoskote, a test driving track is provided for customers to test drive and experience its buses under the supervision of a qualified driver.Meanwhile, BMTC ’s 33% reservation plan for women drivers has remained a non-starter for long. Of the total licence-holders in the state, women comprise only 15%. BMTC has earmarked around Rs 7.5 crore to train 1,000 women in driving buses and light motor vehicles free of cost under the Nirbhaya fund . This will also help women explore employment opportunities with app-based taxi firms and schools.Those who have held LMV (light motor vehicle) licence for a year can apply for HPV (heavy passenger vehicle) licence to drive buses. While LMV applicants are being trained on city roads, HPV applicants are trained at the centre in Vaddarahalli on Magadi Road.Will inspire other women“Our MD (Shikha) is an inspiration and a role model for others. I have never seen a woman officer driving a bus. It is not easy but she was focused and drove without fear. This also shows she’s passionate about the buses and understands the problems faced by drivers. This will inspire more women to take up driving”Prema Ramappa Nadapatti, lone woman driver in BMTCIn Video: Bengaluru: Woman IAS officer takes bus wheel for test drive, inspires many

Title: Tea outing trauma: Bengaluru Police ask Kerala youths are you from Pakistan, thrash 3
Content:
Sceengrab of the video

Apartment bodies get notice

BENGALURU: When 18-year-old Ikram (name changed) and his two friends stepped out of their flat in SG Palya, east Bengaluru, for tea past midnight on Monday, little did they know that they’d be in the soup.While Ikram and his two friends left the flat at 1am for tea at a nearby stall, the teen’s elder brother, Saif (name changed) and two others stayed back as they were getting ready to hit the sack. All six are students of various city colleges and hail from Kerala .Within a few minutes, Saif heard commotion downstairs and looked out of the balcony to see Ikram calling for help. Ikram and his friends had been stopped by two patrol police, who wanted to know what they were doing on the road so late and where they lived. Saif, 21, approached the policemen, wanting to know what the issue was. The cops asked them for their names and ID cards. On learning that Saif was a Muslim, one of them asked him if he was a Pakistani.Though Saif was taken aback, he again asked what the problem was. The cops then asked the youngsters to give them their mobile phones. “Even as Ikram’s friend showed them his phone, the cops tried to snatch it. At that moment, I asked them if they have a warrant to check our personal belongings. My question appeared to tick off a cop, who immediately turned to me and said that if I needed a warrant, I should come to the police station,” said Saif, adding that they kept asking if they were Pakistanis. The youth said cops also told them that they had arrested a few terrorists recently. “I was perplexed as to why they needed to tell us all that,” he added.One of Saif’s friends, meanwhile, began filming the incident on his phone and a policeman asked him to stop. A video clip shared with TOI shows the cop angrily asking the student to stop filming, while the person shooting the video is heard, saying: “Sir, it is a public place. I can record.”Within minutes, the policeman called for four more cops – two in Hoysala and two in patrol bikes. The quartet turned up with lathis and forced Saif and two of his friends into the patrol car. Around 1.30am, they were taken to SG Palya police station.According to Saif, the cops initially spoke to them nicely. “But within seconds, the scene changed, and a policeman came into the room with a lathi. I thought it was just to scare us, but then he began hitting us,” Saif recalled. “Three cops took turns to beat us until my local guardian came to the police station at 3.30am,” he added.The three youths took blows on their hands, back and legs. Before releasing them, the cops made them give an undertaking declaring they won’t step out late at night and slapped petty cases against them (causing nuisance) and a fine of Rs 500 per person. “The document read that we will not step out late at night and if cops found us, any action could be taken against us. They also made us sign another document in Kannada , which they said is signed by persons riding without a helmet,” Saif explained.The youngsters said the men in uniform also threatened to get them evicted from the apartment and even get their internships cancelled. Saif said stepping out for tea after midnight is normal among students and young professionals living in the area, but such unwarranted police action is new.With the incident going viral on Instagram, DCP (Whitefield) MN Anucheth, who is in charge of south-east division, ordered an inquiry into the case. “I learnt about the incident through social media. I have ordered the assistant commissioner of police (ACP) Mico Layout to conduct an investigation and submit a report,” said Anucheth.Close on the heels of the arrest of terror suspects in Bengaluru and elsewhere in Karnataka , police issued notices to apartment associations to reveal details of occupants.The notice, a copy of which is available with TOI, seeks details of occupants at apartments. It states that if the association finds anyone suspicious, they need to immediately inform cops.Police sources said: “At many apartments, flat owners have either rented or leased out their premises. But in several cases, tenant details have not been collected and this could be a security threat. We are asking residents to be alert to anything suspicious in their neighbourhood.”According to them, many apartments are seeking contact numbers, photos and email IDs, not just of occupants, but also of visitors.In Video: Bengaluru cops ask Kerala youths are you from Pakistan

Title: Govt’s reluctance to bear treatment cost rattles rare disease patients’ kin
Content:
This story is from January 15, 2020

Bengaluru: Support groups of patients with rare diseases are upset with the draft national policy on rare diseases. They say it’s vague about financial responsibility of treatment in such cases.

Stating the government has failed in taking ownership of treatment cost of patients, they say the draft policy is more like an information bulletin on rare diseases. It also does not put a timeframe on its implementation.

The draft was released on January 13, inviting objections, if any, from the public. The government first came out with the policy in 2017 and withdrew it abruptly in 2018, claiming it wants to improvise it.

“There are certain positives in the draft policy like newborn screening and high-risk pregnancy test. But it puts a cap of Rs 15 lakh for treatment of rare diseases. For many patients with rare diseases, where bone marrow transplant is the only solution, the procedure itself costs Rs 30 lakh. For many with lysosomal storage disorders, the treatment costs per annum runs into several crores of rupees. The draft policy hardly gives hope to such patients,” said Prasanna Shirol, founder, Organization For Rare Diseases India.

Prasanna’s daughter Nidhi Shirol who is suffering from Pompe, a rare disease, has been on ventilator for more than two years now. Pompe is a lysosomal storage disorder, which is a rare inherited neuromuscular disorder that causes progressive muscle weakness.

Vineeth Dev, 9, suffers from Hunter syndrome, a type of mucopolysaccharidoses (MPS) which is a metabolic disorder caused by the absence of a lysosomal enzyme that is needed to break down complex molecules in the body. Patients with this rare disorder suffer from abnormalities in many organs, including heart, respiratory system, affecting the neurological development too.

“For children born with MPS, the minimum cost of drugs is more than Rs 2.5 crore per annum. In my son’s case, for the last two years, we have been getting drugs free from the drug manufacturing company. The drugs come directly to Indira Gandhi Institute of Child Health (IGICH ), where they are administered to my son. We have not got any drugs from the government. The draft policy makes no mention of the financial support, instead speaks about crowdfunding. Rare diseases like MPS have no one-time solution and those who may donate on crowdfunding platforms don’t keep on donating,” said Vidya CA, Vineeth’s mother.

Vidya says her child’s treatment would have been completely taken care of by the government had he been born in the US.

Parents of several patients are aghast that the draft policy does not mention insurance policies for rare diseases, already a grey area.

Ten-year-old Deeksha Sampath’s parents spent over Rs 25,000-30,000 per month for medicines for her Spinal muscular atrophy, a genetic disease affecting the nervous system in the body and muscle movement. “How do we depend on the government’s crowdfunding move? It hardly gives hopes,” said Deeksha’s mother Rashmi Sampanth.

However, Dr KS Sanjay, director, Indira Gandhi Institute of Rare Diseases, says the draft policy is the first step and certainly a big move. “In India there has been no epidemiological survey on rare diseases. Globally, there are close to 5,000 diseases considered rare. In India, there are over 450 rare diseases. Currently, in India, research updates aren’t conclusive of diagnosis, gene analysis. There is much to do in terms of research. The draft policy is a preliminary step and it will be improved gradually,” he added.

Currently, 29 paediatric patients with rare diseases are seeking medicines at IGICH through state government funds.

Title: Asad: Adivasis & Dalits will suffer if NRC is implemented
Content:
This story is from January 15, 2020

Hyderabad: All India Majlis-e-Ittehadul Muslimeen (AIMIM) president Asaduddin Owaisi said if the National Register of Citizenship (NRC) is implemented, Adivasis and Dalits would also face the brunt along with Muslims. “When the Citizenship Amendment Bill was introduced in Parliament, I considered it as black law and tore a copy of the bill...It’s unacceptable,” Owaisi said late on Monday.

The Hyderabad MP urged people to view the National Population Register (NPR) and National Register of Citizens (NRC) seriously. “If NPR happens then NRC will also be implemented. They are twins, so if one of them begins the other will too. While its not mandatory that these should be together, they want to implement both,” he added.

Campaigning for AMIM candidates in Medak district for the civic polls, Owaisi targeted the RSS for describing the Indian flag as “inauspicious”. “Let BJP answer. Isn’t it a fact that when the tricolor was declared as the national flag, the RSS organiser had written the flag was inauspicious? If they dare to refute this, I will show them evidence,” Owaisi said at a meeting.

Title: Make proposed 6-lane Porvorim flyover 4-lane: Residents to CM
Content:
This story is from January 15, 2020

Panaji: Some residents of Porvorim on Tuesday asked chief minister Pramod Sawant to reduce the six-lane flyover from Pundalik Nagar to Socorro junction to a four-lane corridor on NH-66. The CM said that he would look into this demand.

The delegation comprised waste management minister Michael Lobo, Socorro sarpanch Sandeep Vazarkar and others. Lobo said residents of Porvroim have demanded that the flyover should be reduced to four lanes from six lanes.

Porvorim resident Ravi Chodankar said that the new proposed flyover bridge touches many balconies and houses. He also said that the corridor would be built over two pillars on either side of the road. “This is not viable for anybody,” he said.

Chodankar said that health is going to be a huge problem for children in the locality due to vehicular pollution.

“We want the corridor, the flyover bridge, but it should be four-lane bridge as it touches the Atal Setu, a four-lane bridge,” Chodankar said. “The plan is to build a six-lane bridge. For what, we have no idea.” He added that the width of the bridge should be 20m.

Chodankar also said the bridge should at least be 7m tall so that gases generated by vehicles go horizontally and don’t affect the children and people of Porvorim. He also said the new flyover would be detrimental to the houses of Porvorim, many of which are a hundred years old. Chodankar said Porvorim should be considered a virgin area where health is concerned. “People have lived here for years, and suddenly taking decisions is not correct,” he said.

Title: Hyderabad: Leopard severely injured after falling into boar trap
Content:
This story is from January 15, 2020

The incident came to light on Tuesday morning after farmers noticed the leopard trapped in the metal snare

HYDERABAD: A five-year-old male leopard was left critically injured after getting trapped in a snare laid for wild boars by unidentified persons in Agilapuram thanda of Nalgonda district on Tuesday. The leopard, which was rescued by a team of veterinary officials, has been kept under observation for 48 hours at the Nehru Zoological Park in Hyderabad.

“There are a few serious internal injuries because it got caught in the snare and tried to fight it and escape for almost two hours. There are also external injuries on the neck, shoulder and hind leg. It is unable to bear weight on hind legs,” said a zoo source. “Treatment is being done but (the leopard) is still scared and has not eaten anything yet,” the source added.

However, a statement by zoo officials stated that the medical condition of the leopard was static. “The zoo rescue team led by Dr Asadullah, Veterinary Assistant Surgeon rushed to the spot after receiving information from the Nalgonda Forest Divisional Officer (FDO) and rescued the panther safely by chemical immobilization. The leopard is currently under medical care and supervision of veterinarians at the Nehru Zoological Park, condition of panther is static,” the statement said.

The incident came to light on Tuesday morning after farmers noticed that instead of wild boars, a leopard was trapped in the metal snare. They then alerted the police, who in turn informed in the Forest department officials.

Title: IndiGo pilot threatens 75-year-old lady on wheelchair, daughter
Content:
This story is from January 15, 2020

Representative image

BENGALURU: A pilot working with IndiGo Airlines has been grounded for misbehaving with a 75-year-old passenger and her daughter on board flight 6E 806 from Chennai to Bengaluru on Monday.

According to the younger woman, who narrated her ordeal on social media on Tuesday, the pilot ‘harassed and threatened’ her and her mother for requesting wheelchair assistance upon landing at Kempegowda International Airport , Bengaluru.

Civil aviation minister Hardeep Singh Puri responded to the passenger on Twitter , assuring a full inquiry into the matter.

The passenger, Supriya Unni Nair, on Tuesday tweeted that the pilot ‘yelled’ at her and her mother and threatened to prevent them from disembarking. The pilot also threatened Supriya and her mother with jail time, she said, in a series of tweets.

“I requested my office to contact @Indigo6E as soon as I saw the tweet by Ms SupriyaUnniNair about the pilot’s behavior with her and her 75-yr old-mother. The has informd @MoCA_GoI that the pilot has been off-rostered pending full inquiry,” the minister tweeted in response to the complaint.

Supriya said she put out her experience on social media because what she and her mother went through was very traumatic. “Regardless of age, one must never be treated in this manner. This was the first time I was treated like this on a flight,” Supriya told TOI.

In her tweets, Supriya said: “@IndiGo6E Your captain on 6E 806 from Chennai to Bangalore on January 13 Jayakrishna harassed, threatened and prevented me and my 75-year old diabetic mom from disembarking the flight and threatened to arrest us because we asked for wheelchair assistance. I always ask for wheelchair beforehand for my mom & remind staff when we land. Staff on all airlines have always been helpful. Our flight was late & when we landed at 9:15 I tried calling the assistance bell & when the crew didn’t respond I walked up for help. She claimed we don’t have access to a wheelchair when it was clearly printed on the ticket. When I pointed this out to her, the captain came barging out and yelled at me for pressing the assistance button and annoying him and his crew. How dare you call her Veena he asks. (FYI her name tag says Veena) Taken aback, I tell him not to yell at me and then the threats start. The wheelchair guys arrive and he points at mom and says you’re not going anywhere (sic).”

Continuing with her tweet, Supriya said the pilot prevented the wheelchair assistants from taking her mother out of the aircraft and threatened them that he’d ensure they are detained and spend a night in jail.

Supriya said her mother got worried as the pilot was so aggressive that he looked like he’d get physically abusive with her. She asked the pilot not to be rude like that, to which he retorted he is the captain, his job is to fly the plane and not be polite to mere passengers. “You have paid piddly Rs 2000, you don’t own the aircraft ... I will make sure you are barred from the skies” Supriya tweeted him as saying.

“Captain’s parting shot was another threat that there will be an FIR filed against me and my mom… NONE of the other crew onboard 6E 806 intervened or helped us on the plane,” Supriya said.

Title: Bhainsa Violence: Bhainsa remains tense, 59 arrested
Content:
This story is from January 15, 2020

Police maintained strict vigil to prevent untoward incidents

HYDERABAD: Two days after the communal clash, Bhainsa continued to remain under strict police vigil. Around 1,000 police personnel, including two companies of Rapid Action Force (RAF), have been deployed in the Korva Galli and surrounding areas where the clashes took place. So far, 59 persons have been arrested in the six cases registered pertaining to the clashes.

Apart from one incident wherein a parked auto was set ablaze, the law and order remained peaceful on Tuesday. “Prohibitory orders are in place with imposition of section 144 of CrPC. We are not allowing any outsiders, including political leaders, to enter the communally sensitive areas,” inspector general (IG) Y Nagi Reddy said.

Police did not allow Adilabad MP Soyam Bapu Rao to visit the localities where clashes took place. The MP held a meeting with the IG and left the town. “Miscreants burnt the building belonging to one of the religious organisations. The family lodged a complaint and a case was registered. Police asked me not to go to the affected areas as it might lead to trouble,” the MP told TOI. In Hyderabad, police prevented lone-BJP MLA Raja Singh from going to Bhainsa and meeting a section of the violence-affected families on Tuesday. “I have been house arrested while I was leaving to Bhainsa,” Singh tweeted.

Of the six cases registered, one pertained to the damaging of property at a place of worship. Two cases have been registered, based on complaints of an inspector and constable, against rioters from both communities. A case of attempt to murder, criminal conspiracy and arson was registered on the basis of a complaint of a religious organisation’s head who alleged that his house was burnt.Another case was registered based on the complaint of a businessman who alleged that his car and two-wheeler were burnt. Police have also registered a case of assault following a complaint by a 65-year-old who sustained bleeding injuries as a result of the clash.

“So far, we have arrested 59 people in six cases. A total of 14 houses, 24 motorcycles, one car and two autos were damaged in violence. The number of cases might increase if more victims whose houses were burnt lodge separate complaints,” the IG said.

Title: 90% of rural kids aged 4-8 are now going to school
Content:
This story is from January 15, 2020

NEW DELHI: The latest Annual Status of Education Report (Rural) ( ASER 2019) released on Tuesday shows that 90% of children in the age group of 4-8 years are enrolled in some type of educational institution with the figure standing at 99.5% for the 8-year-olds.

Overall, more girls are going to school, but there are more boys in private schools than girls. While the ability at tasks improves substantially in the age group of 4 to 5, a large proportion of 5-year-olds are unable to perform expected tasks with ease, with children from less advantaged homes affected disproportionately.

The survey found that older students do better in terms of performance on cognitive, early language, early numeracy , and social and emotional learning. While 50% of the children whose mothers have eight years or less schooling ended up in anganwadis or government schools, mothers who studied beyond elementary stages are more likely to enrol their wards in private schools.

Every year, since 2005, ASER has reported on the schooling status and the ability of students at basic reading and arithmetic tasks for children in the 5-16 age group in rural India.

After 10 years on this job, ASER switched to an alternate-year cycle in 2016, where basic ASER is conducted every other year (2016, 2018, and next in 2020). In the intervening years, ASER focuses on a different aspect of children’s schooling and learning.

In 2019, ASER puts the spotlight on the early years, reporting on the schooling status, as well as on a range of important developmental indicators for young children in the age group of 4-8 years.

Conducted in 26 districts across 24 states in India, the survey covered 1,514 villages, 30,425 households, and 36,930 children in the age group of 4-8 years.

National policy recommends that children in the 4- to 5-year age bracket should be in pre-primary classes. At this stage, children should be encouraged to develop a range of abilities and skills, including cognitive, social, and emotional skills as well as the conceptual foundations needed for formal schooling.

Title: Education survey shows students in district struggle with numbers
Content:
This story is from January 15, 2020

Nagpur: Students aged between four to eight years are struggling with numbers (basic math problems) in Nagpur district, says a survey by NGO Pratham, published in its Annual Status of Education Report (Aser). This year Aser survey’s theme was ‘Early Years’, and they chose just one district in each state (except Madhya Pradesh and Uttar Pradesh), for their sample survey. Nagpur district was chosen in Maharashtra and the report states that only 4.8% students of Std I are able to do two-digit numeric addition.

Even in Std III, only 32.3% students were able to do numeric subtraction of two digits, whereas 46.4% were able to do two-digit numeric addition. Std II students fared worse, with only 17.8% being able to do two-digit numeric addition whereas only 9.9% were able to do two-digit numeric subtraction. For Std I students, the results were extremely poor as just 2% were able to do two-digit numeric subtraction whereas only 4.8% were able to add.

Statistics improved drastically when single-digit addition and subtraction problems were given to kids. For Std III, 78.1% students were able to do numeric subtraction whereas 88.4% were able to add. Std II students found things difficult with just 55.2% being able to do subtraction and 65.4% able to do addition.

Purshottam Panchbhai, office bearer of Mathematics Teachers Association (Nagpur), said, “The survey size sometimes skews the data drastically and is not truly representative of the larger ground reality. Regardless, math is something which children do find tough because probably they have not been taught in the correct way. Teaching has to be made more student-friendly with authorities adopting out-of-the box teaching techniques.”

Aser 2019 also surveyed ‘emotional’ aspect of children by asking them to identify emotions based on pictures shown to them. Four emotions; happy, sad, angry and afraid, were displayed through placards and students asked to relate to it. Children aged four identified the most with happy emotion, with 72.4% being able to recognize what feeling the picture in front of them generated.

For the remaining three emotions, only 40% odd kids were able to relate. At the upper end of the age group, eight-year-old students too were quickly able to recognize ‘happy’ with 88.6% responding correctly. But in contrast to the younger students, these eight-year-olds were also better at identifying the other three emotions, with a strike rate of anywhere between 60% to 75%.

Key points about Nagpur district in Aser 2019 report:-

SIZE OF SAMPLE SURVEY

60 villages

1,212 households

1,474 children

Age group 4-8

DISMAL STATISTICS

1.2% children not enrolled anywhere

97.5% children in pre-primary class

1.3% in Std I or above

21.1% children of Std I cannot read letters

53.2% can read letters but not words

16.9% children in Std I cannot recognize numbers up to nine

31.1% children in Std I can do a 1-digit oral word addition problem

31.9% can do a 1-digit oral word subtraction problem

Title: 3 channel partners jailed for telecasting Darbar
Content:
This story is from January 15, 2020

Madurai: Usilampatti police on Tuesday arrested three partners of a local channel for telecasting the recently released Darbar movie starring Rajinikanth. While the telecast took place on January 12, Lyca productions, which produced the movie, took the issue to the police and also issued a statement against the illegal act.

Meanwhile, CLN cinemas, a film distribution company, lodged a complaint with the Usilampatti police through its manager Sundarapandian. A team led by DSP, Usilampatti, Raja conducted an inquiry. The DSP said that four people have been booked under a couple of sections of Copyright Act and 506 (i)- criminal intimidation, and three of them were arrested. They were identified as Gubendran, Suresh and Manimaran, partners of the newly launched Saranya TV. Another police officer said that the channel was launched only a few weeks ago and they could have telecast the movie to gain attention among people. They have viewers based in and around Usilampatti, he said. Meanwhile, CLN cinemas conducted a press conference on Tuesday evening slamming Tamil rockers for releasing movies online and spoiling the business prospects of people who have invested huge money in them.

Title: Rare surgery performed at Rajaji hosp
Content:
This story is from January 15, 2020

Madurai: A rare tracheal resection and anastomosis was done at Government Rajaji Hospital (GRH) for a 35-year-old man who had developed breathing difficulties. The man had previously been admitted for drinking poison five months ago and survived on mechanical ventilation for a month.

The patient, Kesavan R from Sivagangai was admitted at GRH with symptoms of stridor and breathing difficulty which indicated stenosis or narrowing of the trachea or windpipe. “After being diagnosed through a 3D CT Scan, a tracheal resection of 3 cm length and subsequent anastomosis was done for the patient. It was a rare and delicate reconstructive procedure which was successfully completed. The patient was vulnerable because of the previous prolonged intubation,” said doctors.

With no complications post the surgery, Kesavan is expected to make complete recovery. tnn

Title: Except Calangute, no beach implements no-drinking law
Content:
This story is from January 15, 2020

Panaji: Six months after its introduction, the law penalising people for drinking on beaches and other public places is yet to be implemented. Except for Calangute, no other beach in the state has implemented the amended legislation—Registration of Tourist Trade Act.

Tourism minister Manohar Ajgaonkar on Tuesday held a meeting to discuss tourism related issues. The department is also yet to install signboards on beaches warning visitors that drinking is not allowed, and violators will be made to pay a penalty. “It has been decided to meet the DIG to find out why police have not been implementing the provisions of the Tourist Trade Act,” said an official who was part of the two-hour meeting. He added that it was felt police have not shown much interest in penalising people drinking on beaches.

Minister for science and technology Michael Lobo, who is also the Calangute MLA, said that since the amended provision of the act came into force, Calangute police registered 63 offences and penalised people. “If Calangute police can do it, why can’t other police stations,” said Lobo after the meeting. Calangute is the only panchayat so far to have installed signboards that drinking is not permitted and the offence will attract a penalty.

Persons held guilty of drinking on a beach attract a fine of Rs 2,000. A similar penalty is to be imposed on persons caught cooking in public spaces.

Lobo said it is only in his constituency that the amended Registration of Tourist Trade Act is being implement because he has been continuously pursuing the matter with the Calangute PI. If the existing rules are implemented in to-to, Lobo said Goa would not require to do anything more to keep nuisance tourists at bay. “Once they are penalised for drinking on a beach or cooking in the open and littering, they will either behave themselves or stop coming,” he said.

The legislation was amended after continued lobbying by tourism stakeholders who highlighted how drinking on beaches was manifesting into a big problem and needed to be stopped.

Title: Street hawkers mushroom in Salem region for Pongal sales
Content:
This story is from January 15, 2020

Salem/Erode: Street hawkers selling Pongal festival items were a common sight in Salem, Namakkal, Dharmapuri, Krishnagiri and Erode districts on Tuesday. More than 10,000 of them had surfaced in the region to sell sugarcane, turmeric plants, pots, fruits, banana and flowers.

M Athikesavan, a street hawker in Erode city, said, “It’s the 12th year that I am setting up this roadside shop on Bazaar Street to sell sugarcane and turmeric. I usually earn nearly Rs 10,000 in a single day.” He would wind up the business only on Wednesday afternoon.

According to him, during the festival, many sugarcane and turmeric farmers in the district come forward to sell their produce by themselves. “They will realize a good profit as therte won’t be any middlemen.”

The prices of the festival essentials have also, meanwhile, gone up. A pair of sugarcane, which was sold at Rs 40 on Monday night, was priced at Rs 50 on Tuesday morning. “The price touched Rs 80 in the evening and it will cross the Rs 100 mark on Wednesday morning,” said A Usharani, one of the sugarcane sellers in Salem city.

Similarly, a pair of turmeric plant was priced at Rs 40 on Tuesday morning. By evening, the price had crossed Rs 80. “The rate will further go up on Wednesday morning,” Usharani said.

Flower prices have also increased on the Pongal eve. One kilo of jasmine was priced at Rs 1,500 on Tuesday, up from Rs 300 last week. “The prices would come down only after the festival,” said S Kumar, a flower merchant in VOC flower market in Salem city.

Title: BJP’s door-to-door drive on CAA in Jaipur from Wednesday
Content:
This story is from January 15, 2020

Representative image

JAIPUR: Though dates for municipal elections have not been announced, political parties have already chalked out strategies to woo voters.

BJP has planned for a door-to-door campaign to spread awareness on Citizenship (Amendment) Act (CAA) from January 15 to 20 with a focus on minority communities.

The saffron party’s move to woo the minority communities comes on the backdrop of intense protest against CAA and NRC all over the country.

According to Jaipur BJP committee, the party will target at least 10 minority families in every booth. There are around 1,800 booths in the city which will make it a huge number for BJP in the elections.

Sunil Kothari, head of BJP (Jaipur city) said that the elections will be held soon in Jaipur which makes it necessary for the party to make people aware about the basis of the CAA.

“We have to start preparing now and clear doubts of the minority community regarding the CAA. Minorities are scared of CAA but it is actually in their benefit and we will work hard to make them understand that,” said Kothari.

Protests against CAA and NRC have been going on for a long time in the nation. Rajasthan Congress party is claiming that the BJP is trying to divert the mind of the people from the real issues.

Congress leader Archana Sharma said, “Economy is going down and unemployment is rising in the country. This is a crisis situation for the country and BJP is focused on the CAA. This is a method to divide people as they have no other option in fighting elections.”

She said that Congress party stands with the people of the country and will fight for the rights of the youth. Some councillors of the Congress party said that municipal elections should be fought on the local issues and not on national issues.

Title: One Billion Rising to focus on unity this year
Content:
This story is from January 15, 2020

A file photo of last year’s One Billion Rising

KOLKATA: The widespread protests against CAA and NRC has also touched One Billion Rising (OBR). Organised by Mary Ward Social Centre, an initiative of the Loreto order, housed on the premises of Loreto Entally, the annual programme to celebrate womanhood will give a clarion call to bridge all inequalities and urge people to stand by the minorities in their “hour of need”. The sixth edition of the programme in the city will be held at Allen Park , in association with the Kolkata Municipal Corporation, on January 31. The event will be in keeping with this year’s theme, Rise, Unite, Resist. “Hatred and exclusion has become the order of the day, dotted with lingering insecurity of the minorities,” reads the national pledge. One Billion Rising (OBR) is a global movement started by women’s rights activist Eve Ensler in 2012 in response to the UN data that stated that one billion girls/women across the world faced or lived with threat of violence. In India, OBR is headquartered in Delhi. The partners in different cities organise programmes, themed on topics adopted for the year. “OBR is a celebration of womanhood, we sing paeans to the feminine spirit, which is indomitable. This year, however, we cannot limit our protest to just the cause of women because the atmosphere of the country is charged with insecurity... we are at one with the national resolution of OBR,” said Loreto nun Monica Suchiang, director of the Mary Ward Social centre. The national resolution doesn’t mince words when it says, “We stand amidst a rising tide of nationalism, staggering economic crisis, attacks on academic autonomy, violation of basic human rights and a repressive regime. Citizens who were ensured a right to vote are being de-legitimised as non-citizens and are on the verge of being expelled from the country. We call for a collective rising…” Though the theme changes every year, the focus remains on violence against women, with renowned singers, schools and the who’s who in the city participating to show solidarity with the cause. Given the nationwide movement against the new citizenship law and NRC, the organisers will hold a panel discussion, “Addressing the inequality chain”, where the speakers will include social entrepreneur and arts curator Nandita Pal Chaudhuri, model Nick Rampal, gender rights activist Saira Halim, social activists Madiha Ahmed and Deep Purakayastha and writer Anchita Ghatak. The discussion will be moderated by Anglo Indian MLA Shane Calvert. Calvert, who has been vocal not only against CAA and NRC but also against the de-reservation of Anglo Indian seats in the Parliament and state legislative assemblies, felt OBR will rightly reflect minority insecurities. “We have to resist, rise and speak in one voice against different forms of injustices and inequalities that are being meted out to us. Hope, we are able to create a change-making dialogue,” he said.

Title: Class VII kid crushed under wheels of government bus
Content:
This story is from January 15, 2020

Representative image

KRISHNAGIRI: A Class VII girl student died after she fell from a government bus and came under the wheels near Denkanikottai on Tuesday evening. The incident took place when the victim was returning home from school in the bus.

The deceased was identified as M Akshaya, 12, of Thadikkal village near Denkanikottai. She was studying Class VII in John Britto Aided High School at Denkanikottai.

Akshaya was travelling on the footboard of the crowded bus.

“She lost her grip and fell. She came under the wheels of the bus and died on the spot,” an officer from the Denkanikottai police said.

The body was taken to the government hospital at Denkanikottai for postmortem. The Denkanikottai police have registered a case and further investigation is on.

Title: Eco buffer zone outside Mukundra tiger turf planned
Content:
This story is from January 15, 2020

MHTR will be first tiger reserve in the state for which an ESZ will be declared

JAIPUR: The ministry of environment and climate change has issued a draft notification to declare a 1km eco-sensitive zone around Mukundra Hills Tiger Reserve (MHTR) spread over 759.99 sq-km covering the four districts of Kota, Bundi, Chittorgarh and Jhalawar.

The ministry, which had issued the notification on January 10, has sought suggestions and objections within 60 days.

This is the first tiger reserve in the state for which an ESZ will be declared. The MHTR, established in 2013, encompasses areas of Mukundara Hills National Park, Dara Sanctuary, Jawahar Sagar Sanctuary and part of National Chambal Ghariyal Sanctuary (From Garadia Mahadev to Jawahar Sagar Dam) which constitutes its core area.

A senior forest official said the eco-sensitive zones will be treated as a ‘breathing space’ for wildlife. It is demarcated based on their ecological importance which reigns in development activities inimical to wildlife and their habitats.

While the zone will be completely compatible to livelihoods of local communities living around the tiger reserve, it will bring the order on tourism, mining activities, industries and other footloose development activities disrupting wildlife corridors outside reserve boundary.

“The ESZ is a critical tool for wildlife conservation and MHTR is in the process to declare it soon,” said an official

The reserve is not only rich in scenic beauty and biodiversity, but also has at least two probable corridors from Ranthambhore– one through Indergarh - Lakheri - Ramgarh Vishdhari Sanctuary-Dabi – Jawahar Sagar Sanctuary and the other through the ravines of Chambal and Kalisindh to Dara. The draft reads, “Special efforts are required to conserve this rich natural heritage, to provide safe passage/corridor to the tigers of adjacent Ranthambhore Tiger Reserve and to reintroduce tigers in the area. Hence it has been given special legal protection as is available under Section 38(V) of Wildlife (Protection) Act, 1972 by constituting it as a tiger reserve.”

A draft notification of the environment ministry also mentions that the government shall also constitute a state-level eco-sensitive zone monitoring committee (SESZMC) to monitor the compliance of the ESZ notification.

An offical source said, “No fresh mining lease shall be granted in the eco-sensitive zone and the existing mining leases, if any, shall be phased out in five years or with the term of current lease renewal, whichever is earlier.”

Title: Kolkata: Students donate ‘gifts of survival’ to women protesting at Park Circus
Content:
This story is from January 15, 2020

The women at Park Circus Maidan with the supply of sanitary napkins and biscuits

KOLKATA: The protesters at Park Circus Maidan, who have been braving the cold to stage a sit-in demonstration against the CAA and NRC, have received “gifts” from three students to see them through the trying times.

Md Masoom Rana Dewan, Debkanya Halder and their friend distributed sanitary napkins, bottled water and a bag full of biscuits to the women who have been stationed at the maidan for the past one week without even basic amenities, like washroom, running water and shelter from the biting cold. The three have also urged citizens to support the movement by donating shawls, bed sheets, bottled water and packaged food, rudimentary everyday items that the protesters need.

On her earlier visit to what is now being called Kolkata’s Shaheen Bagh , Debkanya noticed the hardship the women had been facing. “Hundreds of women, children and infants are sitting here and protesting for the past one week without basic amenities. We thought of getting them sanitary napkins as there are women of all ages at the venue. We also got them water and biscuits,” said the research scholar, adding that this was the least they could do for the women, who were fighting a battle for everyone. Referring to the distribution of sanitary napkins, Nousheen Baba Khan, a research scholar and a participant, said, “This act has shattered taboos about menstruation.”

Farhat Islam, a homemaker who has been at Park Circus since last Tuesday said, “These small gestures motivate us to carry on this protest.” Asmat Jamil, an NGO activist, said, “It shows how concerned the young generation is. They think about the problems women here might face. I am thankful to everyone who is supporting this movement, without any political banner.”

For Masoom, it is their duty, as a sensitive human being, to stand by those protesting at this hour of crisis. He is using social media to mobilise people so that more women can join the demonstration. He has also urged citizens that on their next visit ti the protest venue, they could get shawls, bed sheets, packaged food, bottled-water and sanitary napkins.

The sit-in, which started last Tuesday with a group of burqa-clad women and students from different campuses, has witnessed a steady rise in the number of participants, with more and more people joining in every day. Debkanya and Masoom’s friend, who studies abroad, has come home for a holiday. He is overwhelmed to see hundreds of women, along with their kids, spending nights in the open, shouting slogans ‘Azaadi’, ‘Halla Bol’, ‘Inquilab Zindabad’ to protest against the discriminatory law.

“Privileged people like us walk rallies and then return to the comfort of our homes. But what these people are doing is heartening and powerful. It can be called a true people’s movement,” said the youngster. He added that the movement could not be limited to only rallies and meetings. “The presence of more people will strengthen the movement and will help send out a message of inclusiveness,” he said.

Title: Flying colours above, festivities on ground
Content:
This story is from January 15, 2020

Jaipur: Kites of various hues and shapes ruled the city sky on Tuesday. Right from early morning, thousands of these flying beauties filled the sky while people on the ground celebrated Makar Sankranti.

People of all ages gathered at Jal Mahal where a kite festival was organised by the tourism department. Inaugurating the festival, tourism minister Vishwendra Singh said, “It is a festival of the city which should be celebrated with fanfare. I am happy that we have been able to preserve the rich heritage of the city which attracts thousands of tourists every year.”

Kites ranging three inches to 25 feet were flown near Jal Mahal. Abdul Raoof, founder of Pink City Kite Club, flew kites from Holland, New Zealand and China. “We have kites from all over the world and this festival help us to showcase our possession. However, people snap our kites which is unfortunate and a major financial loss for us. People must understand that these unique kites should not to be cut as they are every expensive,” said Abdul.

After a few of his kites were cut, Abdul decided to stop flying them and just display them at his counter to avoid any more losses.

A shopkeeper from the Walled City, Mohammad Akram, was flying his 8-feet-long kite at Jal Mahal. Akram said his kites are home-made and designed for the special occasion of Makar Sankranti. “I have made three 8-feet-long and 5.5-feet-wide kites. These require normal materials as used in any other kites, but the quantity is more. It costs between Rs 1,200 and Rs 1,500 per kite. Last year I made a 12-feet-long kite. Have to be cautious though, people are always eyeing to cut this kite,” he said.

At City Palace, kite and wooden charkhi of Sawai Ram Singh II of 1870 were displayed. As per the descriptions given by the palace authorities, the kite shaped like a butterfly is called as Tukkal, which were famous during his era.

Title: NIA seizes Rs 82 lakh in NSCN (IM) funding case
Content:
This story is from January 15, 2020

NEW DELHI: Searches conducted by the National Investigation Agency (NIA) in Imphal and Dimapur on Tuesday in a case relating to terror funding of Naga rebel outfit NSCN (IM), led to recovery of Rs 82.6 lakh cash, documents of properties worth Rs 3 crore and other incriminating material, the agency said.

The searches were carried out at five premises of close associates and relatives of accused Alemla Jamir, wife of NSCN (IM) steering committee member Pungting Shimrang alias James Jamir. Alemla, alleged to be working for NSCN (IM), was arrested last year from New Delhi airport with Rs 72 lakh in cash.

The NIA registered a case alleging terror funding of NSCN (IM) — wherein unaccounted funds were being taken by “cash courier” Alemla from Delhi to Nagaland .

Searches conducted on Tuesday at the premises of close associates and relatives of Alemla led to recovery of Rs 82.6 lakh in cash, documents of properties worth Rs 3 crore, incriminating diaries, photographs, digital devices including 15 smartphones, a hard disk, a pen drive, a memory card and four laptops.

Certain insurgency and extortion related literatures as well as other documents were also seized.

Sources said the searches also revealed that unaccounted money was being used for purchase of properties.

An NIA official said the recoveries showed that NSCN (IM) leaders were using money from extortion activities to buy personal properties.

An NIA special court had on January 10 extended the judicial custody of Alemla for one month. Her husband Pungting Shimrang is absconding.

Title: Frauds strike before e-sale season in Kolkata
Content:
Representative image

KOLKATA: A caller introduces himself or herself as a representative from an online sales platform and offers hefty discounts, prizes to and special access to products to a ‘lucky winner’ way before the big discount sales begin. The customer takes the bait and before s/he realizes, she is left poorer by several thousand rupees. Sounds familiar? Online scams are back this year with the same modus operandi.In the latest incident, for which an FIR was registered on Monday, Hindustan Park resident Chandra Chur Banik claimed to have lost Rs 46,500 to fraudsters. He received a text message from an unknown number. Identifying themselves as e-commerce company employees, the sender stated that Banik had won Rs 12,80,000 in a lucky draw. “Accordingly they induced the complainant to deposit a processing fee of Rs 46,500, thus cheating him of the amount,” a Gariahat cop said.Kolkata police have cited a communication from an e-commerce site to advise consumers to be wary of frauds in the upcoming discount season around Republic Day. Now, almost a yearly phenomenon beyond the festive months, four incidents of online frauds offering prizes to ‘lucky draw winners’ in south Kolkata has led cops to act.“Several teams from the cybercrime cell are already probing the multiple e-wallet frauds that took place in the city under the garb of KYC verification. Investigators are working on the Bengal-Bihar and Bihar-Jharkhand borders. New cases will only increase the panic,” an officer said.Kolkata police has decided to prepare a Standard Operating Procedure for online shopping portals to stop cheats from using their platform. Cops said that they would forward their recommendations to the firms, detailing how the employee of an e-commerce platform managed to steal and then sell confidential data of customers to a gang of cheats.Cops have established that customer data — including their contact details and buying preferences — is being sold at the throwaway price of Rs 10 per person. “We found that a few former employees of such companies are selling crucial customer data to the gang members. This means that the accused not only had the contact details of their victims, but also details of their buying preferences. Hence, when the fraudsters contact the customers, the latter has little inkling of the trap,” an officer explained.

Title: Cong MLA trying to topple Puducherry govt, says whip
Content:
This story is from January 15, 2020

Puducherry: Government whip R K R Anantharaman accused Congress MLA N Danavelu , who levelled corruption charges against chief minister V Narayanasamy, his son and health minister Malladi Krishna Rao, of acting as an agent of the BJP party and attempting to topple the Congress government in the Union territory.

Speaking to the media on Tuesday, Anantharaman charged that Danavelu has been making attempts to overthrow the Congress government and form a government headed by the former chief minister and All India NR Congress founder-leader N Rangasamy.

He alleged that Danavelu with the support of AIADMK MLAs attempted to broker a deal with an independent MLA from Mahe for the change in government. He said the Congress MLA has not been in the fold of the party and not been participating in the party affairs for the past two years.

“He (Danavelu) failed to work for the party’s candidate in the recently-held Lok Sabha polls. He has launched efforts to create a mirage that the Congress government failed to implement people welfare schemes,” Anantharaman said. He strongly condemned Danavelu’s remarks that chief minister has become ‘unfit to govern the Union territory’ and has occupied the post ‘through the back door’.

“Danavelu has levelled false charges of corruption against the chief minister and others. In fact, he was the third elected member to sign after Narayanasamy was unanimously elected as the Congress legislative party leader and was set to occupy the top post,” the government whip said. Anantharaman challenged the Congress MLA to prove the charges of corruption against the chief minister and others.

Condemning Danavelu for attempting to tarnish the image of the Congress government, Anantharaman said a CBI probe into activities of the Puducherry Agro Products, Food and Civil Supplies Corporation (Papsco) managed by chairman Danavelu will expose his corrupt practices.

Anantharaman pointed out that the Congress government allotted Rs 50 crore of a Rs 100-crore centrally sponsored project to the Bahour assembly segment represented by Danavelu to refute the charges levelled by the MLA that his constituency has been ignored by the government.

Moreover, the government has earmarked Rs 1.5 crore to construct an indoor stadium at Bahour constituency and the construction work has begun, he said.

Anantharaman while refuting MLA’s charges maintained that the health directorate has ensured adequate stock of life-saving drugs at the government hospitals and centres in the territory.

“The MLA does not have the political maturity. He is carried away by his emotions. It is high time that he changes his attitude and approach lest the party high command will take appropriate action against him,” Anantharaman said.

Title: Credit card fraud on the rise, victims lose Rs 50k to Rs 2 lakh
Content:
This story is from January 15, 2020

Hyderabad: Cases of credit card fraud are fast rising in the city. This is evident from the fact that there have been over 60 such cases across the city recently, where the fraudsters lured the victims in the guise of a bank employee asking them to clear dues or increase the limit. Victims have lost Rs 50,000 to Rs 2 lakh.

In a recent incident of credit card fraud, a 28-year-old private employee from Borabanda lost Rs 87,000. “The accused asked for one-time-password (OTP) and said that the transaction could not be completed due to a problem,” said the victim. The victim provided his OTP seven times and in the process, lost Rs 87,000. The accused had lured him by asking him to clear his credit card dues.

In another incident, A 32-year-old businessman from Nizampet lost over Rs 50,000. According to the victim, the offenders, pretending to be from the credit card department of Axis Bank, offered to increase the card limit and sought the details. The victim provided the details and lost the money, after which the accused switched off his mobile phone.

According to the police, there have been instances where the victims have lost money without receiving the OTP. “The credit card details are sold on the dark web, the fraudsters who are based abroad get the details or buy them online and then use the details to carry out transactions. The victims in Hyderabad or Mumbai would then get a message that someone bought something with their resources in London,” said a police officer.

Title: 980 students have enrolled in govt’s Neet coaching
Content:
This story is from January 15, 2020

Madurai: Since September 2019, 980 students have enrolled for the government’s free Neet coaching classes offered at 15 centres in the district.

District education officials said the number is relatively less as compared to the previous year, but more students are expected to join in the next few months.

Among the 980 students, 510 are from Class 12 while 470 are from Class 11, according to data from the chief education officer’s (CEO) office.

The last date for registration of application for Neet was January 6. Among the 510 Class 12 students, 120 have applied for the exam. The applicants include 45 for Tamil medium and 83 for English medium.

The coaching centres in Madurai are all government or aided higher secondary schools at Sokkalingapuram, Karungalakudi, Othakadai, Melur, Thiruparankundram, Kallikudi, Peraiyur, Usilampatti, Sedapatty, Alanganallur, Chekkanoorani, and Solavandhan. OCPM and Sethupathi schools in Madurai city and PKN Boys school in Thirumangalam make up the rest of the 15 centres. Classes are being conducted during the weekends, with practice tests also being conducted every Friday and Sunday.

The Neet coaching classes are being conducted by trained government teachers who have been duly appointed.

“The classes are completely organized by the government and there is no tie-up with any NGO for faculty or study material,” said one of the officials responsible for co-ordinating the programme.

Officials also said they are yet to plan on conducting special camps for Neet coaching in March and April. “Last year, we had handpicked students from across the state including Madurai to attend special intensive Neet coaching camps in Theni, Chennai etc. We might organize such camps this year too,” added the official.

Title: Military training will instill patriotism, says Sawant
Content:
This story is from January 15, 2020

Panaji: Chief minister Pramod Sawant on Tuesday said that compulsory military training would instill patriotism among citizens.

“I am not saying that military training should be made compulsory, but if it is done so, it will inculcate patriotism in all Indians— and today, that is required in the country”, Sawant said.

Without directly referring to the anti-CAA protests in the country, Sawant said, “I feel that there is less patriotism in the civilians in the country”, emphasising that such training would do the nation good. Sawant was speaking at ‘know your Army mela’, organised as a part of the 72nd Army Day celebration, at Campal , Panaji.

He further said when Prime Minister Narendra Modi makes any law in Parliament, it is binding on the people of this country and “our responsibility to follow the law”. Applauding the Armed forces for their role in liberating Goa from Portuguese rule, Sawant said that it is unfortunate that Goa had to wait for 14 years after India’s independence to gain freedom.

“Then Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru was responsible for the delay in liberating Goa,” said Sawant. “If he had political will and had really cared about Goans, then Goa would have been liberated in 1947,” he added.

I am not saying that military training should be made compulsory, but if it is done so, it will inculcated patriotism in all Indians and today, it is required in the country

Title: Cop security, medical & transport aid for Dhangar families
Content:
This story is from January 15, 2020

Valpoi: Taking cognisance of the memorandum submitted by the Dongurli-Thane panchayat, the Sattari deputy collector and other officials visited Golauli, Sattari, on Tuesday to hear the grievances of families whose members have been arrested in connection with the four tiger deaths that took place in the Mhadei Wildlife Sanctuary. The panchayat had submitted the memorandum to Sattari deputy collector Mangaldas Gaonkar seeking provision of necessary facilities — security, transport and medical aid — for the family members of those held.

Gaonkar was accompanied by Sattari mamlatdar Anil Rane Sardessai, sub-divisional police officer Gurudas Gawade, Valpoi police inspector Shivram Vaingankar, Valpoi CHC health officer Dr Gajanan Naik among other officials.

The family members urged officials to help them out of the troubles they had been facing over the past few days. The officials assured their assistance and Gaonkar told the children who had been missing school that transport arrangements had been made for them to start attending by Wednesday.

The deputy collector also said that the police had been deployed in Golauli to serve as protection to the families. “They need not worry about living alone in the forest as police personnel will be present round the clock to guard them,” he said.

Health officer Dr Gajanan Naik said that after administering the necessary medication, the health of people was improving. He added that health officials will visit their houses in case of any emergency. Officials said food items had also been handed out to families.

Title: 2 Jadavpur University students beaten up by BJP workers
Content:
This story is from January 15, 2020

Representative image

KOLKATA: Two students at Jadavpur University were reportedly attacked by BJP supporters near the Bikramgarh market in Tollygunge on Tuesday evening.

Trouble started after BJP workers, who had organised a programme to garner support for CAA, allegedly badmouthed JU and its students for supporting the anti-CAA protests. An argument broke out between the BJP workers and the JU students, who were at the spot. Soon, it snowballed into a fight, with the BJP supporters allegedly beating the two up.

But before it could spiral out of control, cops reined them in. No complaint was lodged till late. Several students took to social media to write about the attack and requested others to assemble to neutralise further attacks by BJP supporters.

Title: GRH doctors remove 150g heart tumour from 11-year-old in Madurai
Content:
This story is from January 15, 2020

Representative image

MADURAI: Doctors at Government Rajaji Hospital (GRH) in Madurai have removed a tumour weighing 150g from the heart of an 11-year-old girl.

Seethalakshmi G, a Class VI student from Tirunelveli district, had been complaining of palpitations and chest pain.

Admitted to GRH, an echo cardiogram and a CT scan revealed she has cardiac fibroma, a benign tumour in the right ventricular chamber of her heart.

Doctors performed an open-heart surgery on her on January 13 and removed the tumour sized 9cm x 6cm x 4cm and weighing 150g.

“It is a rare surgical procedure,” said Dr Rathnavel A, former head of the cardio thoracic department at GRH.

Dr Rathnavel led the team of doctors who treated Seethalakshmi.

The Glenn shunt procedure was done after the surgery to re-join the right pulmonary artery and superior vena cava to ensure proper blood flow with the right ventricle.

“There were no complications during post-operative care. Seethalakshmi has now made complete recovery and will be able to lead a normal life,” said GRH Dean, Dr Sangumani J.

The treatment, which could cost up to Rs 5 lakh, was done free of cost under the Chief Minister’s Comprehensive Health Insurance Scheme (CMCHIS).

Title: West Bengal: 4 held for forgery of NSCs, KVPs
Content:
This story is from January 15, 2020

Representative image

KOLKATA: The detective department nabbed four men on Monday night from various parts of the city and South 24 Parganas for allegedly duping a public bank using 60 fake National Savings Certificates (NSC) and securing a total loan of Rs 40 lakh.

Seizures worth Rs 47 lakh were made from them. Another 60 fake NSCs with face value of Rs 10,000 each and 84 fake Kisan Vikas Patras (KVP) of Rs 50,000 face value each were seized from them. The complaint was lodged by the bank in July last year, following an internal probe that revealed that the loan had not been repaid for a long time.

Joint CP (crime) Murlidhar Sharma said, “The accused produced 60 fake NSCs and siphoned off Rs 40 lakh. The verification was done via post and the results were passed off as genuine,” said Sharma. The accused had applied for the loan at the bank’s Jodhpur Park branch to start a business and it was processed at its Shakespeare Sarani branch. “The roles of then branch manager and the postal department are also not beyond doubt,” another officer said.

Title: Kolkata: Salt Lake doctor, alone at home, found dead
Content:
This story is from January 15, 2020

Joy Basu’s CD Block house where he died

KOLKATA: A doctor, in his early forties, who lived alone at his Salt Lake CD Block house-cum-chamber was found dead on Monday evening. Cops said he suffered a cardiac arrest. They informed his sister — the only immediate family he had — who lives in the USA.

Alerted by neighbours and the domestic help of the doctor, Joy Basu, cops broke into the house, to find him lying on his bed. He had no pulse and was frothing at the mouth.

There was no injury and a blanket was wrapped around the body, indicating that he had probably died in sleep. “Basu had been living alone for several years. We sent his body to RG Kar Medical College and Hospital where an autopsy confirmed that he had died of cardiac arrest,” said a senior officer of the Bidhannagar commissionerate.

Basu, who was a doctor of medicine (MD), was a general physician. Cops said he suffered from schizophrenia and was under medication. “Of late, he had stopped seeing patients. A relative confirmed his condition,” the officer said.

On Monday, Basu didn’t open the door despite repeated knocks by the domestic help. She then alerted the neighbours, who called the police. “Basu’s sister said she would need three to four days to fly to Kolkata. We have informed his aunt who helped us with the legal procedures, but we can hand over the body only after his sister approves. Till she arrives, his body will be kept in a morgue,” said another officer.

An elderly neighbour said that he was a popular doctor in the area.

Title: Tiger trouble: Rs 15k payout for 2 families
Content:
This story is from January 15, 2020

Valpoi: The families whose cows were attacked by a tiger at Golauli and Deroda villages in Sattari received Rs 15,000 compensation each from the Chief Minister’s Relief Fund.

On Tuesday, deputy conservator of forests (DCF), North Goa, Kuldeep Sharma, and Valpoi range forest officer handed over compensation cheques of Rs 15,000 to Vitho Pawane’s family (received by his wife Gangi Pawane) of Golauli and to Ladko Jadhav from Derode. Dongurli-Thane sarpanch Prajita Gawas was also present. On December 20, a tiger had killed a cow belonging to Pawane. In the second incident, another cow was killed by the tiger at Derode belonging to Jadhav. A third family from Golavali whose buffalo was attacked by the tiger has not received compensation yet. tnn

Title: Albert Hall turns into Jaipur’s Shaheen Bagh
Content:
This story is from January 15, 2020

Jaipur: The iconic Albert Hall of Jaipur is turning out to be Jaipur’s Shaheen Bagh. From the last 11 days, over 200-500 people — mostly women in large numbers — protesting against CAA , NPR and NRC, gathering from 5pm to 7pm, are drawing attention not only from the locals but foreign visitors too.

Taking a cue from Shaheen Bagh in Delhi, everyday protest begins by a group of women raising slogans ‘Aawaz do, hum ek hai (Call, we are one). CAA ka kala kanoon wapas lo (Take back draconian CAA).’ The protest culminates at sharp 7pm, by taking a pledge over the preamble of the Constitution.

Three siblings — Saba, Huda and Mehnaz Ahmed — holding a copy of the Constitution and portrait of Baba Bhimrao Ambedkar started the protest on Tuesday, by reading the poem of Faiz Ahmed Faiz ‘Hum Dekhenge’ (We will see) and for the next two hours, the trio anchored, coordinated and managed the crowd at the venue.

“It is crystal clear that CAA is just one side of the coin and the real intention of the government is to strip the citizenship of Muslims. I am coming every day as it is about the future of my family,” said a medical student Saba, who is also joined by her father Tariq Ahmed and Gazal Parveen.

These women come from the middle class families, mostly housewives, who also bring children every day braving the chilly cold winds. The protesters chose to celebrate Makar Sankranti or the kite festival at the venue by distributing kites with a message saying ‘No to CAA, NRC and NPR’. Most of the men are young and have never participated in any protest. Sharzil Ali of Sawai Madhopur has joined as a protester and has become the most visible face among men in the protest. Building momentum every day is difficult but not impossible, says Mujahid Naqvi, one of the coordinators of the event, who every day seeks ideas from the people to make the protest attractive and creative. “By now, everybody is aware of dangers of CAA added with NRC to vulnerable communities, especially Muslims. Our protests aims at evoking the sense of activism among the last man standing and seeking support from others,” said Naqvi. Several Dalit groups have also extended their support to the daily protest.

Title: Realtors seek to strike big by using riches to test their luck in municipal poll race
Content:
This story is from January 15, 2020

Apart from politicians, many realtors willl test their luck in the Medchal civic body poll race.

After the completion of withdrawal of nominations, a total of 118 candidates are in the fray in 23 civic wards of Medchal municipality and over 60% of the candidates are realtors.

Explaining his reason for contesting the poll, a realtor opined, “The civic polls are being conducted for the first time after Medchal Nagarapanchayat become as municipality. There is nothing wrong in contesting the polls. We have enough money and decided to contest in the elections to serve the people. Of course, we are new for voters but as realtors, we have contacts with them.”

Another realtor said, “One need not have political experience to serve the people of Medchal. My agenda is to resolve the civic issues on top priority and being available round-the-clock for the voters.”

“The large amounts of money earned through real estate has encouraged the realtors to contest in the polls. The money may play a key role in these elections to impress the voters,” according to a political analyst.

Moreover, Medchal is among the top real estate hubs after Kompally, Gundlapochampally, Manikonda, Gachibowli and Madhapur. “All the realtors have become ‘crorepatis’ after selling out hundreds of acres due to the real estate boom for the past decade,” he said.

While major political parties including TRS, Congress and BJP have fielded their candidates in civic polls, the realtors in fray will make their political debut without parties’ support.

The fate of 118 candidates will be decided by 35,899 voters in the polls to be held on January 22.

Title: Congress, NSUI demand action against SHO who lathi-charged protesters on campus
Content:
This story is from January 15, 2020

AGRA: A delegation of Congress and National Students Union of India (NSUI) leaders met senior superintendent of police (SSP) Babloo Kumar on Tuesday and demanded action against Hariparwat station house officer Ajay Kaushal for allegedly abusing and ordering lathi-charge on protesters on Dr Bhimrao Ambedkar University’s Paliwal Park campus on Saturday.

According to NSUI leaders, they complained to the SSP that Kaushal was “biased” in his action as the protesters had their allegiance to the Akhil Bharatiya Vidyarthi Parishad (ABVP) were not even touched by policemen.

Congress’ district president Manoj Dixit and city president Devendra Singh said they demanded a fair investigation into the matter and immediate suspension of the SHO.

Dixit said, “The SHO should be suspended immediately for brutally beating and abusing students. NSUI state secretary Satish Sikarwar and coordinator Ankush Gautam got their hands fractured in the lathi-charge ordered by the SHO. Several other NSUI workers sustained injuries. We have video clips as evidence of his brutality.”

NSUI spokesperson Apoorv Sharma said, “Taking cognisance of the matter, the SSP assured us of a fair investigation and suitable action. We will move court if denied justice”.

On Saturday afternoon, ABVP activists had also assembled on the Paliwal Park campus and protested against recent violence on the campus of Jawaharlal Nehru University in Delhi and demanded that left-wing organisations should be banned on the JNU campus.

Later, NSUI and SCS members also gathered on the Paliwal Park campus and high-pitch sloganeering ensued between them that lasted for around 40 minutes. During the protest, a minor scuffle took place between members of ABVP and NSUI and police resorted to lathi-charge to disperse protesters.

Title: CM Narayanasamy urges Shah to grant statehood to Pondy
Content:
This story is from January 15, 2020

Puducherry: Chief minister V Narayanasamy called on home minister Amit Shah , defence minister Rajnath Singh and finance minister Nirmala Sitharaman in New Delhi on Tuesday and urged them to fulfil various demands of the Union territory of Puducherry.

Narayanasamy urged Shah to accord statehood for the Union territory, extend additional central assistance, hike financial assistance by 10% every year, waive legacy loans, refund expenses incurred for implementing recommendations of 7th central pay commission, pay pension and other dues to employees of central government in Puducherry like in Delhi and release the Centre’s share for centrally-sponsored schemes until Puducherry attains statehood.

He insisted that Nirmala Sitharaman release Goods and Services Tax (GST) compensation to Puducherry immediately.

The chief minister requested Rajnath Singh for surveillance of Navy vessels off Tamil Nadu and Puducherry coasts to protect fishermen from the two regions from possible attacks by Sri Lankan Navy.

Title: Man caught for bid to steal chain
Content:
This story is from January 15, 2020

Hyderabad: Locals caught a thief while he was attempting to steal a gold chain of an elderly woman on Qadari Chaman Road in Falaknuma on Tuesday. The thief was handed over to Falaknuma police and the chain was recovered from his possession.

The incident occurred at 9am on Tuesday when the victim, Shankaramma (68), a resident of Gandhi Nagar in Falaknuma, and her granddaughter, were on their way to a tiffin centre to buy breakfast.

The accused (30), appeared from behind the victim on a bike and tried to snatch the gold chain weighing around 2.5 tolas. “While the accused was trying to escape, a few locals caught hold of him,” said police.

The accused was booked under IPC Section 392 (robbery). tnn

Title: ‘Discrepancies in police affidavit in AMU violence’
Content:
This story is from January 15, 2020

Agra: Police’s claim justifying their December 15 action on AMU campus on grounds that they were summoned by the university authorities there and they did not make an unwarranted entry have proved to be inconsistent with the registrar’s letter and subsequent orders they have produced in the court, according to the lawyer for the students’ coordination committee, Asad Hayat.

The lawyer said though the affidavit filed by police states that the university registrar had requested for appropriate police force on the campus to control public order on December 15, the compliance order by the SSP was signed on December 16, a day after the police had entered the campus.

Claiming this to be a major discrepancy, which exposes both police and AMU authorities, Hayat said the students had presented these discrepancies to the National Human Rights Commission team, which is probing the alleged police aggression on the campus. Hayat said the SP (city) concerned and SSP had signed on the registrar’s letter on December 16, thus ruling out the possibility of any typographical error.

Hayat told TOI that this is an important fact, which indicates that the police entered the campus on the night of December 15 on their own and made an attempt to justify their actions by using the “hand written” letter of the AMU registrar of December 15. He alleged that this is a “post-facto” justification made by the police for their presence on university campus on the night of the violence.

When contacted, DIG Akash Kulhary said action was required on the spot and they could not have waited for the signatures during the prevailing situation on the campus then.

In the affidavit filed by the district authorities, it was stated that when the situation went beyond control, the university administration had sent a hand written letter (December 15) requesting the district administration to use appropriate force to control public order on the campus. There was no option for the district administration and police force but to enter the campus to disperse the gathering, prevent the property from being damaged and to avoid any further violence.

Title: No flights delayed due to lanterns
Content:
This story is from January 15, 2020

Jaipur: No flights were delayed from Jaipur International Airport due to manjha and lanterns on Tuesday as confirmed by the authorities. On Monday, the Airports Authority of India (AAI), Jaipur, issued an advisory urging people not to fly kites or lamps within the 5km periphery of the airport.

Title: Birds bear brunt of manjha in Jaipur, many won’t fly again
Content:
This story is from January 15, 2020

An injured Grey Lag Goose being treated at a rescue centre in J L N Marg on Tuesday
