JAIPUR: Kite festival again turns out to be horrific day for birds. A bright sunny day with ideal kite flying conditions on Tuesday turned out to be problematic for the winged creatures in the city.

Despite a ban on the deadly glass-coated manjha (string) and mass awareness campaigns by the admin, scores of birds were grievously injured. The volunteers rescuing injured birds were ferrying them in show boxes to temporary med camps but the baskets fall short as the number of injured birds increased when the day progressed. The kite strings caused mass death of birds, both indigenous and foreign species.

A Grey Lag Geese rescued from Benar Road was diagnosed with the joint capsule rupture of wing with severe laceration of wing. “The bird underwent cross pinning to stabilize the joint. It is likely to survive,” said veterinarians Dr Ushma Patel and Dr Rina Dev who treated the bird at the makeshift bird hospital at Ramniwas Garden.

Rohit Gangwal of RAKSHA NGO holding a medical camp informed that the day saw one of the highest injured birds. “Our team of doctors have handled over 200 injured birds with many of them will never able to fly again,” said Gangwal.

Similar is the situation at a bird rescue camp at EWCS at Jain temple in Raja Park. Dr Vikas Sharma told that the rescue calls have come from even far-off areas like Bhakrota, Tail end of Sitapura and Kalawar. “I believe that more number of rescue centres must come up to handle the rising rescue calls. The far-off calls means that chances of bird survival is very low as the caller rarely guard the injured bird for an hour or two,” said Sharma.

Title: Mauvin: Won’t be able to reduce Motor Vehicles Act fines
Content:
This story is from January 15, 2020

Representative image

PANAJI: Months after transport minister Mauvin Godinho said that he would reduce the fines imposed under the amended Motor Vehicles Act because the government didn’t “want to trouble our people”, the minister on Tuesday hinted that he may not be able to do so.

“Because of the bad conditions of the roads, I had said I will not implement the act immediately. Goa is one of the few states that has not implemented it. At the next cabinet I want them to deliberate and decide whether we will go by what the Centre says and impose the fines or whether we should relax the fines,” Godinho said, speaking at the 31st National Road Safety Week event. “But the bad news as far as relaxation is concerned is that the attorney general of India has opined that you have to go as per the central Motor Vehicles Act. ”

He urged citizens to accept the act in “good spirit” and not to engage in a campaign of negativity on social media.

He also said that a “citizens versus the government” situation should not arise when the new fines are implemented.”

The state cabinet is expected to take up discussions on the act soon and its implementation could begin in Goa this month itself.

Godinho said that he does not want a situation to arise where the Centre issues directives to Goa asking it to follow the act in toto.

“What you should do is promote positivity about road safety. Tomorrow it should not be government versus the citizen. I am sure this will happen to an extent when the new Motor Vehicles Act is implemented. Because imagine a fine going from Rs 100 to Rs 1,000 for not wearing an helmet. Who will want to shell our Rs 1,000 for not wearing a helmet? They will feel it is better to wear a helmet,” Godinho said, endorsing the need to implement the amended act.

“It is not because of a (economic) slowdown due to mining not taking place that we intend to collect more money through fines. It is a pittance what we will be collecting through fines, if you look at the shortfall. The intention is to make the road safe for citizens of Goa. Therefore, when we enforce the new law please do not feel offended that is my humble request,” Godinho said.

He said that the number of vehicles are increasing by the day and there is urgent need for road discipline.

“Government is not found wanting as far as engineering goes. We have the new Zuari bridge being build, we have the new Mandovi bridge, we have the highways being widened. But people drive so rashly that they bang into the crash barrier and go down the hill with the crash barrier, then which national highway and which government can protect you. One has to realise this and we have to ponder what is right for us. I have seen when the traffic policeman waves his hand, people avoid his hand and ride past him. What kind of society are we building? Therefore, do not feel bad when the law is enforced. You all have to follow it,” Godinho said.

Title: Panchayat circular misconstrued: Mauvin
Content:
This story is from January 15, 2020

Panchayat minister Mauvin Godinho said that a recent circular on garbage management issued by the directorate of panchayats was being opposed without understanding its purpose. “We also have to stop one more habit of crying hoarse over good things. Garbage is the next issue we need to fix. What is the use of just road safety if there is rotting garbage spreading disease? Are we waiting for an epidemic? Even a simple circular issued by the panchayat department for managing garbage in multi-dwelling units is misunderstood. We are being accused of trying to take away the power of the panchayats,” he said. tnn

Title: 4 held for stealing pharma firm’s data
Content:
This story is from January 15, 2020

Hyderabad: Four former employees of a pharma firm were arrested on Tuesday for stealing data from the company and manufacturing drugs illegally at Visakhapatnam in Andhra Pradesh.

The accused were identified as Gunturu Srikanth Reddy from Medchal, Mekala Krishna Reddy from Medipally, Mekala Venkat Reddy from Miriyala and S Yogeeswara Rao from Visakhapatnam.

Acting on a recent complaint from the company’s senior executive M.Koteshwara Rao, police registered a case against the accused.

Investigations revealed that Srikanth Reddy, who was earlier business development manager at the company, had allegedly resorted to malpractices resulting in loss and damage to the company, after which he was fired from the company in 2017.

Police said that Srikanth, who was harbouring a grudge against the management ever since his exit, instigated the company’s manager (production) Krishna and a chemist, Venkat, and lured them with a lucrative job offer at his company Hubert Healthcare Pvt Ltd in Jeedimetla.

The employees stole the company’s confidential information pertaining to batch production control records, certificate of analysis, standard testing procedure, raw data of the drugs etc. Police said that after the data was collected, Yogeeswara Rao would save the data electronically.

Title: ‘Taximen can still unite under app-based service’
Content:
This story is from January 15, 2020

Panaji: Taxi operators in Goa could still tie-up with an app-based aggregator service or launch their own taxi app, said transport minister Mauvin Godinho while discussing the need to make the state more tourist-friendly. He said that if the transport sector was not regulated, Goa may stand to lose on the tourism front, as many Southeast Asian destinations were providing better options in terms of transport, cleanliness and affordable hotel rates.

“When the app-based taxi service, GoaMiles, came in, we had to face much opposition. The government had to go through hell,” he said. “Even today, I give taxi operators the option to tie up with somebody or to come up with their own app. The government has no business getting into the taxi business. We are only regulators because we have to look after the interests of the tourists who visit and the locals who need to commute,” Godinho said.

The minister said he has already stopped issuing new licences for rent-a-bike and rent-a-car services and was not renewing as many licences, keeping traffic discipline in mind.

“We are a tourist state. We have a 15 lakh population, and sometimes, 75 lakh tourists coming in, but we do not have a very happy situation where transportation is concerned. We cannot allow our tourist footfalls to reduce especially when there are cheaper destinations, especially in Southeast Asia, where traffic is regulated, people are friendlier and hotels are cheaper,” Godinho said.

Title: Resolution issue: Under secy appears before committee
Content:
This story is from January 15, 2020

Puducherry: Under-secretary (local administration) Giddi Balaram, who was summoned by the privilege committee on charges of disobeying a resolution passed by the legislative assembly of Puducherry, appeared before the committee headed by deputy speaker M N R Balan on Tuesday.

Balaram reached the assembly at 11am but had to wait for 40minutes as the committee didn’t have quorum to commence proceedings. The other members of the committee are government whip R K R Anantharaman, AIADMK MLA A Baskaran, DMK MLA R Siva, Congress MLAs V Vizeaveny and E Theepainthan.

Congress MLA T Djeamourthy had filed a breach of privilege issue with speaker V P Sivakolundhu against chief secretary (Ashwani Kumar), local administration secretary (Ashok Kumar), local administration director (G Malarkannan) and local administration under-secretary (Giddi Balaram) of disobeying a resolution of the assembly and releasing an advertisement to select a state election commissioner (SEC) bypassing the government’s appointment of Balakrishnan as SEC.

In the last three years, MLAs cutting across party lines had raised ‘breach of privilege’ issues against lieutenant governor Kiran Bedi, Puducherry BJP president V Saminathan, who is one of the three members nominated to the legislative assembly by the Centre, under-secretary (confidential and cabinet) M Kannan, Bedi’s secretary G Theva Neethi Dhas and former Puducherry municipality commissioner R Chandrasekaran accusing them of lowering the dignity and decorum of the House.

Title: Cop on duty hit by car, dies
Content:
This story is from January 15, 2020

Hyderabad: A head constable was knocked down by a car at Marrikunta in Wanaparthy district. Mohammed Salim Khan, who sustained a head injury, succumbed on way to a hospital. Police said a Swift car hit Salim when he was checking vehicles on Monday night. Police have booked a case and have launched a manhunt for the accused, who has not yet been identified.tnn

Title: UP: Man arrested with aide, accused of murdering his father for refusing to pay his debt
Content:
This story is from January 15, 2020

An alcoholic man and his aide were arrested by Jasrana police of Firozabad district for allegedly murdering hi... Read More

AGRA: An alcoholic man and his aide were arrested by Jasrana police of Firozabad district for allegedly murdering his septuagenarian father, after the latter refused to bail out his son, who is facing huge debt.

Identified as Harprasad , the father was murdered in the intervening night of January 6 and 7 in a farm in Nagla Padman village. His son, Udayveer Singh , had then lodged an FIR of murder under IPC Section (302) against unknown men.

Rajesh Kumar, superintendent of police (rural) Firozabad said, “Udayveer, who has outstanding debt of Rs 4.5 lakh taken from 6-7 people, was infuriated with his father after the latter refused to bail him out. So he hatched a plan to eliminate his father and sell his property to repay his loans.

A month back, Harprasad had received Rs 70,000 after he sold his rice crop. “Along with two aides Ramniwas and Chandrashekhar, Udayveer strangled his father to death. He had promised to give handsome rewards to his aides after selling his father’s property. Accused is the sole son of the victim,” said the SP (rural).

According to police, the third accused, Chandrashekhar, is still on the run.

Title: 22-year-old airline staffer falls to death from hostel
Content:
This story is from January 15, 2020

Hyderabad: A 22-year-old Air India employee died after reportedly falling from the third floor of her hostel in Shamshabad on Tuesday. The victim, Simran, worked with the customer care department of Air India and was a native of Bagalkot in Karnataka. Police said that the victim fell from the hostel while she was sitting on the edge of the terrace of the three-storey building. The victim was allegedly suffering from depression. However, police are yet to find out if it was a case of accidental death or suicide. A case of suspicious death was registered and the victim’s body was shifted to a hospital for autopsy. tnn

Title: Domestic power tariffs not hiked, clarifies Cabral
Content:
This story is from January 15, 2020

Panaji: Power minister Nilesh Cabral on Tuesday refuted reports about a hike in domestic power tariffs. “We have not hiked tariffs for domestic consumers, but only revised slabs under which power bills are being charged,” he said.

Cabral also said that the proposed 10 paisa tariff hike, from April onwards, is restricted to industries. Speaking on the power woes affecting residents of the coastal belt in Bardez, Cabral assured that 95 % of these problems will be resolved by May, that too without the need for constructing new a substation there. The measures undertaken, he said, will also bring relief to residents to Assagao, Candolim, Baga, Calangute and Anjuna.

Cabral also elaborated on the government’s plan to come up with a long-term solution for providing uninterrupted power supply to the state. He said he is working towards organising funding worth Rs 2,000 crore that is required to complete the works in a time-bound manner. This, he said, will ensure uninterrupted and reliable power supply to consumers for the next 30 to 50 years at least.

On the government’s proposed plan to build three extra-high voltage substations at Verna, Saligao and Tuem, Cabral said that plans for the Verna and Tuem substations have be dropped. “Work of setting up the Saligao substation will be tendered within a month.”

Meanwhile, work on the Verla-Canca power line, which was in limbo since almost one-and-half-year has been completed and the line charged, the minister said, and added that in order to resolve the problem of power shortage during the month of May, the electricity department plans on buying 20 MVA transformers. “These will help provide uninterrupted supply.”

Title: Rajasthan: Kite flying turns sour, one dead; 200 injured
Content:
This story is from January 15, 2020

(Clockwise) An injured person being treated at Jaipuria Hospital on Tuesday. Bereaved wife of Kamal Kundani, w... Read More

JAIPUR: Makar Sankranti celebrations turned tragic for a 50-year-old man who died after falling from the rooftop while flying kites here on Tuesday.

Another person is battling for life at the intensive care unit (ICU) of Institute of Traumatology and Orthopedics (ITO) of Sawai Man Singh (SMS) Hospital after falling off the rooftop of a hotel during kite flying.

Apart from these incidents, 200 people sustained injuries in kite-related incidents in the city. There are 30 people admitted to different hospitals in the city. The deceased has been identified as Kamal Kundani, a resident of Malviya Nagar. He was rushed to the ITO by his relatives after he lost his control and fell off the rooftop. The doctors declared him brought dead.

In another case, 30-year-old Saurabh, fell off the rooftop of a hotel in Jalupura. He was rushed to the hospital in unconscious state. The doctors admitted him to the ICU where he is battling for life.

Fourteen-year-old Hemant Kumawat fell from the rooftop and an iron rod pierced through his stomach. His condition is critical and undergoing treatment at Institute of Traumatology and Orthopedics. SMS Hospital spokesperson Dr S S Yadav said 59 injured persons were treated at the hospital.

Out of 47 persons brought to the hospital, 17 have been admitted. Among those injured are 13 children and 34 adults. The doctors remained busy all day treating the patients.

Dr Virendra Singh, who treated many at the SMS Hospital, said many persons suffered cuts in their necks by manjha. Neck bones were exposed due to injury in many cases. However, their neck vessels remained intact, he said.

Many bikes suffered serious injuries when snapped kite strings cut their nose and neck. One of the injured is 28-year-old Ravi Soni, who was riding a bike from Kishanpole to Bagru Walon Ka Rasta. He suffered deep cuts on his neck.

“I do not know from where the kite string came. I was riding the bike and I tried to grab it to protect myself. It cut my fingers and it came onto my neck. It severed my neck badly. I would have been died had I not stopped the kite string with my hand,” said Soni, who was returning to his home after purchasing kite string from Kisan Pole market.

Children also suffered serious injuries. A seven-year-old Chetan fell from rooftop, while 15-year-old Zainab’s throat suffered injury on her neck. A 17-year-old Mahtuba’s nose suffered injury, while 31-year-old Vikki, 41-year-old Lokesh, 30-year-old Gajendra and 16-year-old Aslam fell from the rooftop.

Title: Francisco Sardinha backs locals for Western Bypass on stilts
Content:
This story is from January 15, 2020

Sardinha (C) came out strongly against the Citizenship Amendment Act

MARGAO: South Goa MP Francisco Sardinha on Tuesday lent his support to the demand of locals for construction of the Benaulim stretch of the Western Bypass on stilts .

Sardinha told reporters that building the bypass on stilts was the “only solution” to prevent flooding of the area. Stating that he has spoken to National Highways Authority of India (NHAI) officials over the issue, Sardinha said, “They say that the cost of construction of the bypass on stilts will be too high. I have told them whatever the cost, think of the posterity, because you construct only once. After the bypass is complete, the flow of traffic shouldn’t be stopped by people.”

While slamming the government for the delay in resumption of mining which he said was once the biggest employment generating sector, Sardinha spoke about the decline in tourism. Referring to the recent three deaths at an electronic music dance (EDM) event which he attributed to drug overdose, Sardinha urged the chief minister to “open your eyes and stop this before tourists stop coming to Goa”.

Speaking on the demand of the faithful to allow public access to the Anjediva island for the annual feast on February 2, Sardinha said he has already spoken to minister of state for defence Shripad Naik who, he said, has assured him to look into the matter.

Pointing out that the financial condition of the state is bad, Sardinha said, “The government is taking loans because I have heard they have no money to take the ongoing projects further. I would urge the government, please increase your resources and try to stand on your own feet.”

Sardinha also came out strongly against the Citizenship Amendment Act (CAA). “Congressmen who died for the independence of the country have given us a secular government and a secular country. Today after so many years we can’t destroy the secularism of the country,” he said. He also decried police “brutality” on students at JNU and lamented “the sorry state of affairs of the country”.

“Religion should not be the criteria for anything in this country,” he said.

Title: Two held for torching shoe unit near Ambur
Content:
This story is from January 15, 2020

Representative image

VELLORE: The Umarabad police in Tirupattur district arrested two people and launched a search for the prime accused after a warehouse of a shoe manufacturing company was set ablaze by them at Bangishop village near Ambur in the wee hours of Tuesday.

Akbar Basha, 50, of Bangishop used to supply insoles to shoe manufacturing firms in the vicinity of Ambur and Vaniyambadi and had a warehouse to stock the insoles, said a senior police officer.

Around 12 am, some road users, who spotted thick smoke emanating from the warehouse, alerted the Umarabad police. As the blaze was intense, more than 15 fire tenders from three nearby fire service stations rushed to the spot but struggled for eight hours before bringing the blaze under control. Police initially suspected an electrical short circuit may have cause the fire.

However, a police officer said, “Warehouse owner Akbar, considering its safety, did not even fix any switches inside the facility to prevent electrical accidents. Preliminary investigation revealed Mujahideen, who had enmity with Akbar, had set fire to the warehouse with the help of his associates Suresh and Aarif Khan. Prime accused Mujahideen absconded. His associates have been booked under Prevention of Damage to Public Property Act. We launched a hunt to apprehend Mujahideen.”

Though the value of the property damaged was yet to be ascertained, Akbar lodged a complaint stating that more than Rs 50 lakh worth shoe manufacturing materials in the warehouse were gutted in the blaze.

Title: 1 held for use of Chinese strings
Content:
This story is from January 15, 2020

Jaipur: One person was arrested in Jyoti Nagar police station area here for using Chinese manjha for flying kites on Tuesday. The person is a resident of Churu and had bought the banned manjha from there.

The accused, identified as 25-year-old Anand Aggarwal, hails from Churu and bought the manjha from there. He was released in the evening.

Jyoti Nagar SHO Sudhir Kumar Upadhyay said, “We received information that the accused was using banned manjha following which we arrested him. This manjha is sold in Churu and that’s where the accused bought it from. We also informed Churu police regarding its sale and are awaiting their response. The accused was released after we questioned him thoroughly.”

Aggarwal was arrested under IPC Section 188 (disobedience to order duly promulgated by public servant) for violation of CrPC Section 144 as well as under IPC Section 336 (act endangering life or personal safety of others). Police recovered a roll of the manjha from the accused.

Title: U’khand lost 148 tigers in 19 years, 11 in 2019
Content:
This story is from January 15, 2020

Dehradun: Uttarakhand, which is home to over 442 tigers and hold the third position nationwide for its tiger population, lost 148 tigers in the past 19 years. In 2019, the state lost 11 tiger whereas only eight big cats died in Uttarakhand in 2018.

According to TOI sources, in 2019, nine tigers died in Corbett Tiger Reserve, followed by two in Western Circle. Data of the forest department, exclusively accessed by TOI, reveals that of the 11 deaths in 2019, five are due to infighting, followed by four due to natural causes and two due to “unknown” reasons.

So far, 72 tigers died due to natural causes, followed by 28 due to mutual fights, 19 due to unknown reasons, 15 in accidents, six in poaching, four killed after being declared man-eaters, two died in fire accidents and one each due to snake bite injury and snare traps.

Forest officials claimed that most tigers died due to ageing or in territorial fights. A senior IFS officer said, “We should not forget that Corbett landscape can handle a specific number of tigers. However, with each passing year, big cat population is increasing and this is triggering infighting for territory among tigers.”

However, Corbett director Rahul said that the landscape of the reserve has got nothing to do with the big cat deaths. “There is no specific reason behind big cat deaths. While, sometimes it is due to aging, on most occasion infighting is the main reason. It is not at all due to the landscape as tiger sustainability depends on the quality of its habitat, including prey base, water availability and security.

Meanwhile, a trans-border tiger corridor between India and Nepal is being developed, which will focus on tiger monitoring for their conservation and for conflict mitigation. The initiative is being planned with assistance from Wildlife Institute of India, Zoological Society of London and the forest department of both the countries.

Title: Uttarayani Mela starts in Bageshwar
Content:
This story is from January 15, 2020

Bageshwar: Kumaon’s biggest cultural festival —the Uttarayani Mela — started in Bageshwar on Tuesday. The Uttarayani Mela this year also marks the 99th anniversary of the Kumaoni Satyagraha inspired by Gandhiji’s non-cooperation movement.

The annual fair which is organised on the day of Makar Sankranti at the banks of Sarayu and Gomti rivers has been the hub of trade between India and Tibet for years.

The festival started with a series of tableaux being carried out by school students of Bageshwar district depicting the local culture. “I study at a private school in the district and the Mela is the time of the year when we prepare for weeks to showcase the traditional dance forms as well as many other aspects of the Kumaoni culture,” said Neha Rawat, a student of class VIII, who took part in the tableaux.

Bageshwar district magistrate Ranjana Rajguru, meanwhile, said that the fair marks the beginning of the 100th year of the Satyagrah and therefore it has a special significance for the people of the town. “We have made all the arrangements and tourists are coming here from across the state to witness the fair,” she said.

On January 14, 1921 a group of people led by BD Pandey, also known as Kumaon Kesari, had torn the papers of the British Registers and threw them in the Sarayu river as a mark of protest against the unjust laws made by the British. This was the first non-violent protest against the British Raj on the lines of the non-cooperation movement started by Mahatma Gandhi.

The highlight of the fair, however, has been the dog market where dogs — especially the Bhotia breed — are sold by local residents.

Bhopal Arya, who owns three dogs, said that he has come from a village near Munsyari and has already sold two dogs for over Rs 40,000 to buyers from Moradabad. “I bought three dogs from locals and the breed can be used to control herds. Two of my dogs have already been bought and now I will go back to Munsyari to get more,” he said.

Meanwhile, Aslam who has bought Arya’s dogs said that he has been coming to the fair for years now and owns eight such canines. “These dogs are famous for holding together a herd of 300-400 sheep. A group of them can even fight off leopards. I now own eight of them and will make special arrangements for them since they cannot survive in the heat of the plains,” Aslam said.

Title: Goa: Censured for drinking in public, group attacks cops
Content:
This story is from January 15, 2020

Representative image

MARGAO: The Cuncolim police on Tuesday arrested two persons and are on the lookout for at least five more after a group of drunken revellers assaulted policemen and damaged their vehicles at Demani in Cuncolim in the intervening night of Monday and Tuesday.

South Goa superintendent of police Arvind Gawas told reporters that the culprits attacked police personnel after they were warned against creating nuisance on the streets.

“Police received a complaint that some persons were drinking liquor in the open and creating public nuisance. The highway patrol vehicle reached the place followed by the police patrol van. When police told the miscreants to stop drinking and go home, an altercation ensued between the group and the police,” Gawas said.

When police tried to nab one of them and put him inside the police vehicle, the rest of the group got angry and attacked them. They damaged both the police vehicles and injured four policemenbefore fleeing.

The police managed to nab two — Mayur Dessai and Shaikh Abdul Razak — and hunt is on for Sandeep Dessai, Santosh Naik, Shubham Borkar, Saish Dessai and Swapnesh Dessai, police sources said.

Police have booked the case under charges of forming unlawful assembly, rioting with deadly weapons, assaulting public servants on duty and damaging public property. Gawas said police teams have fanned out to arrest the accused who are on the run. “We will not allow people to drink on public roads, and we will not tolerate assault on police,” he said.

This is the second such incident in a little over two months of police being assaulted by persons in a drunken stupor.

Title: Woman injured in big cat attack in Kaladhungi
Content:
This story is from January 15, 2020

Dehradun: A 37-year-old woman, identified as Parvati Devi, was attacked by tiger in Kaladhungi area on Tuesday. The victim was rescued by her friends who accompanied her to the forest for collecting fodder in the morning.

Parvati is currently undergoing treatment at Susheela Tiwari Medical College after being administered primary treatment at Kaladunngi community health centre (CHC). The victim says that she had climbed up a tree to cut its branches but she fell from the tree right in front of the big cat.

“It was a huge animal with stripes on its body and I simply fell from the tree directly in front of him. Thereafter, all I could hear was loud sounds of my children trying to shoo away the big cat,” said Parvati, while speaking to media persons at Kaladunngi CHC.

However, the forest department officials claim that the victim was attacked by a leopard and not a tiger. “Tiger stays only inside dense forest but leopards have been spotted by locals in other areas as well on several occasions. As these women had not gone deep into forests, it is likely that the victim was attacked by a leopard and not a tiger,” said BP Singh, DFO, Ramnagar.

Meanwhile, the doctors who treated Parvati at Kaladunngi CHC also couldn’t confirm whether Parvati was attacked by leopard or tiger. “She has been attacked by an animal. There are marks of nails and paws just above her neck and below her ear. But it cannot be ascertained if she was attacked by a leopard or a tiger. After providing her with primary treatment, we referred her to a to higher centre where any internal injury like brain haemorrhage can be diagnosed,” said the medical officer treating her.

The forest department would give a compensation amount to the victim in the range of Rs 15,000-Rs 50,000. The amount would depend on the medical certificate provided by the doctor. “We are yet to get accurate details from the health department. Once we get that, we will be able to divulge more information about the attack,” added Singh.

Last week, a Van Gujjar was attacked in the terai west forest division by a tiger but the forest dweller bravely fought the big cat and saved his life.

Title: BJP functionaries defend Sawant over Mhadei issue
Content:
This story is from January 15, 2020

Bicholim: BJP functionaries from Sakhali, Bicholim and Mayem constituencies have condemned opposition party leaders for making ‘false allegations’ against chief minister Pramod Sawant , with regards to the Mhadei water diversion issue.

Sakhali BJP block chief Gopal Surlakar said that Sawant has been “very active” in the Mhadei agitation since 2012. “I request the Congress and other party leaders not to make false allegations against him, as far as the Mhadei issue is concerned, said Surlakar.He recollected that Sawant had also held talks with the three-member Mhadei water dispute tribunal that had came to Kankumbi in 2013, to inspect the Kalsa-Bhandura project construction and Virdi dam construction work.

Bicholim BJP block president Vishwas Gaonkar added that Sawant had organised meetings of different village panchayats and municipal councils from Bicholim, and took different resolutions pertaining to development. “One such resolution stressed that the diversion of Mhadei’s waters would affect Goa adversely, and it was passed unanimously,” he said.

Sawant told journalists that it was “ridiculous” that people who do not know about the origin, length and breadth of Mhadei were bent upon making false allegations against him. “ No Congress leader made any attempts to solve the Mhadei issue, when they held the post of chief minister,” Sawant further said.

Title: Nirbhaya convict moves Delhi high court against death warrant issued by trial court
Content:
This story is from January 15, 2020

Mukesh Kumar

Title: Lingayat seer, BSY involved in public spat over cabinet berths
Content:
This story is from January 15, 2020

Davangere: Just hours after he more or else admitted that the party’s central leadership had refused to lend him an ear on his plans to expand the cabinet, chief minister BS Yediyurappa was involved in a very public confrontation with a Panchamsali Lingayat seer — a prominent sub-sect of the community — who openly lobbied for a ministerial berth for an MLA.

In the presence of Yediyurappa at a function on Tuesday, Veerashaiva Lingayat Panchamasali Samaj Gurupeetha seer Vachanananda Swamiji said the community will revolt against the BJP if Yediyurappa does not induct at least three Lingayat MLAs in his cabinet. Lingayats are generally seen to favour the BJP.

"Of these, Murugesh Nirani must get a ministerial berth... He has stood like a rock behind you and this peetha. If you fail to do so, then the entire Panchamasali community will desert you," the seer said.

The seer had barely finished saying this when Yediyurappa jumped up from his seat and confronted the seer. "If you talk like this, I will not stand for it. I did not expect such words from you. I cannot function as per your whims and fancies. If you continue to speak like this, I will walk out of this event," Yediyurappa said

The seer attempted to justify his stand and asked Yediyurappa to take his seat. But the CM continued to fume: "You can give suggestions, but you cannot threaten me..." he said.

Then, realising television cameras were on him, Yediyurappa sat down. He, however, rebuked Nirani on stage and was seen angrily pointing fingers at the former minister.

The seer clarified the community was only asking for its rightful share of cabinet berths considering five Lingayat legislators, including two from the Panchamasali sect — Ashok Poojar and Mahesh Kummatalli — were elected in the recent byelections.

When Yediyurappa spoke at the event, he expressed his haplessness over accommodating any of the BJP’s own. "I would like to remind the swamiji and the people, it was because of the 17 disqualified legislators that I became the CM," he told the audience. "If not for their sacrifice, I would not be sitting in this chair. Understand my position too. If the swamiji does not understand this, then I am prepared to resign from my post tomorrow itself. I am not dying to be on the CM’s chair."

Yediyurappa urged the seer to speak to him privately on any concerns he had. "I am ready to listen to you in private. Name the date and place and I shall sit and discuss any issue with you," he said.

Title: Petit Seminaire’s past students meet after 35 yrs
Content:
This story is from January 15, 2020

Puducherry: The 1985 Class XII batch of students of Petit Seminaire Higher Secondary School (PSHSS) congregated at the alumni meet here on Saturday, 35 years after they completed higher secondary education.

PSHSS principal R Pascal Raj presided over the meet in which 55 former students of one of the oldest educational institutions in south India participated. The past students had gathered from various parts of the world.

Former principals of the school M Peter and S J Paul sent recorded audio-visual messages greeting the former students. Former teachers and teachers of the school participated in the meet.

The former students resolved to participate in the 175th anniversary of the school scheduled next year.

Established as a seminary in the 1840s with 89 students, including 25 seminarians, Petit Seminaire became a public college in 1873.

Title: Aligarh Muslim University wants FIR for police action
Content:
This story is from January 15, 2020

AGRA: A fortnight after Aligarh Muslim University vice-chancellor Tariq Mansoor regretted the police action on the campus on December 15 in an open letter to students and their parents, the varsity gave a complaint to local police to lodge an FIR against security personnel for “unauthorised entry into the students’ hostel on the ill-fated night”.

The local police, however, refused to lodge a case, saying the matter is sub-judice in the high court, said varsity registrar Abdul Hamid.

The varsity administration has been under pressure from protesting students who want the VC and registrar to resign “for their failure to take action against security forces for the brutality against the students”.

The VC clarified on Tuesday that the university administration had given the permission to the police “only to bring the situation to normalcy and restore public order and to clear the main road” and that they were “not supposed to enter any residential hostel”. He further said that the evidence brought to the knowledge of the university administration suggests that the “police personnel might have crossed the mandate by entering the Morrison Court hostel premises”.

Talking to TOI, vice-chancellor Tariq Mansoor said, “I had allowed security forces inside the campus in order to maintain law and order situation in the university. We did not give them permission to enter the hostels.”

Adding that their entry into the hostel was illegal, Mansoor said, “I was not aware of the damage that the security forces did in the hostel.”

He said he took the decision of approaching cops for an FIR against the security forces after seeing the situation inside the Morrison Court hostel, which was sealed after the mishap to prevent the tampering of evidence. It was opened on Monday for investigating team of NHRC.

Meanwhile, the NHRC team members met the chemistry research scholar, Mohammad Tariq, who lost his hand in the violence and the doctors in AMU medical college, who treated scores of students injured in the December 15 violence. They also recorded statements of guards and other university staff, confirmed AMU proctor Afifullah Khan.

Earlier, inmates of the hostel had alleged that police not only entered the Morrison Court hostel forcefully on December 15 night, but also thrashed some of them. One of the rooms of the Morison Court hall also caught fire after RAF personnel lobbed a tear gas shell from the window, claimed students.

The university, which has to be opened in phases, started functioning on Monday, but students boycotted classes, demanding resignation of VC and registrar.

Earlier in an open letter written to students and their families on December 31, the VC had said, “I want to tell you and your families that I regret what happened (on December 15).”

Referring to the decision to call in the police on the night of December 15, he said it was taken in “good faith and a clear conscience”.He sought to assure them that he has “no intention whatsoever” of trying in any way “to subvert the right of students to protest peacefully against any legislation”which they find objectionable.

Title: Maharashtra cotton farmers defy govt, plant ‘seeds of hope’ in fields, and hearts
Content:
This story is from January 15, 2020

YAVATMAL (Maharashtra): The evidence is on the ground. The next generation of genetically modified (GM) technology in cotton changed the life of 29-year-old Rajendra Madghane in the tribal village Ghorkhindi, 15 km from Yavatmal in eastern Maharashtra , once he got hold of unapproved variety herbicide-tolerant transgenic seeds, known as HTBt.

He procured the seeds from a fellow villager in June last year and planted it in two acres of rocky and hitherto infertile land which had never supported a crop. “It gave me 15 quintals of cotton and income of Rs 54,000 after deducting my cost. I had never seen that much of money. It’ll now help me lead a better life in our village where most of us are daily wage labourers and depend on odd jobs,” said Madghane.

Most of Ghorkhindi is infertile with patches producing Jowar (Sorghum) - a single crop in this non-irrigated area. Madghane and others are changing the area’s profile, some 23 km from centre of resistance Hiwari, which has defied the law by planting what it calls “seeds of hope” when incomes from the legally available option (Bt cotton) began to taper off.

Bt cotton is still the preferred cotton seed in Maharashtra where over 87% of cotton farms are under GM seeds, but the “revolt” of Hiwari is spreading with villages in Yavatmal, Wardha, Akola, Ahmadnagar and other districts opting for next generation GM seeds, HTBt, in the current crop year.

Over five lakh hectares of 42 lakh hectares of total land under cotton in Maharashtra is in Yavatmal.

Regulation and the law are playing catch up. “Had I continued with Bt variety, it would have been impossible for me to repay my loan to the moneylender. Use of HTBt had reduced labour cost, resulting in better returns during the ongoing picking season,” said Rupesh Thakre, a 28-year-old farmer who planted cotton in eight acres of land in Hiwari.

Many others explained how Bt variety needs use of labourers multiple times to clear weeds and how it developed a vulnerability to pink bollworm (pest) over the years, forcing indiscriminate and unscientific use of pesticides and higher costs.

Doesn’t HTBt need weedicide Glyphosate , considered hazardous for human health? “We need to spray it twice or thrice. Had this been hazardous, the government would have banned it,” said Akshaya Ramesh Mahajan of village Bori in Yavatmal district . There are many like Thakre and Mahajan in Yavatmal, Wardha and Akola who have adopted unapproved HTBt. A round of several villages reveals that three-four of 10 farmers use HTBt.

Hiwari itself has nearly 90% of its nearly 800 farmers banking on HTBt. “Farmers know they would get assured return with less cost of production. No one can do farming if there is no hope of return,” said Vijay Niwal, pointing at a signboard ‘HTBT Gram’ - the name given by farmer organisation Shetkari Sanghatana that has been leading the demand for approval of the new variety of transgenic seeds.

But, how could so many farmers get seeds not sold legally? “There are reports that the HTBt seeds are produced illegally in Gujarat and Telangana . I don’t have any authentic information about it. It, however, needs to be investigated. We have sent our reports to the Indian Council of Agricultural Research (ICAR),” said V N Waghmare, director of the Central Institute for Cotton Research (CICR) in Nagpur. He warns there would be no redressal of complaints if someone cheats farmers by supplying wrong seeds.

Many are sticking to legally sold GM variety - Bt cotton seeds but temptations are growing. “I would like to use HTBt once the government approves it. I am not using it at this juncture. Since use of unapproved variety is illegal, no one would assure guarantee of seeds’ quality,” said Ramkrishna Patil, a big farmer of Pandharkawda in Yavatmal district.

India allowed commercial cultivation of Bt cotton, developed by the then US-based multinational seed company Monsanto, in 2002. Its next generation of GM cotton seed (HTBt) is, however, not approved by the central biotech regulator Genetic Engineering Appraisal Committee (GEAC). Monsanto had submitted the application seeking approval of HTBt long ago. The company, which was formally merged with the German agro-chemical and seed company Bayer AG last year, had, however, in 2016 withdrawn its application over pricing for existing GM cotton seeds.

In the face of opposition from organisations, including RSS-linked Swadeshi Jagran Manch (SJM), over concerns regarding health hazards due to use of Glyphosate and impacts of transgenic seeds on overall biodiversity , the government isn’t keen to push a politically sensitive case. But many stakeholders, including agriculture scientists, want government to rethink and approve seeds that passed trials on bio-safety parameters.

Though there is no application before it, the government can consider certain options. “Considering benefits of the HTBt cotton seeds, the government should invite the seed company to renew trials and application. The government must negotiate with the company and buy its technology by paying lump sum amount. The technology can then be transferred to ICAR or agricultural universities for adoption of genes in suitable varieties for commercial cultivation,” said C D Mayee, agriculture scientist and former director of the CICR.

He argued that such a move by the government will make new generation of seeds available to farmers without any additional burden to them on its cost.

Title: ‘New pipeline will resolve water issue’
Content:
This story is from January 15, 2020

Calangute: The water shortage along the Calangute-Candolim beach-belt is expected to ease up once the new water pipeline is laid from Guirim to Calangute, said ports minister and Calangute MLA Michael Lobo .

Lobo told reporters that the work, expected to cost nearly Rs 6 crore, is currently awaiting approval from the finance department.

Once approved and tendered, the new pipeline will be ready in about a year, he said. Two new water tanks are also currently under construction near the Calangute bus stand.

Once the pipeline is functional, these tanks will be used to store water from where it will be distributed to consumers.

A first-of-its-kind water storage facility in the state, both tanks are being constructed on the same spot, one above the other. This was necessitated due to paucity of land on the coastal stretch.

The already existing PWD overhead water tank in Calangute, also in the same vicinity, has a capacity of just 150 cubic metres of water. The new tanks will have a combined capacity of 1,850 cubic metres, a Calangute pancha specified.

“Once the tanks are ready, the water storage capacity will increase by nearly 18 times,” a panch said.

Title: NFDB to promote aquaponics for efficient utilisation of water
Content:
This story is from January 15, 2020

Hyderabad: In order to efficiently utilise water to produce two crops rather than one and to share nutrient resources between fish and plants, National Fisheries Development Board (NFDB), Hyderabad is aiming at promoting aquaponics (a mixture of aquaculture and hydroponics) this year across the country.

Experts see the move positively due to a shortage of water and rising prices of fish, considering the fact that the fish and plants grown in aquaponics system are organic in nature. “This farming system is commonly used in resource-limited areas to raise both fish and vegetables in an integrated system but the only issue is that it is costly and not possible for one to install it on their own. And we are helping the beneficiaries set these up,” said a senior executive, NFDB.

According to officials, the initial investment of the system is high, but the recurring cost is less and gives reasonable returns like the advantage of using less water, lesser area of land and waste renewal. “Green leafy vegetables with low to medium nutrient requirements are well adapted to aquaponics systems. The fishes are fed with quality floating pellet feed and waste generated from the fish is pumped into the troughs having horticulture plants,” he added.

Title: Rainfall over next four days predicted, as cold wave & poor air quality continues
Content:
This story is from January 15, 2020

Agra: The Indian Metrological Department (IMD) has predicted a phase of intermittent rainfall over the next four days in Agra. Light rainfall is expected on Wednesday and Thursday, with one or two spells of rain or thundershowers expected on Friday and Saturday, which is likely to push the mercury level down over the week.

Following light rainfall on Monday evening, cold wave intensified in the Agra region. Sky remained covered with clouds throughout the day. Air quality deteriorated to “very poor” category. Agra remained among the 10 most polluted cities in the country.

According to Central Pollution Control Board (CPCB), the air quality index (AQI) was 314, which falls in the “very poor” category, with particulate matter 2.5 (PM2.5) the main pollutant. Upon prolonged exposure, “very poor” AQI can cause respiratory illnesses.

On Tuesday, maximum temperature in Agra was 17.5°C, 5°C below normal, while minimum temperature stood at 11.6°C.

Besides Agra, cold wave swept across Firozabad, Mathura, Etah, Aligarh and Mainpuri. Neighbouring Aligarh was colder than Agra, with maximum temperature at 16.6°C and minimum temperature at 10.6°C.

For the relief of street dwellers, Agra Municipal Corporation (AMC) operated gas heaters at over a dozen places in the evening. Besides, people set up bonfires. On Sunday, over a dozen trains including Gatiman Express and Shatabdi Express ran behind schedule.

Title: Sanjay Place traders see red over AMC’s move to charge parking fee
Content:
This story is from January 15, 2020

Businessmen of Sanjay Place on an indefinite strike against the Agra Municipal Corporation (AMC) for charging ... Read More

AGRA: Scores of businessmen in city’s commercial hub Sanjay Place on Tuesday launched an indefinite strike against the Agra Municipal Corporation ’s (AMC) for charging parking fee at 44 places in the market.

They claimed that it violates norms as they had already paid a fee for parking space at the time of purchasing the property.

“The Sanjay Place market was developed by the Agra Development Authority (ADA). In 2005, the market was handed over to the municipal corporation. The municipal corporation was required to collect property tax, conduct maintenance work and look after street lighting and sewer system. There was no mention of collecting of parking fee in the handover document. We have already paid for the parking space. It is clearly written on the registry of the properties available with the property owners. The parking contracts raised by the AMC administration are completely illegal,” Hiren Agarwal, secretary of the Sanjay Place market association said.

Meanwhile, the leaders of Sanjay Palace market association have decided to give up their BJP membership if the AMC fails to withdraw the contract proposal.

“Almost all the businessmen of Sanjay Place have been supporting BJP in every possible way. It is very unfortunate that despite having BJP government at the Centre and state, we are being exploited. BJP Mayor Naveen Jain has failed to address our issues,” Association's treasurer Vinay Mittal said,

“We will end our several years old loyalty to the BJP if the parking contracts raised by the AMC are not cancelled,” he added.

Meanwhile, municipal commissioner Arun Prakash said, “The claims made by the market association leaders are misleading. Contracts have been issued for parking on public space, which is the right of the municipal corporation. We have brought all the facts to the notice of the court. No change will be made in the parking system in Sanjay Place.”

The dispute over parking began when a group of 10 businessman of Sanjay Place filed a case at the Agra sessions court in 2008 when the contract for parking space was first issued. The court later put a stay on the AMC order for five years. In October 2019, the municipal corporation again raised the parking contract for Sanjay Place after which the businessmen applied in the court to reopen the case.

Title: Siddaramaiah meets Sonia, pitches for aide MB Patil for KPCC prez job
Content:
This story is from January 15, 2020

Bengaluru: The on-going process to select a new Karnataka Pradesh Congress Committee (KPCC) president is likely to drag on for few more days with former CM and opposition leader Siddaramaiah making a strong pitch for former minister MB Patil over DK Shivakumar for the post.

Siddaramaiah, who met AICC president Sonia Gandhi and other senior Congress leaders in New Delhi on Tuesday, reportedly argued in favour of Patil, saying his elevation would help the party win Lingayats to the fold.

“Yediyurappa, the undisputed leader of the Lingayat community, is almost at the end of his career and it is an opportunity for the Congress to gain the confidence of the community. Being a leader from North Karnataka, Patil fits the bill perfectly,” Siddaramaiah reportedly told Sonia.

Siddaramaiah is said to be backing Patil over Shivakumar as he is worried about losing his hold over the state unit, given Shivakumar’s popularity. While Sonia did give the former CM a patient hearing, she is said to have told him that he should obey and cooperate with whatever decision high command takes.

The high command is looking to evolve consensus on the new state president. “Sonia’s meeting with Siddaramaiah is part of this exercise. She wants to keep everybody in the loop,” said a functionary.

Siddaramaiah also met senior leaders Ahmed Patel and AK Anthony. He is expected to meet former AICC president Rahul Gandhi on Wednesday.

However, some including Mallikarjun Kharge and Shamanur Shivashankarappa have expressed reservations against Patil’s elevation, pointing to his role in the controversial separate Lingayat religion issue which dented the Congress’ prospects in the 2018 assembly polls.

“He has a very bad name among Lingayats and making him president would prove counter-productive. Moreover, it is difficult to win back Lingayats as long as Yediyurappa is active in politics,” said a senior Congress leader.

Another functionary said a majority of state functionaries — and even some in the high command — favour Shivakumar as he is not only “resourceful”, but also has momentum. “With HD Deve Gowda and HD Kumaraswamy losing popularity among Vokkaligas, the possibility of the community backing Shivakumar is high. This may land him the top job,” the functionary said.

Title: Vasco cops stop flagpost work on ‘anonymous call’
Content:
This story is from January 15, 2020

Vasco: Undercurrents brewing in Vasco’s political arena came to light on Tuesday after the port town’s police stopped the erection of a flag post in front of the railway station on Tuesday based on “an anonymous call” stating that the project did not have permission. Mormugao Municipal Council (MMC) councillor Krishna Salkar, who had proposed the idea of erecting the national flag told TOI, “It is a politician from Vasco, who is jealous as he will not get any mileage.”

Refusing to name the politician, he clarified that the ruling council had no role to play in this. The South Western Railway had undertaken the project. Krishna’s wife Shammi said that the MMC chairperson had given them the go ahead and even directed his staff to provide temporary power supply to facilitate the work.

“Around 12.30pm, police arrived and told us to stop the work stating that we had no permissions. Till 5.30pm we were at the police station asking them to show us the complaint. Later they told us to go ahead with the installation,” Shammi said.

Vasco PI Nilesh Rane said they received an anonymous call about an illegal construction in front of the station. “We told the person to settle it with the MMC, but as it was their lunch time, the complainant asked us to check out the work,” Rane said. “After checking the inwarded letter to the MMC chief officer, we told them to go ahead with the work,” he said. Station manager Ramdas Gudemane said, “On December 31, we had inwarded a letter before the MMC CO and got verbal permission. I have contacted the Vasco MLA. He has asked me to meet him on Wednesday.”

Title: Jamia VC asks MHRD to inquire into December 15 case
Content:
This story is from January 15, 2020

Jamia Millia Islamia vice-chancellor Najma Akhtar (PTI File photo)

NEW DELHI: Jamia Millia Islamia vice-chancellor Najma Akhtar met Amit Khare, secretary for higher education, MHRD , on Tuesday and briefed him about the cancellation of the ongoing examinations. Akhtar again requested the ministry to set up an inquiry on the police action in the university on December 15.

The VC also met Delhi Police commissioner Amulya Patnaik and urged him to lodge an FIR in connection with the violence, university officials said.

An HRD official said that the VC was not invited but she paid a visit to brief them about the circumstances on why exams at the university were cancelled. “Akhtar also reiterated her earlier demand for a probe into the December 15 violence. The request has been forwarded to the ministry,” the official added.

On Monday, Akhtar had said the varsity administration will “explore the possibility” of moving court for registration of an FIR against “police brutality” on the campus after hundreds of angry students gheraoed her office demanding action against Delhi Police. Students on Monday had demanded that the VC file an FIR against the cops. Akhtar had then announced that the exams in the campus were cancelled and an Executive Council meeting on Tuesday would decide the plans to take up legal recourse.

The EC meeting, however, could not happen due to absence of several members as the meeting was called at a short notice.

On December 15, as violence over the Citizenship Amendment Act flared up, police personnel entered the campus and cracked down on students, leaving several injured. Since then the university has been witnessing constant protests.

Title: Carambolim civic body, locals file plaint against garbage dumping
Content:
This story is from January 15, 2020

Panaji: Two police complaints have been filed by residents of Old Goa and Carambolim, and by the Carambolim panchayat, over the Corporation of the City of Panaji’s “illegal” dumping of “unburnt/burnt/wet and stinking garbage” at Carambolim on Monday.

The Old Goa police seized six trucks that were transporting garbage from CCP’s wet waste facility at Patto that caught fire on Monday, to a private property in Carambolim, on the border of Old Goa.

Locals noticed the dumping only at 8 pm on Monday and protested against it, stating that it was taking place illegally, without the permission of the Carambolim panchayat and was posing a threat to the heritage fortress wall that runs through Old Goa and Carambolim. The locals in their complaint demanded an investigation into the 50-odd truck loads of waste dumped there.

Old Goa resident Glean Cabral said the waste hadn’t been cleared despite assurances from Panaji mayor Uday Madkaikar, who was supervising work at the site Monday evening. No permissions were taken from the Carambolim panchayat in whose jurisdiction the waste was dumped, he said.

Former NIO senior principal scientist Arvind Kumar Saran said the waste was not completely dry, and was mixed with plastic, and emanating an unbearable stench.

“There is a strong feeling of distrust among the people. Waste from the municipal area is being dumped in panchayat jurisdiction. They thought it would go unnoticed,” he said.

The villagers from Carambolim and Old Goa were called for a meeting late Tuesday night, and were asked to be on the alert for dumping of garbage in their respective localities.

Mayor Madkaikar said that it was not garbage that was dumped, but “half-treated compost”.Compost was taken to the site last year and the owner granted permission to CCP to dump the compost there, he stated.

“ We told them we will remove it if they wish. We just have to screen it. It is all dried compost. It began to smell because water was used to douse the fire. We were instructed to remove it by fire service personnel,” Madkaikar told TOI. A massive fire was also reported at the proposed site of the garbage treatment plant at Bainguinim on Monday morning. It was doused in the afternoon.

Title: ECoR planning cyber cell to stop e-ticketing frauds
Content:
This story is from January 15, 2020

Bhubaneswar: The East Coast Railway (ECoR) will set up a cyber cell to investigate cases related to e-ticketing frauds at its headquarters in Bhubaneswar.

Raja Ram, principal chief security commissioner of ECoR, said the cell was likely to be functional within the next three months. “We hope that the cyber cell will add teeth to our railway protection force (RPF) in dealing with cyber crimes, especially e-ticketing frauds,” he added.

Ram said, “The primary job of the cell will be to identify touts who hoard tickets by creating fake user IDs on IRCTC website and trace their networks. The cell will have modern gadgets to help RPF personnel gather digital evidence and retrieve lost/deleted data from a computer for investigation.”

In 2019, RPF personnel have arrested 164 persons on charges of committing e-ticketing frauds under the ECoR jurisdiction. Tickets worth more than Rs 1.2 lakh were seized from the accused, including travel agents. The Railway police said they blocked at least 1,006 fake online user IDs last year. The RPF had launched special drives under the banners of Prabal and Thunder for a wider crackdown on touts.

Ram said ECoR has taken a slew of measures to strengthen security at stations, including Bhubaneswar. Statistics showed that the incidents of stone pelting on running trains increased to 36 in 2019 from 10 in 2018. RPF personnel had arrested 19 persons, mostly juveniles, on charges of stone pelting in 2019 as against eight in 2018.

“We identified at least 13 vulnerable locations, mostly inhabited by slum dwellers, along the tracks under the ECoR jurisdiction. Reports showed that attackers, who were mostly children, were having fun by pelting stones on trains. We have been organising sensitization programmes in slums to dissuade people from doing so,” Ram said.

The ECoR said incidents of chain-pulling came down in 2019 as compared to 2018. At least 5,039 such incidents were reported from 5,860 trains. Altogether 2,579 people were arrested in 2018. The numbers came down to 3,801 in 3,666 trains in 2019. The total number of arrests stood at 2,841 in 2019.

Ram said crackdown on coal thieves in goods trains has been intensified. In 2019, at least 35 coal theft cases were registered and 71 persons held. “We appeal to the citizens to call us on our helpline number (182) or send photographs/videos of illegal activities in trains or on railway properties on our social media channels for prompt action,” he added.

The ECoR said incidents involving deaths of passengers on track due to negligence while on train witnessed a marginal drop in 2019. While 1,012 passengers had died after accidentally falling off from running trains in 2018, the number came down to 989 in 2019.

Title: State to seek add’l grants for mining
Content:
This story is from January 15, 2020

Panaji: The state government will make a strong plea for additional grants for mining and tourism industries during the visit of members of the 15th Finance Commission next week.

An official said the state has never received grants for the mining industry in the past but considering its present status, they will have to try to get some help from the Centre. Also grants will be sought for the tourism industry.

He said the existing pattern of assistance for smaller states will be modified under the 15th Commission . “The team is visiting Goa for our inputs and requirements but I don’t think there will be significant increase in grants,,” he said.

Under the existing pattern of assistance, Goa receives Rs 210 crore a month as share of central taxes and another component is GST.

Title: Rajinikanth: Murasoli means DMK, Tuglak intellectual, says Rajinikanth
Content:
This story is from January 15, 2020

Vice-President M Venkaiah Naidu flanked by actor Rajinikanth and Tuglak editor S Gurumurthy at the Tamil weekl... Read More

CHENNAI: Actor Rajinikanth has stirred a controversy with his one-liner that a person with a copy of “Murasoli” (DMK’s mouthpiece) can be identified as a DMK man , while one with a copy of “Tuglak” can be termed an “intellectual”.

Addressing a gathering at an event to release the 50th anniversary special magazine of the Tamil weekly Tuglak in the city on Tuesday in the presence of Vice-President M Venkaiah Naidu, the actor heaped praise on the magazine’s late founder-editor Cho Ramaswamy.

Noting that present-day politics was “in a sorry state of affairs”, Rajinikanth underscored the role of the media and the need to have journalists like Cho. Indicating that media houses owned by political parties take a stand on issues, the actor said, “Media should be unbiased and bring out the truth for people. Do not portray lies as truth.”

Before beginning his address, the actor made it clear that his speech will be apolitical due to the presence of the Vice-President and the protocol in place. “I will speak at an appropriate time,” he added, amid applause. As a word of advice, he said, “If you look at a problem as being permanent, it will become a disease. Rather, consider it temporary like Cho did, and thus, he became a great man.”

Venkaiah Naidu said even as he exited politics, Rajinikanth was entering the fray.

Responding to a question raised by a reader on whether Rajinikanth would make an impact on politics in the future, Tuglak editor and RSS ideologue S Gurumurthy said the actor was “no ordinary man”. “He is aware of his responsibilities. We have to leave him to take the right decision at the right time,” he said, adding that it would be “a positive outcome” ahead of the 2021 assembly elections.

Recollecting his conversation with Cho on Rajinikanth, Gurumurthy said, “He (Cho) frequently told me that Rajinikanth wanted to do good for the people and he will enter politics.”

On the occasion, Prime Minister Narendran Modi’s recorded speech was screened. He praised Cho as a great journalist and emphasised the role of the media in highlighting the government’s welfare schemes. He lauded Tamil Nadu as home of the “world’s oldest language” and said the state was in the forefront in various sectors.

Title: VNIT extravaganza IG gives enriching experience
Content:
This story is from January 15, 2020

Aristes in a scene from the play staged at VNIT

Nagpur: Visvesvaraya National Institute of Technology (VNIT) stood testimony to camaraderie between students of various departments during annual ‘Institute Gathering’, its biggest ever event, that saw their best in literary, artistic, athletic and other creative fields.

Students were emotionally charged as the extravaganza will conclude on Wednesday evening with the valedictory function. VNIT director PM Padole will be the chief guest while dean (student welfare) BS Umre will be in the chair.

The Times of India was the print partner of the event.

‘Institute Gathering’ (IG) is organized by the Student Council in which all departments get a platform to showcase their talent. More than 95 events held in the course of ten days were curated to encourage bonding between various departments.

While kabaddi, kho-kho, cricket and basketball matches, besides others, tested the physical strength of students, literary and creative events gave them food for thought.

Slam poetry, JAM, creative writing competitions and cultural events like street and stage plays, dance performances and competitions and stand-up comedy were outstanding.

The events included ‘Triathlon’ which had cycling, running, long jump and hurdles, besides others. Stage play was also an exciting and challenging event in which all the eight departments gave 20-minute performance each. The teams were given words based themes like ‘ink’, ‘table’, ‘chair’ etc to choose from, and write and present a play that centred around it.

Tug of war, collage and rangoli making were enjoyed by the students. There were informal events too like poker, NFS, FIFA, DOTA and Counterstrike. In fact, there was something for everyone at the IG.

The spectacular events were made memorable by the hard work put in by the team of Student Council consisting of general secretary Yogesh Patil, secretaries Aditya Kumar (academic affairs), Mohit Rathi (cultural affairs), Chaitya Chheda (sports), Gyan Pratik Singh (alumni affairs), Jidnyasa Badwaik (training and placement), Ayush Singh (technical), Sanket Joag (magazine and literary affairs), Shuvendu Ranabijuli (hostel affairs for boys), Prachi Janorkar (hostel affairs for girls), Mohsin Khan (PG sports and cultural), Saurabh Dharmare (PG social affairs), Saurabh Khairnar (PG academic affairs) and ladies’ representative Vaishnavi Shringi.

Title: Union roads mantri lauds #Rosto safety movement
Content:
This story is from January 15, 2020

Panaji: Zumba instructor and former AAP candidate from Taleigao, Cecille Rodrigues and her team received recognition for their work of painting speed breakers to caution motorists from the Union minister for road, transport and highways, Nitin Gadkari.

“Cecille Rodrigues, Seema Chimulkar and Prakash Malani have developed unique road stamp ‘Rosto’ which cautions drivers of blind spots, thus reducing accidents on the road. #RoadSafetyHeroes,” Gadkari tweeted on Tuesday, the first day of road safety week. “Lots of Deaths, Accidents and Damages due to Potholes and Unmarked Speed Breakers in Goa.LOCALS & Tourist face a lot of problems. Need your big support to inform our Minister of PWD & MLAs of Goa to take care of the Public. @DrPramodPSawant @MauvinGodinho,” Rodrigues replied on Twitter, tagging the chief minister and transport minister.

Armed with cans of white paint, Rodrigues and her team have painted 84 stretches of roads in North Goa in a bid to caution citizens and tourists about blind spots and unmarked speed breakers, with an eye-catching “#ROSTO”, starting a social media trend.

“Reducing accidents and saving lives is our key focus area. We have started today, the ‘Road safety week’. During the next 7 days, I will share stories of individual initiatives doing their bit to save precious lives. They are an inspiration for all of us.#RoadSafetyHeroes “ Gadkari tweeted.

Title: Relief at Centre nod to transfer approvals to new bidders
Content:
This story is from January 15, 2020

Bhubaneswar: The state government has welcomed the Centre’s recent decision to transfer the existing forest and environment clearances of mining blocks, lease period of which will end on March 31, to the new lease holders, who will be selected through the ongoing auction process.

The decision will help the new lease holders to start mining production immediately. It, generally, takes two years for new lease holders to start mining operation from a block by obtaining various approvals like forest and environment clearances.

The Centre’s decision is part of the mineral laws (amendment) ordinance approved by the Union cabinet on January 8. As per the decision, the name of the lease holder would only change after March 31 while production would continue as usual.

“Since the state government has approached the Centre to transfer the existing clearances in favour of the new lease holders, its a favourable decision for us. There would be no disruption in mining production and supply to the ore-based industries,” said mines director Deepak Mohanty.

As many as 20 mines, including 12 iron ore, lease period of which would end on March 31, have been put on auction by the state government. Immediate start of ore production from these blocks by the new lease holders after March 31 is crucial as these 12 iron ore blocks produce around 50 million tonne of ore annually against states total annual iron ore production of 120 MT. Delay in start of production from these blocks would also have a negative impact on state’s revenue collection as Odisha earns a major portion of its revenue from mining and metal sector.

The Centre’s decision also came as a big sigh of relief for the ore-based industries, who had earlier expressed concern over the situation and urged the state government to find out alternatives. A top executive of an Odisha-based steel plant termed the decision a big-relief for them as they would continue to get raw material.

Title: Nirbhaya case: Tihar asks convicts to give date for last meet with kin
Content:
This story is from January 15, 2020

File photo of Nirbhaya convicts.

Title: Family of Farmington accused will suffer most if he is found guilty
Content: HYDERABAD: A YouTube video shows Phanideep Karnati ’s family at their candid best: He is seen with his wife during a marathon; in another clip with his just-born son and then dancing awkwardly with his eldest. It is this video that his counsel will use on Friday to try and keep him from getting jail time.Karnati stands charged with conspiracy to commit visa fraud in the US in the University of Farmington case. His counsel is arguing that he be allowed to leave the country without serving time owing to the hardships his family will face otherwise.A ‘downward variance’, as it is called, would allow Karnati to return to Hyderabad. He faces between 24-30 months of prison time as per the advisory guidelines of the probation department. The final sentencing could be above or below the range. Karnati and seven others are accused of recruiting students to enrol in the University of Farmington, a fake university, operated by Homeland Security agents.“Farmington University held itself out to be completely legitimate, and only the most cynical person would have imagined it was a trap by the government,” said Anjali Prasad, a Detroit-based criminal defence attorney and former federal prosecutor representing Karnati. “Genuine, hard-working, educated people don’t think that way. They trust and believe.”Speaking about the trauma Karnati has been through, Prasad said, “This has been an absolute gruelling experience for my client who believed the University was in its infant stages with online classes.”The sentencing memorandum, which seeks to provide a complete picture of Karnati, will be placed before the United States District Court Eastern District of Michigan on Friday.Karnati’s sentence will rest on how the hardship of the family will be viewed. The memorandum states: “Regardless of what sentence the court imposes, Karnati’s wife and two minor children must leave the United States. That is because Mrs Karnati and their nine-year-old son carry H-4 visas, which are issued to dependents of an H-1B visa holder.Karnati anticipates non-renewal of his H-1B visa in the next 60 days. Once Karnati’s visa expires or becomes revoked, so will his wife and eldest son’s.” Karnati’s three-year-old son is a US citizen.The memorandum will further highlight how the family is dependent on Karnati. “If Karnati receives a custodial sentence, his family will have no choice but to leave the country without him. In addition to lacking his physical and emotional support as they return to India, the family will be without means in India since Karnati is the sole provider for his family,” the memorandum states.In September 2019, Karnati pleaded guilty to a single count indictment charging ‘conspiracy to commit visa fraud and harbor aliens for profit’ in the now notorious University of Farmington fake university case.Over 250, Indians, including many Telugu students, were arrested or sent back over the issue. Karnati has already paid $11,700 obtained through 39 student enrolments made to the University of Farmington, for which he was paid $300 per student.

Title: ‘Musetta with Drums’ takes people to golden era of music
Content:
This story is from January 15, 2020

Nagpur: Melodies of the golden era of Bollywood were impressively rendered during ‘Musetta with Drums’, organized jointly by Rajanigandha, and Shahnai Musical Group at Scientific Society Hall on Sunday.

The programme was directed by Parineeta Maturkar and coordinated by Simran Naidu. The playlist was carefully curated with emphasis on the beats of the drum to match the theme.

Santosh Sharma was the first performer with legendary singer Kishore Kumar’s song ‘Tum kitni khoobsurat ho’. Sandeep Singh followed with the rendition of ‘Zamana to hai naukar biwi ka’. Another number by Kishore Kumar from the movie Alag Alag, ‘Kabhi bekasi ne maara’, was presented by Jitendra Rajkumar to the sound of thunderous applause.

Shrirang Kurhekar stepped on the stage to deliver a memorable performance on ‘Main jahan chala jaoon bahar chali aaye’. Vikas Shende’s ‘Main jat yamla pagla deewana’ seemed to be the crowd favourite as he sang while shaking a leg to the melody. Harsha Chhabda teamed up with Rajkumar for the first duet of the evening on the song ‘Dil mera akela’.

Mohammad Rafi’s magic was recreated as Deepak Sutawane sang ‘Kis kisko pyaar karoon’. Girish Sharma sang ‘Nadiya se dariya’, followed by Sudesh Iyer’s rendition of peppy number ‘Bambai se aaya mera dost’. ‘Mere pairon mein ghungroo’ was sung by talented singer Dinkar Pande.

Listeners tapped their feet to the tune of ‘Laila main laila’, presented by Vijaya Waindeskar and ‘Jab chhaye mera jadoo’ by Priya Gupta.

Anchor Nasir Khan engaged the audience with shayaris. Music arrangement was done by Tushar Vighne.

The singers were accompanied by Pankaj Yadav (tabla and bongo), Deepak Kamble (dholak and congo), Akshay Harle (drums and octopad), Pawan Manwatkar and Mangesh Patle (keyboard), Manoj Vishwakarma (guitar) and Manna Deb (bass guitar).

Title: Maha tourist drowns off Palolem beach
Content:
This story is from January 15, 2020

Poinguinim: A tourist from Maharashtra drowned off Palolem beach late on Monday. Sachin Bramhane, 27, was declared brought dead at the Canacona community health centre(CHC), police said.

Bramhane, a resident of Chhadwel, Dhule, Maharashtra, was visiting Palolem with his friend and ventured into the sea for a swim. The current was strong and the young man was swept away, even as his friend watched, helpless. Lifeguards on duty tried to resuscitate Bramhane, but there was no response, police said. He was rushed to the CHC, where the duty doctor declared him dead, and informed police.

The autopsy was performed at TB hospital in Margao, and the body was then released to the family of the deceased.

Police have registered a case of unnatural death under section 174 CrPc.

PSI Rifha Barretto and PI Tukaram Chawan are investigating the case.

Title: 175 illegal buildings in city face demolition
Content:
This story is from January 15, 2020

Bhubaneswar: The Bhubaneswar Development Authority (BDA) and Bhubaneswar Municipal Corporation (BMC) have decided to demolish 175 illegal buildings that have come up on government land or has not compiled with building norms. The demolition will be carried out in a phased manner with the help of excavators.

The decision comes days after the Odisha Development Authority (ODA) court gave the go-ahead for demolition of the illegal structures. Altogether 6,000 disputed cases related to building rules violations are pending in BDA and BMC courts, which are being heard. Only in the case of 175 apartments the ODA court hearing has been final. BDA vice-chairman and BMC commissioner Prem Chandra Chaudhury said the demolition will be carried out using excavators as they are small buildings. “The demolition will be carried out as per ODA court order. But those who have appealed before the higher authority or moved the Orissa high court seeking stay, their buildings will not be demolished till the disposal of their cases,” Chaudhury said.

Chaudhury said the nature of violations committed by the developers vary from building to building. “While many have constructed buildings illegally on government land, drains or natural nullahs, others have not complied with mandatory norms,” Chaudhury added.

Around 1200 families are likely to be affected if the 175 apartments are razed. As per Section 92(2) of ODA (Amendment) Act, 2015, the BDA and BMC can seal the illegal buildings before demolishing them.

Before carrying out the demolition, the BDA and BMC will make a joint appeal to the occupants to vacate the buildings will all their belongings.
