After the ODA court’s order, people have the option to appeal to the appellate authority in the housing and urban development (H&UD) department. If the verdict by the appellate authority goes against them, they can move the high court.

The cases related to building rule violations are decided in the ODA courts in BMC and BDA. The 175 apartments against which the demolition has been ordered are the ones whose fate has been decided in both the courts. The apartments which fall under BMC jurisdiction will get demolition notice from BMC court and the ones coming under BDA jurisdiction will get notice from the BDA.

Title: Bengal yet to get GST compensation for 3 months
Content:
This story is from January 15, 2020

Kolkata: West Bengal is yet to get GST compensation for last three months despite repeated request to Centre. This was disclosed on Tuesday by state finance and industries minister Amit Mitra after a pre budget meeting with the chambers. Mitra pointed out that state has not received GST compensation for October, November and December. The total shortfall in collection for these months is around Rs 2,000 crore. GST compensation for August and September also was released late. Incidentally, as per GST regulation, if the GST collection falls below 14% growth of the last year in month to month basis then states will get a compensation. This would be valid for five years since the roll out of GST.

“GST we are not in good shape. There is below 14% growth but not getting compensation. This is our constituional right and CM has also communicated to PM about this dues,” he added. Mitra also cautioned about stagflation like situation prevailing in the economy where inflation is being coupled with unemployment. “It has never happened in India. In US there was stagflation once in mid seventies.” he added.

Commenting on the meeting with chambers, Mitra added that there was 60 representatives from 19 chambers that included national chambers like FICCI, CII, Assocham, other leading chambers like ICC, MCC, Bharat Chamber, BNCCI and district level chambers. “It was a very good meeting. They are asking to do something to support production,” he added. According to Mitra, there was discussion in issues like assessment of demand for training in different sector, skill development, entrepreneurship development along with others. “The banks will give Rs 70,000 crore credit to small businesses this year, we have already trained the officers in district industry centres (DIC) by IIM, Kolkata,” he added.

Title: First skin bank in twin states may come up in Hyderabad soon
Content:
Representative image

HYDERABAD: With an average of 100 burn patients landing at the Osmania General Hospital (OGH) in a month for skin grafting and 7,000 patients a year, the hospital is planning to set up the first skin bank in the twin Telugu states soon.At present, both Telangana and Andhra Pradesh don’t have a skin bank, which hampers large grafts. While larger grafts are typically required by patients with severe burns, nearly half of them do not survive.“Skin burns leave open wounds. Without the protective layer of skin, dehydration and body temperature loss happens. In case of severe burns, multi-organ function is affected within three to five days. With all the electrolyte imbalances and impact of organs, patients do not survive easily. With skin grafting, once the protective layer of the skin is back, the wound starts healing and it improves the survival rate,” said a senior doctor associated with the project.In the absence of this protective layer, many severe burns patients succumb quickly. The OGH skin bank, which will be the first in the twin states, can meet the demand of nearby states, as only one skin bank in the private sector is currently operating in entire southern India, said doctors.“We have sent the proposal for setting up a skin bank to the government. It will be managed by the plastic surgery department,” said hospital superintendent, Dr B Nagender.Currently, plastic surgeons carry out grafting by taking skin from one part of the body and transplanting it to another. This does not allow large grafting and the alternative dressing of collagen sheet is a very expensive option. Meanwhile, skin banks use skin from cadavers (donated), which is then cleaned up in various solutions to wash off any antibodies and kept ready for grafting.

Title: Amrapali case: ED charges two banks
Content:
This story is from January 15, 2020

Representative image

NEW DELHI: In the Rs 800 crore Foreign Exchange Management Act violation case against Amrapali group and J P Morgan, the Enforcement Directorate has made HDFC Bank and Bank of Baroda parties in the “unauthorised” repatriation of over Rs 187 crore, made without taking RBI’s approval.

HDFC Bank is likely to face a penalty over “unauthorised remittance” of Rs 140 crore to J P Morgan while Bank of Baroda is being held liable for repatriation of Rs 47.3 crore which the ED claims are illegal transactions in violation of FEMA rules and lacking RBI approval. The ED complaint claimed two shell companies of Amrapali promoters were used to move money out of India by hugely inflating share prices.

The ED issued summons to the banks seeking clarification on the “unauthorised remittances” but they failed to respond, sources said. When TOI sought comments from the two banks, a spokesperson for HDFC Bank said the bank was not aware of any such summons. No response was received from Bank of Baroda.

The investigating agency, likely to take Amrapali promoters in custody this week for questioning, named the two banks in its FEMA complaint filed on January 8. The FEMA complaint is equivalent to a chargesheet and further proceedings before the special director of ED, a quasi-judicial authority, will determine the amount of penalty that may be levied on the two banks.

The ED has also registered a separate case against Amrapali and J P Morgan under Prevention of Money Laundering Act (PMLA) for attachment of properties. The agency has also questioned former nominee directors of J P Morgan, who were on the board of Amrapali Zodiac and Amrapali Silicon City, under PMLA. Amrapali has been accused of making dummy directors in “collusion” with J P Morgan to siphon off homebuyers’ money.

On Monday, the ED informed Supreme Court that a PMLA court in Lucknow had issued three production warrants against directors of Amrapali group to join investigation. The agency urged the apex court to issue directives for custodial interrogation of the accused Amrapali directors.

Title: HTBt seeds illegal but it’s easy to procure them, say farmers
Content:
HTBt farms in villages of Yavatmal and Wardha districts (TOI photo)

NEW DELHI: Amid reports of cultivation of unapproved variety of transgenic HTBt cotton seeds, the Union environment ministry has written to the chief secretary of Maharashtra for “taking necessary action” and requested the state to “provide lateral flow strip test kits for preliminary field level testing” to frontline staff who visit the fields for inspections.“A reply from the government of Maharashtra is awaited,” said the central regulator, Genetic Engineering Appraisal Committee (GEAC), secretariat under the ministry while responding to TOI’s questions on cultivation of HTBt episode in several districts of the state.Since cultivation of unapproved variety of genetically modified (GM) seeds is illegal in India, it is the responsibility of chief secretary, being chairperson for the State Biotechnology Coordination Committee (SBCC), to take action against such practice.As per rules for the Manufacture, Use, Import, Export and Storage of Hazardous Micro-organisms or Genetically Engineered Organisms or Cells, 1989, the SBCC serves as a nodal point at state level for coordinating activities related to GMOs in the state. There is also a provision of District Level Committees (DLC) which serves as a nodal point at district level.Farmers, however told TOI during farm visits to different villages in Yavatmal and Wardha districts on last Saturday and Sunday that they did not find any difficulty in procuring HTBt seeds. “Though such seeds are not sold by licensed seed retailers, we could get it easily through network of farmers,” said Madhusudan Harne at village Shegaon (Kund) of Hinganghat taluk in Wardha district. Harne planted both approved (Bt cotton) and unapproved (HTBt cotton) varieties of seeds in his separate farms.The issue was earlier flagged by the environment ministry to the Maharashtra government in 2019 when it came to know about suspected illegal cultivation of HTBt cotton in villages of Akola district .“In reply, the government of Maharashtra has confirmed presence of HT positive cotton seeds in Akola district and has filed two FIRs against responsible persons,” the GEAC secretariat told TOI.In the backdrop of Maharashtra episode and detection of illegal cultivation of GM brinjal in Fatehabad district of Haryana last year, the ministry had then written to chief secretaries of all states/UTs to constitute and strengthen SBCC and DLCs and take penal action under Section 15, 16 and 17 of the Environment (Protection) Act, 1986, in case cultivation of illegal GM crops are detected.

Title: 13 coconut trees felled to make way for toilet block at Colva beach
Content:
This story is from January 15, 2020

Colva: As many as 13 coconut trees with a height of 8-10m have been cut down by the Goa Tourism Development Corporation (GTDC) in the children’s park at Colva beach to make space for the construction of a toilet block for beach development and beautification works.

The Union government has sanctioned Rs 11.7 crore for the works to turn it into an iconic beach under the Tourists Sites Development project. The cluster of coconut trees in an area admeasuring 2,000 sqm with its front to the beach would provide shade to visitors.

Colva panch member Pio Furtado said that GTDC personnel showed them permission from the deputy conservator of forests to cut 13 trees. Furtado said that he requested them not to cut all 13 but to chop only four to make enough space to build the toilets but the official told him that it would be difficult for them to cut the remaining trees individually at a later stage.

Director of tourism Menino D’Souza said he is aware of trees being chopped down for toilet blocks. He added that the property has been handed over to GTDC for the development and they have permission to cut the trees.

The tourism department also allowed the children’s park to be used as a transfer point for garbage collected from shacks and beach stretch from Cavelossim to Arrosim.

GTDC executive engineer Kiran Kumar said that the earlier plan was to construct the toilet block at the far end of the children’s park but the public objected because of the presence of a chapel. He added that the block consists of washrooms for ladies, gents and handicapped and they also have CRZ clearance. Kumar says that in place of the 13 trees they will plant 39 coconut palms as per the conditions of the forest department.

The works undertaken by GTDC under the project include road beautification at Colva beach, beautification of existing islands, pathways, drainage, construction of toilet blocks with changing rooms, four-wheeler parking for 80 vehicles and two-wheeler parking for 327 vehicles, bus parking for 54 vehicles, play equipment for children’s play area, landscaping and illumination.

Title: Conman dupes woman of Rs 47,000
Content:
This story is from January 15, 2020

Nashik: A city-based woman was cheated of Rs 47,000 on Saturday by a conman who claimed to be calling from an online payment wallet company and sough her bank details for opening an account with them.

The woman readily provided details of her bank accounts following which the conman withdrew Rs 47,000 from both the accounts. The women lodged a complaint with the cybercrime police station on Monday.

An officer from cybercrime police station said they have registered an offence of cheating against the unidentified conman and the case is being investigated.

“We have been spreading awareness among people that they should not share details of their bank account or passwords of their debit or credit card to anyone at any cost,” he said.

“Despite this a large number of people still end up falling to the tricks of the online fraudster . Many fraudsters have also uploaded their cellphone numbers on the internet as customer care executives of banks and other organisations. People should not fall in the trap of such people,” he added.

Title: Lawyers march from SC to Jantar Mantar; oppose CAA, NRC
Content:
This story is from January 15, 2020

New Delhi: Hundreds of lawyers under the banner of ‘Lawyers for Democracy’ on Tuesday marched from the Supreme Court to Jantar Mantar opposing the Citizenship Amendment Act (CAA) and the National Register of Citizens (NRC). Lawyers raised slogans against the government and stated that the educational institutions should not speak the language of the government. The march also led to traffic disruptions in and around Central Delhi.

The protest march began around 3.30pm outside the apex court with Sanjay Hedge, senior advocate at Supreme Court, reading out the Preamble. Somdutt Sharma, convener of Lawyers for Democracy, then led the protest. He repeatedly requested the participants to ensure that no miscreants entered their protest.

“Both CAA and NRC strike at the core of the constitutional values and are against the idea of a secular democracy. Religion should be no basis of giving citizenship to people. The six communities, which have been mentioned in the act, are already living in India and can apply for citizenship even through the citizenship act. Then what was the need to amend it,” said Somdutt.

Women lawyers, who were a part of the protest, also included Surya Rajapan. She had to shift her house after she protested against CAA and NRC during Union home minister Amit Shah’s visit to Lajpat Nagar. “The new Act is against the constitutional values where religion has been made a base for citizenship. The government is an elected representative of the people of this country. If there is a dissent, why can’t they have a dialogue,” asked Rajapan.

Title: State-level skirmishes cast shadow over Cong’s attempt at creating anti-BJP axis at national level
Content:
This story is from January 15, 2020

NEW DELHI: A day after it stayed away from the joint opposition meeting, DMK said it skipped the gathering in protest against Tamil Nadu Congress’s accusation that M K Stalin had violated the coalition dharma, its gripe again highlighting that state-level pinpricks were impacting coordination in the anti-BJP axis at the national level.

Senior DMK leader T R Baalu said, “We did not take part in the meeting since our chief was accused of violating coalition dharma (over local body elections).” He said only time would tell if the relations between DMK and Congress would come back to normal.

At the same time, TN Congress chief K S Alagiri met party president Sonia Gandhi and told reporters that there was no bitterness among the TN allies. Downplaying the discord, he said, “The coalition is going on good, I have told our party chief.”

DMK along with Trinamool Congress, BSP, SP and Shiv Sena skipped the joint meeting called to discuss the CAA-NRC-NPR controversy as also economic downturn.

DMK was not alone to complain against Congress. Earlier, TMC chief Mamata Banerjee accused the Congress-Left compact of violence during the national strike in Bengal last week and accused it of conspiring against the state government.

Left and Congress are rivals to ruling TMC in Bengal while they are together in the national opposition camp against BJP.

Interestingly, BSP chief Mayawati said her party was skipping the meeting since Congress had poached upon BSP MLAs in Rajasthan.

The fact is that BSP has been targeting Congress since AICC general secretary Priyanka Gandhi Vadra stepped up organisational and agitational activities on its turf of Uttar Pradesh.

With the national opposition umbrella comprising both partners and rivals in states, the abstentions at the Monday meeting brought to the fore the complications that competitive politics was creating in coordinating a joint stance against BJP.

While the brainstorming issued a strong statement against BJP and drew up an agitation plan, the anti-Modi offensive was diluted by the news of cracks in opposition unity.

There appeared a regret in Congress about the turn of events even though managers pointed out that 20 parties had come together at the meeting. Also, it was pointed out that DMK and TMC, despite staying away, were vociferously opposing CAA-NRC-NPR, and stay bitterly against BJP. Also, Shiv Sena on Monday declared for the first time that the Maharashtra government would not implement CAA in its present form.

It was felt that problems like in Bengal cannot be avoided since the Congress-Left have to fight against a vehemently “dictatorial” ruling TMC. But party office-bearers added that care would have to be taken to ensure that minor issues don’t impede the relationship over bigger projects.

Title: NU’s reval applications jumped by nearly 25,000 in 3 years
Content:
This story is from January 15, 2020

Nagpur: Even as Nagpur University (NU) claims to have significantly reduced the number of revaluation applications, which once used to cross one lakh mark a few years ago, its own reply under the RTI Act bellies its own claims.

In its reply to a slew of queries by RTI activist Abhay Kolarkar, the university’s assistant registrar Manoj Joshi mentioned about the number of students applying for the revaluation, which proves that the figures are increasing with each exam.

In 2016 summer examination, about 20,858 students applied for revaluation which jumped to over 45,500 in 2019. Even the funds collected from the students towards revaluation applications have witnessed a surge. From Rs47.66 lakh in 2016-17, fee collection increased to Rs1.66 crore in 2018-19.

On refunding fees of those who cleared in revaluation, Joshi said their office didn’t’ have any instructions in this regard, despite VC SP Kane announcing it in 2016 while terming it as “one of his dreams”. It was reported by TOI on October 23, 2016, when the VC first declared about his intentions of refunding the students.

Pro-VC Vinayak Deshpande told TOI that he wasn’t aware of the RTI reply, but he would seek information from his subordinates in this regard. “We need to see the jump from the perspective of number of students appeared for summer and winter exams in all these years, along with those who applied for the revaluation. The university permits two papers in one semester for revaluation. Change may be due to the number of subjects applied for it,” he said.

Till 2016-17, revaluation was a major headache both for NU authorities and students due to old system of photocopy. The results used to witness inordinate delay of at least three months to one year in some cases on account of old rules.

After introduction of semester system, a majority of applicants used to get revaluation results after the supplementary exams. Thousands lost their precious academic year due to this delay, as they used to clear the subjects after winter exams.

Subsequently, the NU used to face large-scale protests throughout the year and it was the biggest bone of contention between the students and authorities. TOI regularly exposed NU’s apathy on how hundreds of innocent students lost their precious academic year due to delay in revaluation results.

NU authorities claimed that things had changed drastically after the introduction of online system from Promarc company. They used to claim that the number of applicants had reduced significantly and even revaluation results were declared within a week. Though their claims were found to be correct to some extent, there is no denying the fact that those applying for revaluation have jumped drastically, as per the RTI reply, Kolarkar told TOI.

Title: Pune: Civic body to assess impact of additional FSI for Metro
Content:
The top view of night picture of Metro work on Paud road - Metro station at Vanaz in Pune

PUNE: The civic body has decided to assess how the increased Floor Space Index (FSI), to be allotted for the Metro rail project, will impact the city.The standing committee of the Pune Municipal Corporation (PMC) on Tuesday approved the civic administration’s proposal to hire a private consultant at Rs1.19 crore to assess the real estate development and its cascading effect in the Metro’s transit oriented development (TOD) zone.The civic administration has declared up to 4 FSI along the TOD zone within a 500m radius of the Metro stations. Factors such as road width, plot size and distance of a plot from a station will be considered while allotting the FSI.“The allotment of the additional FSI will certainly put pressure on the civic infrastructure and municipal services. Amenities have to be improved for this. A study by the consultant will focus on all these factors,” standing committee chairperson Hemant Rasane said.“The current status of development along the TOD zone and the future prospects will be studied. The consultant will suggest ways of sustainable development along the TOD zone,” said Yuvraj Deshmukh, a senior official in the PMC’s building permission department.“The study will be carried out in accordance with the state and the Centre’s directives within nine months. The study will focus on all Metro corridors. The impact of development along the Bus Rapid Transit System and High Capacity Mass Transit Route areas will also be assessed,” he said.The state government had in March last year announced transit oriented development in a 500m radius around Metro stations in the city and fixed the maximum permissible FSI at 4. The government had then told the PMC to undertake an impact assessment study of the policy and prepare a comprehensive action plan.As per the PMC’s proposal, the consultant will base the study on factors such as the existing situation analysis, demography, transport, parking, street network, urban block and non-motorized transport.

Title: Magisterial probe set up in death of two sisters run over by truck
Content:
This story is from January 15, 2020

Meerut: Days after two sisters riding a scooter were crushed to death by a truck while on way to school, a magisterial probe has been set up in the matter.

The accident took place near Kankarkhera flyover on December 9 when the truck rammed their two-wheeler. The truck had allegedly entered a no-entry area in Meerut Cantt in order to avoid paying entry charge. Both sisters, who were not wearing a helmet, sustained head injuries and died on the spot.

Ajay Kumar Tiwari, Meerut additional district magistrate (city), said, “Meerut district magistrate has set up a magisterial probe into the death of two sisters who died in an accident after a truck allegedly entered a no-entry zone in Meerut Cantt to save on entry charge on December 9. If anybody has any written or verbal statement or evidence to give in the matter, he/she can approach us between January 14 and January 20 to help in a fair probe.”

The victims, Annu Kumari (16) and Anjali (12), were students of Army Public School and City Vocational Public School, respectively.

TOI had earlier reported that Annu Kumari was driving the scooter with Anjali on the pillion. A truck rammed into their two-wheeler and smashed their heads. Locals gathered at the spot and alerted police.

This comes at a time when a tiff is on between transporters and the Meerut Cantonment Board over entry charge at three new spots in the district. While the entry charge was stopped by the Cantt authorities, the contractor in question started levying a charge again starting January 8, citing a stay on Cantt order by Allahabad High Court.

On the day of the accident, the Cantt authorities had given a green signal for collecting entry charge to gather funds for maintenance activities. The instruction to levy a fee was given by the Cantt board on December 8. However, after protests, the board authorities withdrew its order on December 12 and cancelled the contract with the contractor. Later, the contractor approached the Allahabad High Court for relief and obtained a stay on the Cantt board order.

Title: Missing brothers found murdered
Content:
This story is from January 15, 2020

Bijnor: Bullet-ridden bodies of two brothers , aged 23 and 16 years, were found on Tuesday in a sugarcane field, 4 km from their house at Baankpur village. The two had been missing for the past two days.

While investigating the case, police are also checking if the murders are linked with old cases filed against one of the deceased. Ramit Sharma, IG, inspected the spot where the bodies were found lying in a pool of blood near Bhagain’s jungle.

According to police, the two brothers went out for a walk after dinner on Sunday evening. Their mobiles were switched off around 9 pm the same night. Their family members searched for them when they did not return home but could not find them.

Devendra Singh, their father, approached police on Monday morning to file a missing complaint. Police too could not trace their whereabouts. On Tuesday morning, a farmer spotted their bodies in a cane field near Bhagain’s jungle and informed police.

The bodies were lying in a cane field close to a road. Police suspect that they were gunned down elsewhere and their bodies were dumped there. Both brothers had several bullet injuries.

Family members suspect a man of the same village for murdering the two brothers. However, an FIR was registered against unidentified killers.

Talking with TOI, superintendent of police Sanjeev Tyagi said, “Police are probing the matter thoroughly. There were two cases pending against deceased Shubham. One of them pertains to harassing a woman and another is a case manhandling. Police have collected some clues.”

Sharma, IG, said, police are likely to crack the case and arrest the culprits soon.”

Title: Cops shielding Milind: Cong
Content:
This story is from January 15, 2020

Vasco: The Goa Pradesh Congress Committee on Tuesday gheraoed Mormugao police inspector Pravin Powar and asked him why he was not registering cases against urban development minister and Mormugao MLA Milind Naik . They alleged that Naik was abusing his power and using the police force to settle personal grudges.

“Recently a case was filed against him (Naik) for tree cutting without required permissions. Had that been done by a common man, police would have put him behind bars. In this case police has not even questioned him (Naik) so far,” vice-president of the GPCC Sankalp Amonkar said.

President of the Mahila Morcha Congress, Pratima Coutinho said that police are paid from tax payers’ money and as such should work to safeguard the public and not the minister who will not permanently hold the position.

General secretary of the GPCC, Amarnath Panjikar read out the complaints against Naik, which included a molestation case filed in 2017. He asked Powar what action they had taken so far in the case.

The around 100 Congress workers asked police to register the complaints made against Naik and to work honestly for the betterment of the people.

Title: Police ask duped investors to contact them
Content:
This story is from January 15, 2020

SLUG: 2018 Investment Fraud Case

Nashik: After a cheating case was registered with Bhadrakali police against three people for duping an investor of Rs 39.50 lakh in November 2018, city police have appealed to the investors to come forward with their documents for further investigation of the case.

According to a release issued by city police, a 38-year-old resident of Jail Road Nashik Road had accused the three suspects of cheating her on the pretext of giving good returns on her investment.

The woman in her compliant said that the trio had set up an office in Trimbak Naka area of the city from January 2014 to November 2018 by forming a group of companies like Parisparsh Land Developers, Parisparsh Agro Farming Ltd, VB Pro Brad OPC Ltd and through these companies they were seeking investments.

According to the complainant, the investment schemes were created for a period of five years, three years and six years and had even assured to return twice the invested amount.

The woman subsequently invested Rs 39.50 lakh but did not get any return following which she lodged an offence against the trio with Bhadrakali police station. The case was later transferred to the Economic Offences Wing (EOW) of the city police.

During the course of investigation, the suspects in the case were arrested in June 2019 and the case is still under investigation. “A large number of people would have invested in these schemes may have lost their money. However, such investors have still not come forward to lodge complaints against the accused,” a police officer said.

Title: Lit-up Aga Khan Palace open for viewing till 9pm
Content:
This story is from January 15, 2020

graphic with photo with chandni

Pune: The historic Aga Khan Palace in Pune, with its façade now illuminated by LEDs, is the only monument under the Mumbai circle of the Archaeological Survey of India (ASI) that will be open to visitors till 9pm.

The Markanda Mahadev temple in Gadchiroli in the state and the illuminated monuments of Red Fort, Humayun’s Tomb, Purana Qila and Safdarjung Tomb in the national capital, also stay open till till 9pm.

Officials said Aga Khan Palace was chosen after the ASI took up the project of LED illumination of important monuments in the country. The project was completed by Vin Semiconductors.

“More than 1,000 advanced LEDs illuminate the façade of the palace. Illumination will consume 62% less electricity than conventional light fixtures,” Subhash Pawar, managing director of Vin Semiconductors, said.

Illumination of historic monuments showcases them during the late evening and promotes night tourism. Officials in ASI Pune said visitors can witness the LED illumination of the Aga Khan Palace after 5.30pm on entering the monument precincts.

“We have received a letter from ASI headquarters in New Delhi, stating that the palace should be kept open till 9pm as part of the LED illumination project undertaken by ASI. The museum in the palace is also being refurbished. The revamped museum is open for viewing till 5.30pm. Visitors would be allowed to enter the precincts of the monument and witness the lighting till 9pm,” an ASI official said.

The illumination is done on the lines of Tamil Nadu’s Mamallapuram Shore Temple. “Monuments in the country, including the Aga Khan Palace, where illumination has been done have a closing deadline extension,” Rajendra Yadav, superintending archaeologist, ASI, Mumbai circle, said.

The museum at the Aga Khan Palace is being refurbished, and the displays are based on India’s freedom struggle. The revamped museum will depict important historical events through picture panels and fibreglass statues, including one of Mahatma Gandhi addressing the public in the main hall, and another of him reading in the fourth gallery.

Light Show From 6pm To 9pm

More than 1,000 advanced LEDs used to illuminate façade of the palace

Illumination to consume 62% less electricity than conventional light fixtures

Warm lights will highlight architectural features

Main palace, some pathways lit with elegant post off lamps

New illumination accentuates silhouette of the monument with interplay of light and shade

Title: CM to inaugurate Ganga Yatra in Bijnor, address public in Hastinapur
Content:
This story is from January 15, 2020

Bijnor: Preparations for Ganga Yatra, which will be flagged-off by UP CM Yogi Adityanath on January 27 from Bijnor’s Sabalgarh village, are on in full swing. The Yatra, whose aim is to sensitise villagers along the banks of the river about plastic pollution and cleanliness, was to be flagged-off on January 1, but got delayed by anti-CAA protests that rocked the state.

The CM will address a public meeting at Meerut ’s Hastinapur, spend a night here and set off for Garhmukteshwar on January 28.

According to officials, Ganga has been included in the list of the world’s top 10 most polluted rivers. The biggest sources of its pollution are sewage, plastic/polythene, garbage, defecation and industrial effluents. Lack of proper management of cremation and wharfs in rural areas, and lack of awareness among villagers, are considered other big causes of pollution.

UP has been declared “open defecation free”. A campaign to make the state polythene free is going on. In addition, several programmes, including management of solid and liquid waste, are being run under Swachh Bharat Mission.

Bijnor district magistrate Ramakant Pandey said, “Ganga Yatra will be held between January 27-31. It’s aimed at raising awareness about the importance of cleanliness and river Ganga in our lives. The river, which enters UP at Bijnor’s Sabalgarh village on the Uttrakhand border, passes through 26 districts in the state.”

Meerut’s administration is leaving no stone unturned to make the CM’s programme a success. District magistrate Anil Dhingra said, “CM Yogi Adityanath will inaugurate the Yatra on January 27 at Sabalgarh village. It will pass through 26 districts covering 21 civic bodies and 1,026 village panchayats, and end on January 31 at Kanpur, where PM Narendra Modi could join.”

“From Bijnor, the Yatra will reach Hastinapur where the CM will address the public at Government Inter College, spend the night here and depart for Brajghat,” Dhingra added.

Title: Inspections reveal violations in Empress Mall elevators
Content:
This story is from January 15, 2020

Nagpur: A day after TOI report, the state industries, energy and labour department (Nagpur section) lifts inspector on Tuesday found brazen violations of norms at the Empress Mall where 15 people were stuck in a lift late on Saturday evening.

Nagpur Municipal Corporation (NMC) fire and emergency services personnel too conducted a separate inspection of the mall lifts the same day. The lifts inspector found the mandatory annual maintenance contract (AMC) of eight lifts had not been renewed. The overload sensor was also not working in the lift involved in the incident. A show cause notice will be served on mall management on Wednesday.

Acting chief fire officer Rajendra Uchake said the report was yet to be finalized but his team too found problems in functioning of the lifts.

On January 14, TOI had reported how 13 moviegoers and two salespersons were stuck in the mall lift on fourth floor following a malfunction on January 11. The 13 occupants had gone for a movie at PVR Cinemas while the salesperson were returning home from third floor when the lift unexpectedly went to the upper floor and got stuck for over 30 minutes.

Speaking from his Mumbai office, assistant electrical inspector (lifts) Uday Dambhe said the inspection team confirmed the incident took place at 10.30pm. “I will be inspecting the mall lifts in the next couple of days. The AMC lapsed in February last year. After this, the mall owner signed up a local contractor who too left midway. I have informed the lift company and asked them to come during my visit,” he said.

Lawyer Ankita Shah said the electrical inspector needed to comply with the stringent provisions of Sections 17, 19, 22 and 24 of the Maharashtra Lifts, Escalator and Moving Walks Act 2017. “These powers need to be exercised to prevent tragedies,” she said.

Dambhe said as per Sec 22, decision to seal the lift can be taken only if owner failed to reply to show cause notice, the third party insurance as per Sec 23 is yet to be implemented while suspension of licence as per Sec 19 can’t be done until an inquiry is completed.

Title: Robber brutally assaults man on Parvati hill
Content:
This story is from January 15, 2020

Pune: An evening stroll on Parvati hill on his day off turned horrific for Manoj Bahutule (35), a salesman with a garment shop, on Monday. An armed robber brutally assaulted him when he resisted him and fled with his cellphone as well as cash, collectively worth Rs7,200.

With the robber assaulting him with the butt of a knife, Bahutule suffered a cut on his chin and lost three teeth. The victim also suffered fractures to his left wrist and left leg in the sustained assault.

After preliminary treatment, Bahutule lodged an FIR against the robber. The police have registered an offence under relevant sections of the Indian Penal Code.

Sub-inspector K D Sankpal of the Dattawadi police station said Bahutule was a resident of Janata Vasahat and worked as the salesman in a garment shop. Since Monday was his weekly off, he had gone for stroll on the Parvati hill in the evening. “After reaching the top, Bahutule decided to sit on a wall located along the route towards Kartik Swami temple,” Sankpal said.

The officer said around 4pm an unidentified man appeared in front of Bahutule from the forest and threatened him with a sharp knife. When the man tried to snatch Bahutule’s mobile phone, the latter resisted. “The suspect all of a sudden assaulted Bahutule on his face. While attempting to dodge the blow, Bahutule received a cut on his chin,” Sankpal said.

The suspect then began hitting him on his mouth with the knife’s butt. Due to the sustained assault, Bahutule lost three teeth. As the assault continued, Bahutule raised an alarm. However, at the time, there was hardly anyone on Parvati hill. “Security guards of the Parvati temple heard the screams and ran towards the wall. Seeing the guards, the suspect snatched Bahutule’s cellphone and his wallet containing Rs200 before disappearing into the forest,” Sankpal said.

The guards immediately alerted the police. When the police team reached the spot, they found that Bahutule was in a bad condition. He was bleeding from his mouth and was also unable to move his hands and legs. “Our team brought him down the hill and sent him to the hospital. He is out of danger,” Sankpal said.

The officer stated that the police had launched a search for the suspect. “We have carried out searches in the slums located on the foothills. Our investigation is under way,” Sankpal said.

Title: HC’s contempt notices to state secys
Content:
This story is from January 15, 2020

Nagpur: Nagpur bench of Bombay high court on Tuesday issued contempt notices to three senior secretaries of the Maharashtra government over failure to upgrade Dr Babasaheb Ambedkar Hospital and Research Centre.

A division bench comprising justices Ravi Deshpande and Atul Chandurkar directed the respondents — Urban development secretary Manisha Mhaiskar, revenue secretary Manu Srivastava and medical education and research secretary Sanjay Deshmukh — to reply before March 11.

Petitioner Kunal, son of energy minister Nitin Raut, through counsel Rohan Chabra accused all three senior officials of wilfully disobeying the court’s orders while hearing a PIL No 96/2016 on December 31, 2018. The HC had ordered to upgrade the hospital within four months, but nothing progressed for over a year.

According to Chabra, North Nagpur is underdeveloped and backward area and there is need of better health care facilities for the residents there. He contended that the free land of 14,528 sq mtr is available for the upgradation and new construction, but the respondents were ignoring the HC’s orders.

During the Congress-NCP government, a cabinet note was released on February 25, 2014, in this regard and later a Government resolution (GR) was issued March 4 in same year for upgradation of the hospital.

(With inputs from Rushabh Rathod)

Title: JNU news: Classes can’t resume until VC is removed, says JNUSU
Content:
This story is from January 15, 2020

The JNU administration claimed the classes for the new semester had started at many schools.

NEW DELHI: In a hardening of its stand, Jawaharlal Nehru University Students’ Union ( JNUSU ) said on Tuesday that normal academic activities couldn’t resume on the campus till vice-chancellor M Jagadesh Kumar was removed.

“We will ensure that the main culprit behind ‘JNU terror attack’ on January 5, Mamidala Jagadesh Kumar, is removed as the vice-chancellor at the earliest. JNUSU, along with JNUTA, reiterate the position that there cannot be normal academic activities until the VC is removed,” JNUSU said in a statement.

Despite Union human resource development (HRD) minister Ramesh Pokhriyal ‘Nishank’ having said on Monday that the agitation was no longer justified as the fee demand had been met, JNUSU claimed success in suspending academic activities and boycotting the registration process. It also reiterated its key demands — complete rollback of the Inter-Hall Administration (IHA) manual, no punitive action against protesting students and holding an IHA meeting in a democratic manner with JNUSU in attendance.

The union called Pokhriyal’s support for the VC shameful and condemnable. “It just goes to show the complete support of the BJP government in the VC’s agenda to destroy JNU. As MHRD has ended the dialogue with JNUSU, it is clear that the government has completely sided with the JNU administration” JNUSU alleged, adding that the administration has neither provided a buffer period for exams nor withdrawn the proctor inquiries but the government has turned a blind eye to this behaviour.

Meanwhile, the administration claimed the classes for the new semester had started in many schools and centres and the timetable for more classes had been notified. Similarly, the MPhil/PhD viva-voce examination of various research scholars have been conducted, it added. On Tuesday, general body meetings (GBMs) were held at different centres to decide their stand on the registration.

JNUSU has called a council meeting on Wednesday. According to the statement, it is exploring “constitutional avenues” to fight the IHA manual and “has been in dialogue with the student faculty committee, hostel presidents and various organisations. We want to inform the students’ community that our struggle against the illegal IHA manual has entered its decisive phase as even the brutal state-sponsored violence has not dampened the spirit of resistance”.

Title: Goa: NGT asks for details on waste management, pollution
Content:
This story is from January 15, 2020

Representative image

PANAJI: The National Green Tribunal ( NGT ), New Delhi, has directed the governments of various state and Union territories to fill the gaps in information pertaining to solid waste management , sewage treatment and air pollution that has been submitted to it.

The bench issued the order recently after the matter was put up before it seeking that reports of the Central Pollution Control Board (CPCB) be considered in pursuance of the NGT’s September 12, 2019 order on the status of compliance of waste management and other issues in different states and UTs.

The CPCB had filed its status report on December 27, 2019 and another one on January 6 this year on the three major issues of waste, sewage and air pollution.

Although states had furnished some information, the NGT said the nature and extent of the information did not match the requirement. It also noted that there were huge gaps in information about sewage generation and treatment.

The tribunal also found fault with the grading of states by the CPCB. “Grading made by the CPCB into ‘good’, ‘average’, ‘poor’ and ‘no information’ is not based on any qualitative analysis but on the extent of information furnished,” the order stated.

With regard to municipal solid waste, the NGT sought more information on the quantity generated, segregated and treated. Gaps in waste-processing in terms of generation and treatment, and enforcement of statutory timelines needed to be explained, it stated. It also sought an explanation over bridging the gap and number of sites, the quantity of legacy waste therein and timelines for remediation.

The NGT further sought clarity on the quantity of sewage generated and treated in each state, the gap in sewage treatment and timelines to bridge the gap, including strategy for the use of treated water for secondary purposes.

Title: Shinde wants April start to services on priority stretch
Content:
This story is from January 15, 2020

Pune: State urban development minister Eknath Shinde on Tuesday told Maharashtra Metro Rail Corporation Limited (MahaMetro) to start Metro service for commuters by April.

At a meeting in Mumbai on Tuesday, Shinde told MahaMetro to complete trials on a 5km elevated portion by the end of March and start the service by April, officials said.

MahaMetro is conducted trials runs of two rakes on the “priority stretch” between the Sant Tukaramnagar and Phugewadi stations, which fall on Line 1 (PCMC-Swargate) of the Pune Metro project.

At the meeting, MahaMetro officials presented a progress report of the work in Pune and Pimpri Chinchwad. Shinde told them to give him timely updates.

Shinde also met officials from Pune Metropolitan Regional Development Authority (PMRDA), which has sought 4 TMC of water for the next 10 years. Shinde reportedly told PMRDA to furnish details of the various sources of water, which can supply the 7,000sqm region, considering that Khadakwasla dam supplies water to Pune. The minister told PMRDA commissioner Vikram Kumar and planner Vivek Kharwadkar to check the feasibility of sourcing water from the Mulshi Tata power dam.

Further, the minister told officials to speed up the land acquisition process for the first phase of the 128km ring road project.

On Friday, deputy chief minister Ajit Pawar will review the progress of all three Metro lines in Pune and Pimpri Chinchwad, while CM Uddhav Thackeray is expected to chair a PMRDA meeting this week, sources said.

Title: PMC pay boost for specialist doctors
Content:
This story is from January 15, 2020

Pune: The Pune Municipal Corporation (PMC) will increase the remuneration of specialist doctors to encourage them to join the civic medical services.

As per the new package, these medical practitioners will get Rs 71,679 per month as against the earlier salary of Rs 52,000. Of the 124 posts for specialist doctors, only 22 have been filled so far.

“Finding medical practitioners for civic health services was difficult due to low financial returns offered to them. The civic administration will increase their remuneration now from Rs 52,000 per month to Rs 71,679. A proposal in this regard has been tabled and approved,” Hemant Rasane, chairman of the standing committee of PMC, said.

The committee has also given green signal to appoint doctors on bond for the civic hospitals to tide over the vacancies. Once the approval for regular doctors comes from the state government, their services will be discontinued.

“Both these decisions will help in improving the civic medical services. The hospitals and medical facilities that remained unused due to manpower crunch can be utilised now,” Ramchandra Hankare, head of PMC’s health department, said.

PMC runs 49 out patient departments, 18 maternity hospitals, two mobile health centres each and one general hospital, among others.

A total of 216 health officers and resident doctors have been approved for these civic health facilities, of which 56 posts are still vacant. They will be filled with doctors who will sign the bonds. The civic administration will pay Rs 52,000 per month to these medical practitioners.

Title: After dozen gold heists in 7 months, Meerut jewellers knock on ADG’s door, threaten to shut shop
Content:
This story is from January 15, 2020

Meerut: A day after major police reshuffle in the state which saw two police commissioners taking over Lucknow and Noida, a large number of bullion traders knocked on the doors of additional director general of police (law and order) Prashant Kumar on Tuesday. Unnerved by over a dozen cases of loot and theft in the city involving gold and silver worth crores in the past 7-8 months, the bullion traders threatened to down shutters if a special team was not formed to solve these cases.

Exactly a month ago, prominent city jeweller Akshay Jindal lost gold and diamond jewellery worth Rs 54 lakh to robbers who daringly looted his shop in broad daylight. In November, another jeweller Govind Agarwal was divested of gold worth Rs 10 lakh. In October, two daring loots of yellow metal worth Rs 22 lakh took place in the district while in July, Meerut-based National Institute of Jewellery Technology witnessed theft of costly gadgets worth Rs 23 lakh and the list goes on.

None of these cases of loot and thefts have been solved so far.

Unnerved by the never-ending crime scenario, a large number of bullion traders knocked the doors of ADG Police Meerut zone Prashant Kumar on Tuesday morning and threatened to close down their businesses if cases are not solved at the earliest after the constitution of a special crack team for the purpose.

With a daily earning of nearly Rs 10 crore, Meerut is the largest jewellery market in Uttar Pradesh and among the top ten in the country. Over 40,000 artisans and 2,000 jewellery shop owners in the city depend on the industry which, according to a conservative estimate, involves an annual turnover of Rs 2,000 crore.

According to Pradeep Kumar Agarwal, president, Meerut Bullion Traders’ Association, “The situation is alarming. Out of a dozen cases, seven cases are of thuggery, in which gang members came in police uniform and pressured the person carrying the jewellery consignment. We gave sketches of these men to the police several times. But the security agencies have failed to make a single arrest. We have demanded ADG Kumar to set up a five-member crack force to seriously look into the matter. Otherwise, we will be forced to shut our shops.”

ADG Prashant Kumar told TOI, “We are already on the trail of this gang. Once they are nabbed, half of the cases will be solved. Besides, we are quite close to cracking the latest robbery in a showroom that took place at Akshay Jindal’s shop. But I think jewellers should also take some precautions in not falling prey to these thugs, who are able to divert their attention easily.”

Title: Courage seen in Gandhi’s time visible now, says freedom fighter Chitale
Content:
This story is from January 15, 2020

Freedom fighter Leelatai Chitale, who took part in the Quit India movement, addresses protesters after the agi... Read More

Nagpur: Protesters wound up their agitation against NRC-CAA at Samvidhan Chowk after four days as Leelatai Chitale, who took part in the Quit India movement, made a fiery speech on the last day.

“Not many would be knowing this but the colour green in the national flag represents Muslims of the country. This is because Muslims were in equal number in India those days. Hindus are represented by the saffron colour which also stands for the spirit of selflessness,” she said.

“Anyone who is son of the soil has an equal right to live in the country. Green also stands for nature and the government should not dare to go against nature,” she said.

Sounding loud and clear, the 89-year-old said she was 12 when she responded to Gandhi’s do or die call. “We were three girls who marched up to the Sitabai Arts College in Akola. The police detained us till the evening. On being released we got a rousing welcome. The courage instilled in the people by Gandhiji those days can be again seen now,” she said.

Chitale said her family faced tough times after her father, also a freedom fighter, lost his mental balance after coming out of jail. Later, her brother too was put under detention. “Those days it was difficult to make two ends meet. At that time, the Syed family of Borgaon Manju village in Akola came to our help. Even at that time there were people with a different mindset who objected to our taking help from them. But we could survive the crisis only because of the Syeds,” she said to a rousing applause.

Earlier, during the meet, Marathi writer Yeshwant Manohar hit out at RSS and the upper caste. “A Hindu rashtra means country of Brahmins and RSS where Manusmruti will be the law and women and lower caste will be slaves,” he said.

“You may be poor but Dr Babasaheb Ambedkar’s constitution gives you privilege of being the country’s citizens. I think it is beginning of the end of racism and I support you in the fight against it,” he said.

Social activist Rupa Kulkarni also toed the same line. “If they are accepting PAN cards for filing returns, why should they not treat it as a proof of citizenship too? If PAN is enough to pay your tax it should be so for citizenship also,” she said.

The four-day agitation was organized by an outfit — We the Citizens of India — formed during the anti-NRC-CAA protests. As the protests ended, calls were made to take part in another rally planned next week. On Wednesday, a group of students from Nagpur university are expected to hold protests at Samvidhan chowk.

Title: House set on fire by miscreants, woman and her kids suffer burns
Content:
This story is from January 15, 2020

Meerut: A 40-year-old woman and five children suffered burns while one of them were rushed to a hospital in Delhi later in a critical condition when unidentified miscreants set their house on fire when the family was asleep early on Tuesday.

The incident occurred at Zahidpur village in Kharkhoda region of Meerut .

Rahmeen, whose husband abandoned her eight years ago and she works as a labourer to fend for her family, was sleeping with her five children, when unidentified assailants poured petrol inside her house through a pipe and later threw a lit matchstick inside.

According to Manish Bisht, station incharge, Kharkhoda police station, “The family says it’s clueless about who could possibly be behind the act. They do not seem to have any enmity with anyone. Once the woman stabilizes a bit, we will question her."

Fatima, a distant relative of the woman, said, “Rahmeen is the only earning member in the family and was mostly busy with her children when she was not working. There wasn't any enmity angle as we know.”

Title: Seize WhatsApp group members’ phones: Delhi high court
Content:
This story is from January 15, 2020

NEW DELHI: Members of two WhatsApp groups allegedly linked to the January 5 violence at Jawaharlal Nehru University (JNU) must be summoned by police and their mobile phones seized “at the earliest,” Delhi high court said on Tuesday.

Justice Brijesh Sethi asked the police to act against members of the two suspected WhatsApp groups — Friends of RSS and Unity Against Left — after the social messaging service informed the court that messages and chats are end-to-end encrypted and not stored on its servers. It claimed that the chats would only be available on the recipient and sender’s phones. “It works on end-to-end encryption and the only way to access and preserve it is by preserving the phone of those persons,” the global giant’s counsel told the court after it sought to know steps taken to preserve the conversations in the two groups under scanner, as sought by the petitioners — three professors of JNU.

The court further told JNU administration to preserve and provide CCTV footage that may have captured incidents of the violence for which police have already sent a request.

The directions came as the court was hearing a plea filed by the academics seeking to preserve CCTV footage and other evidence relating to the WhatsApp groups allegedly used in coordinating the attack inside campus.

Senior advocate Rebecca John, appearing for the petitioners, told the court that mobile phones of the members of these two groups are a primary evidence. Once police seize any phone, they can get basic information from WhatsApp.

During the hearing, Google informed the court that if the police provided it with the user information, including email IDs, of the members of the two WhatsApp groups it could verify if any chat histories were backed up on Google Drive. That may be then shared. It told the court that the search engine will “protect whatever is there on our system as on date.”

On its part, Delhi Police told the court that it had identified 37 persons who were part of the two groups, and notices were sent to them to appear before it. But no phones have been confiscated or examined, it added.

After hearing all the parties, the high court issued various directions and disposed of the petition which had sought directions for preservation and retrieval of all materials and evidence available with WhatsApp, Google and Apple pertaining to relevant data of the two WhatsApp groups, including messages, pictures and videos and phone numbers of the members, related to JNU violence.

Title: Vehicle rams static car on eway, Mum architect dies
Content:
This story is from January 15, 2020

Pune: A 58-year-old architect from Andheri (West) in Mumbai was killed on Tuesday morning when an unidentified vehicle rammed his car from the rear after he stopped his four-wheeler in the shoulder lane of the Mumbai-bound corridor of expressway amid low visibility and came out of it.

The accident occurred near Devale bridge between Malavli and Lonavla, about 50km away from the city, around 7am. Police said the victim, Aziz Abbas Kachwalla, was proceeding towards Mumbai from Pune. He had stopped in the shoulder lane of the Pune-Mumbai expressway probably to relieve himself.

The Lonavla rural police’s investigating officer Ajit Nanaware said, “Kachwalla got down from his white Fiat Punto car and walked to the rear of the vehicle. He suddenly found himself stuck between his car and the speeding vehicle that came from the rear and crashed into his four-wheeler.”

He said, “The accident may have occurred because of low visibility caused by foggy morning conditions. The vehicle coming from the rear may not have spotted the white car in the shoulder lane in time. The unidentified vehicle’s driver did not stop at the site nor did he/she make any calls to the expressway emergency control room. Going by the circumstances at the site and the impact of the crash, we suspect that the offending vehicle might be a truck or a bus.”

The police said, “After hitting the car, the unidentified vehicle dragged it for almost 25 metres with the victim stuck in between. It then swept aside the car to the extreme right side of the eway lane near the median. The victim died on the spot.”

Nanaware said, “Kachwalla was in Pune on Monday for visiting his mother, who stays at Kalyaninagar. He also has a bungalow at Khandala. After spending a day with his mother, he had left for Mumbai early in the morning on Tuesday.”

The Lonavla rural police have filed a case of rash and negligent driving causing death, against the unidentified four-wheeler driver.

Title: Morning haze to continue as moisture incursion prevails
Content:
This story is from January 15, 2020

Pune: Constant moisture in the air has pushed up occurrences of fog and haze in the city this winter.

As per India Meteorological Department (IMD), haze caused visibility in Shivajinagar to drop to 4km on Tuesday morning, which means that objects were not visible beyond the 4km radius due to the obscurity in the air. The visibility in Lohegaon was even less, plunging to 2km.

IMD officials said though there wasn’t data available on the frequency of haze and fog instances this winter, they seem to have gone up in Pune due to constant moisture presence in the air.

In meteorological glossary, fog is defined as ‘obscurity in the surface layers of the atmosphere, which is caused by a suspension of water droplets’. Haze is a suspension of extremely small, dry particles in the air, not only water droplets.

Anupam Kashyapi, head of weather, IMD Pune, told TOI, “The interaction between the moist southwesterly/ westerly breeze from the Arabian Sea and southerly/ southeasterly winds, the upper air cyclonic circulation over north Madhya Maharashtra are causing moisture incursion. This will further increase haze formation chances over Pune from January 15,” he added.

Title: GREEN VICTORY: NO ROAD VIA BHARAT VAN
Content:
This story is from January 15, 2020

Nagpur: With the Nagpur Municipal Corporation all set to refuse permission for cutting and transplantation of trees, the MahaMetro and Public Works Department has decided to drop the proposed road through Bharat Van as well as the alternative one through Ravi Nagar government quarters. This is a major victory for the greens who were fighting against the construction of the road through a thriving bio-diversity area.

In a letter to PWD on September 13, 2019, Metro has also stated that the plan for the tunnel road and viewing gallery at Futala Lake has been changed. “Now, there is no necessity for an alternative road from Amravati Road to Telangkhedi Hanuman Mandir via Bharat Nagar,” the letter stated.

TOI has also repeatedly written how Metro’s transplantation efforts have failed miserably even after using the services of experts and spending lakhs of money.

Originally, the viewing gallery was to occupy the entire Futala waterfront. It is now been reduced to half. A new permanent road is also being constructed in the area where the demolished eateries once stood.

NMC sources told TOI that municipal commissioner Abhijit Bangar discussed reports submitted by all agencies in the meeting held on Tuesday and directed NMC, PWD and MahaMetro to keep on hold the proposed roads. “MahaMetro officials informed that road in front of Futala lake was to be blocked for traffic for construction due to which an alternate road was proposed through Bharat Van. Now that the plan has changed, there is no need for a new road,” sources said.

The road through Bharat Nagar will however continue to remain as part of the development plan (DP). West Nagpur MLA Vikas Thakre had assured residents that it will be deleted.

NMC sources added that the Tree Authority headed by municipal commissioner Bangar will now procedurally reject the application of MahaMetro seeking transplantation of the 558 trees in Bharat Van. “Tree Authority, NMC, PWD and MahaMetro will submit similar affidavits before the Nagpur bench of Bombay high court informing it about Tuesday’s decision. The next hearing of the suo motu PIL is slated for January 29,” sources said.

Sources also added that the decision to drop the road “is not a sudden one but an outcome of various deliberations”. “In the last meeting held with MP Nitin Gadkari at Vanamati, it was decided that alternate options would be explored. Simultaneously, a thought came forward that the gallery’s design should be modified to avoid road blockage. That’s how things started unfolding,” said sources.

TOI was the first to report on October 27, 2018, about the proposal to construct the road cutting down 588 trees, displacing different species of birds and also monkeys. Honorary wildlife warden Jaydeep Das wrote a letter to HC seeking its intervention in saving the mini forest. He wrote that road was being planned without any traffic and environmental assessment.

The HC treated Das’ letter as a suo motu PIL on December 3, 2018 and also imposed a stay on the cutting of trees.

After activists and residents of various parts of West Nagpur including Bharat Nagar protested, Gadkari, who had sanctioned funds for the proposed road, directed the NMC to find an alternative one.

This other choice was to cut through two playgrounds in Ravi Nagar government quarters. Residents of the area were opposed to this too.

Thakre also held a meeting with PWD engineers, talked to NMC officials and directed to drop all proposed roads. NMC sources said Thakre also took up this issue with PWD minister Ashok Chavan recently.

The state PWD conducted a Origin-Destination Traffic Survey and stressed on the need for a road through Bharat Van. MahaMetro inspected the alternative through Ravi Nagar and apprised NMC about the problems.

The MahaMetro had earlier denied that the road through Bharat Van was an alternate for closing the road in front of Futala lake. It had said that the proposed road was the main project and Futala lake works were ancillary.

A MahaMetro official told TOI on Tuesday that it “was an executing agency and will implement the project as per decisions of PWD”. “It is not our project but planned and sanctioned by PWD,” he said.

Thakre said no project can be executed unless it is beneficial for the people. “Everyone were opposed to the proposed roads. I will ensure that it is deleted from the DP. I will also take efforts to ensure that the Bharat Van is reserved as green zone,” he said.

Title: Kirloskar Brothers Limited celebrates Laxmanrao’s legacy
Content:
This story is from January 15, 2020

Laxmanrao Kirloskar’s many innovations on display at KBL’s office in Baner.

PUNE: The foundation for the 100-year-old Pune-based Kirloskar Brothers Limited (KBL) was laid when Laxmanrao Kirloskar started a bicycle trading company with his brother in 1888. Years later, he moved to Belgaum to pursue his dream of manufacturing things that could find a market in India.

When he moved to the countryside, he became transfixed with the idea of making iron ploughs, as he thought they would find a market among the agrarian population, which then comprised 80% of the people in India. A voracious reader, Laxmanrao studied catalogues and American magazines — like the ‘Foundry’ — to learn to make good ploughs. In early 20th century, his efforts bore fruit and he brought out six ploughs, only to realize that there was no market for them.

“It took him two years to sell the first six ploughs — a progressive farmer from Karad bought them. The company hasn’t looked back since,” says Sanjay Kirloskar, Laxmanrao’s great grandson and KBL managing director.

As KBL marks the 100th year of the inception of its registered office in Kirloskarwadi, it also celebrates Laxmanrao’s liberal thinking which made it possible for the township to be built from scratch.

“What I found great about him was that when he had to leave Belgaum, he could bring 32 families with him to a place that had nothing. They constructed this township. He was neither particularly religious nor a believer in rituals or superstitions. It did not matter to him that people who came with him were from different backgrounds, castes and religions — that was how Kirloskarwadi grew,” says Sanjay.

Laxmanrao’s many innovations still find a place of pride in KBL’s ground floor headquarters in Baner, many dating back to Kirloskar Group ’s efforts to industrialize India, at a time when the Freedom Movement was gaining momentum.

Such is the goodwill that Laxmanrao had earned over the years that many erstwhile employees and acquaintances have offered to help the group for free to manage events that the company wishes to undertake in his name.

“All the time, Laxmanrao was thought about work — he hardly gave himself time for relaxing, entertainment, holiday tours or even family. He sacrificed everything for India’s industrial independence — he was working when his son got married, and was doing social work when his wife passed away,” says B V Chaukulkar, who was born in Kirloskarwadi and spent time with Laxmanrao from 1940-46.

The family has kept in touch with the families all those who had supported Laxmanrao’s enterprise at the time. In 2019, the newer generations of those families flew in from different parts of the world to celebrate Laxmanrao’s sesquicentenary.

Title: Bihar schoolgirl found in Siliguri month after kidnap
Content:
This story is from January 15, 2020

Representative image

PATNA: A 13-year-old girl from Katihar , who was kidnapped while returning home from school more than a month ago, was rescued from Siliguri in West Bengal on Monday by her parents with the help of Bihar Police .

“The girl was kidnapped by Lakhman Paswan and his associates in the last week of November while she was returning from her school,” Katihar’s Sahayak police station SHO Rajesh Kumar said, adding, “Paswan took her to Siliguri where he works at a tea manufacturing company and raped her.”

In her police complaint, the girl alleged that she was raped by Paswan, a father of three, in his rented accommodation soon after they landed at Siliguri. When she complained to his wife Munni Devi, she allegedly threatened her and told her to follow her husband’s diktat.

According to the complaint, the minor overheard a conversation between Paswan and his wife about selling the minor to pimp in a red light area. Frightened, she narrated her tale to a sympathetic neighbour.

“The neighbour took pity on her and somehow contacted her parents in Katihar over phone and disclosed about the place where she was held captive,” said an investigating officer, quoting the victim.

Paswan (40) and his wife Muni Devi (35) have been booked under Section 366A of IPC and POCSO Act 2012. “Other sections will be added after receipt of the victim’s medical report,” the SHO added.

Katihar SP Vikas Kumar said, “The girl comes from a poor family and her neighbour took advantage of the family’s economic condition. The couple’s links with those involved in human trafficking in Siliguri are being verified. Our first priority was to get the victim released safe and sound.”

Since the police were made aware that Paswan was trying to sell her off, the Katihar police exerted pressure on his relatives in Katihar. “Going to Siliguri would have taken time so we exerted pressure on Lakshman’s relatives in Katihar to hand over the girl to her parents. And the girl was let off near the ‘hawai adda’ under the Katihar Sahayak police station on Monday evening from where she was brought to the police station,” said a police officer.

“We will now send a police team to Siliguri to trace the place where the girl was kept in illegal confinement and subjected to sexual abuse. A woman police officer has been entrusted with the task of counselling the victim on a regular basis,” the SP said.

The minor was produced at the Katihar civil court on Tuesday and sent to the local sadar hospital for medical examination. The medical report is awaited.

Though the Sahayak SHO denied that any missing complaint was lodged, the girl’s father claimed that he had filed a complaint petition to the local police but nobody cared. “Thane wale bole ki pata lagao (cops asked me to search her myself),” the girl’s father said.

Title: GK Gurukul organizes three-day annual concert, ‘Anubhuti 2019’
Content:
This story is from January 15, 2020

Pune: The GK Gurukul recently organized its three-day annual concert ‘Anubhuti 2019’ .

The first day featured ‘A Mosaic of Indian Culture’, where the primary students gave information about a particular state and presented its folk dance. On the second day, two musicals were staged — Oliver Twist and Arabian Nights. The students of Standard III to VIII enacted the adaptation of Charles Dickens’ famous work, which was followed by ‘Journey from Dickens to Desert of Arabia’, an amalgamation of various stories of Arabian Nights, including the famous Aladdin. They were trained by the speech and drama academy Helen O’Grady International.

The students of Standard I and II performed ‘A Saga of Fairy Tales’ on the third day that included the story of Sleeping Beauty and various dances.

Over 1,000 parents attended the three-day event.

RIMS, NIBM celebrates annual day

RIMS International School and Junior College, NIBM Road, recently celebrated its annual day on the theme “Seasons of Life”.

The theme showcased the story of an ex-Army man and his journey through life with his best friends. An excerpt from the ‘Mind Your Language’ series was also presented, to exhibit the main character’s experience in an international atmosphere. The protagonist’s life was portrayed through the three stages of life symbolizing “life is an experiment, the more you experience the better it gets”.

The students of pre-primary to A-Level showcased their talents through performances in dance, drama and music. The highlight of the finale was a performance by the staffers and a flash mob.

The chief guest on the occasion was Prem Nath Gulati, a television, cine and theatre artist. Members of the managing committee, guests and parents were also present on the occasion.

Principal Sujata Sharma mentioned the laurels and achievements of the school and its students. The chief guest also delivered an inspirational talk on the occasion.

SFS student bags silver in athletics

Gauravi Naik of Standard IX from St Francis De Sales School recently became the first student from the institution to win a medal at the national-level as she clinched a silver medal in the 4x100m relay in the girls’ under-14 category at the recent 65th National School Athletics Championship at Sangrur in Punjab. She represented the Maharashtra relay team.

Earlier, she had clocked the fastest time in 100-metre sprint in the inter-school district sports office’s School Athletic Games, held at Shree Shiv Chhatrapati Sports Complex, Mhalunge Balewadi.

After winning the gold at the district-level, she won a silver medal in 200-metre at the Pune Division Athletics Championship held at Sant Dnyaneshwar Athletics Stadium, Bhosari, securing her place in the State Athletics Championship.

She was trained by physical education teachers Mukund Singh Negi and Aakash Nadhe. The principal, Fr Daniel Pareste, staffers and parents congratulated her. The school management waived her fees for six months, acknowledging the feat accomplished by the promising athlete.

Title: To save money on rent, govt may shift some offices to IGC
Content:
This story is from January 15, 2020

Amaravati: In a move that could lighten the burden on the exchequer, the state government is mulling the shift of many government offices, such as commissionerates and directorates, that are operating from offices taken on rent in Vijayawada and Guntur cities to the Interim Government Complex (IGC) in Velagapudi.

The IGC, which houses the secretariat, is likely to be unoccupied once the government clears the decks for the relocation of the executive capital city in Visakhapatnam. In fact, shifting of head of the departments (HoDs) to Velagapudi will show the local residents that the government will not ignore Amaravati.

Sources said shifting the commissionerates and directorates to Velagapudi would also help counter the criticism that the buildings constructed with public money would go waste.

“The proposal is only in the initial discussions. It needs further fine-tuning,” said a senior official privy to the development.

IGC has six blocks with G+1 structure. While assembly and council are located in one block, another block is dedicated to the CMO. The chambers of cabinet ministers and about 33 departments are housed in the remaining four blocks. Since Amaravati is likely to continue as legislative capital, the government might keep the assembly and CMO blocks available for future requirements. In such a case, about four lakh square foot of space would be available in the remaining four blocks in IGC as each block measures one lakh sqft. Since many of the HoDs are housed in offices, which are about 20,000-30,000 sqft, and located in remote locations in different parts of Vijayawada and Guntur cities, shifting a few of the offices to Velagapudi would have dual benefit. First the staff will no longer have to work from insufficient space and the government can save money on the rent.

For instance, some of the senior officials have offices, which are about 1 lakh sqft, and they pay a monthly rent of Rs 30-Rs 40 lakh. Besides, the commissioners and directors have spent a large amount of money on doing up the interiors. The then managing director of APMDC had reportedly spent a fortune to make the install central air-conditioning in the office, despite knowing that it was a private property.

The state government is spending nearly Rs 80-Rs 90 crore on annual rent for the private space, which means the state government has already spent close to Rs 250-Rs 300 crore exclusively on rents. These offices were hurriedly shifted to Amaravati from Hyderabad without proper planning and facility. Private buildings located in Gollapudi to Gannavaram in Vijayawada and Tadepalle to Syamalanagar in Guntur city were taken on lease. There were allegations that many of the buildings were taken on lease in remote areas due to pressure from the then ministers and TDP functionaries. “We could have constructed permanent buildings with these amount had the previous government not moved all the offices from Hyderabad to Amaravati region without planning,” commented a senior official.

Title: Pune Cantonment Board removes 200 hawkers, seizes over 150 handcarts
Content:
This story is from January 15, 2020

The seized handcarts in a Pune Cantonment Board-owned vehicle.

PUNE: A special squad of the Pune Cantonment Board (PCB) removed over 200 hawkers on MG Road and its surrounding areas during anti-encroachment drives over the past 12 days.

The squad led by PCB’s deputy executive officer Rahul Gajbaye fined over 200 hawkers and confiscated around 150 handcarts during the drives. With the previous efforts of the PCB to curb illegal encroachments within the cantonment limits having come unstuck, the board officials said they would conduct regular and prolonged drives till the desired results were achieved. “We would continue our endeavour,” Gajbaye said.

The board had received several complaints from residents and Army officers regarding encroachments on public pavements, particularly on MG Road and East Street. “Either side of MG Road and East Street is reserved for parking. So, there is limited carriageway available for vehicular movement. With illegal vendors hijacking most of the pavement, commuters and pedestrians hardly get any space. We want to change this scenario,” Amit Kumar, chief executive officer of the PCB, told TOI.

Kumar said the PCB had carried out similar drives in the past, but they were not effective as hawkers would return in a few days. “This sort of prolonged campaign will send a stern message to the encroachers. The drives would be done on a regular basis in the future too,” he said.

The PCB has also decided to act against the traders encouraging encroachments by allowing hawkers to operate in front of their shops on the busy roads in the Cantonment area.

A section of the board officials said some of the hawkers had support from some of the board members. “Some members had approached the board authorities to return the seized materials. This needs to be stopped,” a senior official said.

Title: BBMP washes its hands of 4 multilevel car parking projects
Content:
This story is from January 15, 2020

Representative image

BENGALURU: Almost 12 years after 10 multilevel car parking (MLCP) projects were proposed for the city and several reiterations of budgetary allocations were made for four, BBMP has washed its hands of them citing lack of space.

The four locations shortlisted for MLCP were opposite Sukh Sagar Hotel in Gandhinagar, Gandhi Bazaar , opposite Hosmat Hospital on Magrath Road and on the BBMP office premises near NR Square.

“Major exercises were conducted by the Palike to undertake the projects. Many working hours were spent to prepare detailed project reports, drawings and documents. Sadly, the projects have been found to be unviable. We have almost wasted a decade on them without getting any results,” a BBMP official said.
