On record, though, BBMP says the projects have only been handed over to Bengaluru Smart City ( BenSCL ), which will take them up under central grants. “We have not given up on any MLCP. Some of them are being taken up under Smart City,” BBMP commissioner BH Anil Kumar asserted.

BenSCL too has not responded positively to the civic agency’s proposal. “Just like the Palike, even we have checked the project’s feasibility. There is no space. How can we go ahead with MLCP projects,” wondered a BenSCL official.

Besides, BenSCL’s resources are stretched. Of the Rs 1,000 crore funds in its kitty, it’s spending Rs 500 crore on road infrastructure and has several other projects in the pipeline. Sources said they want to take up the projects under public-private partnership but private parties are not showing any interest.

The urban land transport department in its parking policy prepared in 2008 had recommended MLCP projects at 10 locations — the existing flower market in Gandhi Bazaar; opposite Sukh Sagar Hotel in Gandhinagar; old Central Jail complex (Freedom Park); opposite Russell Market; SP Road behind LIC Building; opposite Surana College, Kengeri; opposite football stadium, Richmond Town; next to Ambedkar College, Outer Ring Road, Nagarbhavi; opposite RTO office, Yelahanka and Sant Maidan, Yelahanka to accommodate 3,055 cars and 1,400 two-wheelers. Barring the one at Freedom Park , not a single project has taken off.

Title: Shivaji Maharaj’s name used for pol gains: Udayanraje
Content:
This story is from January 15, 2020

Former MP Udayanraje Bhosale

Pune: Udayanraje Bhosale, the 13th descendent of Chhatrapati Shivaji Maharaj, on Tuesday condemned the publication of a book authored by BJP member Jay Bhagwan Goyal calling Prime Minister Narendra Modi as a modern day Chhatrapati Shivaji Maharaj. He said political parties were using the Maratha king’s name for gains.

Senior Shiv Sena functionary Sanjay Raut on Monday had asked the warrior king's descendants to clarify their stand over the issue. Without taking any names, Raut had targeted BJP's Rajya Sabha member Chhatrapati Sambhaji Raje and former Satara MP Udayanraje Bhosale who are from his lineage.

Udayanraje, without naming NCP chief Sharad Pawar, who is often referred to as “Janata Raja” (a wise and aware king) in political circles, said Shivaji Maharaj is the only one who can be called “Janata Raja”.

He challenged the Shiv Sena to rename itself as “Thackeray Sena” and remove Chhatrapati Shivaji Maharaj’s reference.

The former Satara MP, who had switched over to the BJP from the NCP ahead of the state assembly polls, said he felt dejected about the release of the controversial book.

“I have not read it. But what I have heard from the people and from the social media… Chhatrapati Shivaji Maharaj cannot be compared to like this. No one can reach his stature. He always thought of the people and followed “sarvadharma samabhav” (equality to all religions) secularism and social harmony. We can always follow his thoughts but we can never be Shivaji Maharaj,” he said.

He targeted the Shiv Sena for using Chhatrapati Shivaji Maharaj’s name. “How can a vada paav be named as Shiv vada? Why Maha-Shiv-Aghadi which was then renamed Maha-Vikas-Aghadi? Why is Shivaji Maharaj’s name being included in the party’s name? Instead, make it Thackeray Sena. If you want to use his name, then implement his thoughts. Citizens of the state are facing immense problems. Farmers are in distress. Those leading the state should work on these issues instead of taking mileage from Shivaji Maharaj’s name,” Bhosale said.

Bhosale wanted to understand why Shiv Jayanti was celebrated on three different days in the state. “A single date can be fixed to avoid politics over the days,” he added.

The Congress and NCP have demanded the book’s immediate withdrawal.

Title: Lungs of Nagpur saved, say elated green activists
Content:
This story is from January 15, 2020

Nagpur: The collective decision of the authorities to make way for public demand by not making the road through Bharat Van is a big win for thousands of citizens, who stood hand-in-hand at Futala lake stretch on May 1 to save the urban jungle.

Since more than a year, citizens have been protesting to save one of the last biodiversity hotspots of the city — a lush green patch of land owned by Dr Panjabrao Deshmukh Krishi Vidyapeeth (PDKV), which was to be sacrificed for the proposed road.

Appreciative of the move taken by the civic agencies, greens welcome the development but with a word of caution. Honorary wildlife warden of Nagpur Jaydeep Das, whose letter highlighting the dangerous impact of the road was treated as a suo motu PIL by the Nagpur bench of Bombay High Court, said, “The authorities realizing that transplantation of trees is a big failure is a very positive step. However, this road should be deleted permanently from the city’s development plan as in future, some other agency might want to build it.”

Adding that environment has come out to be the big winner in the Bharat Van case, Das demanded that environment impact assessment and structural audit should be done for the redevelopment of Futala case. “Rather than gaining commercial benefits at the cost of heritage and environment, authorities should now start being more considerate,” he said.

Celebrating the decision which saves the “lungs of Nagpur”, founder of Green Vigil Foundation Kaustav Chatterjee said, “It has been proved that public say matters. The final decision is in the hands of tree authority and we hope that the agencies stick to its decision.”

The authorities have accepted peoples’ verdict, stated Anasuya Chhabrani of NGO Swachh Association. “We are thankful to all the government agencies and politicians who supported citizens’ demand. To ensure sustainable development, this and other such roads threatening green cover should be immediately removed from the development plans. With changing times, the government needs to be receptive to alterations,” she added.

President of NGO Paryavaran Prerna Sharad Paliwal agreed. “It is good that the authorities realized the drastic consequences of constructing the road. Now, it should immediately inform the high court about its final decision so that the case can be disposed off,” he said.

In May last year, Paliwal had filed an intervention in the ongoing case highlighting that the proposed road construction cannot be looked in isolation while considering environmental impacts. “The area is home to around 140 bird species and other animals which will get adversely affected by the road,” his affidavit stated.

Title: Expert touch to engineering curriculum at Trinity college
Content:
This story is from January 15, 2020

Pune: Over 100 industry experts will review and design the curriculum at Trinity College of Engineering.

A core-industry advisory board was formed recently to undertake specialized pedagogical training, a statement issued by the college stated.

Swroop Kulkarni, an expert from Emerson, was appointed the chairman of the advisory board. He suggested that a feedback mechanism be institutionalized to track alumni. “They could help us in active engagement with the industry,” said Kulkarni.

Trinity College is affiliated to Savitribai Phule Pune University and offers under-graduate and postgraduate programmes in engineering.

“We often invite industry experts to participate in our academic process and over 100 industry personalities have visited the college. Taking their expertise further, we have decided to form this advisory board and develop a curriculum fit enough to respond to the industry’s demand,” Kalyan Jadhav, the president of the institute, said.

The board also comprises Balasaheb Nanaware, general manager (HR) at BAG Electronics India Pvt Ltd; Suryakant Jankar, project manager at Loramendi; Sakshee Kale, Oracle Technical Consultant (Cloud) at Cognizant, and others.

Title: Festival to encourage startups from Feb 28
Content:
This story is from January 15, 2020

Pimpri Chinchwad: The Pimpri Chinchwad International Festival of Future, which provides a platform to startups to attract investment and encourage innovative thinking, will be held at Autocluster on February 28 and 29.

Pimpri Chinchwad mayor Usha alias Mai Dhore and municipal commissioner Shravan Hardikar shared this information while addressing a news conference in Pimpri.

An exhibition of commercial projects of 20 innovative startups will also be held. “Around 1,000 startups from the city are expected to participate in the festival,” Hardikar said.

The expenditure on the festival is around Rs 40 lakh. “Street carnival, green building, arts and cultural events and other innovative programmes will also be organised,” the civic chief said. The City Transformation Office(CTO) of the civic body has created a policy to encourage young industrialists and provide them with a friendly environment to start new industries by 2030. The festival is a part of this initiative.

Title: Canoe with 8 capsizes in Wainganga, 2 drown
Content:
This story is from January 15, 2020

Chandrapur: Two persons drowned while six others had close shave after a canoe capsized midstream in Wainganga river separating Chandrapur and Gadchiroli districts on Tuesday morning.

Rescue team from disaster management cell failed to recover the bodies despite intense search operation till late evening. The river has deep water as the doors of Chichdoh barrage upstream are closed after monsoon.

The victims Ramchandra Pendam and Parshuram Atram were returning from Chamorshi after attending a funeral. They had boarded a canoe with six others to cross the river at Talodhi ghat on Gadchiroli side. As the canoe started for Kadoli ghat on Chandrapur side, it started filling with water as it has excessive load of eight people, informed Saoli teshildar PK Kumre. As Pendam and Atram, who did not know how to swim, panicked and jumped into the water, said Kumre. As the duo jumped, the canoe overturned and all other occupants fell into water. Pendam and Atram met watery grave even before anyone could save them. The six others managed to swim to the riverbank. One of them was travelling with his mother and he carried her on his back and swam to safety.

Soon the disaster management cell was informed and search operation to fish out the bodies was started in the afternoon. However, the rescue team failed to locate the bodies till evening. Search operation will resume on Wednesday morning.

Title: Maharashtra: Twins found abandoned near Pashan lake
Content:
This story is from January 15, 2020

Representative image

PUNE: A day-old twins, a boy and a girl, were found abandoned near Pashan lake on Tuesday morning.

Police have admitted them to the Sassoon General Hospital and said that both the newborns were in a healthy condition.

Senior police inspector Anil Shewale of the Chatushrungi police told TOI, “Some morning walkers from Pashan and Bavdhan heard cries of the babies and rushed to the spot along the eastern banks of the lake.”

He said, “They found both the babies wrapped in blankets. We believe the infants were born in a good family but for some reasons were abandoned.”

The persons on the morning walk called up the police and also fed them milk. “There were no stray dogs in the area at that time. The residents guarded them at the spot until the police reached,” Shewale said.

The twins were taken to the child welfare committee, following which they were admitted to the hospital.

“We have registered a case against unidentified man or woman for abandoning the children,” he said.

Title: Mayor to hold Janata Darbar from Jan 16
Content:
This story is from January 15, 2020

Nagpur: After resolving various issues of the people through Walk and Talk with Mayor initiative, mayor Sandip Joshi will hold Janata Darbar in various zones of the city to redress the grievances of the residents.

The Janata Darbar will be organized from January 16 to March 18, between 9am and 3pm, said the mayor.

The initiative will start from Laxmi Nagar zone on January 16. It will be followed by Dharampeth zone on January 22, Hanuman Nagar (January 29), Dhantoli (February 5), Nehru Nagar (February 12), Gandhibagh (February 18), Satranjipura (February 26), Lakadganj (March 4), Ashi Nagar (March 11) and Mangalwari (March 18).

Joshi also urged citizens to submit their complaints with the respective zone offices of the NMC.

Meanwhile, chairman of women and child welfare committee of the NMC Sangita Girhe has asked civic administration to identify spots in all 10 zones for constructing food stalls. On January 16, Girhe will visit all zones in this regard.

Girhe also reviewed the preparations for the upcoming women entrepreneurship exhibition to be held in Reshimbagh from January 19 to January 26.

Title: 2-day adventure sport fest at Horsley Hills
Content:
This story is from January 15, 2020

Tirupati: The state tourism department will organise an adventure sport festival at Horsley Hills near Madanapalli in Chittoor district on January 18 and 19.

Chittoor district administration and the Tourism department have joined hands to develop Horsley Hills as a destination for adventure sports in a bid to increase tourist footfall.

As part of the two day festival, a series of events including a survival camp event, trekking, tree climbing, hot air balloon rides, tree climbing and many other adventure sporting events will be organised at Horsley Hills on January 18 and 19.

The Tourism department will also organise cultural events as a curtain raiser at BT College grounds at Madanapalle on January 17.

Chittoor district administration and Andhra Pradesh tourism officials have appealed to all interested people to register themselves for the events scheduled as part of the two day adventure festival to be held at Horsley Hills later this week.

Title: Street play contest for engineering students
Content:
This story is from January 15, 2020

Pune: Students from various engineering colleges demonstrated their artistic skills on Monday with street plays on various issues and solutions related to the construction industry.

The street plays were held as a part of the Abhiyanta Karandak, a street play competition for civil engineering students at the College of Engineering Pune (CoEP). The event was organized by the Builders’ Association of India, Pune.

The street plays were followed by a prize distribution ceremony, during which Sinhgad College of Engineering, Narhe, bagged the first prize, JSPM’s Rajarshi Shahu College of Engineering, Tathawade, was the first runner-up, Pimpri Chinchwad College of Engineering was the second runner-up.

The theme of the competition was challenges of engineering contracting and importance of civil engineering to the society. Each team had the option of performing for a maximum of 15 minutes with a team size of 10 students.

Consolation prize was given to DY Patil College of Engineering. All the teams will get opportunity to perform during CONSTRO 2020 exhibition, which will be held between January 16 and 19 at Agriculture College Ground.

Title: Rotten meat transportation: Corp to write to Railway Board
Content:
This story is from January 15, 2020

Kozhikode: City corporation will write a letter to the chairman of Railway board and police department to curb the transportation of rotten chicken meat via trains to be supplied to various food chain outlets in the corporation limits.

This was announced by mayor Thottathil Raveendran at the corporation council meeting held on Tuesday.

He said the letter will be submitted to avert similar incidents in the future. A reply in this regard was given when two councillors moved a joint adjournment motion in this regard. The adjournment motion was moved in the council following the seizure of 600kg of rotten chicken meat from Kozhikode railway station that arrived from Nizamuddin on Mangala Express train on January 9.

Inviting the attention of mayor, K M Rafeeq of CPM urged the mayor to put in place an effective mechanism to curb the supply of meat from outside the state via trains.

Councillor Sayed Mohammed Shameel said that formalin-laced fish and meat are being supplied to various hotels via train and buses. He urged the mayor to strengthen vigil and conduct inspections covering all types of food chain outlets comprising hotels, bakeries, makeshift eatery outlets making use of such meat items for the preparation of shawarma and snack items. Corporation health standing committee chairman K V Baburaj said that civic body has already taken steps to curb the supply of inconsumable meat to eatery outlets which are harmful to health. The council also decided to strictly enforce the ban on all types of single-use plastic items in the corporation limits from January 15 onwards. Councillor C Abdurahiman of IUML urged the mayor to provide time for the execution of a ban on the single-use plastic items. He said the traders need time for the disposal of bulk quantity of plastic carry bags purchased by them.

Mayor replied that enough time was given to the traders for the disposal of the remaining stock of single-use plastic items and they must comply with the government order. He also urged the traders and shop owners to switch over to cloth and paper carry bags. Corporation secretary Binu Francis said that that all types of single-use plastic items have been banned on January 1 and the ban will be strictly enforced in the corporation limits from January 15. He said the ban will be imposed by three enforcement authorities of local self-government bodies, district administration, and the pollution control board. The corporation secretary informed the council that the civic body will impose a fine of Rs 10,000 against the violators in the initial phase. The fine will be increased to Rs 25,000 and Rs 50,000 in case the officials detect the violations for the second and third time.

Title: Garbage plant raises a stink at AMC meet
Content:
This story is from January 15, 2020

Aurangabad: The proposed 150 tonne-a-day waste management plant at Harsul dominated the standing committee meeting held at the Aurangabad Municipal Corporation (AMC) on Tuesday.

While Shiv Sena members wanted the project to be given to the agency proposed by the administration, the members of BJP marked a strong protest against finalising the previous tender and sought a new tender.

Last year, the AMC had called a tender for the appointment of an agency to run the waste management facility at Harsul. Pune’s PH Jadhav made the lowest bid followed by Waluj’s Mayo Vessels. In September 2019, the standing committee, chaired by BJP’s Jaishree Kulkarni, rejected the tender four months after it was submitted. The committee had raised questions on the shortlisted agency’s efficiency.

On January 9, in a meeting held in the city, Chief Minister Uddhav Thackeray had asked the AMC to expedite the establishment of the Harsul facility.

On Tuesday, Sena brought the old tender before the standing committee as a last-minute proposal. Sena’s Rajendra Janjal, Sachin Khaire and other members sought approval for the same agency the committee had earlier rejected. Janjal, who is also the deputy mayor, alleged that BJP’s decision to scrap the old tender is based on vested interests. In response, BJP’s Raju Shinde said that they (BJP) too were aware of Sena’s truth. However, BJP group leader Pramod Rathod had a different stand from his party members. He said the Harsul waste management facility was crucial and he would seek information on why the tender was not approved.

Gajanan Barwal, of Shahar Vikas Aghadi, also objected to the old tender.

Notably, Nandkishore Bhombe, the head of the AMC’s solid waste management cell, had skipped the meeting. Executive engineer Hemant Kolhe attended the meeting on his behalf. When asked about the previous record of the agency, Kolhe said he had no idea about it.

Meanwhile, Sena members have asked mayor Nandkumar Ghodele to bring the project before the general body for its approval. Ghodele said he would get the legalities checked by the legal advisor to see if the GB can approve the agency.

Title: Only one cash lane at toll plazas from today
Content:
This story is from January 15, 2020

Nashik: Toll plazas across Nashik from Wednesday would have only one lane for cash payment, while all other lanes will have electronic toll collection system through FASTags.

A senior National Highway Authority of India (NHAI) official said motorists who do not having FASTags but enter the electronic toll collection (ETC) lanes will have to pay double toll fees. “Even motorists who do not have sufficient balance in their account, will have to double toll fees,” he said.

“There was fear among people that double toll fee was being deducted from their bank account. Even if that was the case, the money would be transferred back into their account within two to three days,” he added.

Vehicle owners who are eligible for concession in toll fee like the ones staying within the 20-km radius of the toll plaza would have to visit the toll plaza and get their names and vehicles registered so that toll fee is not deducted from their account.

NHAI officials said that police bandobast will be maintained at all the toll plazas in the district to ensure that there is no law and order situation.

Title: Tamil Nadu: Tangedco may not get support of finance companies
Content:
Representative image

CHENNAI: Even as Tangedco’s financial woes go from bad to worse, it has received a further shock with Union power minister R K Singh writing to chief minister Edappadi K Palaniswami and threatening to stop financial support to various thermal projects of the discom from Rural Electrification Corporation (REC) and Power Finance Corporation (PFC). The minister in a letter, a copy of which is available with TOI, has said that REC and PFC will be able to provide financial support only if Tangedco fulfills certain commitments.The letter was particularly critical about the delay by Tangedco in clearing payments to private power generators, besides not collecting its own dues from government departments. Following the letter, state power minister P Thangamani and TNEB chairman Vikram Kapur met Singh on Monday in New Delhi.“The distribution company, in the present circumstances, is not good credit risk and therefore the PFC and REC will find it difficult to extend further loans to it. The PFC and REC are financial institutions and they have to follow prudential norms,” Singh said in the letter. According to these norms, the distribution companies which have over-dues to generating companies and which are running losses do not qualify for lending. “This is a serious matter for the distribution company because PFC and REC are the major source for raising finances,” said the minister.The Tangedco website said a total of 5,700MW of thermal projects and 506.7MW of hydro power projects are dependent on finances from PFC and REC. As per the PRAAPTI (Payment Ratification and Analysis in Power procurement for bringing Transparency in invoicing of generators) website under the Union power ministry, Tangedco’s pending dues to various power generators, as on November 30, 2019, stood at Rs 11,728 crore.The minister attributed three factors for the discom’s troubles. “The non-payment of power dues by government departments is one major factor. The departments will need to pay every month for the electricity they consume. With power theft being another factor listed, the state government and discom will need to start taking stringent action to reduce theft and bring down the aggregate technical and commercial losses,” said Singh. He also referred to non-reimbursement or delayed reimbursement of subsidy provided to various category of consumers.Singh suggested a few areas to focus upon immediately to get REC and PFC to rethink on providing finance support to various power projects in the state. “The departments must clear their dues within three months and there must be a system wherein the departments pay their monthly power bill without any delay. One option is to install prepaid meters in all the departments as some states have done already,” said the minister.The minister also stressed on the need to have a strict system of energy accounting in place, as the core business of the discom is sale of electricity. “Power supplied to all categories of consumers must be strictly accounted for and the subsidy claims of the discom must be based on specific energy accounts with accurate metering. The subsidy must be paid to the discom every month,” said the minister.Efforts to get a reaction from Thangamani as well as Kapur proved futile. There was no response to calls, SMS and Whatsapp messages.

Title: JNU violence case: 3 suspects ignore notice by police, declared absconders
Content:
This story is from January 15, 2020

JNU's gate on Monday.

NEW DELHI: Delhi Police has declared three suspects in the JNU violence case — Komal S, Rohit Shah and Akshat Awasthi — as absconders after they did not respond to the notices even on Tuesday. Police said they will now try to track down and arrest the three, all allegedly members of ABVP, and present them before the Special Investigation Team (SIT).

Police on Tuesday called Jawaharlal Nehru University students Sucheta Talukdar and Priya Ranjan Kumar, both from the Left-backed students’ groups, to appear before SIT. On Monday, notices were sent to Yogendra Bhadrwaj and Vikas Patel, both students belonging to ABVP.

At least two notices and a reminder were sent to the residences of the three suspects following a sting operation by a television channel, said a source. While Awasthi and Shah are students of JNU, Sharma is a DU student. A police team went to Awasthi’s home in Kanpur on Monday but he was not there.

Meanwhile, after SIT questioned four students, including JNU Students’ Union president Aishe Ghosh, about the violence on January 3 and 4, a forensic science laboratory (FSL) team spent the entire day on Tuesday in retrieving the CCTV footage from the server after the students claimed that it was functional even on January 5. Cops hope to retrieve some more CCTV footage. An FSL team will visit the university again on Wednesday to scan other areas, including ATMs.

A team from the cyber cell of Crime Branch also inspected the server room that was allegedly vandalised to prevent registration for the winter session.

It has been alleged that though the university authorities had restored the server temporarily, it was damaged again on January 4 by a group of students who entered the office through a rear door. The cyber cell team inspected the damage and will submit a report to the investigating team.

Some of the mobile phone footage submitted to police during the probe have also been sent for re-examination following the students’ stat0kements.

SIT has already opened a temporary office on the campus to record the statements of the 34 injured students.

Title: Won’t let stricter hospital rules be applied in Maharashtra: IMA
Content:
This story is from January 15, 2020

Nagpur: Reasserting that stringent provisions and regulations in the new Clinical Establishment Act can shut down nearly 70% of small and medium clinics in state, the Indian Medical Association’s (IMA) state president Dr Avinash Bhondve said the doctors in Maharashtra won’t let the act to be implemented in its present draft form in the state.

“The entire draft has a series of rules which makes it impossible for single-doctor clinics and small nursing homes to follow. These establishments will lose their licence if this draft becomes an Act,” said Dr Bhondve.

Health is a state subject in the Constitution. As a result, the state is free to have its own Aact for medical establishments. Doctors are hopeful that the Maharashtra government would form its own law.

“The government under Devendra Fadnavis had agreed to amend the existing Bombay Nursing Home Establishment Act instead of implementing the new law. A drafting committee was also formed to suggest these amendments. We hope the present government also will follow the same path,” he said.

Dr Prakash Deo, who was one of the members of this drafting committee said they have drafted balanced regulations considering the needs of the state. “The draft of this Act presented by the central government is full of draconian laws. But at the state level, we considered views of all stakeholders and came up with a balanced document. As the draft is ready, it is for sure that central regulations will not be applied in Maharashtra,” he said.

State hospital board chairman Dr Mangesh Pate said the central draft has been made considering only corporate hospitals. “Doctors are not against regulations. But excessive and unnecessary regulations will hurt the entire health service scenario in Maharashtra. The central law has many provisions which may promote red tape and corruption,” he said.

For example, under the head of biomedical waste management, there is a one-line mention that doctors must follow Waste Management Rules, 2016. As per these rules, hospitals/clinics should have their own effluent treatment plants (ETPs) and sewage treatment plants (STPs). “Do you think a small ten-bedded hospital in a crowded localities can have its own STP?” Dr Pate asked.

IMA is also gearing up to start a nationwide agitation as the central government is yet to table the Doctors’ Protection Act, a central law to protect doctors from attacks.

Title: MERC withdraws compulsory gross metering for solar power
Content:
This story is from January 15, 2020

Aurangabad: The Maharashtra Energy Regulatory Commission (MERC) has done away with the plan to have a compulsory gross metering for solar power generation.

The measure was one of the alleged provisions in the draft regulations that did not find any place in the final regulations declared by the regulatory body.

While the draft regulations had also envisaged an arrangement by which the power supplying companies were entitled to bill the power produced by solar users at allegedly higher rate, this too has been also made consumer-centric now.

TOI had reported the outrage on part of stakeholders about the draft rules. Maharashtra Solar Sanghthan, an umbrella organization of over 1,000 solar system manufacturers from Maharashtra, was up in arms against the MSEDCL over the draft regulations.

“It is a welcome move on part of MERC to do away the compulsory gross metering. The metering will be applicable to only those consumers who have captive generation of over 10 KW. By virtue of the new rules, around 85% small and medium solar power generators, including domestic users, will not fall in the purview of net metering,” Vipul Joisher, a senior functionary of Maharashtra Solar Sanghthan, said.

“We would like to see whether state power companies are ready to buy power from solar roof-top projects and pay for it in time,” he added.

Energy expert Hemant Kapadia of advocacy group Urja Manch said the final regulations in question are consumer-friendly as compared to what was proposed in the draft rules.

“We hope the new regulations will promote solar power generation, which is one of the objectives of the government. The regulator has more or less accepted all our demands, which will benefit the consumers,” he said.

Elaborating on some of the key changes in the policy governing the solar power generation, Kapadia said, “The MERC has increased the processing fees from Rs 1,000 to Rs 10,000. The expenditure on meters will be borne by the consumers and not by the state power utility. Also, consumers who are defaulters towards the payment of electricity bills, will be barred from net metering of solar power,” he said.

Notably, Maharashtra has a target of producing 11,926 MW of solar power by 2022 as part of renewable cumultative power target of 1,75,000 MW to be achieved the country.

Title: Amry showcases increasing lethality with firepower demonstrations at Topchi
Content:
This story is from January 15, 2020

Nashik: The firing range of Devlali thundered with deafening sounds and explosions as the School of Artillery demonstrated its firepower at the annual ‘Exercise Topchi ’ on Tuesday.

The accuracy and consistency of the state-of-the-art guns and rocket-launchers as well as the manoeuvers of the Cheetah and Chetak helicopters kept everyone present on the edge of their seats for close to two hours.

Topchi, meaning a gunner in English, is an annual exercise by the School of Artillery, Devlali, to showcase the synergy and the orchestration of the immense firepower of the regiment of Artillery.

The event was witnessed by Lieutenant General Depinder Singh Ahuja, Ati Vishisht Seva Medal, Chief of Staff, Southern Command as the chief guest, and Lieutenant General R S Salaria, Param Vishisht Seva Medal, Vishisht Seva Medal, Commandant School of Artillery and Colonel Commandant Regiment of Artillery, senior defence, civilian officers and a large number of dignitaries.

The event not only showcased the firepower of artillery, but also the surveillance, weapon locating radars and army aviation assets.

Salvos fired by the 155 mm Bofors, Soltum, Ultra Light Howitzer M777, self-propelled gun K Vajra and other lethal weapon systems left every invitee at the event in awe. The precision of delivering the explosives in the target area, the coordination and timing of the firepower was complimented by all. Apart from the demonstration of the deadly firepower, the display of rockets, missiles, surveillance and target acquisition radars, remotely piloted aircraft and hi-tech equipment too left everyone impressed.

The latest inductions into the Army, including the Ultra-Light Howitzer M 777, self-propelled gun gave a glimpse of the increasing lethality and technical threshold of our army. The army aviation assets included the indigenous Advanced Light Helicopters, Light Combat Helicopters, Chetak and Cheetah helicopter.

At the end of the show, the invitees had a close look at the weaponry system on display and got information about their origin, calibre, range, etc. The School of Artillery enjoys the unique status of an outstanding and unparalleled military institution whose alumni have excelled in all action since World War II.

Title: Literature helps us deal with life: Jokha
Content:
This story is from January 15, 2020

Malappuram: Literature trains readers’ minds to be flexible , to understand different perspectives, to realize facts and to interact creatively while facing the complexities of life, said Omani writer and Man Booker International prize winner Jokha Alharthi.

She was delivering keynote address at an international academic conference on the topic ‘Applying Theory; Paradigms, Practices and Faultlines’ at Dr Gafoor Memorial MES college Mampad on Tuesday.

She said literature cannot be separated from thought, nor can it be separated from psychology, sociology, philosophy, history and other sciences. “Mark Twain notes that travel eliminates narrow-mindedness and intolerance, and this is applicable perfectly to the literature”, she said.

“In my last 20 years of studying and teaching literature, students have always confronted me with this question: What do we benefit from a poem or a novel? Does literature teach us? Yes of course. We may simply say that literature helps us understand the world. But, it is really more than that, it is the real field where various knowledge intersects and overlaps,” she said. She has pointed out that when Sigmund Freud wanted to name his psychological discoveries that were considered modern at that time, such as the complexity of the attachment of the son to the mother and the exclusion of the father, he did not find better than literature that draw from.

“If literature teaches us things related to the hidden aspects of the human soul, related to the complexity of human relationships, related to our deepest and most intuitive feelings, and things related to human life in times we have not witnessed, and places we have never trampled and teaches us the history that history’s official subjects do not teach and the history of human dreams, their torments and their desires, then why do we suspect for a moment that literature teaches us?” she said Literature must illuminate human existence. We want literature that doesn’t preach to us but rather teach us. One of the most important things it teaches us is to avoid superficiality and direct judgements, and to know that things are more complicated that they appear”, she said. TNN

Title: TRS claims win in 84 wards in 35 local bodies
Content:
This story is from January 15, 2020

Hyderabad: In as many as 84 wards in 35 municipalities, TRS candidates have won unanimously as no other nominations were received for the forthcoming municipal polls.

TRS secretary Gattu Ramachandra Rao and MLC Srinivas Reddy said at a press conference here on Tuesday that TRS had won in one division without any contest. Ramachandra Rao said as per their information, BJP did not get candidates to field in as many as 700 wards and Congress could not put up candidates in 400 wards.

“While Congress has no cadre, BJP has no support of voters,” he said. TRS alleged that in many places Congress and BJP were trying to work together clandestinely to hand their candidates the win.

Ramachandra Rao said this secret pact was evident in Karimnagar and Nizamabad. “At the national level, BJP and Congress are rivals but in Telangana they are friends,” he charged. The TRS leaders said the party would emerge victorious in the January 22 municipal elections.

Title: TOI Young Change Leaders: Are you the one to fight for the planet?
Content:
This story is from January 15, 2020

In the wake of teens fighting for the environment across the world, The Times of India dares young guns with spirit and energy and a love for the planet to join it in the ‘ TOI Young Change Leaders Contest’ finale to be held on February 6, 2020, in New Delhi.

This is a platform to assist school students in not only voicing their opinions about the ecological scenario, but also to establish themselves as a TOI Young Change Leader . The platform will provide students with the opportunity to interact with an esteemed panel comprising eminent environmentalists, journalists, celebrities and people deeply involved with the cause.

Students of classes VI to IX from Delhi/ NCR schools are invited to take part in the challenge. They have to begin by recording a video of up to 2 minutes in which they express their views on ‘Fighting Climate Change’ and uploading it on www.toiyoungchangeleaders.com.

Entries will be accepted from January 15 to January 26, 2020.

Besides medals and certificates, the winners will get a Kindle e-book reader each, among many other exciting prizes. This is also an opportunity for students to be featured in The Times of India and the students’ edition of TOI, Newspaper in Education. The winners will also get an opportunity to be student guest editors and contribute to NIE.

It is time for Delhi to avoid the ‘airpocalypse’. Join us.

Title: First 1,000 days of a child crucial for devpt, say experts
Content:
This story is from January 15, 2020

Aurangabad: A workshop on violence against children and the first 1 ,000 days of child was organised by the Unicef through its implementing partner NGO Charkha in the city on Tuesday.

Pandurang Sudame, master trainer for infant and young child nutrition, Unicef, conducted a session on the first 1,000 days of child. Holding a doll in his hand, Sudame said, “This child cannot hold morchas or rasta rokos, neither does it have the right to vote. But it has four main demands — touch of mother and breastfeeding within five minutes of birth, only breast milk for the first six months, clean homemade food after six months and communication with the mother during feeding.”

Project leader at Charkha Alka Gadgil said that the brain of a child developed significantly in the first 1,000 days i.e. until it is two years old. If a child is given proper attention during this time, the country will have smarter children. “The care given to the child upto two years also impacts health indicators like infant mortality rate and maternal mortality rate, besides determining the quality of athletes the country will have in future,” she said.

Gadgil also conducted a session on violence against children. She said that the violence could in an form—physical, psychological, sexual or economical. “Any kind of violence impacts the mindset of children, leading them to become insecure,” she said.

Title: Fadnavis’ assembly poll victory challenged in HC
Content:
This story is from January 15, 2020

Nagpur: Advocate Satish Uke has again moved Nagpur bench of Bombay High Court against former chief minister Devendra Fadnavis, this time challenging his victory in last year’s assembly polls from Nagpur Southwest constituency.

While praying to set aside the ex-CM’s candidature, the petitioner has also moved an application to delete names of other respondents by amending his petition.

A single-judge bench of justice Manish Pitale on Tuesday issued notice to Fadnavis, now leader of opposition in the assembly, asking him to reply before February 14. The judge also permitted petitioner to delete names in his plea.

Fadnavis had recently moved the Supreme Court to grant a stay on summons issued to him by the chief judicial magistrate here in the first case filed by Uke. The latter had accused Fadnavis of suppressing information about two police cases while filing his nomination forms in 2014 assembly polls.

Uke, who had earlier challenged Fadnavis’ last victory in 2014 from same constituency, claimed the latter allegedly indulged in corrupt practices, thereby vitiating the election. He informed that on October 6, 2019, he lodged a complaint with senior election officials against Fadnavis, his representative and mayor Sandip Joshi and collector-cum-returning officer, but nothing progressed.

Accusing the returning officer of improperly accepting Fadnavis’ nomination form, Uke claimed that he was present at the collectorate from 3pm to 5.45pm but the election officer didn’t allow him to access the ex-CM’s affidavit till 6pm. “Election officer and Joshi were trying to hide the CM’s affidavit for unknown reasons. On October 10, 2019, when all the candidates requested the returning officer to open sealed documents and access papers of all candidates, he again refused to do so on the directives of Fadnavis’ representatives. All of us were told to move the court if we wanted access to the papers,” he said.

The petitioner requested to cancel and recall the respondent’s certificate as an elected member of assembly from 52 South-West Nagpur Constituency with immediate effect. He appealed to declare that Fadnavis’ rival Ashish Deshmukh be declared elected from the constituency, as he had received a majority of the valid votes while those obtained by former CM were through corrupt practices.

Uke prayed for directives to call all original nomination records of Fadnavis from the returning officer, including affidavit Form 26 submitted by him while filing his papers for contesting last year’s polls, so that they couldn’t be tampered with. He demanded declaration of Fadnavis’ victory void due to non-compliance with provisions of Constitution of India, the Representation of People Act as well as the rules and orders framed under related laws.

Title: Tamil Nadu: 2 suspects in SSI murder case held in Udupi station
Content:
This story is from January 15, 2020

Abdul Shameem and Thoufique

CHENNAI: The two men wanted for the murder of the TN special sub-inspector Y Wilson were picked up from Udupi railway station in Karnataka early on Tuesday.

Police said Abdul Shameem and Thoufique had shaved off their beards and were wearing coolers in a bid to disguise themselves but police acting on a tip-off that they were travelling in an unreserved compartment on the Thiruvananthapuram-Veraval Express intercepted them at Udupi station . The operation was carried out by a joint team of the TN and Kerala police with help from the Karnataka police. Two loaded guns were also seized from the two men.

The TN and Kerala police had formed 10 teams to trace the two after Wilson was gunned down on January 8. One of the teams tapped an informer at a hideout near Pune in Maharastra, who told them about their movement. The police were told the duo were on their way to meet a handler in Bengaluru on Tuesday.

The unarmed 57-year-old Wilson, who was just five months away from retirement, was shot dead while he was manning alone a checkpost near TN’s border with Kerala at Kaliyakkavila in Kanyakumari district. CCTV camera footage from a mosque showed Shameem and Thoufique running back from the checkpost and then nonchalantly walking along the nearby highway into Kerala. Investigators who asked not to be identified said they suspected the two had gunned down the cop after they got wind that their mentor Khaja Moideen had been picked up by the Delhi Police. Moideen and Navas, who was one of the two men picked up with him, had jumped bail along with Shameem in December while on trial for the July 2014 murder of Hindu Munnani functionary Suresh Kumar at Ambattur in Chennai.

The search for Wilson’s killers has unveiled a network of ISIS sympathisers from Tamil Nadu that police said was masterminded by Khaja Moideen, 52. Soon after the Delhi police announced his arrest, the Gujarat police announced the arrest of a man from Cuddalore, Zafar Ali, at Vadodara, who, investigators said, was a member of a sleeper cell Moideen had set up. Ali was to have been joined by Shameem and Thoufique in a bid to try and garner support among youth in Gujarat, investigators in TN said. Thoufique also has a case against him for attacking a BJP functionary at Nagercoil in 2016.

Shameem and Thoufique are being brought to Kanyakumari on a transit remand granted by an Udupi court, and will be produced before a magistrate court on Wednesday. On Sunday, five other men have been arrested by the Tamil Nadu police, four from a forest area near the tourist centre of Courtallam, known, for its waterfalls, and one from Bengaluru during their search for Shameem and Thoufique. All are suspected of being part of a network that Moideen set up under cover of Al Hind Trust.

Title: M’wada pattern of ‘nikah’ across state soon
Content:
This story is from January 15, 2020

Aurangabad: The state minorities development department has decided to follow the Marathwada pattern of solemnising marriages of Muslim couples across Maharashtra but the issue of appointment of qazis has stalled the move.

Sources in the minorities department said that the waqf board has set a condition that the candidate applying for the post of qazi should be ‘aalim’ (a graduate in in Islamic theology from a reputed madrassa), but a number of existing and aspiring qazis are not comfortable with the condition.

“State minorities minister Nawab Malik has decided to set up an expert committee to decide on the issue after stakeholders raised an objection to the waqf board condition.”

Mosques across the state issue couples ‘nikahnama’ or marriage certificate, which needs to be taken to the municipal council or corporation for registration. However, the nikahnama issued by a qazi in Marathwada is recognised by the waqf board and treated like a government document.

According to the government resolution (GR) issued on January 7, qazi, chief qazi and additional qazi are to be appointed in districts and towns across the state. In addition to this, the format of marriage form, marriage certificate for bride and groom has also been approved by the state government.

An official from the minorities department said that the GR will definitely come into force, but only after the expert committee decides on the new rule of the waqf board on appointment of qazi for solemnising marriages. If all goes well, the newly-appointed qazis will be affiliated with the Aurangabad headquartered waqf board and the marriage procedure for Muslims will be easier across the state.

Three days after the GR was issued on January 7, the state issued another GR announcing stalling of the appointment process until further orders, following objections raised by a number of stakeholders to the waqf board condition on qazis.Sources said that after the GR was issued, a delegation of Muslim scholars made a representation to the state minorities minister requesting him to reconsider the existing norms laid down by the waqf board for appointment of qazis.

When contacted, Malik said, “There are certain issues related to the conditions of appointment and they need to be addressed before we go ahead with the appointment of qazis and implementation of the Marathwada pattern of solemnising marriages.”

A waqf official said, “The GR is the result of several years of follow-up with the state minorities department requesting them to implement Marathwada pattern in the state and streamline the marriage record.”

Title: Night curbs on rly line to be lifted
Content:
This story is from January 15, 2020

Malappuram: Shoranur-Nilambur rail line would be opened for night traffic from January 20, Monday.

The office of the operational manager of Palakkad Division of Southern Railway has issued an order approving opening of the line for night traffic, on Tuesday.

It was a long-pending demand for the night train services to operate through the line. When the general manager of Southern Railway visited Angadippuram and Nilambur stations recently, different organizations had approached him with the same demand.

The order issued on Tuesday says that necessary arrangements would be made for dealing with the trains during night hours on the rail line from Monday.

The Southern Railway office in Chennai had granted technical permission for the night-traffic on the line in December. At present Nilambur-Shoranur line closes after Nilambur-Kochuveli Rajyarani Express leaves Nilambur station at 8.50pm and the section opens only at 6am for Kochuveli-Nilambur Rajyarani Express which arrives at 7.50am next day.

It is expected that the opening of the section during night hours will allow Kochuveli-Nilambur Rajyarani Express train to reach Nilambur around 5.30am.

Nilambur rail action council which was on warpath raising the demand for night-traffic on the line expressed their gratitude to the rail minister Piyush Goyal, local MP P V Abdul Wahab and Railway officials for their efforts to introduce night traffic on the line. Meanwhile, the electrification on the rail line will begin soon, as L&T gets contract for the electrification of the rail line. The electrification of the line is expected to increase the speed of the trains on the track and bring down the operation cost. The railway board had granted permission for the project last year and a detailed project report (DPR) regarding the electrification project was submitted to Central Organisation for Railway Electrification (Core), Allahabad.

Title: Nashik: Two booked for selling nylon manja
Content:
This story is from January 15, 2020

Representtaive image

NASHIK: The Bhadrakali police have booked two vendors for selling nylon manja and have seized the banned product worth over Rs 16,500 from them.

The suspects have been booked under various sections of the Indian Penal Code, said police.

After receiving a tip-off about nylon manja being sold in markets, police teams raided two shops, conducted inspections and seized the banned product. While the first raid was carried out on January 8, the second one was undertaken on January 13.

Deputy commissioner of police (zone II) Amol Tambe said that the police is keeping a tight vigil on those selling kites to ensure that the banned product is not being sold anywhere.

He appealed to revellers to refrain from buying or using the banned product. In addition, police have appealed to the citizens to come forward and inform them if they come across any sale or purchase of the banned product.

Moreover, the local NGOs have also been roped in to keep an eye on kite vendors. The members of Manav Uthan Manch have been displaying placards at traffic signals since a month informing people of the damage caused by nylon manja.

“We have created some animated videos and have forwarded them to maximum people explaining about the dangers of using nylon manja and the effect it has on humans as well as birds and animals,” Jagbir Singh , secretary of the NGO, said.

Title: Bengalis being hounded out of BJP-run states: Didi
Content:
This story is from January 15, 2020

KOLKATA: Bengal chief minister Mamata Banerjee on Tuesday accused BJP of hounding Bengalis out of states where it is in power and plotting to “make Indians foreigners in their own country” while offering citizenship to outsiders funding the party.

“Even before the CAA rules have been framed, they are talking of 30,000 citizenship applications. Where have these come from? They (the applicants) are funding BJP,” she said while addressing an anti-citizenship law rally organised by TMC’s student wing on Rani Rashmoni Avenue. Mamata reminded BJP members that “in united India”, people had the right to move out of their state to another for work.

“But I am seeing that people from Bengal are being hounded out of states where BJP is in government. This should not be repeated. If this happens, or is repeated, then people of no state will be safe in another,” the chief minister said.

Claiming to have solved the “mystery of CAA”, Mamata said that BJP’s ploy was not only to grant citizenship to those funding it but also ensure that no case can be made out against “such foreign contributions”.

“These people are going to convert black money into white. BJP is now going from door to door to find out who is Hindu and who is Muslim, and they are going to provide some people with citizenship,” she said.

Mamata said contrary to BJP’s assertion, CAA-NRC-NPR were interlinked. “NRC is not for Hindus or Muslims. It is for all. It is being said it is only for Muslims, which is not true... baaje kotha (false talk). It will affect all Hindus, Muslims, Christians and Jews. In Assam , during the NRC process, 19 lakh Hindu names were left out. If a fire or flood takes place, then it will affect all, irrespective of religion.” Mamata said she met PM Narendra Modi at Raj Bhavan during his visit to Kolkata last Saturday only out of courtesy.

Title: A week on, citizens still fight tooth and nail against implementation of CAA
Content:
This story is from January 15, 2020

Aurangabad: The round-the-clock sit-in agitation by people from different walks of life in the city against the Citizenship Amendment Act (CAA) and National Register for Citizenship (NRC) on Tuesday entered its seventh day.

A forum, Aurangabad against CAA, NRC, NPR, has been formed by the citizens for providing a platform to all those protesting against the government’s move.

A pandal has been set up outside the revenue divisional commissioner’s office where a large number of people from different age groups are protesting by singing folk songs, reciting poems, shayari and raising slogans.

Ahmed Jalees, a civil contractor and one of the protesters, said, “Through this protest we are trying to bring it to fore that these new rules are not only discriminatory against Muslims, but also against all those belonging to the reserved categories.”

“The poor, downtrodden and those belonging from the reserved category who will fail to produce documents prior to 1971 will be excluded from the NRC list. Of those excluded everyone except Muslims will be given fresh citizenship through CAA,” he added.

“This granting of fresh citizenship through CAA will deprive them of their reservation category as they will be treated as people with fresh citizenship,” CPI office-bearer Abhay Taksal said.

“If the voter-id is not a proof of citizenship then why do politicians seek our votes. According to the government, even AADHAR card, PAN card and passport are not proof of citizenship, then why is AADHAR linked with bank accounts, or taxes are collected through PAN. Also, why Indians are allowed to fly abroad using these passports,” student activist Kunal Kharat asked.

Aurangabad MP Imtiaz Jaleel said the common citizens hit the street to reclaim their rights after it became unbearable for them.

“The government is pushing their agenda by portraying that Muslims are against CAA, NRC and NPR. In fact, whoever is pro-Constitution is against these draconian laws,” he said.

Sumit Pandit, an activist, said that the on-going protest is nothing but the fight to save the Constitution. To ensure that the protest remains politically neutral, the forum has invited members as well as officer-bearers of all political parties without any discrimination.

Title: Signal to control vehicular movement at Sadar flyover
Content:
This story is from January 15, 2020

Nagpur: The Sadar flyover, inaugurated by city MP and Union transport minister Nitin Gadkari on January 9, is causing a bottleneck on the side of its landing between Vidhan Bhavan Square and LIC Square on the busy Wardha-Kamptee Road.

To ease the congestion, the traffic police and the National Highways Authority of India (NHAI) have found a solution to the problem. They have installed a traffic signal at the landing of the flyover.

“Until the signals are installed, we have decided to restrict the vehicles coming towards LIC Square from Vidhan Bhavan Square to use the Kamptee-Wardha Road. We will divert the vehicles from beneath the Sadar flyover and they can either take the Shriram Towers road or use the Liberty Square road to move towards Kamptee Road,” deputy commissioner of police (traffic) Chinmay Pandit told TOI.

However, those who used the Y-shaped flyover towards Katol Road and Mankapur Squares had a smooth sailing.

Pandit along with senior traffic police inspectors Jayesh Bhandarkar and Atul Sabnis, NHAI project director Abhijit Jichkar, officials from the NMC’s traffic department carried out a spot inspection. During the construction of the flyover, TOI had highlighted the issue of the likely mess near the same spot.

To avoid collusion of vehicles coming from the flyover, the traffic police have diverted them towards LIC Square and provided a U-turn for them to go towards Vidhan Bhavan Square. Though it has eased congestion at the flyover’s landing but it is causing a bottleneck at two merger points on either side of the road, between LIC Square and Samvidhan Square.

During the two-hour spot check, TOI observed that traffic from the Sadar flyover heading towards Samvidhan Square was facing a tough time and it was causing a bottleneck at the traffic lights on the stretch.

Due to the faulty design, a stop-gap measure was put in place. Traffic coming from the Sadar flyover and going toward Wardha Road is being diverted with the help of a U-turn near LIC Square. There’s also a flip side to the move. It’s affecting the flow of traffic coming from either side of Wardha Road.

TOI also found many motorists (coming from the flyover and intending to go towards Liberty Talkies), especially two-wheelers, taking the wrong side as a shortcut, adding to the congestion at the landing spot.

After discussing the situation with NHAI officials, the DCP traffic said that installing a traffic signal at the landing area is a permanent solution to the problem.

“When the signal for vehicles coming from the Sadar flyover turns green, for those coming from both LIC and Samvidhan Square, it will be red. The distance between LIC Square and Samvidhan Square is around 200m. It is the only permanent solution the traffic police have found to regulate vehicular movement at the flyover landing spot,” the DCP said.

The traffic police will submit its recommendation to install a signal at the flyover landing spot.

“It’s unethical to complain about any project after its completion when the same is being constructed before your eyes. In 2017, the VTA delegation met the NHAI director to study the plan of the Sadar flyover so that suggestions, if needed, could be submitted before its completion,” said Tejinder Singh Renu, secretary of Vidarbha Taxpayers’ Association (VTA).

“The NHAI plan was good and hence, we appreciated it. Later, the plan was modified by the authorities at the landing area on the RBI side, probably due to the Metro project and we learnt about it recently,” pointed out Renu.

In the original plan, the divider on the Kamptee Road junction at the landing spot on RBI side was open and a separate loop for traffic towards Kamptee side and Kingsway was proposed. These two modifications have caused major traffic problems at the landing area on the RBI side.

“We need some modifications in the landing area to ease the traffic. Otherwise, traffic moving in the north-south direction will avoid using this flyover and the objective to provide time and traffic advantage will not serve its purpose,” Renu added.

He noticed another flaw in the project. “The RCC parapet wall on the flyover is quite low. It may be as per the NHAI norms, but for the traffic in the city, it could be dangerous, especially for two-wheelers. Some kind of an MS frame on the parapet is needed,” said Renu.

Endorsing Renu’s views, traffic activist Deepak Lalwani, who owns a shop on Residency Road, stressed the need to install delineators on the flyover to bifurcate traffic coming from either side of the flyover.

PROS AND CONS

THE CURRENT SCENARIO

* Sadar flyover causing a major traffic hurdle at landing area on RBI side

* U-turn near LIC Square for Sadar flyover causing jam at merger points on either side of road

* Impatient drivers and riders using wrong side as a short cut, making the situation more chaotic

TEMPORARY MEASURES

* Traffic moving towards LIC Square from Samvidhan Square will be blocked with barricades

* It will be diverted from the road beneath the new flyover

* Vehicles heading towards Kamptee can take right turn from NIT office via LIC Square or have other options like Sadar Coffee House Square

* Vehicles can also take the flyover and can take right turn from Mankapur Square for Kamptee

PERMANENT SOLUTION

* Traffic signal will be installed at the median to pave way for vehicles coming from Sadar flyover

* When signal for vehicles coming from Sadar flyover turns green, for those coming from both LIC Square and Samvidhan Square, it will be red

Kite effect: Sadar flyover closed today (10am to 10pm)

Due to the kite-flying festival of Makarsankranti, the Sadar flyover will be closed on Wednesday from 10am to 10pm. “The decision was taken as a preventive measure in view of two-wheeler riders getting injured due to kite strings,” said Atul Sabnis, senior PI (traffic) of Sadar Zone. A notification in this regard was issued to the media to inform citizens.

Title: Drones to survey gaothan areas for cluster devpt
Content:
This story is from January 15, 2020

Nashik: The agency appointed by the Nashik Municipal Corporation ( NMC ) for conducting a survey of the old city (gaothan) areas for cluster development has begun its work with the help of drones.

This is for the first time that gadgets such as drones are being used by the civic body for carrying out development in the congested old city areas.

Once the survey is completed, the agency will prepare a report detailing the congested zones in the old city areas, following which the civic body will prepare a blueprint for its development under the cluster development programme.

The NMC has deployed private consultancy agency M/s Crisil Risk and Infrastructure to conduct impact assessment survey in core areas of the city.

Earlier, the municipal corporation had sought permission from the police administration for carrying out the drone survey. However, the administration had advised the NMC to seek permission from the Director General of Civil Aviation (DGCA).

Thereafter, the civic administration had again urged the police administration to grant permission for the drone survey stating that it will follow all the guidelines set by the DGCA.

Accordingly, the police administration recently issued permission to the NMC for conducting survey of gaothan areas using drones.

The appointed agency will now carry out the survey and shortlist areas that require improvement, estimate number of buildings and the number of clusters. Also, providing facilities like open space, roads, parking, waste and sewage management will also have to be considered while conducting the survey and preparing the report.

“We have received permission from the police administration to conduct drone survey of gaothan areas. The agency has already started the survey from the Panchavati area of the city,” a civic official said.

The survey is to be conducted in gaothan areas including the old city, Satpur, Deolali gaon, Makhmalabad, Adgaon and other parts of the city.

Title: Maharashtra: Govt lobbies for ‘rational’ approach to new Ready Reckoner rates
Content:
This story is from January 15, 2020

The ready reckoner rates remained unchanged in 2018-19 and 2019-20. (File photo)

PUNE: Land use changes in the past two years, boundary modifications from rural to urban areas, sale transactions in all zones and alterations in the development control rules will be reflected in this year’s “rationalized” Ready Reckoner (RR) rates expected to be announced on April 1.

The RR rates are assessments of property value by the state government, on the basis of which stamp duty and registration charges are paid and properties valued. The government usually revises the rates every year.

“There are several instances of changes in land use. For instance, some agriculture zones have become residential in nature, leading to increased land transactions. Many areas been merged in the corporation limits as well. All this will be reflected in the RR rates this time,” a revenue department official said.

The state has been divided into four regions — rural, influential (peri-urban areas peripheral to urban areas), municipal council and municipal corporation areas — to compile the RR rates. “The valuation this time will be done rationally and at the micro level,” an official privy to the process said.

Last week, deputy chief minister and finance minister Ajit Pawar held a meeting with the registration department and told its officials to ready the rates in a rationalized way for both the urban and rural zones through a zone-wise analysis.

A release issued after the meeting stated that the new government has sought streamlining of the RR rates without increasing stamp duty. The aim is to improve revenue from the registration of property sale. This year, the department’s revenue target is Rs 27,000 crore. With a deficit of Rs 43,000 crore, Pawar said a separate team would be set up to study the market rate of properties and prepare the RR rates.

Officials in the revenue department it would have to ready the entire chart by the end of February for the rates to be declared on April 1.

An official said it was too early to state if the new government would like to maintain a status quo on this year’s rates or announce any change.

The state had in 2017-18 increased the RR rates by 3.9% and kept it unchanged in 2018-19 and 2019-20.

Title: Garbage contractor to be roped in soon
Content:
This story is from January 15, 2020

Nashik: The Nashik Municipal Corporation (NMC) has decided to appoint a new contractor for door-to-door garbage collection from its Panchavati and Cidco divisions.

The new contractor will also have to provide vans for the filth collection. The civic body had earlier terminated the services of the last contractor due to its shoddy services. “We have entrusted the works of lifting garbage in these two divisions through garbage van contractors, who are already working in the other four divisions of NMC. But we are in the process of floating a tender to rope in a new contractor in Panchavati and Cidco division,” said Sunil Bukane, director, NMC’s Solid Waste Management department.

Earlier, a lot of complaints were raised about the irregular garbage collections in both the divisions, which forced them to terminate the services. “We are expecting the tender process to be started and completed quickly,” he added.

Another major reason for terminating the services was not paying the salaries of garbage van workers on time, even though the NMC paying the bills on time. Even after over 30 show-cause notices in the past two years, things didn’t improve, which forced the NMC chief Radhakrishna Game to cut-short the services.

Apart from Panchavati and Cidco, other four divisions of the civic body include Nashik Road, Satpur, Nashik East and Nashik West.

Title: Home min makes tea on chullah, serves it to orphans
Content:
This story is from January 15, 2020

Nagpur: Newly anointed home minister Anil Deshmukh displayed his other side on Monday when he visited the Late Ambadaspant Vaidya Matimand Mukbadhir Bewaris Balgruh in Amravati on Monday.

On the request of its owner Shankarbaba Papalkar, the Katol MLA himself prepared tea and served it to the orphans and senior citizens, much to their delight. A video showing the minister preparing tea on a chullah inside Papalkar’s hut went viral on social media and was appreciated for his noble gesture.

Deshmukh is a regular visitor to the Papalkar’s orphanage, which not only takes care of orphans and mentally challenged but also some senior citizens. Even before the assembly polls, he visited the orphanage sought Papalkar’s blessings, said the octogenarian. Papalkar looks after 123 inmates on the sprawling 25-acre premises located on Dharni Road.

“It was most the satisfying experience I ever had after serving those orphans and mentally challenged children. I stayed there for over an hour and interacted with them. The smiles on their faces made my day,” said an elated Deshmukh.

The minister also attended engagement ceremony of inmates Varsha and Sameer, both deaf and mute and hailing from Papalkar’s orphanage. “Since it was my first visit after becoming the minister, Papalkar asked me to witness their engagement and also perform the role of bridegroom’s father. After they exchanged garlands, I assured them that their marriage would be solemnized in Nagpur shortly where I will perform bride’s kanyadaan,” Deshmukh said.

Papalkar, who’s fighting for amendment in the Orphanages and other Charitable Homes (Supervision and Control) Act, 1960, said all inmates were extremely happy to see Deshmukh. “He freely mingled with the inmates who all are familiar with him. When he asked me whether I need any monetary help for running the centre, I told him that we don’t want money, but want to have tea made by you and he readily agreed,” he said.

Talking about the engagement ceremony between the orphans, the 80-year-old said it was a love marriage between Varsha and Sameer. “Police had found 22-year-old Varsha on railway tracks and handed over to us. Similarly, the boy, who’s now 24 years of age, was found at Shirdi. Varsha now cooks for 50 inmates and takes their care while Sameer was assured a job in Buldhana Cooperative Bank by Radheshyam Chandak after marriage,” he said.

“We’ve planned their marriage on a big stage at Reshimbagh Ground where we’re expecting a turnout of over one lakh people. Collector Ravindra Thakare has agreed to play maternal uncle’s role while police commissioner BK Upadhayay would be the bridegroom’s father. We’ve decided to name this ceremony as “Rashtriya Mohotsav’ to spread the message of amending the Act to allow orphans/mentally challenged to stay beyond 18 years with same shelter home,” he added.

Deshmukh assured Papalkar to raise his demand with social justice minister Dhananjay Munde to see if amendment could be made in the existing laws to take care of orphans, who find themselves in the lurch after becoming adults.

Title: Karvy pacifies investors with new date, but clients don’t believe co
Content:
This story is from January 15, 2020

Hyderabad: The wait for Karvy Stock Broking Ltd investors to get their money back is getting longer. Swamped by investor complaints since the scam broke out in November 2019, Karvy group on Tuesday reached out to investors saying that their payouts will be cleared by the first week of February this year. However, the once-bitten-twice-shy investors are sceptical as Karvy has failed to stick to its payout deadlines over the past two months.

When the scam came into light in November last year, C Parthasarathy, chairman and managing director of the Hyderabad-based Karvy Group had said that the company will clear all payouts by the first week of December.

What is also pinching many seasoned investors is that they have missed cashing in on market highs on multiple occasions in the last two months as their money is stuck with Karvy.

“There are many brokers who offer discounted brokerage but I opened my account with Karvy as they were an established broking house. The scam has come as a bolt from the blue. My entire trading capital has been blocked due to this scam. Karvy has been coming up with new dates for payouts since the scam broke, but they have lost all credibility as they have still not honoured their promises. I don’t know when I will get my money back. In the meantime, the market has scaled new highs over the past two months. All the Karvy scam victims have lost out on opportunities,” said Deepesh Kumar, an investor from Mumbai, who is awaiting a payout of over Rs 5 lakh from the company.

Gautam Umaraliya, who hails from Bhavnagar in Gujarat, said his shares worth Rs 7 lakh are out of bounds for him due to the scam. “I planned to buy property here but had to postpone it because my resources are stuck with Karvy and I do not have enough money at hand now. I have reached out to them multiple times about my shares but have not got any satisfactory response. What shocks me is the inaction of SEBI and other authorities as many investors like me are scared of losing our hardearned money. The culprits should be arrested.”

An investor from Sivasagar in Assam, Ankit Garg said when the scam broke out and he checked the status of his shares, he was shocked to find that 30% of his shares valued at around Rs 2.5 lakh were lying in Karvy’s pool account. “I lodged a complaint with Sebi on December 3, which the market regulator forwarded to Karvy on December 18 asking it to reply within three days but they have not responded despite sending multiple reminders,” he rued.

When contacted, the company did not share the exact number of investors and the quantum of money they have to pay them but said they have been reaching out to investors individually and is hopeful of fulfilling commitment this time.

Title: Two killed, 10 hurt as truck rams Bolero pick up
Content:
This story is from January 15, 2020

Nagpur: Two migrant hawkers were killed and another 10, all natives of Madhya Pradesh, were injured when a tipper laden with loose earth hit a Bolero pick up van on which the victims were travelling. They were all sellers of household plastic goods.

The accident had taken place on Ring Road at accident-prone Mhalgi Nagar chowk at 6.55 am on Tuesday. The signal had just turned green for the Bolero which tried to cross the square at high speed. The tipper entered the square despite its signal having turned red as per CCTV footage in possession of TOI and hit the rear side of Bolero.

It is learnt the victims were coming to city from a village in Mandsaur district of MP, covering around 800 km, to sell their ware. They are unable to cultivate any crops in their village in Chambal river basin. The river kept most of the lands around their village submerged this year. They had come earlier for a brief period and around three months ago had rented a place at Khapri. The community of hawkers brought household plastic goods from Hyderabad for selling in Nagpur and other places.

Rahul Vanjara and Baharulal Gaud, both aged 25 years old, were the ones killed. They were crushed under the plastic cargo loaded in the pick up in which 13 persons were travelling. After being hit on the left side, the jeep crashed into the divider and fell on it’s side. Gaud had married around two years ago.

Though Bolero’s driver Fakira Babukhan was among the injured, Tofan Vanjara seated beside him escaped unhurt. Tofan’s younger brother Jagdish is learnt to be in a critical condition. The injured are being treated at Government Medical College and Hospital (GMCH).

The tipper, owned by Javed Khan, was moving towards Hudkeshwar Road from Gajanan chowk. The Bolero was heading towards Dighori naka from Manewada side. The footage of a camera installed at the junction showed the truck trying to pass through the square in red signal. Despite its slow speed, the truck did not wait for the fast moving Bolero to cross the junction ending up hitting it.

Of the injured, Rahul Baghara said he was thrown out of the vehicle by the impact and landed some distance away. “People rushed to help us but the damage was already done. Onlookers rushed us to hospital. There was one person who helped us a lot,” he said.

Sakkardara police have arrested the driver of the tipper, Shamnath Tikapate, and booked him for causing death due to negligence. The truck has also been seized.

Title: Trichy tops TN in Swachh citizen feedback
Content:
This story is from January 15, 2020

Trichy remains on top closely followed by Madurai which got 15,572 feedback and Salem with 5,130

TRICHY: Despite its plunge in ranking for the first two quarters of the cleanliness survey, Trichy corporation has managed to lead the rest of Tamil Nadu in recording feedback from residents for Swachh Survekshan 2020 (SS2020), the national cleanliness survey conducted by the ministry of housing and urban affairs (MoHUA).

Citizen feedback for the activities taken up by the local body is one of the key parameters for a city to score significant marks in the survey for being crowned the cleanest city. Of the total 6,000 marks, 25% is earmarked for the citizen feedback category. The feedback will be obtained by the designated agency through face-to-face interviews, outbound calls, Swachhata application, Swachh Survekshan 2020 portal and “vote for your city” application. The feedback includes negative responses to a questionnaire to evaluate the performance of the local body in waste collection, public toilet maintenance and public hygiene. The number of feedback received by a civic body also plays a role in grabbing adequate marks in the survey, officials added.

As on January 14, Trichy stood first among the cities in the state in the number of feedback received through the multiple platforms. With 15,897, Trichy remains on top closely followed by Madurai which got 15,572 feedback and Salem with 5,130.

“We have planned to reach out to the colleges, residents welfare associations and traders for their feedback on the work we have taken up in the past one year,” a sanitary official with the city corporation said.

Title: Communities get ready to celebrate Sankranti, Pongal
Content:
This story is from January 15, 2020

Students of New English School, Ramanbaug, get into a kite formation on Tuesday to spread awareness about safe... Read More

PUNE: Kites are set to dot the sky on Makar Sankranti on Wednesday with Punekars ready to usher in the harvest festival.

Kothrud resident Shubhangi Barve said her two sons were excited to fly kites. “This time, one of my sons will be flying kites for the first time, so he is very excited,” she said.
