Barve added that they were using traditional string as manja. “We made sure to buy simple thread to use as the kite string. This time, my elder son Sachin found some videos online on how to make kites and he has made his own kites following the instructions,” she said.

She added that this was also a time all the neighbours got together. “Everyone heads to the terrace of our buildings to watch the children fly kites. Everyone meets and gets a chance to exchange sweets like Tilgul,” she said.

The Tamil community will also be celebrating the harvest festival Pongal from Tuesday. Both festivals centre around different kinds of sweetmeats and festive wear to signal the mark the Sun’s transition into Makara (Capricorn) and the start of longer days.

Explaining the significance of Pongal and Makar Sankranti, assistant professor at the department of English at Ferguson College Chitra Sridharan said, “Pongal literally means boiling over. As part of this, you cook the rice and add plenty of milk with sweet. This is supposed to spill over. It is a metaphor for abundance and bringing in the harvest.”

About Sankranti, she said, “While in South India, it is called Pongal, it is known as Makar Sankranti here and also signifies the harvest season. The Marathi community have a Haldi Kunku at the very start. They have a custom called ‘lootna’ where they give you something sweet. Generally, it means the spring equinox is starting.”

Title: Shaheen Bagh: Look into commuter woes, Delhi high court tells police, govt
Content:
This story is from January 15, 2020

Protests at Shaheen Bagh against CAA and NRC on Tuesday.

NEW DELHI: Delhi high court on Tuesday declined to pass any specific directions against restrictions in place on the Kalindi Kunj - Shaheen Bagh stretch due to CAA protests. But it asked police and the state government to look into the problems faced by commuters while keeping in mind the larger public interest.

A bench of Chief Justice D N Patel and Justice C Hari Shankar noted that whenever an agitation or protest erupts, the situation becomes “fluid” as it keeps changing with the temperament of the protesters. “Simultaneously, police have to maintain the law and order....they have all power, jurisdiction and authority to control the traffic, wherever protests or agitations are going on, in the larger public interest,” the bench noted, adding that “it all depends upon the ground reality and the wisdom of the police.”

It, however, asked the police and traffic authorities to examine the grievance raised in a petition against the continued blockade and disposed of a PIL filed by advocate Amit Sahni. It had sought a direction to the Delhi police commissioner to lift restrictions on Kalindi Kunj-Shaheen Bagh stretch and Okhla underpass, which were closed on December 15, 2019 for ongoing protests against CAA and NRC.

The PIL argued that the clampdown was a temporary measure but had been extended from time to time. Closure of Kalindi Kunj stretch, which connects Delhi, Faridabad (Haryana) and Noida (Uttar Pradesh), has forced commuters to take the Delhi-Noida-Delhi (DND) Flyway and Ashram, triggering traffic jams and wastage of time and fuel.

According to the petitioner, the road closure is causing huge inconvenience to lakhs of commuters everyday as they are compelled to take different routes for last one month while students are forced to travel for hours to ensure they reach school in time. The petition claimed that the authorities have failed to take appropriate action to give relief to the residents of the locality and lakhs of commuters of Delhi, UP and Haryana despite representation to them.

Owing to the heavy traffic on alternative routes, it takes 15-20 minutes for people to cross just one traffic signal at Ashram, it claimed.

Title: Vandals damage 20 vehicles
Content:
This story is from January 15, 2020

Pune: Vandals damaged a total of 20 vehicles on Monday night — eight in Sanjay Gandhinagar in Pimpri and 12 in Hadapsar.

Two persons — Akshay Bhosale (20) and Deepak Raut (19) of Pimpri — of a gang of six were arrested on Tuesday. The others are on the run, said sub-inspector AP Nimgire of the Pimpri police.

The Wanowrie police, on the other hand, detained six minors on Tuesday for their involvement in damaging the parked vehicles in Hadapsar.

Around 10.30pm on Monday, the gang of six, armed with sticks, entered the Sanjay Gandhinagar area on motorcycles. They created a ruckus and abused residents. “All of sudden, they started damaging the vehicles parked along the road,” Nimgire said.

He said the suspects damaged parked two-wheelers, an autorickshaw and a van. The terrified residents alerted the police. “When we reached the spot, the suspects had fled,” Nimgire said.

The Pimpri police took Bhosale and Raut into custody after launching a manhunt. Prima facie probe revealed that the suspects had damaged the vehicles under the influence of alcohol, police said.

Senior inspector Krantikumar Patil of the Wanowrie police said the minors broke the windscreens of the parked autorickshaws, four-wheelers and commercial vehicles.

Title: MADC awaits state order on Purandar airport project
Content:
This story is from January 15, 2020

Pune: The Maharashtra Airport Development Company Limited (MADC) is banking on the outcome of its board meeting with chief minister Uddhav Thackeray and awaiting an order from the state government for the future of the proposed airport in Purandar.

A day after deputy CM Ajit Pawar stressed last-mile connectivity for Purandar, the stakeholders are expecting some movement in the project that was announced in October 2016 but has failed to gather much pace.

“The project has been delayed. We hoped that funds will flow once the the state got a new government after the elections. But the delay in government formation had a cascading effect on the Purandar project. Once the government directs us, we will issue a notification for land acquisition in Purandar,” an MADC official said on Tuesday.

Pawar on Monday discussed the connectivity issues related to the Purandar airport with the Pune Metropolitan Region Development Authority (PMRDA), indicating that the project was still on track.

Purandar MLA Sanjay Jagtap on Tuesday said the government was “very positive” about the project and would soon make a formal announcement on it. “We have requested Pawar to shift the project to a different place in Purandar from the proposed site,” he told TOI.

Altogether 2,832 hectares of land in Purandar taluka are likely to be acquired for the project. Landowners of Pargaon, Khanauri, Munjwadi, Udachiwadi, Ekhatpur, Vanpuri and Kumbharvan villages have been opposing the project.

Aviation expert Dhairyashil Vandekar recently said the city needed a new airport, as the facility in Lohegaon was under pressure with the number of flights rising. Air Marshal Bhushan Gokhale (retired) said, “The government should take a concrete stand on the issue instead of urging Indian Air Force to provide more land for the expansion of the airport in Lohegaon.”

Title: NMC collects Rs 116 crore property tax
Content:
This story is from January 15, 2020

Nashik: The property tax department of the Nashik Municipal Corporation ( NMC ) has garnered Rs 116 crore this fiscal, the highest so far.

The second highest property tax collection of Rs 113 crore was recorded during last financial year 2018-19. It was for the first time that the NMC’s property tax collection target had touched Rs 100 crore.

During the corresponding period last year (by Jan 13), the property tax collection ofstood at Rs 94 crore. There has been almost 25% rise in property tax collection by January 13 of the current financial year as compared to corresponding period last year.

Civic officials said that an increasing number of defaulters are coming forward to clear their dues as the municipal corporation has been prompt in serving notices to defaulters warning them of auctioning their properties if they failed to clear the dues.

“We had introduced amnesty scheme for property tax defaulters around three months back. We had collected property tax dues amounting to Rs 30 crore during just one month due to amnesty scheme,” civic officials said.

NMC officials said that they are optimistic about meeting the set target of Rs 218 crore from property tax this fiscal.

There are over 4.35 lakh property tax payers across six divisions of municipal corporation. Of which, 1.97 lakh property tax defaulters have total tax dues worth Rs 53.28 crore.

There are about 439 big property tax defaulters with dues of over Rs 50,000 each while around 1,240 tax defaulters have dues between Rs 25,000 and Rs 50,000. There are 1.95 lakh defaulters who have dues below Rs 10,000.

“We have decided to take action against defaulters who fail to pay their tax dues. We have already issued notices to 67,080 tax defaulters for failing to clear tax dues and have asked them to pay their tax dues within a month, said NMC officials.

The civic body collects property tax online and also through six divisional offices — Nashik East, Nashik West, Panchavati, Satpur, Nashik Road and Cidco.

The municipal corporation gives 1% concession to those who pay property taxes online. Moreover, the concession in property tax up to 5% is given to prompt property tax payers who clear their dues during the first quarter of the financial year.

Title: Litmus test for contestants in Medchal
Content:
This story is from January 15, 2020

Voters of Medchal municipality — richest in terms of revenue — are bracing up to grill contesting candidates over unfulfilled assurances, especially those made by labour minister Ch Malla Reddy.

Failure to construct a 4-km flyover to ease traffic problems on NH-44, frequent traffic jams, narrow internal roads, lack of a permanent dumpyard and failure to provide an uninterrupted water supply are some of the immediate issues high on the agenda of voters. Though a detailed project report (DPR) for the underground drainage is ready, it has gathered dust due to inordinate delay in releasing funds.

Little wonder, the coming municipal polls are going to be a litmus test for the candidates in all 23 civic wards. The municipality makes nearly Rs 7 crore from property tax alone from various commercial godowns and industrial units, but basic amenities are still a far cry.

The major issue bothering the voters is the delay in executing the 4-km flyover between Athvelly village and Outer Ring Road on National Highway-44. Currently, the two-lane NH-44 passing through Medchal is narrow and unable to manage the heavy volumes of traffic. As a result, traffic jams during peak hours have become the order of the day.

“Every day, we experience traffic jams on NH-44. Malla Reddy had promised the flyover but it remained a distant dream. We bought a flat in Medchal so that we could lead a peaceful life. But, the burgeoning traffic mess here is worse than what commuters face in Hyderabad,” Mallikharjuna Reddy, a pharmacist, told TOI.

While the main roads in some of the residential colonies in Medchal town are in good condition, internal roads are too narrow with private properties’ owners not willing to part with their land. The civic body has also failed to improve the internal road network and connect it to newly-emerged residential colonies. “We will support only those candidates who will resolve our day-to-day problems,” Naresh Chary, a resident of RTC Colony, said.

The civic body’s hands are also tied with no government land in its possession to set up a permament dumping yard for garbage. Currently, the garbage is dumped in a private land. “Though the dumping yard is 3 km away from the town, it stinks during the rainy season. The civic authorities should shift the dumping yard to another place to avoid inconvenience to residents of various colonies,” said P Vaishali, a private school teacher.

Municipal commissioner B Satyanarayana Reddy said the DPR on the drainage network is ready. “We are waiting for the state government’s nod for financial assistance,” he added.

Title: U’khand guv clears Char Dham Devsthanam Management Bill 2019
Content: Dehradun: Uttarakhand governor Baby Rani Maurya on Tuesday gave her assent to the Char Dham Devsthanam Management Bill 2019 and it would now pave way for the state government to facilitate takeover of 50 shrines in the state, including Char Dham — Gangotri, Yamunotri, Kedarnath and Badrinath.Officials at the governor secretariat confirmed the development and said that the Bill has been passed on to the state government’s law department for further discussion on the date of notification before implementation.In the board, an IAS officer will hold the post of CEO while CM will be the president and there will be other members such as MLAs, MPs and member of the Tehri royal family. Sources said that the appointments in the board and a head office in Dehradun would be made in the next few months.The board will bring Kedarnath, Badrinath, Gangotri, Yamunotri and 51 other temples in the hill state under the ambit of the state government and will also result in the dismantling of the existing temple managements such as the Badri-Kedar Temple Committee. The provisions and composition of the Bill will be like the Vaishno Devi shrine board and Tirupati Balaji shrine board.Meanwhile, local priests and Congress MLA from Kedarnath Manoj Rawat threatened to launch a protest against the Bill and said that it is against the interests of the priests’ community. Rawat said, “The state government is ruining the century-old Hindu traditions set up by Adi Shankaracharya for Char Dham. This government is doing something which even the British couldn’t do.”Rawat added that unlike Vaishno Devi, Char Dham has everything in place. “From rituals to appointments and tenure of priests, everything is in place in Char Dham. The takeover will mean dismantling a perfect system that is in place. Why does the government even want that?”Badrinath priest Ashutosh Semwal said, “Our community is opposed to the new board as it will undermine the existing system. We will soon hold a meeting of all priests to decide the next course of action.”However, state government spokesperson and Haridwar MLA Madan Kaushik said that the system of head priests, which was set up by Adi Shankaracharya, will continue as it is. “The new board will not interfere in the daily operational affairs. It will just manage donations and the money would be used to develop the shrines.”

Title: Trichy tops TN in Swachh citizen feedback
Content:
This story is from January 15, 2020

Trichy remains on top closely followed by Madurai which got 15,572 feedback and Salem with 5,130

TRICHY: Despite its plunge in ranking for the first two quarters of the cleanliness survey, Trichy corporation has managed to lead the rest of Tamil Nadu in recording feedback from residents for Swachh Survekshan 2020 (SS2020), the national cleanliness survey conducted by the ministry of housing and urban affairs (MoHUA).

Citizen feedback for the activities taken up by the local body is one of the key parameters for a city to score significant marks in the survey for being crowned the cleanest city. Of the total 6,000 marks, 25% is earmarked for the citizen feedback category. The feedback will be obtained by the designated agency through face-to-face interviews, outbound calls, Swachhata application, Swachh Survekshan 2020 portal and “vote for your city” application. The feedback includes negative responses to a questionnaire to evaluate the performance of the local body in waste collection, public toilet maintenance and public hygiene. The number of feedback received by a civic body also plays a role in grabbing adequate marks in the survey, officials added.

As on January 14, Trichy stood first among the cities in the state in the number of feedback received through the multiple platforms. With 15,897, Trichy remains on top closely followed by Madurai which got 15,572 feedback and Salem with 5,130.

“We have planned to reach out to the colleges, residents welfare associations and traders for their feedback on the work we have taken up in the past one year,” a sanitary official with the city corporation said.

Title: Secunderabad: Rachakonda traffic police to train volunteers to help ease traffic woes
Content:
Representative image

SECUNDERABAD: Following the Cyberabad model , the Rachakonda traffic police is all set to commence the traffic volunteering scheme in its limits, in order to improve traffic conditions at key junctions.The decision to start the traffic volunteering scheme was taken following a meeting held between Secunderabad residents and Rachakonda traffic police recently.“There are many areas in Rachakonda limits where vehicular movement is heavy, especially during evening hours. We decided to collaborate with traffic police to tackle the issue,” said Malcom Wolfe, an activist for pedestrian rights.As part of the scheme, volunteers of the age of 18 years and above will be engaged to manage traffic at various junctions. They will be trained by traffic police and will be equipped with reflective jackets, caps and whistles. The scheme will be implemented on par with the Cyberabad traffic police scheme where over 300 techies are traffic volunteers.In Rachakonda limits, traffic police has identified many areas including ECIL junction, Neredmet X roads, LB Nagar, Uppal, Nagole among others where volunteers will be deployed.“We will be engaging more than 100 traffic volunteers from different areas over the next few months. They will be trained on basic rules and techniques on traffic diversions,” said Mohammed Tajauddin Ahmed, additional deputy commissioner of police, Rachakonda traffic police. All selected volunteers will undergo mandatory orientation and basic life support training .The volunteers will also be empowered to capture violations to raise e-challans.

Title: TNSTC operates 370 special buses to tackle Pongal rush
Content:
This story is from January 15, 2020

Representative image

TRICHY: Tamil Nadu State Transport Corporation ( TNSTC ) Trichy region has begun operating around 370 special buses from Tuesday night to clear extra rush during Pongal week. Similarly, State Express Transport Corporation (SETC) has also begun operating additional omnibuses for long-distance passengers.

TNSTC sources said that special buses being operated for the past three days has been gradually increased on Tuesday foreseeing the last-minute travellers. Officials said that the 370 special buses including mofussil and city/town services in Trichy, Ariyalur and Perambalur districts falling under the TNSTC Trichy region will be operated till January 20, 2020. TNSTC will be operating at least 120 buses connecting Trichy and Chennai while 35 buses will ply additionally between Trichy and Madurai cities.

“Wherever there is major demand, we utilize the spare fleets to connect the particular destination,” an official source with TNSTC said. Since there is a significant demand between Trichy and Ariyalur districts including Jayankondam, TNSTC Trichy region has been operating 30 buses exclusively for the Ariyalur district. Coimbatore-Trichy route and Trichy-Thanjavur route has been allotted 15 additional buses each.

Similarly, SETC that usually operates 90 buses from Trichy to Chennai, Pamba, Tirupati and Bengaluru locations have increased the number of buses to 102 as on Tuesday evening to manage the holiday rush.

“As we have opened two temporary bus shelters near Williams Road and Mannarpuram , 20 city buses on circular routes have been deployed to connect these temporary bus shelters with Central bus stand,” the official added. Adequate crew members were put in reserve to operate special buses on requirement, officials added.

Title: Veterans Day: 600 ex-servicemen receive a fitting tribute
Content:
This story is from January 15, 2020

Secunderabad: Over 600 ex-servicemen from Army, Air Force and Navy attended the fourth Armed Forces Veterans Day which was celebrated under the aegis of headquarters of Telangana and Andhra sub Area at MCEME auditorium, Secunderabad on Tuesday.

According to a press release issued by ministry of defence, Armed Forces Veterans Day is celebrated as a mark of respect and recognition to the services rendered by the veterans of Indian Armed Forces.

Lieutenant General TSA Narayanan, Commandant, Military College of EME, Major General Sandeep Sharma, Commandant, College of Defence Management and Major General RK Singh, General Officer Commanding (GOC), Telangana and Andhra sub area felicitated the veterans.

The GOC lauded the yeoman service rendered by the veterans and highlighted that the aim of such interactions was to make the veterans feel part of the larger family. Military band from 1 EME Centre enthralled the gathering by playing martial tunes.

Title: Land circle rate hike evokes mixed response
Content: Dehradun: In a major decision, the state cabinet had approved a hike in circle rates of several areas (agricultural and non-agricultural land) on Sunday. The hike, in the range of 0-to-15%, has evoked mixed reactions from residents.Some residents claimed that revised circle rates will make buying property in the city more costly while others felt that it was needed to streamline property rates. “As Rajpur and other prime localities hardly have any plots left, people are buying land in other areas. But now, their circle rates have been increased. This will make it difficult for people to buy land in the city,” said Rajvir Pundhir, a Nehru Colony resident.On the other hand, some believe that the decision would prove beneficial. “The decision would reduce gap between the circle rate and actual market rate. However, it may increase burden on those looking to buy land,” said S Benjwal, a retired teacher who lives in Mothrowala area.The major areas where circle rate has been revised from Rs 14,000 to Rs 16,000 are Karanpur Chowk, Dehrakhas, Shimla bypass, Premnagar, Mata Mandir Road, Vasant Vihar, Mohit Vihar, and Ashirwad Enclave among others.Similarly, the main areas where circle rate has been increased from Rs 12,000 to Rs 14,000 are Indira Gandhi Marg, Brahmanwala, Doiwala, Transport Nagar, Bhandaribagh, Panditwadi, Shastrinagar, and Nehru Colony among others.The key areas where circle rate has been hiked from Rs 9,000 to Rs 10,500 are Mussoorie bypass, Mothrowala-Dhoodhli route, Banjarawala, Near Doon University, Kedarpur, Niranjanpur, Kargi Grant, and Indresh Nagar.Meanwhile, the cabinet didn’t revise circle rate of areas where it was already above Rs 14,000 square metre. These include areas which are 350 metres away from Clock Tower to RTO office, from RTO office to Mussoorie bypass, from Clock Tower to Saharapur Chowk, from Clock Tower to Ballupur Chowk, from Prince Chowk to Rispana Bridge, from New Cantt Road, from EC Road, from Subhash Road, and from GMS Road.State urban development minister and government spokesperson Madan Kaushik told TOI that the new circle rates will "definitely benefit locals." "After the revision, people can get loans on revised rates. Besides, the cabinet has not revised circle rates of areas where rate is above Rs 18,000 per square metre," said the minister.

Title: Amnesty scheme: Rs10 cr collected in a month
Content:
This story is from January 15, 2020

Nashik: Over 2,200 people have come forward and cleared their property tax dues ever since the Nashik Municipal Corporation ( NMC ) introduced amnesty scheme .

According to the scheme, the defaulters who pay their dues in one time were to be given a waiver in penalty, warrant and notice fees. The civic body has collected property tax dues of around Rs 10 crore from the defaulters.

The NMC has so far waived off around Rs 1.78 crore under this scheme. The amnesty scheme was introduced on December 16 last year and will be in effect till February 10, 2020.

The NMC recovers a 2% fine per month on tax dues from the last day of paying taxes. Moreover, it also recovers expenses of notices and warrants issued to the defaulters. Hence, the civic body had introduced the amnesty scheme.

The defaulters who paid their property tax dues between September 16 and September 30 were given 75% concession on penalty, warrants and notice fess. Those who paid their tax dues between October 1 and 10 were given 50% concession, while those who paid taxes between October 11 and 15 were given 25% concession in penalty and other fees.

“We received good response to the amnesty scheme introduced between September 15 and October 15 in 2019 wherein we collected property tax dues worth Rs 30 crore. This time around we aim to collect around Rs 50 crore,” a civic official said.

Title: Mayor approves 18naming proposals
Content:
This story is from January 15, 2020

Nashik: Mayor Satish Kulkarni approved 18 proposals for naming chowks, elevated storage tanks (ESTs), gardens, roads, new colonies, gymnasium, auditorium and civic school among others, during a meeting of Namkaran Samiti ( naming committee ) on Tuesday.

The meeting of the committee, including officials from the town planning department, civic standing committee chairperson, group leaders and leader of the house was held after around two years.

The mayor had received 148 proposals by elected representatives for naming of roads, chowks and lanes in localities across the city and the same were tabled during the meeting. However, approvals were given to only 18 proposals.

“There is a four-member ward committee and approval to the proposal regarding naming of various chowks or areas will be given if there is consent by all the four corporators,” the mayor said.

“The proposal will be cancelled or adjourned even if one of the corporators does not give his/her consent. Approval will be given immediately if all four corporators unanimously give their approval,” Kulkarni added.

Now, the meeting of naming committee of NMC will be held once in two months. Around 130 proposals did not comply with the norm of having consent of all four corporators.

Of the 18 proposals approved, three each were about naming of chowks and gardens, two each were about naming of ESTs, roads and new colonies, one each for naming of NMC school, auditorium, gymnasium, sports ground, generic medical stores in hospitals and installation of portrait at the meeting hall of the NMC.

There was also controversy over naming of a water treatment plant in ward no 31. While Shiv Sena had demanded naming the plant after the late Balasaheb Thackeray, BJP wanted it to be named after former Prime Minister Atal Bihari Vajpayee.

Dinkar Patil and three other corportors had submitted a proposal for naming the plant after Vajpayee, but the mayor held back the proposal as it came from corporators from other wards.

Title: Pune: Tip-off helps cops recover FTII pupil’s robbed phone
Content:
This story is from January 15, 2020

Representative image

PUNE: The crime branch on Monday claimed to have cracked the case of a woman student of FTII being robbed of her bag containing a cellphone and cash, collectively worth Rs9,600, near Nal Stop following the arrest of a person.

The arrested person, Ubed Salim Shaikh (25) of Kasba Peth, had purchased the robbed cellphone from the trio, including a minor, involved in the robbery. Barring the minor suspect, the other two — Rahul Sakat (19) and Kiran Galphade (21) — involved in robbing the FTII student were arrested in another case by the Khadki police and languishing in jail.

The FTII student, along with her friend, was on way to have a cup of tea at a popular joint near Nal Stop during the wee hours after completing a film shooting assignment when she was robbed by the trio on November 25 last year.

The Deccan Gymkhana police had taken the custody of the suspects Sakat and Galphade from the jail. “The duo admitted to their involvement in the robbery on Law College Road and revealed the name of their third accomplice, a minor. Sakat and Galphade has been sent back to jail,” said assistant inspector C M Suryavanshi of the Deccan Gymkhana police.

He said the crime branch had recovered the FTII student’s cellphone from Shaikh. “We have found her purse, which the suspects had thrown behind a public toilet. We have also recovered the motorcycle used while robbing her,” Suryavanshi said.

Sub-inspector Uttam Budgude of the crime branch said constables Sudhakar Waghawale and Sudhakar Mane received a tip-off on January 4 that a cellphone robbed on Law College Road in November last year was being used by Shaikh and he would be going to Mangalwar Peth. “We laid a trap and took Shaikh into custody. We recovered the cellphone from him and handed Shaikh over to the Deccan Gymkhana police,” Budgude said.

Suryavanshi said Shaikh revealed the names of Sakat and Galphade during the questioning.

“Both are criminals on the police records. Sakat has cases of body offences against him, while Galphade has cases of vehicle thefts,” Suryavanshi said.

He said the duo sold the robbed cellphones through their minor accomplice. “We have sent the minor to a correction home,” Suryavanshi said.

Title: Sesame: Gajak: The warmth of Chambal that melts in your mouth
Content: Everyone has their own ways of staying warm in the winters and this is the season when food that keeps the body warm is most in demand. Speaking of which, as no one famous once said, "If winter is here, can gajak be far behind?"So, while you put on your body warmers and sweaters to battle Indore ki sardi, we give you some trivia on the state's much-liked winter food- the khasta gajak - with gur, chana and til. The ingredients - namely , provided the much needed energy and protection against the cold. In the 1930s, Sitaram Shivhare in Morena decided to give a festive twist to the mix of winter-food ingredients, namely jaggery , peanuts and sesame - combined with spices like cardamom and cinnamon, and came up with a celebratory sweet called Khasta Gajak. Henceforth, the town located in the heart of the dacoit infested Chambal valley, got a new identity and a new dish."The secret of creating Khasta Gajak was then passed down through generations of the Shivhare family. My mother’s family is from the same line of descendants. Back in the fifties, my father Daulatram Gupta learnt the art from my maternal side and came back with a few workers from the area too who knew how to create the perfect, khasta (flaky) gajak. Since then, our shop has become synonymous with gajak," shares Vinod Gupta, the second generation owner of Daulatram Gupta Morena Gajak Bhandar in Gwalior , who is acknowledged as the king of gajak. Many patrons carry these sweets overseas so their friends and family. Moreover, it has a long shelf life and can last up to two months in cool, dry conditions.The flaky, crumbly sweet finds its presence in almost all festival thalis beginning from Diwali. It is in hot demand during Makar Sankranti festival when winter is also at its peak. Over the years, the sweet has evolved from its humble flaky texture to sticky, sugary ones and ones loaded with dry fruits. Sunnyraj Saini, the second generation owner of Sheetal Gajak, that introduced the sweet to the Malwa region seventy years ago, shares, "There are many varieties and flavours present in the market now. We have dry fruits, chocolate and mawa gajak. But we have noticed that patrons prefer the original gajak over the others." Since the process of obtaining the right flaky and crumbly structure of gajak is quite a tedious process, most people prefer buying it. A nicely wrapped dabba of gajak also becomes an ideal gift during the winter festivals in MP, and all those who visit Gwalior, Bhopal and Indore during the months of November-February, carry back packets of these sweets to their respective cities.In a modern twist, some restaurants in Gwalior serve gajak with a dollop of ice cream. Vinod adds, "Gajak ki taseer garam hai, toh ice cream ke saath ek achcha combination banta hai."Roasted Seasme (til) - 200 gmsJaggery (gur) - 300 gmsGround peanuts - 1/4 cupGhee - 2 tablespoonsCardamom / cinnamon - ½ tsp (optional)Grind the roasted sesame seeds and peanuts to form a thick and coarse powder. In a wok, heat ghee, add jaggery and cook on low heat till reaches a syrupy consistency. Add the spices to this mix if you want. Turn off the heat and fold in the ground sesame, peanuts mix. Once mixed, transfer the contents onto a tray lined with ghee and let it cool. Level with a spatula, and make square/rectangular cuts while it is still warm. Once cool, separate the pieces and you can store it for a month without worrying about it going bad.

Title: Makar Sankranti Quotes, Wishes, Messages & Status: 15 beautiful quotes and messages for wishing Makar Sankranti
Content: Makar Sankranti is an annual Hindu festival which is observed as per the solar cycle. Celebrated on January 14, it marks the day of the sun's transit into zodiac sign Makara (Capricorn) which means the end of winters solstice and the beginning of longer days. The festival has its origins in Gujarat and it is celebrated with great enthusiasm by people. On this day people get-together on the rooftops with their family and friends and engage in friendly kite flying competitions, dances and bonfires. They also relish on sweets made of gud (jaggery) and til (sesame) apart from other traditional delicacies like jalebi, fafda and undhiyu among others.This is also considered an auspicious day by people as they believe that whatever task they begin or perform on this day will be fruitful. While the festival is called Makar Sankranti in West India including the states Gujarat, Maharashtra and Rajasthan, it also known and celebrated by other popular names throughout the country. For instance, is called Maghi in North India (which follows right after Lohri); in Andhra Pradesh, Karnataka and Telangana it is celebrated as Pedda Pandaga; while in Assam it is celebrated as Magh; and in Tamil Nadu it is called Pongal.To help you send warm wishes to your loved ones on this festival, we have compiled a list of some beautiful quotes and messages here for you. Send them to your friends and family and wish them a happy Makar Sankranti this year.1. May you soar high with success just like your kites this Makar Sankranti. Happy Uttarayan!2. May we all be blessed with joy and prosperity on this Makar Sankranti. Wish you and your loved ones a happy Uttarayan!3. Here's wishing you and your family a wonderful Makar Sankranti.4. This year, I hope the rising sun of Makar Sankranti fills your life with happy moments. Wishing you a very happy Makar Sankranti!5. May your life be filled with love, happiness and prosperity. Happy Makar Sankranti!6. May the Sun God bring fills your life and home with sunshine and happiness. Happy Makar Sankranti!7. I wish this Makar Sankranti blesses you with good harvest, peace and prosperity! Happy Makar Sankranti.8. Sending you warm greetings on the auspicious occasion of Makar Sankranti! Have a great day.9. This Makar Sankranti, the sun rises with hope, kites fly in the sky with vigour, and the crops are ready to be harvested – all signifying hope, joy and abundance. Happy Makar Sankranti!10. Makar Sankranti is a new beginning of a new destination, happiness or sorrow. Wish you a happy Makar Sankranti!11. May your life be filled with the sweetness of til and gud. Wishing you and your family a very happy Makar Sankranti!12. It's time to enjoy the first festival of the year. Wishing you a prosperous and delightful Makar Sankranti!13. I hope on this Makar Sankranti the Sun God showers his blessings on you and your family. I pray that it marks the end of difficulties and brings in success, joy and peace in your life.14. We wish you a very happy Makar Sankranti! Sending love, luck and joy from our family to yours.15. This Makar Sankranti, I wish for a good harvest which brings smiles and a blissful year ahead. Here's wishing you a happy and prosperous Makar Sankranti!

Content:
Winters call for a hearty plate of Gajak, especially on Makar Sankranti

Original khasta gajak

Roast gajak

Kaju Chocolate gajak bite

How to make til-mungfali gajak at home

Vinod adds, "Gajak ki taseer garam hai, toh ice cream ke saath ek achcha combination banta hai."Roasted Seasme (til) - 200 gmsJaggery (gur) - 300 gmsGround peanuts - 1/4 cupGhee - 2 tablespoonsCardamom / cinnamon - ½ tsp (optional)Grind the roasted sesame seeds and peanuts to form a thick and coarse powder. In a wok, heat ghee, add jaggery and cook on low heat till reaches a syrupy consistency. Add the spices to this mix if you want. Turn off the heat and fold in the ground sesame, peanuts mix. Once mixed, transfer the contents onto a tray lined with ghee and let it cool. Level with a spatula, and make square/rectangular cuts while it is still warm. Once cool, separate the pieces and you can store it for a month without worrying about it going bad.

Title: Nadella issues a detailed statement, BJP claims it is endorsement of govt policy
Content:
This story is from January 15, 2020

NEW DELHI: BJP criticised Microsoft CEO Satya Nadella for his comment on the fallout of changes in the citizenship law, but warmed up to the tech czar after he issued a detailed statement where he acknowledged a country’s right to define its borders, ensure national security and determine its immigration policy.

After a comment of Nadella, attributed to him by US digital media platform Buzzfeed , which was seen as critical of the new changes in India’s citizenship law, generated excitement, the Microsoft CEO issued a detailed statement.

“Every country will and should define its borders, protect national security and set immigration policy accordingly. And in democracies, that is something that the people and their governments will debate and define within those bounds. I’m shaped by my Indian heritage, growing up in a multicultural India and my immigrant experience in the US. My hope is for an India where an immigrant can aspire to found a prosperous start-up or lead a multinational corporation benefitting Indian society and the economy at large,” Nadella said in a statement issued by Microsoft India.

Asked about the controversy over the Microsoft chief’s remarks, BJP spokesperson Sambit Patra pointed to the latter’s second statement and said it marked an endorsement of what the government has sought to achieve through the new citizenship law. “That is what the government of this country has done. We are looking after national security and protecting borders. As far as immigrants are concerned, there is a process for citizenship. Anybody can apply for citizenship. Even the PM has said so. Once they apply for work permit, for citizenship, many have become citizens. Of course, anybody can then do whatever the Constitution has bestowed on them (sic).”

To a question on CAA, Nadella was quoted by Buzzfeed as saying, “I think what is happening in India is sad...just bad...I would love to see a Bangladeshi immigrant who comes to India and creates the next Unicorn in India or becomes the next CEO of Infosys .”

Title: Ailing woman denied wheelchair at airport
Content:
This story is from January 15, 2020

KOLKATA: A spinal patient travelling to Coimbatore for surgery on low-cost airline SpiceJet was refused a wheelchair by an airline executive at the Kolkata airport’s check-in counter on Tuesday.

All pleas and arguments by Mamta Agarwala — who was leaning heavily on a baggage trolley, wearing a broad orthopaedic belt, evidently in discomfort — and her husband fell on deaf ears. Even efforts by other passengers to make the airline staff see reason failed. It was only when the matter was brought to the notice of the airport director that action was taken, and Mamta issued a wheelchair. Later, a SpiceJet spokesperson issued a statement saying “any shortcoming is deeply regretted”.

Mamta’s airport trauma began around 10.15am, when she and her husband, Tolaram, arrived at departure gate 2A. When she inquired about a wheelchair, the CISF personnel at the gate told her she would have to make the request at the SpiceJet counter. When she made the request at the counter, the executive reportedly told Mamta, “Why did you not make the request at the time of booking the tickets? It is not possible to get a wheelchair now.” Even when Tolaram pointed out that she had problems in her spine, the airline staff allegedly refused to budge.

“Get in touch with the call centre and make your request. I will not be able to provide wheelchair assistance. Please step aside and don’t waste my time,” the Spicejet executive reportedly told Mamta.

Mamta told TOI, “Had I known that the wheelchair needed to be pre-booked, I would have surely done so. But refusing to provide it despite seeing my condition was unfortunate,” she said.

Title: Bumper paddy crop brings cheer to farmers in Vizag
Content:
This story is from January 15, 2020

Visakhapatnam: This Sankranti has brought good news for the farmers of north-coastal Andhra pradesh. The three districts of Visakhapatnam, Vizianagaram and Srikakulam have produced nearly 20 lakh tonnes of paddy .

Over 10 lakh farmers have harvested nearly 4.5 hectares, including 97,000 hectares in Visakhapatnam, 1.4 lakh hectares in Vizianagaram and 2.1 lakh hectares in Srikakulam in the Kharif season, which begins in June and ends by December. Nearly 3.5 lakh tonnes of paddy was grown in Visakhapatnam, 6.5 lakh tonnes Vizianagaram and 10 lakh tonnes in Srikakulam

Speaking to TOI, Visakhapatnam district agriculture department joint director GSNS Leelavathi said, “In Visakhapatnam district alone, an average of 3,300 kgs per hectare paddy has been produced.”

Whereas in Srikakulam district, an average of nearly 4,500 kgs of paddy was produced per hectare. Leelavathi said “This time the paddy crop has yielded good results due to several reasons, including sufficient rain.”

“This time there was no cyclone or bad weather reported in the Kharif season. This helped the farmers to get good returns from the agriculture sector. This Sankranti would be a happy one for the farmers,” said an agriculture scientist.

B Balaram, a farmer from Payakaraopeta in Visakhapatnam, said they got 3,500 kgs of paddy per hectare against last year’s yield of 2,500 kgs. This was because of the favourable weather, he said.

Officials in the agriculture department said the harvesting of paddy crop has been completed in almost all areas in the region, but the hulling and milling is yet to be completed in a few areas.

All the paddy crop of the Kharif season will be completed by the end of January or first week of February. Meanwhile, farmers have already started working on their second crop for the Rabi season, officials added.

Title: Transport dept on overdrive
Content:
This story is from January 15, 2020

Visakhapatnam: In an attempt to cater to the rush of passengers during Sankranti, various transport departments including the railways are taking several measures.

Officials of the transport department in Visakhapatnam said that more than 100 special buses will be run from Hyderabad via Vijayawada to Visakhapatnam to ferry over 10,000 expected passengers.

Helpline number: 08662570005 has been announced to help passengers.

The railway staff at Visakhapatnam railway station informed that nearly 1 lakh footfalls are being registered every day right now, almost double from the 40,000 to 50,000 footfalls registered regularly.

Speaking to TOI, a railway official said that special ticket counters and ticket vending machines will be operational till Wednesday morning.

On the other hand, a number of trains have been cancelled in the Titlagarh-Thiruveli section of the Sambalpur division between January 27 and January 31 owing to safety related modernisation work that will be carried out along the area. The work is slated to begin on January 22.

Title: ‘Delinquent’ DSP Davinder Singh was to get promotion as SP soon based on his seniority
Content:
SIT to probe singh’s links with Hizb

SRINAGAR: Arrested DSP Davinder Singh , held for alleged corruption and links with terrorist organisations, was about to be elevated as superintendent of J&K police as per his seniority after having served as a deputy superintendent for 25 years in the police department.The promotion file of several deputy SPs is under process in the office of J&K home commissioner, and Davinder Singh would have made the grade if he had not been busted in the company of Hizb-ul-Mujahideen members while travelling in a Maruti car on January 11, police sources said .The controversial cop’s long run, who was not only involved in extortion cases, but was in league with terror outfits, continues to be animatedly discussed in official and political circles both in Srinagar and in Delhi even as the NIA took over the investigation regarding Singh’s ferrying Hizb terrorists.Singh was held with top Hizbul commander Syed Naveed Mushtaq at a checkpoint on Srinagar-Jammu highway. Mushtaq was reportedly travelling with associates, including a terrorist who recently moved to J&K. Singh has been accused of allegedly ferrying the militants out of the Valley.The DSP has three FIRs filed against him in extortion cases though his “utility” seems to have ensured he was never long in the dog house. His arrest has brought up his connections with Parliament attack convict Afzal Guru who was hanged for the terror attack. Guru’s wife Tabassum had blamed Davinder Singh of demanding Rs 1 lakh for releasing him, claiming she paid after selling of gold ornaments.Guru had alleged that he was asked by Singh to ferry Pakistani terrorist Mohammad to New Delhi and purchase a car for him and his accomplices. Guru said he was to arrange accommodation for the five Pakistani terrorists in an affidavit in Supreme Court through his lawyer Sushil Kumar in 2004.Though Afzal Guru had gone to PoK for arms training with JKLF, he had surrendered to BSF in early 1997 after he was disillusioned with Pakistan. He, however, remained a suspect in police’s eyes, and his wife claimed that among those who picked him up after an incident of terrorist violence included Davinder Singh.Singh had joined the police force as an SI in early 90’s and got out of turn promotions after the creation of an elite force called special operation group in 1994. In March, 2003, the then CM Mufti Sayeed disbanded the Special Operations Group, following the complaints of misuse of power. There were 49 cases of human right abuse cases against 53 SOG officials. The official figures reveal as many 25 officials were dismissed and this was disclosed in the state assembly by the junior home minister A R Veeri of the Mufti government in 2003.Singh was thereafter reinstated and posted in the traffic department and subsequently transferred to various places including Srinagar police control room, Before his arrest, the “delinquent” officer was at Srinagar international airport with anti-hijacking squad of the police, a highly sensitive assignment.He also escorted a 15-member delegation of foreign envoys when the group was on a two-day visit to J&K on January 9.Meanwhile on Tuesday, J&K police raided the house of a Hizb accomplice Irfan Shafi Mir, who was driving the car when Singh and others were held. The police party is said to have recovered Pakistani currency notes from the house of Mir, the sources said.Surprisingly, Irfan, a lawyer by profession, was over ground worker of Hizb and visited Pakistan five times on an Indian passport. Irfan’s father Mohammad Shafi Mir was district Hizb commander in Shopian in early 90’s and is believed to have gone to Pakistan in 1993 and his son Irfan Mir used to visit his father in Pakistan, the sources said.Jammu and Kashmir police on Tuesday said that a special investigating team (SIT) headed by some DIG rank police officer, has been constituted to conduct the probe in the criminal conduct and any such act in the past committed by arrested DSP Davinder Singh. In a series of tweets on its official twitter handle, the police said that a special investigation team is handling interrogation of the arrested accused officer and the militants which would probe his “criminal conduct in the instant case and his involvement in any such criminal acts in the past.” Another tweet by the police read that Jammu Kashmir Police is known for its professionalism and doesn’t spare anyone including its own cadres if found involved in any unlawful act or unbecoming conduct.The J&K Police also denied Singh was awarded a President’s medal. In fact, the police said he was not awarded any gallantry or meritorious medal by the Union ministry for home affairs. The only medal awarded to him was by the erstwhile J&K state on Independence Day in 2018.Read this story in Marathi

Title: Unemployed youth easy prey for fake job offers
Content:
This story is from January 15, 2020

Visakhapatnam: At least two cases of financial fraud are reported every day in Vizag on average. Residents, especially unemployed youngsters are falling prey to various kinds of fraud on a regular basis.

Over 2,100 cases of cheating have been reported in the city between 2017 and 2019, informed police commissioner RK Meena.

Defrauding people with the promise of employment is the most common of the offences, closely followed by chit fund-based fraudulent activities.

City police chief RK Meena said that fraudsters are duping youngsters by promising them government jobs as well as jobs abroad. The fraudsters are also duping many through illegal chits, promising them huge returns on investments.

On an average, 1,200 cases of job fraud, chit fraud and online lottery fraud have been reported in Andhra Pradesh only in the last one year. The victims of such scams include not only intermediate and polytechnic diploma pass-outs but also engineering and business school graduates.

According to a senior police official, over 780 cheating cases were registered in 2019, of which nearly 690 cases remain under investigation.

“A majority of such crimes come to light one or two weeks after the fraud. By the time victims of fraud approach the police, fraudsters manage to flee,” said ADCP (crimes) V Suresh Babu.

V Gopinath, inspector of cybercrime police station in Vizag said that cybercriminals have been targeting unemployed youngsters by posting job advertisements in free online classified portals and are duping them by promising jobs in software firms in both India and abroad.

“It is very difficult to recover the money siphoned off from fraudsters in white collar fraud as the cyber crooks operate from metro cities,” he added.

Title: ATMs run out of cash ahead of Sankranti
Content:
This story is from January 15, 2020

Visakhapatnam: Several ATMs in the city downed their shutters on Tuesday as people ran from pillar to post in search of money. ‘No cash ’ and ‘out of service’ boards were hung outside several money dispensing machines as people withdrew money in bulk in the days ahead of Sankranti.

Not just the city, the situation is similar in some parts of the district as well as north Andhra. Bankers attribute this to the mad rush for cash before and during festivals. “People generally visit their home towns and go shopping during festivals. So withdrawals would be more than on normal days,” a bank official said.

The city has 400 ATMs of around 50 different banks, both public and private. Cash in around 70 per cent of the ATMs were exhausted in the last two days. North Andhra districts – Srikakulam, Vizianagaram and Visakhapatnam have around 2,000 ATMs of around 1,400 branches of 50 different banks.

“We visited around 12 to 15 ATMs in Madhurawada but could not find cash. The situation is more or less the same at PM Palem, Yendada, Venkojipalem and other areas. People living in the city’s outskirts are the most affected,” Y Swati, a homemaker, complained.

Both public and private banks failed to anticipate the want of cash. Cash has not been added to most ATMs since Monday morning, IOB customer SS Rao alleged. Serpentine queues could be seen in front of the few ATMs that did have some cash, he added.

“Except on holidays, we fill cash in ATMs every day,” Sai, a senior manager of a public sector bank told TOI.

Title: Financially independent family member of road accident victim also entitled to compensation : SC
Content:
This story is from January 15, 2020

NEW DELHI: The Supreme Court has held that family members of a road accident victim cannot be denied compensation merely on the ground that they are not financially dependent on the deceased as his legal representatives have a right to compensation.

A bench of Justices A M Khanwilkar and Dinesh Maheshwari set aside the verdict of Punjab and Haryana High Court which had held that children of the deceased, who are earning themselves would not be entitled for compensation. The apex court held that liability to pay compensation under the Motor Vehicles Act does not cease because of absence of dependency of the legal representative.

“It is thus settled by now that the legal representatives of the deceased have a right to apply for compensation. Having said that, it must necessarily follow that even the major, married and earning sons of the deceased being legal representatives have a right to apply for compensation and it would be the bounden duty of the Tribunal to consider the application irrespective of the fact whether the legal representative was fully dependant on the deceased,” the bench said.

Quashing the HC order, the bench awarded a compensation of Rs 32 lakh to two sons of a woman who was killed in a road accident in 2014. It said the major married son who is also earning and not dependant on the deceased, would be still be considered ‘legal representative’ of the victim.

The court also clarified that the amount of compensation was to be decided on the consideration of gross salary of a victim and not on the basis of take-home salary. It said the Motor Accidents Claims Tribunal had wrongly computed the compensation on the basis of take-home salary and enhanced the amount of compensation.

“It is noticed that the Tribunal proceeded to determine the compensation amount on the basis of net salary drawn by the deceased for the relevant period as Rs 16,918 per month, while taking note of the fact that her gross salary was Rs 23,123 per month (presumably below taxable income). Concededly, any deduction from the gross salary other than tax amount cannot be reckoned. In that, the actual salary minus tax amount ought to have been taken into consideration by the Tribunal for determining the compensation amount,” it said.

Title: LHMS gets lukewarm response this Sankranti
Content:
This story is from January 15, 2020

Visakhapatnam: The police department’s plan to curtail possible house break-in incidents through the Locked House Monitoring System ( LHMS ) mobile app during the Sankranti festival vacation has received a lukewarm response from the public.

The police said that only over 50 people in Vizag utilised the LHMS service before they left for Sankranti festival to their home towns. Even though the police have been requesting residents to use LHMS services by installing the CCTV cameras at locked houses before going on vacation, most people seem to have ignored the appeals.

A senior police officer said that Sankranti is one of the major festivals of Telugu people as most of the people visit their home towns to celebrate the three-day festival (Bhogi, Sankranti, and Kanuma). Sankranti vacation is also challenging to the police as burglars plan property offenses around this time as many houses remain locked.

If one choses to use the app, the police will install CCTV cameras at the house of the person free of cost and the cameras are linked to the police control room. If any burglar enters the house, the police will receive an alert.

ADCP (Crimes) V Suresh Babu hopes that the number of people using the app may increase in the coming days. “We are taking all measures to prevent the possible house break-in incidents during the festival,” he added.

Title: Ajit Pawar breaks silence, files affidavit claiming innocence
Content:
This story is from January 15, 2020

Slug: Irrigation Scam

Nagpur: Deputy chief minister Ajit Pawar, facing a barrage of charges in the multi-crore irrigation scam, broke his silence for the first time by filing an affidavit on Tuesday denying all charges by petitioner Atul Jagtap in his four PILs and an application last month.

Questioning the petitioner’s locus standi (credentials), Pawar said Jagtap was misusing PILs to settle personal business rivalry. “He is a contractor and filed tenders in various projects named in his PILs. His allegations are actuated by personal motives and mala fide intentions, which aren’t in nature of PIL. His only intention is to trouble me.”

Opposing the petitioner’s demand to institute an inquiry by either CBI or Enforcement Directorate (ED) into the scam, the deputy CM said no evidence was brought on record to show that exceptional case is made out and investigations require to be transferred to central agencies. “Decision to name the accused is solely discretion of the investigating agency or trial court. Its power can’t be usurped by any person or institution. Since no FIR is registered against me, it can’t be ground to transfer the probe to central agencies as demanded by the petitioner.”

Further clarifying that he wasn’t made an accused in any case, Pawar said accusing him simply on the basis of mala fide statements made in the PILs is violation of his fundamental rights. “If he has grievance that an FIR was not registered against me, or police investigations are not proper, he had alternate remedy under CrPC before the police. He could also have approached the magistrate under the same Act. Petitioner can’t use HC to settle personal scores, and even courts can’t supervise the investigations or direct that a particular person be made an accused.”

Endorsing the ACB director general Parambir Singh’s statement that there was no inconsistency between affidavits filed by him on September 11, 2019, and by his predecessor Sanjay Barve on November 26, 2018, Pawar asserted that all HC directives were scrupulously followed by the government. “The petitioner has decided to don the role of investigating agency by pointing out defects without any expertise. His allegations are totally imaginative and churlish. Singh’s affidavit clarified everything in detail while Barve didn't have the advantage of actual records collected by the investigating officers at later stages, while filing his affidavit.”

Stressing that he followed all rules as former WRD minister, the 59-year-old Pawar said all decisions were taken in accordance with law and with the help of concerned VIDC officials. “The petitioner shouldn’t have any doubt of investigating agencies favouring me as most of the probe was conducted, FIRs registered and charge-sheets were filed during the term of previous (BJP) government, when I was in the opposition,” said Pawar’s affidavit.

While demanding dismissal of Jagtap’s application, the Baramati MLA also denied granting undue favours to any contractor. “I’ve replied to all 68 queries in the questionnaire which proves that I’ve cooperated with the investigations. There are no prayers sought against me in the PILs. I haven’t indulged in any corrupt, motivated or mala fide acts while discharging duties. No wrongdoing can be attributed to me, as all tenders awarded were in accordance with the rules and didn’t have my interference,” he said.

Pawar’s affidavit was filed in response to Jagtap’s application in his four PILs praying for instituting an inquiry by CBI/ED to probe alleged massive embezzlement and corruption in four projects; Jigaon (Buldhana), Lower Pedhi (Amravati), Raigad Barrage (Chandur Railway), and Waghadi (Amravati).

Box

What The Affidavit Says

— Accuses petitioner Atul Jagtap of filing PILs to settle business rivalry

— Opposes demand for probe either by CBI or ED into the scam

— Not named an accused in the case and allegations made against him with mala fide intentions

— Followed all rules as former WRD minister and all decisions were taken as per law and with the help of concerned VIDC officials

— Demands dismissal of Jagtap’s application and denied granting undue favours to any contractor

Title: City chokes as Bhogi raises levels of particulate matter
Content:
This story is from January 15, 2020

Visakhapatnam: On Bhogi the air quality index in most parts of the city reached hazardous levels, with particulate matter (PM) 2.5 and particulate matter (PM) 10 levels going up. And the sudden dip in temperature only compounded the problem.

Bhogi is a ritual in which old household articles are burnt in a bonfire made of wood and cow-dung cakes. Although, GVMC officials had warned the public against celebrating Bhogi on the streets and burning wood, the ritual continued unabated in most of the parts of the city.

As per the real-time monitoring of Central Pollution Control Board (CPCB), PM 2.5 at GVMC station was at 275mg/m3 at 6 am on Tuesday while PM 10 was 256 mg/m3. The other pollutants, CO, NO2, SO2, also saw a drastic rise deviating from their normal values.

When the air quality index is poor it can cause breathing discomfort among people who are exposed to it for longer hours. The permissible concentration of PM 2.5 particles is 40 µg/m3 (annual average) and 60 µg/m3 (24-hour average) in industrial, residential, rural or other areas, as per Indian National Ambient Air Quality Standards (NAAQS), while the permissible limit for PM 10 particles is 60µg/m³ (annual average).

Speaking to TOI, a morning walker, Srinivas, at the RK beach road said, “When I went for my morning walk, I had difficulty breathing and seeing owing to the smog. The pollution was so high that it lead to irritation in my eyes.

Title: 14-year-old boy helps school kids learn about environment
Content:
This story is from January 15, 2020

Dhruv Advaith Kolagatla interacting with students. A student of Class 9, Dhruv has been selected to be the fir... Read More

Visakhapatnam: 14-year-old Dhruv Advaith Kolagatla from the city has been selected to be the first Pure (People for Urban and Rural Employment) ambassador from India.

Pure is a US-based NGO that works towards providing education to students from underprivileged backgrounds.

The NGO selected Dhruv in recognition of his work with ICCE (International Centre for Culture and Education) for his role as climate counsellor for green revolution and his brief proposal on sharing knowledge about renewable sources and environmental sustainability among students of low-income backgrounds.

Well-known for his community outreach programmes, Dhruv had recently worked with the zilla parishad high school in Makavarapalem village as well as the school in Gaddiraju Venkatpuram village in Visakhapatnam district.

A student of class 9, Dhruv discussed solar, hydro and wind energy with nearly 750 students of the ZP school and 130 students of the mandal parishad upper primary school.

Dhruv had undergone the selection process for Youth Ambassador for Social Law- Youth Initiative programme in October 2019. He is currently leading participants for an exam. The prize money he earns, he donates as scholarships.

A national-level tennis player, Dhruv said, “It was a new experience to share and impart scientific knowledge to the rural students. They were very interactive which made the sessions interesting. I plan on taking up more awareness programmes.”

Title: Priyanka Gandhi in Congress team to ‘intensify’ anti-govt stir
Content:
This story is from January 15, 2020

NEW DELHI: Indicating its intent to step up agitational politics, Congress on Tuesday formed a high-level “informal” committee to draw up programmes to intensify demonstrations against the BJP government on CAA-NRC and economic issues.

Roughly named “Quick Response Committee”, the “informal” panel comprises senior functionary Ahmed Patel , AICC general secretary (organisation) K C Venugopal, All India Congress Committee managers Priyanka Gandhi Vadra, Jyotiraditya Scindia, Shaktisinh Gohil , Rajeev Satav, Deepender Hooda, Jitin Prasada and Randeep Surjewala .

In the immediate context, the panel is expected to build on the agitation against the Citizenship (Amendment) Act, as decided by the joint opposition meeting and Congress Working Committee .

Sources said the party is looking to turn up the heat against Modi government in the Republic Day week by using “celebrations” as the tool. The three important days in the “nationalism calendar” – Netaji Bose’s birth anniversary on January 23, Republic Day on January 26 and Mahatma Gandhi ’s martyrdom day on January 30 – would see “reading of the preamble of the Constitution” and programmes on communal amity across the country.

The panel is expected to focus on how state and its local units can be nudged to organise activities to give sense of a widespread nationwide agitation. Since it decided to hit the streets in recent weeks, Congress managers are satisfied that they have succeeded in shedding the organisational sloth. Congress chief ministers took out rallies in the five states ruled by the party last month and then the party observed its Foundation Day on December 28 by holding rallies in all states.

Title: Activists oppose special classes during holidays
Content:
This story is from January 15, 2020

Visakhapatnam: Conducting classes on school holidays is detrimental to the students ’ psychological health and overall academic development, said psychologists and child rights activists from the city while adding that conducting such classes violates the children’s right of leisure.

The discussion was taking place in the context of the state government having declared Makara Sankranti holidays in state-run schools from January 11 to 20.

G Sitharam, state president of the NGO Child Rights Protection Forum said, “During the 10-day Dusara holidays, certain schools held classes, which we had brought to the notice of the district education officer (DEO). Again, during the Pongal holidays, it has come to our notice that some municipal schools at Madhuranagar, Muralinagar and Madhavdhara are trying to conduct special classes for class 10 students.”

“If we find the managements of (these) schools not implementing the education department guidelines and covertly conducting classes during holidays, we will take this issue up with the higher authorities in the education department,” Sitharam added.

Neuro-psychiatrist Dr B Ramesh Kumar said, “With children growing up in nuclear family set ups, they hardly get the opportunity to spend time with their grandparents. Sankranti is one such festival where they get to travel to their hometown. But with schools deciding to conduct classes, children lose the opportunity to rejuvenate themselves.”

Title: Tribals burn document reserving ZPTC, MPTC seats for non-tribals
Content:
This story is from January 15, 2020

Visakhapatnam: Tribals in many parts of Visakhapatnam Agency observed Bhogi on the first day of the three-day Sankranti festival by burning copies of the reservation announced for ZPTC (zilla parishad territorial constituency) and MPTC (mandal parishad territorial constituency) elections .

The tribals staged demonstrations against the district administration and the state government for reserving seats for non-tribal categories in scheduled (tribal) areas.

Representatives of the joint action committee (JAC), K Surendra, G Surayya and K Suryanarayana maintained that all ZPTC posts and MPTC posts should be reserved for tribal candidates only.

The JAC representatives feel that the state government has done injustice to tribals by allocating 10 of the 11 ZPTC seats in Visakhapatnam Agency to non-tribals.

“Despite our protest, the state government is yet to make any change in reservations for ZPTC and MPTC elections. The government and the district administration seem to be encouraging non-tribals to grab tribal land in Araku Valley, Paderu and Chintapalli,” said one of the representatives.

The protestors further said that they are going to launch a series of protests in the next few days.

According to the AP Scheduled Area Lands Transfer (Amendment) Regulation of 1970, the transfer of tribal land to non-tribals is prohibited, said one protestor while adding that the protests will continue until the government changes its mind.

The tribals of Visakhapatnam Agency staged demonstrations against the district administration and the state government for reserving seats for non-tribal categories in scheduled (tribal) areas

Title: Seek broad engagement with many parties: India
Content:
This story is from January 15, 2020

NEW DELHI: India will not be like a western liberal power but as the world’s greatest democracy, is a “self-defined power” which lives with its own traditions and values and also with global aspirations, former Canadian PM Stephen Harper said at the Raisina Dialogue on Tuesday.

At the inaugural session of the annual event, India’s flagship foreign policy and strategic conversation, foreign minister S Jaishankar said the characteristics of the Dialogue mirrored Indian foreign policy. “Indian foreign policy today seeks to achieve a focus on key challenges, a broad engagement with many parties, and managing, if not leveraging, global contradictions. Advancing our interests in a multipolar world and contributing to global good is what it is all about,” he said.

The inaugural session included seven former heads of government — Caril Bildt of Sweden , Tshering Tobgay of Bhutan, Han Seung-soo of South Korea , Helen Clark of New Zealand, Anders Fogh Rasmussen of Denmark , Hamid Karzai of Afghanistan and Harper of Canada — to set the scene for debating the most important questions in the world today.

Harper bluntly said it was important to change the nature of the regime in Iran for West Asia to have durable peace. On Wednesday, this position will definitely be contested by Javad Zarif, foreign minister of Iran who will speak at the Dialogue.

Harper also referred to the burgeoning political protests that have broken out in different parts of the world over inequality, nationalism etc.

Clark and Tobgay stressed on the importance of dealing with climate change as a global imperative. Tobgay said, “We need global champions,” pointing to PM Narendra Modi who attended the session but did not speak.

Title: National BJP leaders to meet Pawan in Vijaywada tomorrow
Content:
This story is from January 15, 2020

Kakinada: Fuelling speculation of a BJP-Jana Sena alliance in Andhra Pradesh ahead of local body and municipal polls, Jana Sena president and film actor Pawan Kalyan on Tuesday announced that a meeting of Jana Sena and BJP leaders will be held in Vijayawada on January 16.

BJP’s national leaders are likely to attend the crucial meeting, four days before AP assembly session on January 20 in which chief minister and YSRCP president Y S Jaganmohan Reddy is likely to announce shifting of state capital from Amaravati.

Incidentally, BJP and Jana Sena are opposed to the three capital cities plan of the Jagan government and have categorically said Amaravati should be continued as the capital city. Pawan said the state administration should be carried out from one place while development works should be spread across regions. He also said Prime Minister Narendra Modi’s aspirations are not reflected in Andhra Pradesh.

Pawan, who reached Kakinada on Tuesday after holding talks with senior BJP leaders including BJP working president JP Nadda in Delhi on Monday, told reporters the proposed BJP-Jana Sena meeting in Vijayawada will discuss important issues confronting the state including the proposal to shift the state capital.

He said he had briefed Nadda on the developments in Andhra Pradesh, agitation by farmers in Amaravati and foreign investors withdrawing from the state. He said he visited Delhi only after BJP leadership invited him.

Jana Sena sources said Pawan is likely to enter into an electoral alliance with BJP in the ensuing mandal and zilla parishad and municipal polls. Local body elections are due next month while the schedule for civic body polls is yet to be announced.

The party, however, ruled out merger of Jana Sena with BJP. Incidentally, Pawan’s brother Chiranjeevi, who had floated Praja Rajyam and won a few assembly seats, later merged his party with Congress.

Pawan joining hands with BJP is likely to throw a new political equation in Andhra Pradesh. The film actor launched the party after meeting Narendra Modi before the general elections in 2014.

Though he did not contest elections then, he supported BJP-TDP alliance, which won the assembly elections. He sailed with BJP till 2017 when he pulled out of NDA accusing BJP of cheating AP on the promise of special category status.

Jana Sena contested polls in April 2019 in alliance with the Communists. Pawan lost both assembly seats he contested including one in his native place, dominated by members of his social group. Jana Sena, however, managed to win a seat. All through the campaign Pawan did not criticise Prime Minister Narendra Modi or BJP, though he was critical of YSRCP and TDP.

Pawan hails from numerically strong Kapu community. If Jana Sena and BJP combine could manage to consolidate the Kapu vote bank, the new alliance may pose a political and electoral challenge to YSRCP and TDP. The Kapu community is spread across the state but it is dominant in East and West Godavari districts. Historically, the political party that had won the maximum number of seats in these districts had always formed the government.

Earlier, Pawan’s visit to Kakinada was marred by high tension in view of prohibitory orders in the town. On Sunday Jana Sena and YSRCP activists fought a pitched battle forcing the police to resort to lathicharge. Several people were injured.

Title: Top brands shun exclusive e-tail deals
Content:
(Representative image)

NEW DELHI: At a time when online marketplaces have come under the scanner for alleged exclusive agreements with smartphone makers, top apparel and footwear brands, including Under Armour , Nike, Marks & Spencer and Adidas are moving away from such agreements.The move by these brands is an effort to reach a wider consumer base, which is not possible by being available on a single e-commerce platform. For instance, German sportswear maker Adidas, which had an exclusive tie-up with Flipkart and Myntra, has started selling on Amazon India. British retailer Marks & Spencer, which went online in India through Flipkart Group, has now moved to Amazon and Ajio as well.“It’s a strategy by any brand launching in the market to side with one strong online player. But later on, they realised that they could do more business by being on other marketplaces since the customer profile for each platform is different. For instance, a Myntra customer is different from the one who shops for fashion on Amazon,” said a senior industry executive, who did not wish to be quoted.“A single e-commerce platform does not meet the growth aspirations of a brand. When you work with one and get a commitment for an X amount of business from it, you soon realise that selling on others will help you may be do one and half or double of that,” said Abhishek Lal, former senior director of e-commerce and omni-channel at Adidas Group India.While Amazon India and Flipkart spokespersons did not reply to emails from TOI, senior executives of top fashion brands TOI spoke to said, going forward, product segmentation for different online platforms will the key.“Based on the core consumer cohorts of e-commerce platforms, we segment our product assortments very sharply. Such a smart segmentation approach to potential target consumers allows us to deliver more effective and impactful communication, while optimising marketing dollars,” said Sanjeev Mohanty, MD of Levi Strauss India.

Title: Mumbai: 33 years on, man gets back mother’s stolen chain
Content:
This story is from January 15, 2020

On Tuesday, 104 citizens were given back their stolen ornaments, money and electronics, collectively worth Rs ... Read More

MUMBAI: Overwhelmed with emotion, Dilip Shah clasped his mother’s chain tightly in his palm on Tuesday. The last time he had seen it was 33 years ago. His mother had been robbed of the chain while she was on her way to a temple in 1986. The case remained unsolved for long and the family stopped inquiring with the police after Shah’s mother passed away.

Last week, Shah was informed the Railway police commissioner would soon hand over the chain to him.

On Tuesday, Shah was among 104 citizens who received ornaments, money and electronics, collectively worth Rs 1 crore that had been stolen from them over the years.

“I was in my late 20s when my mother’s chain was snatched. It was around 1986. She used to wear the chain every day,” said Shah (62), a garments trader. “During her last days, my mother’s health worsened and we moved homes so we could stay closer to a Jain temple that she frequented.” Meanwhile, the police closed the case. But it was reopened for investigation subsequently. “Two years ago, the police sent a letter to our previous address. The letter said they had recovered stolen property belonging to my mother. I made several rounds of the police station and court to get it back. But it was taking too long for the court to pass an order. I even had an argument with the magistrate in open court a few months ago,” Shah said. His 93-year-old father’s eyes welled up on seeing the chain on Tuesday. The family plans to donate it to the temple.

Bhayander-based housewife Bhavna Desai, who also got her stolen gold chain back after three decades, said it was among the few pieces of ornaments she has ever owned. “My family was not well off and I had slogged to buy myself a gold chain. I was 28 years old then and my parents had fixed my marriage. While walking back home on the railway tracks at Vidyavihar, a thief came up from behind and snatched the chain. I couldn’t stop crying on reaching home and my father accompanied me to lodge a complaint,” Desai, 58, said.

Earlier this month, two cops turned up at Desai’s maternal home in Vidyavihar. “My father is no more and my mother has moved to our native place. When the cops turned up for the second time, neighbours gave them my phone number. I was overjoyed when they mentioned they had got back my stolen chain ,” said Desai. When Desai purchased the chain in the 1980s, it cost around Rs 2,500, but its value today is Rs 41,000.

Being robbed of their jewellery on a long-distance train 18 years ago was an unpleasant memory for Byculla businessman Jitendra Jain and his family. But getting all 83 gm of it back on Tuesday was a “sweet surprise”, said Jain. The family was returning from a wedding in Rajasthan in 2001 when a robber got into the train between Santacruz and Bandra. Pretending to be a government officer, he asked to check their baggage. When Jain asked him to produce his identification, the man whipped out a knife and placed it on Jain’s neck, and stripped the family of all the jewellery they were wearing. “He was caught a couple of years later and I remember identifying him at the police station. But the trial took several years and we had given up all hope of getting our ornaments back,” Jain said.

GRP commissioner Ravindra Sengaokar said they planned to return more recovered jewellery to citizens on Gudi Padwa.
