Title: Realty lobby group rolls out first online portal
Content:
This story is from January 15, 2020

(Representative image)

NEW DELHI: Real estate lobby group NAREDCO has launched the country’s first e-commerce portal, www.housingforall.com, for ready-to-move in houses which its members will upload for home buyers. The organisation said the developers will be allowed to upload the details of projects that have got occupation certificates ( OCs ) for the next one month, and then it will be open for home buyers with a 45-day sale period.

For the initial 15 days, buyers will be able to view offers and shortlist their homes and will be able to start making purchases from March 1 till March 31.

While Union housing secretary Durga Shankar Mishra used the analogy of an ecommerce giant to say this could be like the “Amazon for real estate sector”, experts were of the view that people don’t buy houses online, though the portal will help them to get all the details and work as a facilitator.

National Real Estate Development Council (NAREDCO) claimed that builders will make the best offer to buyers and they can book directly through the portal with a payment of Rs 25,000. The booking amount will be fully refundable. It said at least 1,000 projects would be listed on this portal to give maximum option to the buyers.

Launching the portal, Mishra said, “It is a huge step for prospective home buyers. While having a discussion with the stakeholders, I told them that credibility needs to be the most important factor in this portal. If a person is willing to buy a property then location, price should be exactly what is promised on the portal.”

Title: With KYC ruse, 3 dupe man of Rs 1.7 lakh in Mumbai
Content:
This story is from January 15, 2020

Representative image

MUMBAI: The D B Marg police recently busted a gang that used to con people using the threat of shutting down their Paytm accounts . In a recent case, they duped a 73-year-old man from Vile Parle of Rs 1.7 lakh.

The arrested accused were identified as Narshi Sutar (23), Nandkishore Sutar (26), and Arvind Singh (27), who acted as their mentor to run the scam.

The complainant, Anil Shah, told the police that he had received a text message from a mobile number, that asked him to contact them and update his information (KYC) for his Paytm account, or the account would be closed. When Shah called the number, he was told that those who did not submit their documents and update their accounts, had their accounts shut down. Shah then shared his details. After that, Rs 1.7 lakh was debited from his account.

Shah then approached the police to lodge a complaint. While probing the case, the police found that the fraudsters had purchased six mobile phones and some vouchers from malls in the city. Based on these details, the Sutars were taken into custody from Lower Parel. During their investigation, they told the police about their 'leader', Arvind Singh.The police then picked him up from Jharkhand.

The police have recovered property worth Rs 1.2 lakh in Shah's case. They also found 70 mobile phones that they suspect the three accused had used to run their scam. The trio would get the victim's account details, hack into the account and then transfer the money to themselves. The three were remanded in police custody till January 20.

Title: Delhi: One more held for anti-CAA riots, 100 till now
Content:
This story is from January 15, 2020

Demonstrators throw pieces of bricks towards Delhi cops during a protest against CAA in Seelampur area of Delh... Read More

NEW DELHI: Delhi police's Special Investigation Team (SIT) has arrested 100 people in the anti-CAA riots so far, the latest being Firoz, a resident of Jafrabad. Firoz was identified from CCTV footage recovered during the protests. A probe is on to establish whether the same men were involved in the riots at Jamia and Daryaganj. The SIT took up the probe of the Jamia Nagar and Daryaganj violence recently.

The SIT led by DCP (crime) Rajesh Deo had suspected the role of at least 15 people based on the footage and technical evidence recovered from the scene of riot, among whom Firoz was found to be leading a mob from the front.

In the Seelampur riots, the cops had arrested 16 people from the ground, while two others were caught during the investigation. The SIT took over the probe of the riots at Jamia Nagar last week and interrogated the six people who were arrested earlier, which led them to two more men who were seen pelting stones at the buses on Mathura Road.

Title: Boosting consumption a must to get investment moving: Reddy
Content:
This story is from January 15, 2020

(Representative image)

NEW DELHI: The government needs to focus on spurring consumption through a stimulus to get companies to invest as the reduction in corporation tax alone is not enough to prompt industry to invest, the newly-elected president of industry lobby group Ficci said on Tuesday.

“Number one to pump prime the economy, we need to infuse capital, which is needed to spur consumption. Unless you spur consumption, you cannot catalyse investment. It’s becoming like chicken and egg. People are saying that we have lowered taxes but people are booking those taxes and not spending,” Sangita Reddy, who is also the joint managing director of Apollo Hospitals , told TOI in an interview. “Corporations will not spend it on growth unless they know there is consumption. It’s very critical to put money into the system,” said Reddy.

Presenting a comprehensive blueprint for boosting overall growth ahead of the February 1 Budget, Reddy said the focus must now shift to exports as well as the crucial agriculture sector, including large scale mechanisation and value addition.

Expressing confidence about achieving the $5 trillion target, Reddy said the government and industry must work together as partners to ensure that the target is achieved.

She said the government should not worry about the fiscal deficit target and instead focus on boosting consumption. This, she said, could be done by pumping around Rs 1.5 lakh crore to Rs 2 lakh crore in the economy, particularly in rural areas.

“We have recommended that the government should raise Rs 1.5-2 lakh crore, whether from RBI or bonds, and not worry about fiscal deficit. But use the money to put it directly into the hands of rural India or in areas,” she said.

“In the same breath, create a time-bound plan for disinvestment of around Rs 3 lakh crore so that if both happen in synchrony with each other, and this is well articulated, there will be no reduction in our rating and the fiscal deficit will bloat only for a temporary period,” Reddy said.

She said the government must turn its focus on shoring up growth, which is estimated to slow to an 11-year low of 5%.

“Let’s make 2020 the year of economic growth and economic focus. The potential is huge and industry and government intend to work together to fulfil this potential,” Reddy said.

Title: Merc eyes ‘sustainable luxury’ with 10 new EVs by 2022
Content:
This story is from January 15, 2020

Pune: Mercedes-Benz is developing at least 10 new pure electric cars that will hit global markets by 2022. The German automaker’s R&D unit in Bengaluru is already active in contributing to the development of these new generation cars, at least some of which are expected to make it to the Indian market.

Speaking on the sidelines of the unveiling Mercedes-Benz EQC, its first pure electric global car in India, the automaker’s India MD & CEO Martin Schwenk said the electric SUV would test the market and gauge customer response before the company decided to introduce more electric cars in India.

“The sporty SUV is an entry into the electric space but it isn’t a car for everyone. We are still trying to understand what will work in the Indian market and what won’t. There is strong government focus towards introduction of electric cars. Customer and dealer interest is also picking up. But infrastructure hasn’t changed yet. So we are looking at electric cars that can do 470-500km to a charge,” said Schwenk.

The luxury carmaker is positioning its electric portfolio EQC as sustainable luxury. “Just as Mercedes-Benz stands for modern luxury, Mercedes-Maybach for ultimate luxury and Mercedes-AMG for driving performance, EQC is pointing the way to the future and part of Mercedes-Benz’s philosophy of sustainable luxury,” the CEO explained.

The EQC, to be launched in April 2020, will be among 10 cars that the company plans to introduce during the year. The new GLE will be launched on January 20, the new GLS in the second quarter of the year. The rapid introduction of products is aimed at keeping the excitement going in the market, a critical factor in driving sales when the market is depressed.

Though Mercedes-Benz recorded the highest ever fourth quarter sales in 2019, it was owing to six new launches and a bonanza offer to GLE and GLS customers that allowed free upgrades. Overall, sales dipped by 11% during the year but the carmaker managed to increase its marketshare in the luxury segment from 37.5% in 2018 to 41% in 2019.

Schwenk is cautiously optimistic about the year ahead and hopes the numbers will be close to 2018 when the company sold 15,538 cars (sales dipped to 13,786 units in 2019). He also sees that the industry make a turnaround.

“The uncertainty over BS IV to BS VI migration that has seen many companies cut production and take measures to reduce BS IV inventory will be over and companies can focus on growth. At Mercedes-Benz, there is actual customer movement is showrooms. I see positive signs,” he added.

Title: Bengal beats big states in curbing retail inflation
Content:
This story is from January 15, 2020

Kolkata: West Bengal has done well in containing retail inflation in December compared to most other big states of the country. The state’s retail inflation in the last month stood at 7.53%, which is slightly more that the national average but lower than seven major states. Inflation figure in some states peaked as high as 9.61%.

Economists feel that the Bengal’s number is largely due to better vegetable production and distribution system with relatively lower mark up than the previous years. The other seven states where retail inflation as per the latest figure was higher are: Odisha (9.41%), Telengana (9.39%), UP (8.92%), Tamil Nadu (8.64%), Kerala (7.98%), MP (7.88%), Uttarakhand (7.82%).

Owing to higher food prices, India’s retail inflation rose sharply to 7.35% in December 2019 from 5.54% in November, according to the government data. The retail inflation in December was highest in six years. It was 2.11% in December 2018. Apart from Kerala and Uttarakhand, all the other states in this chart are bigger in terms of size though West Bengal population is higher than most of these states.

Vegetables inflation in December 2019 surged to 60.5% as against 36% in November. As per the government data, the food inflation rose to 14.12% in December as against (-) 2.65% in the same month of 2018. It was 10.01% in November 2019. The central government has mandated the Reserve Bank of India to keep inflation in the range of 4% with a margin of 2% on the either side. Citing inflation concerns, the RBI kept interest rates unchanged in December following five cuts totaling 135 basis points earlier in the year.

Leading economists had attributed this phenomenon to vegetable prices because as per the available data it was the single largest contributor to this high retail inflation. Professor of Economics in ISI, Abhirup Sarkar pointed out that West Bengal is known for its variety of vegetables and volume of vegetable production. “This distribution system too may be little better here so that price spiral is less compared to may be some other states,” he added. Sources close to NSSO pointed out that as per its later report (not yet public), the rural consumption has not gone down like what has happened nationally.

Former head of ISI, Dipankar Dasgupta feels that historically vegetable supply in Bengal is better and the number of organised market is also more. Sources in state government argued that in last 5-6 years, it has constructed Krishi Baazar (rural procurement centres) some of which are operational, might have helped.

Inflation

West Bengal: 7.53%

Uttarakhand: 7.82%

Madhya Pradesh: 7.88%

Kerala: 7.98%

Tamil Nadu: 8.64%

UP: 8.92%

Telengana: 9.39%

Odisha: 9.41%

Title: CCTV footage of Saoner murder exposes sloppy probe by police
Content:
This story is from January 15, 2020

Nagpur: Leaked CCTV footage of Angad Singh’s murder at Saoner on Sunday by his friend-turned-foe Narendra Singh, already under arrest, left the rural police red-faced, forcing them to arrest one more person in the case. On Tuesday, Saoner police of Nagpur rural arrested Vikas Bhagotiya after his presence at the crime scene became apparent in the CCTV footage.

Saoner police had earlier arrested only Narendra for repeatedly assaulting Angad with a sharp weapon, causing his death. The two apparently had an old business rivalry. The probe by Saoner police was slow paced after procuring Narendra’s custody remand for five days.

In the meantime, a 2.17 minute CCTV footage was leaked, and went viral, exposing the presence of several persons at the murder spot apart from Narendra. Though their complicity in the murder is not yet clear, police have arrested Bhagotiya, as he was seen helping Narendra free himself from the grip of some others apparently trying to stop him.

Bhagotiya, on another occasion in the footage, can be seen pushing away another person trying to dissuade Narendra as he was repeatedly assaulting Angad.

Saoner police, based on the footage, have also recorded the statement of two other persons, Sagar Saoji and Chandu Karadikar, who were also present at the murder spot. Karadikar was seen hurling a stone towards Narendra. During questioning, Karadikar claimed he hurled the stone to distract Narendra, who was assaulting Angad.

Unknown voices in the background of the clip can be heard repeatedly referring to Bhagotiya and Saoji.

Though Saoji too was seen running helter skelter at the murder spot, cops are not sure about his role. He was also seen escorting a profusely bleeding Angad away from the spot at the end of the clip. Sources said Saoji was the common friend between Angad and Narendra.

Senior PI Ashok Koli of Saoner police station said the investigation is underway and more developments are likely in the case. “We are thoroughly probing from all angles,” he said.

Title: Mumbai: Grant Road bridge shut for 6 months from Thursday
Content:
This story is from January 15, 2020

The bridge closure will impact traffic movement on Kennedy bridge, Pathhe Bapurao Marg and Warerkar bridge nea... Read More

MUMBAI: The corroded British-era Frere road overbridge (ROB) at Grant Road, that connects Lamington Road (DB Marg) to Nana Chowk, will be shut for traffic from January 16 as Western Railway commences regirdiring work.

The traffic police gave the bridge closure a go-ahead on Tuesday and issued diversions for vehicular traffic. The repair work is likely to take six months and will hit traffic in south Mumbai. "Both arms of Frere bridge will remain shut for vehicles," said a policeman. Heavy vehicles moving from Maulana Shaukat Ali Road and DB Marg (E) towards Nana Chowk Junction will be diverted on Kennedy bridge at Opera House Junction or Diana bridge at Patthe Bapurao Marg or Bellasis bridge at Mumbai Central.

Heavy vehicles moving from Nana Chowk Junction towards Maulana Shaukat Ali Road and DB Marg (E) will be diverted on Kennedy bridge at Nana Chowk or Diana bridge at Patthe Bapurao Marg or Bellasis bridge at Tardeo circle Junction. The estimated cost of regirdiring is Rs 9.6 crore, WR said. The Frere bridge was built in 1921.

The bridge closure will impact traffic movement on Kennedy bridge, Pathhe Bapurao Marg and Warerkar bridge near Sukh Sagar junction.

Title: South Bombay tops in cases of neglect by children
Content:
Representative image

Most parents deserted or not paid maintenance

MUMBAI: A total of 592 senior citizens from Mumbai, Thane and Navi Mumbai filed complaints of neglect against their children under the Maintenance and Welfare of Parents and Senior Citizens Act ever since the legislation was enacted in 2007, statistics reveal. A majority of the cases (289) were from South Mumbai, while 195 were from suburban Mumbai and 108 from Thane district, of which Navi Mumbai is a part.South Mumbai has in recent years seen the highest migration to the suburbs and even abroad, “which primarily appears to be affecting the life of senior citizens as younger couples who migrate might be leaving elderly parents in SoBo homes without proper care,” said Prof Arokia Samy, head of department of development studies with the International Institute for Population Sciences (IIPS).Most cases under the Act are about desertion of parents by children who live elsewhere, non-allocation of maintenance or neglect after having usurped their properties. Collector for South Mumbai Shivaji Jondhale said lack of maintenance was a major reason cited by elders, followed by absence of provision of paramedic staff or servants and misbehaviour.The Act states it is mandatory for children to spend 5% of their income on maintenance of their parents, besides employing servants (paramedics) to take care of them, suburban collector Milind Borikar, who has quasi-judicial powers to decide cases under the law, said.But cases of neglect are numerous. In one case, a widow was detected with cancer in 2018 and the same year, thrown out of her home by her only son. The woman, who sought justice under the Act by approaching the deputy collector, with whom complaints have to be lodged, used to stay in a flat owned by her in Koparkhairane, while her son, who worked in a Dubai firm, stayed with his family in Thane. The son was an alcoholic and later lost his money. He requested his mother to allow him and his family to stay in her flat and later got it transferred in his name through a gift deed on the sly. “He never paid rent or looked after me. Later, he evicted me from my home and tried to sell off the property,” the woman told the panel hearing her case. The authorities heard both sides and ruled in her favour. “She not only got her home back but her son was made to pay Rs 5,000 as maintenance,” said a home department official.The Bombay high court in 2018 ruled that elderly parents can take back a share in property given to a son/daughter as a gift if they fail to look after them or harass them. The Act has provisions that protect parents who have signed away property or assets to a person so they would be taken care of but are left unattended or are mistreated. If a senior citizen has signed an agreement after 2007 to transfer his/her share in property on the condition that their basic needs would be taken care of, but the person to whom it is transferred refuses to take care, a maintenance tribunal can quash the agreement. “Senior citizens who cannot maintain themselves from their own earnings or property can stake claim for maintenance from children, grandchildren or those who are either inheriting or going to inherit their properties. Children or grandchildren (irrespective of gender and in equal proportion) are liable to pay maintenance to parents or grandparents. A special tribunal at the sub-divisional office level can grant up to Rs10,000 as maintenance,” said lawyer Uday Warunjikar at Bombay HC who handles such cases.According to census analysis for Mumbai Metropolitan Region (whose 3 big districts are South Mumbai, Suburban Mumbai and Thane) by Centre for Research Methodology, over 9 lakh fewer people lived in SoBo in 2011 than in 2001. Thane’s population went up by 29.3 lakh in the same period; of this, 8 lakh were people who moved out of South Mumbai.

He requested his mother to allow him and his family to stay in her flat and later got it transferred in his name through a gift deed on the sly. “He never paid rent or looked after me. Later, he evicted me from my home and tried to sell off the property,” the woman told the panel hearing her case. The authorities heard both sides and ruled in her favour. “She not only got her home back but her son was made to pay Rs 5,000 as maintenance,” said a home department official.The Bombay high court in 2018 ruled that elderly parents can take back a share in property given to a son/daughter as a gift if they fail to look after them or harass them. The Act has provisions that protect parents who have signed away property or assets to a person so they would be taken care of but are left unattended or are mistreated. If a senior citizen has signed an agreement after 2007 to transfer his/her share in property on the condition that their basic needs would be taken care of, but the person to whom it is transferred refuses to take care, a maintenance tribunal can quash the agreement. “Senior citizens who cannot maintain themselves from their own earnings or property can stake claim for maintenance from children, grandchildren or those who are either inheriting or going to inherit their properties. Children or grandchildren (irrespective of gender and in equal proportion) are liable to pay maintenance to parents or grandparents. A special tribunal at the sub-divisional office level can grant up to Rs10,000 as maintenance,” said lawyer Uday Warunjikar at Bombay HC who handles such cases.According to census analysis for Mumbai Metropolitan Region (whose 3 big districts are South Mumbai, Suburban Mumbai and Thane) by Centre for Research Methodology, over 9 lakh fewer people lived in SoBo in 2011 than in 2001. Thane’s population went up by 29.3 lakh in the same period; of this, 8 lakh were people who moved out of South Mumbai.

Title: South Bombay tops in cases of neglect by children
Content:
Representative image

Most parents deserted or not paid maintenance

MUMBAI: A total of 592 senior citizens from Mumbai, Thane and Navi Mumbai filed complaints of neglect against their children under the Maintenance and Welfare of Parents and Senior Citizens Act ever since the legislation was enacted in 2007, statistics reveal. A majority of the cases (289) were from South Mumbai, while 195 were from suburban Mumbai and 108 from Thane district, of which Navi Mumbai is a part.South Mumbai has in recent years seen the highest migration to the suburbs and even abroad, “which primarily appears to be affecting the life of senior citizens as younger couples who migrate might be leaving elderly parents in SoBo homes without proper care,” said Prof Arokia Samy, head of department of development studies with the International Institute for Population Sciences (IIPS).Most cases under the Act are about desertion of parents by children who live elsewhere, non-allocation of maintenance or neglect after having usurped their properties. Collector for South Mumbai Shivaji Jondhale said lack of maintenance was a major reason cited by elders, followed by absence of provision of paramedic staff or servants and misbehaviour.The Act states it is mandatory for children to spend 5% of their income on maintenance of their parents, besides employing servants (paramedics) to take care of them, suburban collector Milind Borikar, who has quasi-judicial powers to decide cases under the law, said.But cases of neglect are numerous. In one case, a widow was detected with cancer in 2018 and the same year, thrown out of her home by her only son. The woman, who sought justice under the Act by approaching the deputy collector, with whom complaints have to be lodged, used to stay in a flat owned by her in Koparkhairane, while her son, who worked in a Dubai firm, stayed with his family in Thane. The son was an alcoholic and later lost his money. Later, he evicted me from my home and tried to sell off the property,” the woman told the panel hearing her case. Title: Mumbai: Woman, senior citizen fall victim to e-payment rackets
Content:
This story is from January 15, 2020

Representative image

MUMBAI: An assistant manager employed with an international trading firm was duped of Rs 20,000 after she scanned a QR code provided to her to make a payment on an online payment platform.

Pradeep Sinha, CEO of Inditech International, asked Navita Telang to place an ad to sell five ACs for Rs 45,000 on an online marketplace around 12.30pm on Monday. Sinha said the fraud occurred between 12.30pm and 1pm on Monday. In her complaint, Telang said, “I got a call from a Anil Sharma, who wanted to buy the ACs. He said he would pay Rs 45,000 in two transactions of Rs 20,000 and Rs 25,000.”

Sinha said the fraudster gained Telang’s confidence by transferring Rs 5 to her account via an online payment platform. “He sent a QR code for Rs 19,999. As soon as she scanned it, the amount was debited from her bank account,” he said.

When Sinha sent a few employees to check Sharma’s reported address, at Radhakrishna Apartments in Andheri (east), they found that the address was fake. “When our people visited the address, the people in the society said that no one by that name resides there. It seems like he is a professional criminal,” said Sinha.

Telang said that when she approached the Amboli police to lodge a complaint, they took more than four hours to file an FIR — time that could have been spent looking for the fraudster. The Amboli police sought details from the payment platform and the bank to get to the money trail, to find the account the money was credited to. A case under the Indian Penal Code for cheating and impersonation has been registered.

Title: Mumbai: Neta abuses, slaps workers in 'public interest', no FIR yet
Content:
This story is from January 15, 2020

A video grab of NCP corporator Kaptan Malik slapping a contract worker employed with a power company at Kurla ... Read More

MUMBAI: A video of NCP corporator Kaptan Malik, brother of cabinet minister Nawab Malik, hurling abuses and slapping contract workers repairing the network of a private power company at Kurla in December, has gone viral on social media. Police are yet to register a case.

While the opposition and netizens have demanded action against the corporator for 'abuse of power', Malik justified his act saying that he assaulted the workers "in public interest".

He claimed he had complained to BMC on several occasions about power supply and fibre optics companies carrying out work on roads dug up for repair and reconstruction without permission. "These companies cause the BMC loss of thousands of crores as they have to pay a fee to dig up roads. In this case, I had warned the workers the previous day against carrying out the work. When I saw them back at the site the next day, I assaulted them."

Civic officials confirmed that they had not issued any permission to the power supply company for the work at Kurla, but refused comment when asked why they did not take action against the power firm.

Demanding action against Mailk BJP leader Kirit Somaiya said: "If the work was being carried out without permission, BMC should take action against the company's contractor; who is Kaptan Malik to assault the workers? He is trying to create terror among contractors for ulterior motives. The government should take criminal action."

Advocate Gayatri Singh said, "The company should file an FIR against corporator for assaulting workers. If the corporator felt that the work was being carried out illegally, he could have approached the authority concerned to stop the work. He cannot beat workers; what example is he setting?"

Title: Jagdeep Dhankhar: Arjun’s arrows had nuclear power, says West Bengal governor Jagdeep Dhankhar at science fair
Content:
This story is from January 15, 2020

Jagdeep Dhankhar

KOLKATA: Bengal governor Jagdeep Dhankhar has followed in the footsteps of senior BJP leaders, claiming that Arjun’s arrows had “nuc-lear powers” and there were “udaan khatolas (flying machines)” in the Ramayana.

Dhankhar chose the inauguration of a science and engineering fair at the Birla Industrial and Technological Museum in south Kolkata to drop the N-bomb on an unsuspecting audience. “The plane was (invented) in 1910 or 1911. But ... if you delve into our old scriptures … in the Ramayana, we had this udaan khatola (flying machine). And, in the Mahabharata , we had a situation where Sanjay narrated everything and not from the (battle)field. We had those arrows of Arjun which had nuclear power,” Dhankhar said on Tuesday. He then stressed: “The world can no longer afford to ignore India. I cannot.”

Several BJP leaders have preceded Dhankhar in seeing science in the Indian epics and traditional beliefs. Tripura’s BJP CM, Biplab Deb, brought up the Sanjay parallel in April 2018, when he said the internet existed in the days of the Mahabharata as well. “Sanjay was blind but he narrated what was happening on the battlefield to Dhritarashtra anyway. This was due to internet and technology. Satellites also existed during that period,” Deb had said.

And Bengal BJP president Dilip Ghosh claimed in November 2019 that “research had showed” that cow’s milk contained gold.

Dhankhar has been repeatedly accused by the Bengal government and Trinamool Congress seniors of “acting on behalf of the BJP”. The Bengal governor is also the chancellor of the state’s universities (though a new law enacted by the state higher education department late last year has curbed much of those powers).

Educationists, however, expressed shock and dismay at the chancellor’s comments.

Eminent physicist and former Saha Institute of Nuclear Physics (SINP) director Bikash Sinha described Dhankhar’s remark as “irresponsible, senseless and irrelevant”. “He has lost his mind. The governor should first read a bit of history and try to find out about the development of nuclear weapons in India. Then he should realise that the people of Bengal cannot be fooled by such baseless remarks. The ordinary middle-class and even the lower-middle-class people of our state are educated enough to know that nuclear weapons did not exist then. They will never believe or pay heed to such unscientific observations,” Sinha said.

He went on to add that such irresponsible comments would cost the governor his credibility. “So far we have heard similar remarks from some union ministers. Now, Dhankhar has jumped on to the bandwagon, which is unfortunate. He risks becoming a butt of jokes by making such comments,” Sinha added.

A senior scientist with a leading (central government) science research organisation said he was shocked and surprised by the governor’s observations. “Did flying machines and nuclear weapons exist in the age of the puranas? I think it is both sad and funny that we are having to discuss this. If someone tells me that they really did, my reaction would be, ‘Oh, really?’,” he said.

Presidency University emeritus professor of sociology Prasanta Ray felt that the comments were consistent with the BJP’s agenda of glorifying India’s past as part of its Hindutva agenda. “There is no evidence that science and technology had progressed thus in ancient India. The question that needs to be asked is that, if they did, then why did we have to learn and adopt science from others. The BJP’s explanation would be that Muslim invasion destroyed it all. But historical or archaeological facts do not corroborate that either,” Ray said.

Title: In eye of a storm, but may get a second term
Content:
This story is from January 15, 2020

Kolkata: Bengal BJP president Dilip Ghosh’s recent “beat them, shoot them” remark against Bangladeshi infiltrators may have ruffled feathers, but that seems to be the saffron party’s way on the Citizenship (Amendment) Act and the National Register of Citizens. According to BJP insiders, the 31 zilla presidents and another 31 Pradesh Pratinidhi Sadasyas of the total 49 organisational districts are likely to re-elect Ghosh for a second term on Thursday.

The Bengal BJP is preparing party ranks for a “do or die” mission on the new law, anticipating stiff resistance from Trinamool Congress and other forces at the ground level. BJP leaders have made it loud and clear that Bengali Hindus and Muslims who are Indian citizens have nothing to worry. They are after the infiltrators (Muslims) from Bangladesh, which explains Ghosh’s vitriolic speeches.

State BJP leaders have taken note of the long queues at voting centres for inclusion of fresh names and the rising number of affidavits. “Mark the queues in Murshidabad’s Domkal and the number of affidavits in Basirhat court. They speak for our cause,” a BJP state office-bearer said. BJP leaders are marking time for the Supreme Court to hear out the petitions against CAA-NRC on January 22.

Unlike in Assam, the Narendra Modi government has no ‘Plan B’ for Bengal to customise CAA with the ground reality in the state where most migrants have already obtained ration cards, Aadhaar cards and have their names enrolled in the voters’ list.

BJP organisers are set to reach out to mohallas from January-end on a 1-crore signature campaign in support of CAA. Bengal BJP is likely to take stock of its position in refugee-dominated areas of North 24 Parganas, Nadia and parts of Howrah where its organisational strength is still no match for TMC.

BJP state general secretary Sayantan Basu didn’t want to go into the numbers game. Neither is the state BJP willing to take note of students’ protests against CAA. “We are confident that majority Bengali Hindus and particularly the refugees are with us even in places where we don’t have a strong network,” Basu said.

Title: Kolkata News - Times of India
Content:
This story is from January 15, 2020

CM Mamata Banerjee on Tuesday said she met Prime Minister Narendra Modi at Raj Bhavan due to courtesy which, she said, was the culture of Bengal. “How can I dishonour my guest? Bengal's culture does not teach one to be impolite, even to the enemy,” she said. But she reminded that the Trinamool MP delegation was stopped at Lucknow, not allowed to meet Farooq Abdullah and move out of Jammu. “The same thing happened when our team went to JNU and they were stopped, she said, adding a Trinamool delegation was also stopped at Assam. “Do not teach us democracy," she said.

Title: Malda violence: CID brass silent on probe against 5 securitymen
Content:
This story is from January 15, 2020

Malda/Kolkata: The CID brass remained tightlipped on whether investigators have zeroed in on at least five security personnel who need to be “further investigated” before ruling out their involvement in the violence at Sujapur in Malda during last Wednesday’s bandh.

Police said this includes one RAF personal, two from the battalion and two civic volunteers. The Malda DDI unit of CID has informed headquarters in Kolkata about their findings.

CID last Thursday took over the investigation. At least seven persons have been arrested and raids are on to identify more.

Hundreds of people had allegedly attacked police with bricks, ransacked buses and police vehicles to enforce the strike, a senior CID official said. CID sources claimed video footage analysis and statements recorded from various sources form the basis of their findings. A departmental inquiry has also been initiated against the policemen, who were purportedly seen vandalizing cars near Sujapur bus stand.

Title: Happy Pongal 2020: Images, Wishes, Messages, Quotes, Cards, Greetings, Pictures, GIFs and Wallpapers
Content: PongalPongal is a four day festival which is celebrated when the new crops like sugarcane, turmeric, rice etc are ready to be harvested. This is celebrated in a south Indian specifically Tamil Nadu around mid January. It is dedicated to the Surya Devta (Sun God) as he starts Uttaraayanam his journey towards the north and ends the winter solstice. This festival is celebrated all over the country under different names with the same significance. It is known as ‘Bhogali Bihu’ in Uttar Pradesh, ‘Lohri’ in Punjab and other parts of north India, 'Khichri' in Uttar Pradesh, ‘Makar sankrnti’ in Andhra Pradesh, West Bengal, Karnataka and Telangana 2020.Pongal is celebrated with great pomp and show, it is a multi-day festival with different rituals for each day. It starts with the Bhogi festival on the first day, Thai Pongal, Mattu Pongal and ends with Kannum Pongal on the fourth day.There are many legends associated with this festival. Most popular one is about the Bhogi festival, when Lord Kanha used his little finger to lift Goverdhan Mountain to save the people and cattle from the wrath of Indra, the rain god. Another legend is about the third day of Pongal. On this day Mahadev sent his vahana, Nandi who was a bull to tell people to have oil bath daily and have food once a month. He told people the opposite, to eat daily and have an oil bath once a month. This enraged Lord Shiva and he ordered Nandi to stay on earth and help humans in harvesting the crops so that they could eat daily.The first day is celebrated in the honour of Indra. People burn useless household items in the bonfire. A special ritual is followed on the second day which is dedicated to the Sun God. The traditional sweet dish ‘pongal’ is made under the sun in an earthen pot. It has rice and lentils which are boiled in milk and jaggery. It is then offered to the Sun God. The third day is for the cattles. They are given a bath and then decorated with garlands, bells and are worshipped. As a part of the festival bull fights are also organized. The fourth and the final day has a number of rituals. All the leftover sweet pongal dish and other food items are served on the turmeric leaves with sugarcane, betel leaves and betel nuts. Sisters also pray for their brothers on this day.Pongal images and picturesHere are some of the Pongal wishes and quotes, you can send to your loved ones on this auspicious occasion.“Warm wishes to you and your family on the auspicious occasion of Pongal, Happy Pongal”“May all your worries and fears diminish from your life and fill your heart with calm and healthy thoughts. Happy Pongal”“Pongal marks joy and cheer and brings along everything that’s best.May the festival of harvest season be one that brings along with it all that’s best and everything you deserve. Have a memorable Pongal”“Time for bonfire and the feast. Happy Pongal!”“Wish you a Happy Pongal. Hope this Thai Pongal brings happiness to our life.”“May happiness overflow on the auspicious occasion of Pongal, good luck enter your home and success touch your feet. Wishing you a very happy Pongal”"Wishing that this festival is one, which brings good luck and prosperity and hoping that it is joyous, and fills your days ahead with happiness. Have a wonderful Pongal.""As you celebrate the festival of Pongal, with a lot of fervor and cheer, this warm greeting comes your way, with a world of good wishes for every joy and happiness."“May the SWEETNESS of overflowing milk and sugarcaneFill your home with harmony and happinessWishing you the best and prosperous Pongal!”“I pray that this festival may be the start of your brighter daysFilled with happiness, good luck and prosperity. Happy Pongal!”“Here’s wishing that this Pongal festival brings you good luck and prosperity. Enjoy this day with your family and friends. Pongalo Pongal!”“I pray to the God of Sun to bless you with prosperity, happiness and abundance. May you and your family have a wonderful Pongal!”“Let us meet, greet and eat together with this auspicious decoration and beautiful kolams. Wish you a very Happy Pongal”“On this bounteous occasion, May happiness comes to you in all abundance. Happy Pongal”“May this Pongal brings you everlasting happiness and peace, Happy Pongal”“Let the warmth of the auspicious festival of Pongal fill your home with joy. Have a wonderful Pongal.”Pongal cards 2020Pongal GIFs 2020

Title: Ground executive at Kolkata airport refuses wheelchair, airline says sorry
Content:
Mamta and Tolaram being assured of help by a senior SpiceJet executive at the airport on Tuesday

KOLKATA: A spinal patient travelling to Coimbatore for surgery on low-cost carrier SpiceJet was refused a wheelchair by an airline executive at the Kolkata airport’s check-in counter on Tuesday. All pleas and arguments by Mamta Agarwala — who was plainly in discomfort — and her husband fell on deaf ears.Even efforts by other passengers to make the airline staff see reason failed. It was only when the matter was brought to the notice of the airport director that Mamta was issued a wheelchair. Later, a SpiceJet spokesperson issued a statement saying “any shortcoming is deeply regretted”.Mamta’s airport trauma began around 10.15am, when she and her husband, Tolaram, arrived at departure gate 2A. When she inquired about a wheelchair, the CISF personnel at the gate told her she would have to make the request at the SpiceJet counter. Leaning on a luggage trolley for support, she made her way to the portal that has SpiceJet counters. There, she was directed to counter No. 15.When she made the request at the counter, the executive said it wouldn’t be possible. “Why did you not make the request at the time of booking the tickets? It is not possible to get a wheelchair now,” the executive reportedly told Mamta.Even when Tolaram pointed out that she had problems in her spine and was travelling to Ganga Hospital in Coimbatore for an operation scheduled on Thursday, the airline staff allegedly refused to budge.At this point, a passenger who was in queue behind the couple stepped in and requested the airline staff to set aside formalities and provide a wheelchair as it was clear that the passenger was in distress and needed it. He also pointed to over a dozen wheelchairs stacked next to counter 16, barely 10 metres away. But the airline staff allegedly remained adamant and maintained the wheelchairs were for passengers who had pre-booked them.“Get in touch with the call centre and make your request. I will not be able to provide wheelchair assistance. Please step aside and don’t waste my time,” the Spicejet executive reportedly Mamta. Another passenger awaiting his turn to check called up the airport director’s office. Within a couple of minutes, a senior airline executive arrived at the spot and said she would immediately arrange for a wheelchair. She also profusely apologised to the Agarwalas for the problem they had to face.“We don’t want your apology. You have not done anything. We want staff at the check-in counters to display more empathy. It is she who should be told not to behave in this manner,” a pained Mamta Agarwala told the senior executive. But no apology was forthcoming from the staff member at the check-in counter.Mamta later told TOI that the gap between two of her vertebrae had reduced, affecting the nerve. “I cannot stand or walk for long. Had I known that the wheelchair needed to be pre-booked, I would have surely done so. But refusing to provide it despite seeing my condition was unfortunate,” she said.A SpiceJet spokesperson said the incident would be investigated and appropriate action taken: “As per Civil Aviation Requirements (CAR) Section 3 — Air Transport Series M Part I ISSUE III dated February 28, 2014, a wheelchair has to be pre-booked 48 hours before a flight. It is provided free of cost by the airline. Pre-booking is encouraged to ensure there is no shortage of wheelchairs for passengers and prompt service by our ground staff. That said, every effort is made by the airline to provide a wheelchair to passengers who need one and ask for it at the check-in counter. The staff is always encouraged to go out of its way and serve passengers, especially senior citizens, and any shortcoming is deeply regretted.”Tuesday’s incident highlights a recurring problem at Kolkata airport. Though the airport operator has tried to facilitate ease of travel for passengers with reduced mobility, wheelchairs — the most basic facility for such passengers — is still a problem. Airlines are responsible for providing wheelchairs to passengers. While they do so at other airports, carriers have somehow been unable to put things in order in Kolkata.Though there is wheelchair assistance booths at the entrance, Mamta — like many others before her — have been asked to walk to the airline counter for one. The situation turns worse for those travelling late at night, as services are often neglected at those hours. With a large number of non-resident Indians — many of them senior citizens — travelling to and from Kolkata during winter, wheelchair availability, or the lack of it, is a major issue at Kolkata airport.Last October, disability rights advocate Jeeja Ghosh had faced a similar problem with GoAir while travelling to Delhi to attend an international conference. Following the incident, airport director Kaushik Bhattacharjee had organized a sensitisation programme in partnership with the UK deputy high commission, led by Ghosh. Airports Authority of India employees, staff of various airlines as well as CISF personnel attended the two-day workshop.“We are trying to make the airport customer-friendly and improve access to those with mobility issues. While we have made several changes in the infrastructure, it is the mindset change that we are trying to address now. The incident goes to only show that we have to travel a distance yet,” Bhattacharjee admitted.

Title: Debashis/ Avik Dutta
Content:
This story is from January 15, 2020

Kolkata: Avik Dutta , former editor of CPM party organ Ganashakti passed away in Kolkata on Tuesday morning at the age of 58 years. He was sick since December and died in a private hospital in the city. He was also a member of the CPM state committee.

CPM politburo member Sitaram Yechury and several other senior party leaders offered floral tribute to him. Bengal Governor Jagdeep Dhankhar conveyed his condolence to the bereaved family members. He is survived by his wife and son. He was earlier associated with the management of audio visual channels also. His body was taken to Press Club as he was a member of the same.

Title: Delhi assembly elections: Metro, railway staff can cast their vote by postal ballot
Content:
This story is from January 15, 2020

The election commission has written to the Delhi chief electoral officer asking him to notify the DMRC and Nor... Read More

NEW DELHI: In a first for the country, employees of two essential services — Delhi Metro and Northern Railway Transportation services — as well as mediapersons covering poll day activities with authorisation from Election Commission will have the option of voting by postal ballot in the Delhi assembly poll.

The Election Commission, in a notification issued on January 10, said that it had, on due consideration of the matter and in consultation with the central government, decided that persons employed in Delhi Metro, Northern Railway Transportation (Passenger & Freight) Services and mediapersons covering the poll day activities, “who on account of being on duty on the day of polling....will not be able to be present in their respective polling station”, can vote by postal ballot in Delhi poll due on February 8.

The facility is being extended in accordance with an amendment effected in the Conduct of Election Rules, 1961, by the Centre in October last year on EC’s recommendation. The amendment allowed senior citizens above 80 years of age, disabled persons and those employed in essential services, e.g. railways, state transport and aviation, etc, the option of voting from home using the postal ballot facility.

The commission has written to the Delhi chief electoral officer asking him to notify the Delhi Metro Rail Corporation (DMRC) and Northern Railway and request them to appoint ‘nodal officers’ for the purpose of rolling out postal ballot facility. “The nodal officer may be briefed about the facility and responsibilities and duties to be carried out by him/her. Copies of 12D may be made available to the nodal officer. Nodal officer should inform electors concerned about the facility,” the poll panel said in a communication to Delhi CEO.

Title: Delhi assembly elections: Metro, railway staff can cast their vote by postal ballot
Content:
The election commission has written to the Delhi chief electoral officer asking him to notify the DMRC and Nor... Read More

NEW DELHI: In a first for the country, employees of two essential services Delhi Metro and Northern Railway Transportation services — as well as mediapersons covering poll day activities with authorisation from Election Commission will have the option of voting by postal ballot in the Delhi assembly poll.The Election Commission, in a notification issued on January 10, said that it had, on due consideration of the matter and in consultation with the central government, decided that persons employed in Delhi Metro, Northern Railway Transportation (Passenger & Freight) Services and mediapersons covering the poll day activities, “who on account of being on duty on the day of polling....will not be able to be present in their respective polling station”, can vote by postal ballot in Delhi poll due on February 8.The facility is being extended in accordance with an amendment effected in the Conduct of Election Rules, 1961, by the Centre in October last year on EC’s recommendation. The amendment allowed senior citizens above 80 years of age, disabled persons and those employed in essential services, e.g. railways, state transport and aviation, etc, the option of voting from home using the postal ballot facility.The commission has written to the Delhi chief electoral officer asking him to notify the Delhi Metro Rail Corporation (DMRC) and Northern Railway and request them to appoint ‘nodal officers’ for the purpose of rolling out postal ballot facility. “The nodal officer may be briefed about the facility and responsibilities and duties to be carried out by him/her. Copies of 12D may be made available to the nodal officer. Nodal officer should inform electors concerned about the facility,” the poll panel said in a communication to Delhi CEO.

Title: 700 trees cut: Cidco says no rules flouted, greens cry foul
Content:
Greens say a nod to chop trees on the Palm Beach Road plot was given despite a pending SC case

NAVI MUMBAI: Two days after more than 700 trees were cut on a Palm Beach Road plot , the City and Industrial Development Corporation of Maharashtra Ltd ( Cidco ) said they had not broken any law while giving approval to chop down the trees.However, city environmentalists are planning contempt of court proceedings against Cidco and a private builder as the largescale axing took place even though a case is pending in Supreme Court.The Cidco Public Relations Officer (PRO) stated, "With regard to the cutting of trees, we are clarifying pockets D and E of Nerul, sector 60, were not subject matter of the Bombay high court litigation in writ petition number 218 of 2016. So there is no restraining order against Cidco. Cidco is a planning authority as well as the Tree Authority for the designated area. Tree officer of Cidco has given permission (to cut trees) following due procedure."However, environmentalist Sunil Agarwal, claimed the entire integrated complex of the proposed golf course and 17 residential towers is divided into five pockets. "Cidco and the private builder have been trying to break this integrated project into different pockets to exploit the real estate without first working on the golf course, which was the primary objective. In the past, too, they tried to mislead by claiming pockets D and E were a separate project, but environment clearance was withheld after our representation before a government committee."Agarwal said the matter is in court because of the presence of wetlands, which are part of the National Wetlands inventory and protected by an SC order of October 2017.

Title: Delhi elections: 23 new faces in AAP's full list of 70 for assembly showdown
Content:
Arvind Kejriwal

AAP exudes confidence with early list

Public connect, winnability factors in finalising names

TOI

Achhe beete panch saal, lage raho Kejriwal’

NEW DELHI: Maintaining its momentum for the assembly elections, Aam Aadmi Party has been first off the blocks in declaring its candidates. On Tuesday, it named candidates for all 70 constituencies in Delhi, which will go to the polls on February 8.Chief minister Arvind Kejriwal will contest from New Delhi while deputy CM Manish Sisodia will be fielded from Patparganj with both having represented their constituencies since 2013.AAP released the list after a marathon meeting of the party's highest decision-making body, the political affairs committee. It has re-fielded 46 of the 61 sitting MLAs and included 20 new faces besides three in the ones held by BJP. For one BJP-held seat, Mustafabad, the old candidate has been repeated.The party has repeated all the sitting ministers in the Arvind Kejriwal cabinet. The outcome of the elections will be known on February 11.Senior AAP members Raghav Chadha, Atishi and Dilip Pandey, who had unsuccessfully contested the 2019 Lok Sabha elections, have been fielded from Rajinder Nagar, Kalkaji and Timarpur, respectively. "Best wishes to all. Don't be complacent. Work very hard. People have lot of faith in AAP and you. God bless," Kejriwal tweeted in a message to his candidates.AAP had formed the government with outside support of Congress in 2013 but resigned after just 49 days. It stormed back to office in 2015 with 67 seats. It lost the Rajouri Garden seat to BJP in a 2017 bypoll, and towards the end of 2019, five MLAs – Kapil Mishra, Sandeep Kumar, Alka Lamba, Anil Bajpai and Devinder Sehrawat – were disqualified under the anti-defection law. BJP had four seats in the outgoing assembly.Party functionaries believe that the release of the list by AAP when other parties were still in the process of deciding their candidates shows the party’s confidence. The list contains several names that have recently switched over to AAP from Congress and BSP. Five-time MLA from Matia Mahal Shoaib Iqbal, former MLA from Badarpur Ram Singh Netaji, and former Congress leader Parlad Singh Sawhney, who had won from Chandni Chowk in 1998, 2003, 2008 and 2013 before losing in 2015, have been fielded from their strongholds. The AAP list also contains names of some businessmen.Labour minister Gopal Rai has been fielded from Babarpur, social welfare minister Rajendra Pal Gautam from Seemapuri, transport minister Kailash Gahlot from Najafgarh, health minister Satyendar Jain from Shakur Basti and Imran Hussain from Ballimaran.The MLA from Dwarka, Adarsh Shastri — grandson of former PM Lal Bahadur Shastri — has been dropped along with 15 other MLAs. After working in different MNCs for years, Shastri had left his high-paying job to join AAP with a mission to change politics and espoused the values of transparency and probity. He won from Dwarka with a big margin in 2015.AAP has replaced Shastri with Vinay Kumar Mishra, the son of former Congress MP Mahabal Mishra, who joined AAP on Monday. Vinay Mishra had contested the 2013 assembly election from Palam but could get only around 19,500 votes and lost badly.Many among the dropped MLAs expressed disappointment with the decision of the party. Badarpur MLA Narayan Dutt Sharma has turned a rebel. Sharma launched a scathing attack on Kejriwal and senior leader Manish Sisodia who, he alleged, “have accepted Rs 20 crore in exchange for the induction of Ram Singh Netaji who has been fielded from Badarpur seat.” Neither AAP, nor Netaji reacted to the allegations.Sharma toldhe will contest as an independent while a couple of other MLAs who have been dropped said that they will seek the opinion of the people of their constituencies before taking a decision whether they should contest as independents or not. Some of the more bitter ones said that work had not been a criterion for dropping them.According to party sources, the tickets have been finalized in keeping with the outcome of multiple qualitative and quantitative surveys conducted in all assembly constituencies. AAP assessed performance, public connect and opinion, and winnability of each MLA through the surveys which were conducted by the party and private agencies.Seeking re-election in Delhi, AAP is pitching the performance of its government and its achievements to outmanoeuvre rivals BJP and Congress in a three-cornered contest. The elections are critical for AAP because it does not have a significant presence outside Delhi except in Punjab. It has devised a catchy slogan — ‘— and a report card to woo voters.The pivot to AAP’s carefully crafted approach is Kejriwal, who has undergone a significant image transition in the past seven months. Known as an agitationist, Kejriwal has supported the protests against the Citizenship Amendment Act and National Register of Citizens from a distance. He has refrained from directly attacking Prime Minister Narendra Modi and refused to get drawn into debates over the Centre’s policies and issues. AAP has roped in political strategist Prashant Kishor’s consultancy firm, I-PAC, for the polls.

Besides these, 310 MTC buses will ferry passengers to temporary bus stops such as Tambaram MEPS, Poonamalle and KK Nagar so that they can utilise Pongal special long-distance being buses operated from January

9. According to official data, more than eight lakh passengers have travelled in 30,000 special buses operated across the state. Of these, more than 16,000 buses were operated from Chennai. Patronage was 50% more compared to previous years.

On Tuesday, people flocked to CMBT to take buses to their native places. To clear the rush, State Express Transport Corporation and Tamil Nadu State Transport Corporation, Villupuram, operated 1,600 additional buses.

Title: Delhi voters: Got power, water, what more do we need?
Content:
Poll discussions are in the air at Sangam Vihar, one of the largest unauthorised colonies in Delhi.

NEW DELHI: On a windy winter morning, two Tata Innovas jostled for space with tractors, water tankers, autorickshaws and other vehicles on the congested road near L Block of Sangam Vihar in south-east Delhi. They were covered with posters exhorting people to participate in the matadan ( voting ). It caught the attention of some men at a barber’s shop near the government school there, popularly called ‘Pahadi wala iskul’.Raj Bir, applying shaving foam on his customer’s chin, looked at the SUVs and remarked, “We have got water and electricity now, and in another few years sewer lines will be laid. Ab kya chahiye aur (What more do we need)?” The man being shaved responded, “Yeah, after so many years, our colony finally has some amenities. We have to ensure this MLA is re-elected so the work on sewer and water lines are completed.”Poll discussions are in the air at Sangam Vihar, one of the largest unauthorised colonies in Delhi. Aam Aadmi Party’s Dinesh Mohaniya, elected MLA from the constituency in 2013 and in 2015, has many supporters. And it shows in his ballot performance. In the 2015 assembly polls, his vote share increased from 27.9% in 2013, when he dethroned incumbent Shiv Charan Lal Gupta of BJP, to 65.9%, hitting BJP on what used to be its home turf till then. What is more, AAP also won a majority of the wards in the constituency in the municipal elections of 2017, bucking the trend of other areas that BJP swept.“Kaam toh bahut accha kiya hai,” said H Block resident Joginder Singh about AAP. He smiled and added, “We are traditionally BJP voters. In the Lok Sabha polls, we voted for BJP and made Narendra Modi the PM. But the assembly is different, so we have to give the person who performed another opportunity.”On further probing, Singh elaborated, “Power is free, the drains are being widened and covered to prevent water-logging, and the roads — not just the main road but also the ones in the colonies — are being laid.” He is particularly happy that the drains are being covered. Water logging has been a perennial problem in the area.Drinking water was another problem, with residents dependant on costly water from private tankers. But like housewife Samsin Banu in D Block, others too expressed satisfaction about the situation now. “Our homes now get water,” Banu said, looking pleased. “And on days where there is no water, Delhi Jal Board tanks arrive with supplies.”Like Banu, a migrant from West Bengal, the constituency is home to mostly people who have moved to the capital from other states, including Bihar and Uttar Pradesh. There is also a sizeable Muslim population living in different parts of area.There were some complaints too, mostly from middle-class householders and businessmen, who rued the time wasted in the past five years. Om Prakash, a real estate businessman, said, “They keep on digging everywhere to show that work is being done, but nothing is accomplished. The government built lanes in the colony, but not the main road. And it is surprising it took them almost five years simply to lay the sewer lines. Work hasn't been carried out systematically.” Om Prakash will make his displeasure known on February 8, no doubt.

There is also a sizeable Muslim population living in different parts of area.There were some complaints too, mostly from middle-class householders and businessmen, who rued the time wasted in the past five years. Om Prakash, a real estate businessman, said, “They keep on digging everywhere to show that work is being done, but nothing is accomplished. The government built lanes in the colony, but not the main road. And it is surprising it took them almost five years simply to lay the sewer lines. Work hasn't been carried out systematically.” Om Prakash will make his displeasure known on February 8, no doubt.

Title: Delhi assembly elections: Popular big three who failed Lok Sabha test get second chance
Content:
Atishi

NEW DELHI: Aam Aadmi Party is betting big on three faces who had unsuccessfully contested the Lok Sabha poll. This is also an attempt by the party to capitalise on the popularity the trio got during the parliamentary elections.While Raghav Chadha has been fielded from Rajendra Nagar, where he was born, Atishi , who was born in a Punjabi family from Delhi, has been fielded from Kalkaji . Chadha lives with his family in New Rajendra Nagar. His roots are very deep in the constituency. The families of his parents have lived in this part of the city for more than seven decades. Chadha had contested from South Delhi Lok Sabha seat, but lost by a huge margin.Atishi’s constituency has a sizeable number of Punjabi and Sikh voters. A member of AAP’s political affairs committee, she will be leveraging her Punjabi background to woo voters. Her campaign will focus on AAP’s work in the past five years with an aim to replicate it in Kalkaji. These include providing quality education, healthcare, safe and free drinking water, and ensuring a sustained development of the area. Atishi, who had contested from East Delhi parliamentary constituency, came third in the final tally.The third candidate is Dilip Pandey, AAP’s Poorvanchali face. He had contested from North East Delhi Lok Sabha constituency and has been active in Timarpur assembly for a long time. He is known for his interpersonal skills and connects well with voters. His connect with Poorvanchali voters during campaigning for Lok Sabha poll would come in handy because Timarpur is under North East parliamentary seat.Atishi’s academic background and her work in the education sector may help her draw a large chunk of urban voters in Kalkaji. She graduated from St Stephens College and topped Delhi University. She pursued her Masters in Education from Oxford University and was a Rhodes scholar.All three candidates have been fielded by replacing the sitting MLAs. In what could be a big relief for them, none of the three sitting legislators sounded rebellious when TOI conversed with them.

Title: Onion Price in Kolkata: Onion price dips below government subsidy rate in West Bengal
Content:
Representative image

Times View Prices going back to normal will come as a huge relief. But the factors that have led to the last few weeks’ problems need to be studied so that they can be preempted if possible.

KOLKATA: The onion retail price on Tuesday dropped to Rs 50 per kg — the price prevailed just before the festive season in September. The price, which ‘burnt a hole in pockets’ back then, is now thought to be a respite. The onion price is expected to plunge further with Bengal’s own production hitting the market shortly.The wholesale rate shows the trend of price plunge accurately. The onion price in wholesale market ranged between Rs 900 and Rs 1,400 per 40 kg bag, (Rs 22.5-Rs35 per kg). The supply from Nashik (Maharastra) and Bellary (Karnataka) has steadied and changed the game, said Kamal De, the president of the West Bengal Vegetables Vendors Association.On Tuesday, the bigger variety of onion was sold at Rs 55 per kg while the medium-size onion was priced at Rs 50 per kg. “With the supply stabilising, the price of onion is likely to dip in next two-three days. The demand-supply gap had widened and pushed up the price abnormally, with number of onion-laden trucks falling down to twothree from 45-50 on an average weekday. On Tuesday, 35 trucks reached Bengal's two major wholesale hubs — Posta and Sealdah.However, some retailers at some city markets refused to pass on the benefit to consumers. At Gariahat market, onion price hovered around Rs 60-70 per kg. The wholesalers said that selling onion at Rs 60 and beyond is unethical now and the government must intervene. In fact, the retail price should not exceed Rs 40 per kg, said market experts.On December 4 and 5, onion prices hit the Rs 150-Rs 160 mark. The prices remained unchanged over the next few days, forcing the government to sell onion at a highly subsidized rate (Rs 59 per kg) through its network of 932 ration shops in Kolkata.“I had stopped selling onion the moment it crossed Rs 110 per kg. Today, I resumed the sale of onion. We think onion prices will dip further in next two-three days,” said Sujit Ghosh, a retailer at Behala Purono Bazar."I had cut down on consumption by one-tenth to strike a budgetary balance. Now, we can think of bringing back the appropriate proportion of onion in our daily dishes," said Rittika Guha, a Behala homemaker.But the rise and fall of onion prices seem to be the most dramatic since September 11, when it breached the Rs50 per kg mark. "After a gap of four months, onion prices swung back to the pre-festive period. Today, I sold onion at Rs 50 per kg. Onions just flew off my basket. People had reduced onion consumption to strike a balance in the kitchen economics," said Bhola Saha, an onion seller at Lake Market.Times ViewPrices going back to normal will come as a huge relief. But the factors that have led to the last few weeks’ problems need to be studied so that they can be preempted if possible.

Title: Withdrawal cap: Bengaluru co-op bank tries to placate customers
Content:
This story is from January 15, 2020

Sri Gururaghavendra Sahakara Bank Niyamitha

BENGALURU: Anxious customers lined up before Sri Gururaghavendra Sahakara Bank Niyamitha in Basavanagudi on Tuesday as officials remained tightlipped about the future course of action following the Reserve Bank India cap on withdrawals at Rs 35,000.

Many senior citizens demanded that the management explain why things had come to such a pass. A meeting called by the bank on Monday was postponed to January 19 abruptly. The bank chief adviser did not respond to calls and messages from TOI. Bank president K Ramakrishna told media they have spoken to RBI officials and will sort out the problem soon. Every customer will get his/her money back and the cap will be removed, he added.

Usha Devi NV, 62, said she desperately needs a job as her savings were locked in the bank. “I worked as a private firm secretary. Four years ago, I deposited Rs 8 lakh in the bank and depended on the interest of around Rs 8,000. My husband has a back injury and been advised not to ride. We don’t have children or anyone to help us,” she said.

Title: Kolkata: KMDA to float tenders for new Circular Canal bridge
Content:
Circular Canal, over which the new bridge has been proposed

KOLKATA: The Kolkata Metropolitan Development Authority ( KMDA ) has planned to set up a new bridge over Circular Canal , moving parallel to the RG Kar bridge that would have a ramp to lead vehicles towards Chitpore or Kolkata station. The authorities have prepared the design of the proposed bridge and plan to float tenders soon.Last year, KMDA came up with the plan to have a new canal bridge that would connect Canal West Road and Kolkata Station Road to reduce traffic load on RG Kar bridge, also known as Gaznavi Bridge that connects Shyambazar with Belgachhia.KMDA sources said that topographical and soil surveys have been conducted in the proposed area. “The proposed bridge will help divert vehicles across the canal to Shyambazar or Belgachhia. It would also help decongest RG Kar Road and reduce load on RG Kar bridge,” an official said.There will also be a 300-metre grade-separating ramp from the bridge that would come down towards Kolkata station.The structural health audit of RG Kar bridge revealed that its condition was stable, but its load-bearing capacity had reduced. Additional bitumen layers from the bridge’s surface will be removed to reduce the extra load. “This will be done before PWD starts dismantling the Tallah bridge, as RG Kar bridge will then have to take immense vehicular pressure,” an official said.The authorities recently conducted repairs on the Chitpore circular canal bridge , but the Chitpore rail yard bridge is in poor shape. Experts said that the bridge is beyond long-term repairs and could be dismantled soon. Both the bridges will start taking additional vehicular pressure once Tallah bridge demolition starts.The authorities are also working on plans to set up three bridges over the canal that flows at Julpia on the southern fringes of the city this year.

Title: 87% pedestrians fear crossing roads in Chandigarh: Study
Content:
This story is from January 15, 2020

As many as 87% of pedestrians fear for their lives while crossing the roads in the city, according to a survey... Read More

CHANDIGARH: As many as 87% of pedestrians fear for their lives while crossing the roads in the city, according to a survey conducted by an NGO.

ArriveSafe, the NGO on road safety, conducted ‘Pedestrian Perception Survey’ on 520 pedestrians — 376 males and 144 females — using six prominent locations, Aroma light point; ISBT, Sector 43, Vikas Marg; PGI, Madhya Marg; sectors 34 and 35 market/commercial/residential areas and sectors 45-46 road on Sukhna Path. The study said 452 of the respondents felt unsafe while crossing the roads and called the facilities for pedestrians poor. “As many as 89% of the pedestrians said they were forced to leave footpaths because of obstructions caused by parked vehicles, vendors or their bad condition,” they study said. “As many as 78% of females felt unsafe to walk in the dark. On the cleanliness index, only 13% considered footpaths good, 26% found them fair and 61% poor,” the study said.

According to an analysis by road safety cell of the traffic police, 35 of 98 people killed in road accidents in 2018 were pedestrians.

Harman Singh Sidhu, president, ArriveSAFE, said, “The outcome of the survey leaves a lot to be desired on part of the authorities and citizens. Pedestrians have to fend for themselves while using footpaths or crossing the roads. Their fear further increases vehicular dependability, even for travelling short distances, prompting expansion of roads and considering flyovers, which is not a citizen-friendly approach. The National Urban Transport Policy should be implemented in letter and spirit.”

The National Urban Transport Policy formulated in April 2006 recommended equitable allocation of space on people, not vehicles. Sustainable Development Goals set by the United Nations also talks of making cities inclusive, safe, resilient and sustainable.

The NGO said walkability is a measure of how friendly an area is for walking. According to the theory of walkability by Jeff Speck, “A walk has to satisfy four main conditions: it must be useful, safe, comfortable, and interesting.”

Title: Sood tipped to be next BJP chief
Content:
This story is from January 15, 2020

Chandigarh: The city unit of the BJP will get a new president on Friday after a gap of 10 years. The central leadership of the party has approved the name of former mayor and councillor Arun Sood for the post after bringing unanimity among members of the electoral collegium of the BJP.

The party would initiate the election process on Thursday. Interested members could file nominations for the post. However, since the party has made its choice clear, it appears no one will offer a challenge.

The electoral collegium of BJP has 41 members, including city MP, 20 elected councillors and members from the district wings of the party.

“There is unanimity on the name of Sood and a formal announcement will be made on Friday. All local party leaders, office bearers and councillors have discussed the matter. Since we are a disciplined party and like the mayoral elections, the choice will be acceptable to all,” said a senior BJP leader.

Sources said the party’s senior leadership had been holding discussions in the matter for past few months. Former Madhya Pradesh chief minister and BJP national vice-president Shivraj Singh Chauhan was made the in-charge to select the new party president. Chauhan had forwarded a few names to the senior leadership and after discussions with BJP officiating national president J P Nadda and others, the name of Sood was finalised.

Sood has political experience of almost 20 years and has been associated with the party since his days in ABVP. He was elected as a councillor for the second time in 2016.

As Sood has a few opponents in the Chandigarh BJP, it will be interesting to see how he will manage the party, especially when MC elections are scheduled to be held next year.
